posts.title: Honeymoon Heat
posts.content:
Day 40

So, naturally when you take a flight that leaves after midnight and arrives early morning, you just want to settle down and sleep. Less naturally, the airlines always want to serve you a meal. So as we climbed into the sky, I felt there was little point trying to grab some sleep until the inevitable food trolley had done its rounds and I switched on the new version of West Side Story to watch. I hadn’t caught it in the cinema and was quite interested in catching this interpretation.

And then the turbulence began. It was mild at first, but we were well over an hour in before the seatbelt sign was switched off. The meal trolley appeared at the end of the aisle but it wasn’t long before we hit more turbulence. The air stewards did and impressive job of handing out meals and drinks despite the shaking and juddering of the plane. Pete went for the beef for his plane meal but I was pretty full and didn’t really fancy another round of food in a wobbly plane and just had an orange juice.

A couple of minutes later, the turbulence got worse and the air stewards were told to put suspend the meal service and sit down. Which is never what you want to hear. I held onto Pete, channelling all my energy into pretending I wasn’t scared and breathing deeply and Pete and the other passengers mostly just munched through their meals unconcerned. I kind of admired that.

There were a couple of extra big lurches that had everyone saying “woah” and “ooh” almost like at a fireworks display but a lot less fun, and it was well gone two in the morning before the meal service resumed. Eep.

I abandoned my film; not because it wasn’t good but because I’d seen most of my favourite songs and I wasn’t in the mood for tragedy. I thought Maria and Anita were excellent by the way, whereas Tony was a little more bland. Exceptional choreography too.

Anyway, I popped in a new audiobook and closed my eyes and tried to sleep. I suppose it’s fair to say I had some success but when we landed, I don’t think either Pete or I had had much beyond some slightly restless naps as we struggled to get comfortable.

We clambered off the plane and actually got through passport control very quickly, getting our visa on arrival stamped and finding our bags already on the carousel. We found a taxi rank and got directed to a free car: it was a shiny black one and the driver was wearing a suit so I was immediately concerned it was going to be crazy expensive but also it was about 4:00am local time and I was tired and we needed a car.

It was so fancy the doorhandles were actually flush with the car and I couldn’t work out how to open the door. The driver have to help me (and then Pete) and it was a bit like sliding into the batmobile.

Or possibly I was just very sleepy, but seriously, it wasn’t a normal car.

The journey didn’t take that long thankfully and we were soon pulling up outside our hotel. It was an unassuming door into an old building but a porter outside jumped up to collect our bags and we found that the fair was a manageable £17. Not cheap but also not unexpected for an airport transfer. I hadn’t been able to see a meter in the car, just a big screen showing fancy car information.

It was about 4:30am so of course we were crazy early to check in but we asked if we could have a room anyway. There was a fee for early check in (fair play, we were asking for our room in the middle of the night before) and on a whim, I asked if we could add on breakfast for our stay. At this point, I really wanted a sleep and a shower and was desperately hoping the price wouldn’t be too steep to have our room immediately.

Fortunately we were in luck, and we had a little chilled welcome drink - refreshing - handed over our passports, paid the extra and retrieved our hotel room key cards. Which had pictures of keys on which really amused me. We also got a free upgrade to a room with a balcony as it was out honeymoon. Yay! The porter loaded up our bags onto a little golf buggy and we set off to our room which was apparently in building 2.

OK then.

Saying we went in a golf buggy sounds like we were heading across a huge resort when actually, it was more like driving through an olde-worlde souk. It was dark and the shops were shut up for the night, but the sandstone buildings were pale in the dim glow of the off street light and the moon, and our driver pointed out where we should go for breakfast, where Starbucks was (that made me chuckle) and where we could see the river.

We hopped out and entered the building, going up to the first floor and emerged on a flat roof-terrace type area. We wove our way across a maze of rooftops with cushions laid out for reclining, marvelling at how warm it was even in the middle of the night. We found our room at the end of a passage and entered into air conditioned bliss.

The room was lovely: stylish with Middle Eastern touches without being cluttered and while I was keen to investigate it properly, we were also exhausted. Our phone rang - a bit of a surprise - but it was reception saying they’d accidentally over-charged us so could they void the payment and take the money in the morning. No worries. So we set an alarm for 10:45 and fell into bed.

We woke to my alarm - I was pretty deeply asleep as it made me jump - and we got out of bed to go and investigate breakfast. The hotel served breakfast until noon which had delighted Pete who believes that eating breakfast much before ten is a travesty.

But first we had to find the restaurant. We made a bit of a meal of it, truth be told and pun intended, as the journey past the restaurant which had seemed simple and clear a couple of hours ago in the dark now seemed unnecessarily complex. The heat was INTENSE but it wasn’t nearly as humid as Vietnam had been. More like an oven than a steam room.

We were meandering a bit aimlessly around the soul looking for the right building and following the odd chalk board sign the hotel had laid out, dodging around corners, losing the trail and then finding it again. Eventually, we climbed an outlet door staircase and located the right spot. And we entered breakfast heaven.

I don’t think it’s overdoing it to say it was the best breakfast of the trip to date. Like, seriously epic.

The breakfast room was cool and light, and there was buffet plus a menu of hot food we could order. We both picked with saffron French toast and I ordered a SIDE OF HASH BROWNS!!!! The first ones of the trip! Finally, after 40 days, I felt like the honeymoon was properly starting. Facto.

We helped ourselves to the food, Pete making an array of sandwiches with a selection of tasty breads, meats and salads and I knocked together a pretty epic granola and yoghurt bowl if I say so myself.

The tea was admittedly disappointing mostly because the hot water was decidedly not, but everything else was lush. The French toast we beautiful, served with sweet cream, maple syrup and covered in raspberries and pistachios, the hash browns were a delight and I had a little hash brown butty while promising myself double rations the next day, and we even finished off with a selection of fruit and a donut.

Having a meal seemed to jerk us slightly more into being awake in the right time zone and we headed back to our room feeling somewhat human. It was quite lovely to see the old souk laid out before us, but it also had an oddly curated feel, as though we’d stepped into the shiny Disney version of Aladdin. I sort of loved it, and Pete reckoned he was absolutely one jump ahead of the lawman. It was a whole new world.

We swung by reception to pay our bill and then headed back to our room, keen to jump in the shower. We spent the early afternoon sorting out, chilling with a tea and I caught up with my journal, and then we gathered our things ready to head out to the Aura Skypool.

The Aura Skypool is possibly one of the most “Dubai” things I’ve ever seen: a 360 degree infinity pool at the top of a skyscraper and I couldn’t decide if it was awful or incredible. In the end, I thought probably both and convinced Pete to go and I was intrigued to see what it would be like. If nothing else, it promised excellent views of some of Dubai’s famous sights.

We got a taxi from the hotel lobby and the driver guided the car off down the main highway through Dubai. It was a fascinating journey as the city is genuinely shiny. There’s no other word for it: it glitters with money and expense, tall skyscrapers ten a penny and lots of structures designed to be flashy and noticeable. It was a sunny, clear and hot and haze made the horizon shimmer. We passed the Burj, Dubai’s tallest building (tickets already booked to ascend a couple of days hence) and before long we were driving out onto the reclaimed lands of the palm. Another place that’s surreal, otherworldly and glitzy.

Maybe that sounds like I didn’t like Dubai. I did. But I think I enjoyed looking at it safe in the knowledge that real like isn’t like that.

We pulled up at the lobby of a hotel and queued to take the lift up to the Skypool on the 50th floor. And it was indeed insane. We had booked a couple of loungers facing the Burj Al Arab and a waitress showed us where they were located, gave us towels and a menu. (It was too expensive to have dinner there - you know that when a portion of fries on the side costs a tenner).

I politely declined the offer of an extra menu to peruse the selection of wines by the bottle. I think if you’re saying no to the fries, it’s probably safe to assume the bottles are also out of your league.

Pete and I slipped into the water of the pool which ran all the way around the upper floor and took in the views. Whenever we were in the sun, the rays seemed to laser into us without mercy and I was glad we’d booked a spot on the shady side. But the panorama was incredible!

We could see the fronds of the palm spread below us with little toy box houses and hotels lined up along the branches. We couldn’t help thinking that it’s a foolish man who builds his house upon the sand, but possibly the architect didn’t attend Sunday school. Or British primary school assemblies. If they had, they’d have known not only the proverb but the actions.

We could see the sail of the Burj Al Arab pointing out to sea and moving around the pool, we took in the rest of the palm and the famous Atlantis hotel. We made a gradual full circuit, gazing at the clusters of sky scrapers disappearing back into the haze of the mainland and distantly, just about making an appearance, we spotted the shooting needle of the Burj Khalifa. It took us almost an hour to make our way around and we took our time to appreciate the views. Electronic music was played through the speakers, other pool users posed for pictures and sipped cocktails and it was almost exactly what I imagined Dubai to be like.

After a lounge on the lounger - love a good lounge - we went to make another circuit of the pool, this time with my phone to get some snaps. As we rounded the edge of the pool, we could see the sun sinking lower in the sky, casting orange flashes into the sea and gradually reddening as it descended into the haze. It was a slow and compelling sunset but without the traditional streaking of clouds of vanishing behind the horizon. It was more of a fade out.

We ordered a drink each and had a little read into the history of Dubai; Pete had suggested it might have grown from a fishing village and I guessed that it was perhaps a prominent port, and we were both right in part. What was most startling was how recently it seemed to have been founded.

As we sipped our drinks - a G and T for Pete and a passionfruit amaretto sour thing for me - the light started coming on over the city and the sky darkened. The pool was illuminated from below with lights which cast a shifting green glow across the water and the little golden points lighting the world beyond glowed brighter as the rays of the dying sun departed completely.

It was time to leave. We popped down to the changing rooms to assume our day wear and then caught the lift down to the hotel lobby. They had a queue of taxis waiting which was handy and we were soon bowling along in the good hands of our chirpy Bangladeshi who gave us lots of advice about where to get cheap things and how we should negotiate. He was good fun!

Back outside our hotel, we decided to go straight for dinner; despite a sizeable breakfast I was definitely feeling hungry and according to Google there was a burger place about 10 minutes away. We set off through the souk (all a modern recreation it turns out; no wonder it looked so pristine) and after accidentally walking in a circle, we started following the river and soon made our way to the restaurant.

It was completely empty which is always a bit of strange one, but on the other hard, it had air con and we didn’t have to queue. So we placed an order consisting of a burger, drink and fries for Petr and Lava mac and cheese for me, plus some onion rings, and the whole bill came to less than a portion of fries each back at the sky pool.

And actually, while a burger joint might not be the most authentic place to dine in the world, lava mac and cheese turned out to be yummy, topped with little croutons and spring onions and although the “lava” in the name plus the lurid pink colour might imply it was going to incinerate the inside of my mouth, it was simply pleasantly spicy. The onion rings we shared were top too, and Pete enjoyed his burger so I chalked it up to a win.

We sauntered back through the evening to the hotel, feeling satisfied. The night air was still absolutely stifling and breeze off the river was hot and just stirred the air around a bit, but we didn’t really mind and enjoyed wandering between the jumble of sandy buildings, strolling below strings of fairy lights and weaving this way and that into little alleys and corners. Brightly coloured boats bobbed at the side of the winner bedecked with more twinkle lights and near our hotel, we even found a water station where we could refill our water bottles. As we did this, a chap tried to sell us an assortment of gemstones and when we politely declined to go to his shop, he said that Pete had broken his heart. He might need to work on his resilience a little bit. Didn’t take much.

We wandered over the roof terrace to pour room and dived into the air con - hurrah! We found it had been cleaned and a pair of brownies on a stick had been left as a little honeymoon treat which was lovely!

I went for a shower and came back to find Pete revelling in the air con and happily singing “Ha-cool-a Matata”. I thought it worked. So I sang back:

“What a wonderful phrase”

Pete pointed out that it should be:

“What a wonderful freeze” and he was right, that was much better.

Meanwhile, Air Mauritius who had cancelled our flight home, sent me no less than four emails entitled “Flight Cancellation” all of which suggested the time of our flight had been moved. YOU CAN’T MOVE A CANCELLED FLIGHT YOUR MORONS. I composed an extremely snotty email laying it all on thick and asking them to confirm that we would get our refund. And then I felt slight better and wondered if there was anyone else I could send unpleasant messages to as I was clearly on a role. I used words like “significantly” and “seriously” and “of the utmost”. Stirring stuff.

We were both feeling a bit sleepy so we snuggled into bed with some tea, and episode of Lost and the goodies the hotel had left. We enjoyed the brownies on a stick very much, there was also a chocolate covered date each and the plate had been liberally swirled with white chocolate. This had hardened on to the plate so we used the lolly sticks to chisel it off. Yum!

All in all, a solid evening’s work, a fab introduction to Dubai and the prospect of a full night’s sleep ahead with no alarm. Perfection!

posts.title: Honeymoon Tunnels
posts.content:
Day 39

We arose at seven with an hour to breakfast, pack up and check out. We were soon in the lift up to the restaurant and standard buffet awaited. We tucked into egg and toast and passionfruit, downing a quick tea or two and then retreated to our room to clean teeth, pack wash bags and chargers and so on and Pete even manage to squeeze another quick tea in - top work that man.

And then I got a text from our tour leader for the day: we were supposed to be getting picked up at 8:00am but with less than 20 minutes to go, she had messaged asking us to meet elsewhere.

Nope, not the plan.

After a hasty WhatsApp exchange where I sent my ticket over and said we would would come but we might be late due to the change of plan, she then said they could come and pick us up after all, but that we had selected a different booking point.

I couldn’t see the point in arguing the toss, but our ticket literally said on it “pick up at the hotel at 8:00 -8:10” so I’m not sure how you can re-interpret that.

After this kerfuffle, we hauled down to the lobby, checked out and stores our bags and waited. Hoping the rest of the day would run more smoothly.

The bus showed up a short while later and we hopped on; after a couple more pick-ups we began the slow journey battling the traffic leaving Ho Chi Ming City. We were heading for the Cu Chi tunnels and as we left, our guide gave us a bit of a history of the tunnels and the various conflicts that had prompted their construction. This featured various doings of the French and the Americans with a solid helping of communism and a curious blend of fact, opinion and propaganda which our guide admitted to quite readily, saying that he had to give a different tour when he had Americans, and that as he had Vietnamese tourists on board, he had to make sure the information was good for them too.

We made a stop at a cafe and gift shop where they made art inlaid with eggshell and mother of pearl. All the artisans had some form of disability caused by exposure to napalm; they did have some nice things but we didn’t spend any pennies.

We arrived at the Cu Chi tunnels at around 10:45 and piled off the bus. Following in the wake of our enthusiastic guide - who kept up an inexhaustible patter the entire time - we were presented with entry tickets and a sticker to show we had entry tickets and led to the start of the tour.

This involved watching a 20 minute video about the Cu Chi guerrillas and their daughter against the Americans. It was all in scratchy black and white footage, but there was something about the consistency of the supposed deterioration of the film and the healthy, happy smiles of the guerrillas warriors that made me question its veracity. I could be wrong, but something just didn’t quite ring true.

Afterwards, our guide alternated between calling it a documentary and a propaganda film, so it was difficult to judge. Anyway, the film introduced us to the tactics employed by the Vietnamese during the war and was a handy intro to the Cu Chi tunnels site.

After the film, our guide showed us a map detailing the way in which the conflict had spread throughout the area, highlighting Vietnamese villages, American bases, areas of jungle and fighting and, of course, the tracery of the 250km of tunnels (that’s over 150 miles in old money) the Cu Chi guerrillas dug out to help them move invisibly from place to place, moving food and supplies and launching surprise attacks.

We saw a cross section of the tunnels which often had three levels: the upper layers at a depth of roughly 4 metres often housed chambers for sleeping, storage and even cooking. The latter of these tapered into long tunnels which allowed smoke from the fires to emerge from the ground at a distance far from the tunnels themselves to avoid detection. The next level of tunnels were at a depth of around six metres and the bottom level went as low as 12 metres underground. The villagers tapped into underground wells, tunnelled between villages and key, strategic points and every so often filled the tunnels with trapdoors which could close tunnels off if they were detected.

And that is of course before we even mention the pits of spikes installed at regular intervals to deter enemies. I kid you not. But more on that later.

We took off along a little footpath between the trees on what our guide optimistically termed a “jungle hike” and he led us towards a patch of brown leaves scattered over the ground. Underneath, of course, was an entrance to the tunnels!

The entry was tiny: a small rectangular hatch leading down into darkness and covered with a wooden door that could be lifted on and off. When covered with undergrowth, it was practically invisible and to be fair, if you were looking for a trap door, you’d probably be looking for something bigger.

And so naturally we took it in turns slipping down into the hole and disappearing. When it was my turn, I sat on the edge and lowered my feet in; the opening really wasn’t much bigger than a human, bracing myself on the sides, I dropped down into a ledge inside. The ground was about chest height and at this point, I was able to gather leaves and twigs to cover the hatch and, gripping it from underneath, crouch down in the hole and pull the hatch over the opening. Ta-da! Disappeared!

I pulled myself out again, arms on either side of the hole as I hauled up and out. Pete had a go as well; as I took lots of pictures of him vanishing into the below, it looked strangely like I had photoshopped his top half badly into the picture, anything below the waist having completely vanished.

Various members of our tour group also had a go and I silently but smugly judged those who didn’t have the upper body strength to climb out and had to be pulled out by willing volunteers. Small minded, yes, but true.

We saw various other shapes and sizes of tunnel entrances, many long abandoned now as the tunnels aren’t used and are falling into disrepair. We also saw some of the air holes built for ventilation, disguised cunningly in termite mounds and the like.

Apparently the Americans would sometimes try and send dogs down the tunnels to snuffle out the guerrillas. Whose response was, naturally, to sprinkle around chilli powder. Hard for dogs to smell much around that.

Our next stop on the jungle tour was to see some of the traps the guerrillas would lay along the jungle paths. These were positively mediaeval, and involved rotating wheels of spikes, spiked traps to close around unsuspecting legs, pits of sharpened bamboo stakes and even a folding chair trap which would swallow you while, you guessed it, sticking you with spikes.

And the spikes were naturally all barbed so that you couldn’t pull them out. It was pretty grim stuff, and each of these traps could be sunk into the ground and strewn with undergrowth to make then completely invisible. They don’t have to be sophisticated to be terrifying.

We saw a model of a blacksmith’s workshop where spikes were made, often repurposed from farming equipment, and the guerrillas would also recycle shells, turning them into new bombs that could be set to detonate at the approach of enemy tanks or soldiers.

In fact, our next stop was indeed an abandoned tank, rusty and dilapidated but we had a little clamber over it just to take a peek inside. It was unclear how anyone could have manoeuvred one through the jungle in the first place.

The next stop on our jolly jungle warfare tour was, believe it or not, a shooting range, where for the princely sum of 600 000 dong (about £23) you could buy 10 rounds of ammunition and shoot them from the gun if your choice.

To be honest, that seemed a little bit weird to us. Climbing on an abandoned tank is one thing, but shooting a bunch of guns just didn’t sit right with me. So we passed and sat in the little cafe to wait for those who were a little more trigger happy, the air tent with ear-splitting bangs which reduced a couple of young children to tears.

Fortunately, gun practice didn’t last terribly long as bullets are expensive, even for tourists, and so we were able to move on with our tour after 15 minutes or so. We next went to look at a section of tunnel that had been restored so that we could see what it was like for the soldiers who scurried along them.

Our guide was careful to explain that, not only had this short section of tunnel been restored and reinforced, but it had also been made bigger to accommodate tourists more easily. Because, and I quote: “American too fat because of whopping king hamburger”. Cool. No worries then.

We left our bags in the hands of our guide and climbed down the short flight of steps which led to the passage. We had the option to go 20m, 40m or 100m, following one of the tunnel staff. I found I could walk reasonably well if I was bent double, but our progress ended up being super slow as we were behind a chap who was trying to coax his 4 year old daughter along (the 6 year old had bailed) and meanwhile, his elderly father was coming along behind him and struggling with a bad back. Despite the signs at the start saying: don’t go in if you had a bad back. And despite the fact that this had been pointed out to him by his son.

The result was we ended up being so far behind the guide that we didn’t know where to go and could only go one or two shuffling steps at a time before stopping to wait for the people in front of us to move again.

And so we only got to do the 20 meters. Not to worry, but we definitely would have preferred to try the full whack!

The final part of our tour was to try some cassava, boiled and dipped in sugar and ground peanuts. Apparently this is something the guerrillas would make in the their underground kitchens and the starchy vegetable would indeed give you a decent amount of energy.

All that remained was to exit via the gift shop and return to the bus; we had gained a pretty fascinating insight into guerrillas ware fare in the region, especially given the challenging climate and terrain, and while the history and politics had been sketchy, I got the impression it was a tricky line to tread for the tour guide.

As we clambered onto the bus, the forecast rain finally arrived (good timing) and as we rumbled back towards Ho Chi Minh City, we dozed a bit and I listened to my audiobook.

Back in the city, we decided to be unimaginative (soft potato) and pop to the Starbucks round the corner for a cup of tea. It was much appreciated and was soothing to my throat, and we took the opportunity to grab a bite too as breakfast seemed a long time ago.

Back in the hotel, we had a few hours to kill before we needed to go to the airport, so we retrieved and packed our laundry and worked on a couple of blog posts. Then all that remained was to kick back until we needed to head to the airport. With around an hour to go I went to spend a bit of our remaining cash in the bizarre little shop down the street, picking up some more chocolate orange Kit Kats and, intriguingly, some that seemed to be crackers flavour.

I couldn’t resist. I had to know.

I also tootled back to Starbucks for another brew which was, again, soothing on my throat.

At seven, we summoned a taxi and we were soon bowling along towards Ho Chi Minh City airport. We struggled to communicate with the driver especially when he demanded a question of us near the end of the drive. I was nonplussed but suddenly spotted the diverging roads ahead, marked international and domestic and some frantic hand waving made our intention clear. It was slightly more restrained than my earlier plane-taking-off-mime when I was attempting to explain we wanted to go to airport.

When we arrived, the terminal was swarming with crowds but once we’d managed to wriggle our way through into the airport proper, they dropped away. Whether people were being seen off my family members or it’s just a good place to hang out, we’ll never know. We found the check in queue for our flight and with the desk due to open in 20 minutes, we dumped our bags and prepared to wait.

As luck would have it, a few minutes before the desk opened, a chap came up to us and asked if we’d already checked in online - we had - at which point he unravelled a comically long list and asked me to help him find our names. This completely successfully, we were then ushered to the front of a new queue and seen to immediately without following the long line snaking around the check in desks. SCORE!

Next came passport control and the queue for security. Side note: while I was waiting to show my passport and visa, a mother and her teenage son were chatting in front of me in French. At least, it sounded like French to me. The thing was that the son had the word “pain” tattooed behind his left ear. I consulted Pete about this later: was he being a drippy emo teen and her actually meant pain, or was it in a French, in which case, why did he had a tattoo that said bread on his neck?

Didn’t work either way. Poor life choice. Judged.

Pete declined to get the word “sandwich” tattooed behind his ear.

We had a bit of a set to at security. When Pete’s boarding pass was scanned, an alarm went off and he was directed off to a different queue manned by some guards. I saw from a distance as Pete had a bit of a chat with them, was taken out of security and made to queue for a bit and then was taken off completely.

Um, what?

I took my time in security, unpacking and faffing with my bags as much as possible waiting to see what would happen. In the end, I was holding other people up so I gathered my trays of stuff and stood to one side. A guard beckoned to me to put my stuff through the scanning machines but I refused, explaining I as going to wait for Pete. We had a bit of a set to which went like this:

“You go through security now”
“No, my husband is gone”
“It not a problem”
“Yes it’s a problem”
“It’s good”
“It’s not good. Where is my husband”
“He’s over there”
“Why? What’s the problem?”
“There’s no problem”
“Yes there’s a problem”
“He need to check his bag”
“We already checked our bags”
“You go through security now”
“No, where is my husband?”
“He’s coming back”
“When?”
“Soon”

That was the best I could get out of him. I didn’t really have much of a choice, standing barefoot holding two trays with all my belongings splayed out.

I went through security and quickly repaired my things and then started to hunt for airport wifi. I hadn’t got as far as deciding whether to look up an embassy or contact the U.K. when I did indeed see Pete coming back to security. They let him through without having to queue again and once his things were all scanned, he joined me. Phew.

It turns out the loud alarm and big flashing red light were because he’d left his headphones in his checked bag and they wanted him to put them in his cabin bad. So. Weird.

Also, why do they not just tell you that instead of all the cloak and dagger stuff????

Still, what was done was done and we wandered along the gates in search of the airport lounge. I had a Priority Pass which I got free with my credit card that in theory entitled me to lounge access. But as with all free things, it sounded better than it was and so far, the only lounges I was permitted to use were either in different terminals or were closed due to covid. Sigh.

However, my internet research had shown that we might, just might, be able to use the Saigonnese lounge and so we found the entrance up a flight of stairs and I presented my pass optimistically at the desk.

It worked! I was allowed to bring Pete in as my guest (it’s all about who you know darling) and we were soon seated in the relative peace and quiet of the lounge, overlooking the dark airport runway and taking it in turns to help ourselves to the free food and drinks. I made some toast and tucked into spaghetti bolognaise while Pete had various combinations of sandwiches and a beer. We also both had a passionfruit juice in a can, although it was a bit of surprise when we discovered there was jelly floating in there too.

I went back for more spaghetti but found they’d changed the sauce to a creamy sort of pesto thing. It was cold and therefore a little disappointing but Kirsty doesn’t share food, and she also doesn’t say no to free food so I ate it anyway.

I made up for it with a round of tea and toast. The tea was objectionable but I enjoyed a bit of toast.

We departed the lounge and headed towards our gate at the allotted time, glad that we had had dinner for free and grateful that we could get plenty of water for the flight. It’s the little things. We inches along with the rest of the queue and eventually achieved our seats; it was a large plane and we were in the middle block with Pete on the aisle and me next to a chap who had confidently claimed the armrest. Win some, lose some.

And thus, a little after midnight, we took off.

posts.title: Honeymoon Laze
posts.content:
Day 37

We got up at the slightly early time of half eight in order to plunder the breakfast buffet while the food had a bit more chance of being warm. This was a successfully strategy, and we found there were more choice too; I put away a bowl of fruit, ordered some scrambled eggs and made some toast. Yum.

I also filled my water bottle with what I thought was water but later turned out to be lemon squash, so that was a sugary surprise.

Pete also found the sausage and bacon to be much more appealing and did indeed eat most of it except a couple of bits of rind. Meaning that when the older black dog padded over to make sad eyes at us, he got fed some nice little morsels from Pete’s plate. Lucky boy. All I had to give him was some little scratches behind his ears.

Back in our room, I made a round of tea and we whiled away most of the morning reading, moving out to our little balcony to watch the sun play on the sea and the bright orange, chocolate chip starfish meander quietly around the sea bed. It was so relaxing.

Around lunchtime, we decided to go for a swim, and Pete suggested we go off the edge of the jetty. This turned out to be an excellent suggestion; the wooden planks were warm with the heat of the day so slipping into the water was a relief. The water was little more the waist deep even that far out and could barely be described as cold at all. Patches of cool water and warm water seemed to intermingle as we bobbed and swam and it was blissful.

Eventually, I clambered out of the sea leaving a Pete to swim a little bit longer while I grabbed a shower. It wasn’t long before Pete arrived back though, and we ventured to the little shop to get a snack and an ice cream.

While the cleaners gave our room the once over, we sat on our little deck one more, chomping through a strawberry cornetto each (yum!) and once our room was done, we sat indoors to enjoy a little bit of cooler air con, a cup of tea (because it makes sense) and an episode of Lost.

It was one of those days where I really don’t know where the time went. Somehow it was approaching five and the sun was beginning it’s descent behind the mountains. We decided to go for another sea-swim, starfishing in the water and laughing. It was cooler, but the setting sun left lovely sparkle trails to swim through. We disturbed a small shoal of jumping fish and they swam around us leaping through the water, tiny silver scales glinting before plopping back in.

Some of them misjudged and jumped right into us, pinging unceremoniously off our arms and shoulders. It was comical.

Back indoors, we showered and then watched the dusky sky turn pink and the pier lights flicker on. The hotel dogs pottered along the jetty, the three-legged one lolloping his best and it was all so peaceful and lovely.

Once it was dark, we felt the need for some dinner, but as I felt super lethargic, we decided just to eat in the hotel again. The expense and faff of renting bikes to go somewhere else just seemed like something neither of us could be bothered with.

I put on long trousers and a long-sleeved shirt - confidently asserting I was going to avoid bites this time - and we took our seats again the bar area. We ordered the same thing again partly through lack of imagination and partly through a small menu. Apparently I’m now one of those people that goes abroad and still orders pasta everywhere. Great.

Also Pete said that I had all the imagination of a soft potato which I think was unfair. And mean. He’s a meanie. After all, soft potatoes can have big dreams and become potato smilies, the fluffy insides of triple cooked chips, mash, smash if you’re desperate, and probably other useful things like potato flour and vodka.

And that’s if we don’t even bring our the big guns and include croquettes.

I’m unsure about hash browns as the potato in those is grated, but I also like to think that soft potatoes could give them a go.

So there Pete. There are more things in a soft potato than are dreamt of in your philosophy,

#softpotatoesunite

Anyway, the food came, we didn’t share chips this time (Kirsty doesn’t share food) and the dog with three legs came to site balefully at our table and made sad eyes, so I fed him most of my bacon. The little pup appeared before too long but wasn’t interested in the chips Pete offered (Hopalong II obliged though) and before long went back to his favourite, high energy activity: play fighting with the two other dogs. They tolerated this with a world weary patience, each about 4 times the size of the pup who attempted to terrorise them alternatively. It took both the larger, more chilled dogs just to absorb the puppy’s zany antics.

After dinner, we popped to the shop to buy some more milk and a Kit Kat each. As the receptionist started his rigmarole of taking photos of our selection and making phone calls, we just pointed to the prices on the shelves and offered him the cash. It was considerably quicker.

And then hurrah, back to the room where I flopped on the bed, this time pretty confident that I could now stay in for the night. Marvellous!

We worked on a couple of blog posts

Day 38

Our morning followed the pattern of the previous day: up at half eight, munch through some breakfast, resist the sad eyes of the hotel dogs who came to sit with us. The big black dog nuzzled Pete’s pockets, laying his head adoringly on his lap while I had to tell off the puppy for chewing on my skirt. To be fair, he did then look ashamed of himself.

Back in our room, we had a couple of rounds of tea as we packed up and sorted flight details both for this day to Ho Chi Minh and the next (on to Dubai). Before long, we were hoiking our bags up to reception to check out and waiting for our taxi to the airport.

This showed up in good time and we arrived at the airport by 11:15, a little in advance of our check in time. But I’d always rather be early than late and so I was perfectly content to pass the time with my audiobook.

We checked in relatively easily and we’re assigned exit row seats - nice, bit more leg room - and then we shuffled along through security. Once we were airside, I had a little mooch around in the vague hope that I might find a tea to soothe my sore throat, but nothing doing, which was not entirely unexpected.

We took our seats instead at our gate and waited for our flight to be called for boarding. It was a grey, overcast day and when we started queueing to have our boarding passes checked, we realised it was raining and we’re quite grateful for the little bus that ferried us from gate to plane.

The flight was a short one, taking less than an hour, but our descent into Ho Chi Minh soon proved that the rain was setting in as clouds wreathed the views below and it was some time before the plane was low enough to see through them.

As we climbed down the stairs onto the tarmac, we realised it wasn’t just raining, it was absolutely pelting down, a layer of water already draped over the runway and sheets of water sleeting down the windows of the waiting bus. It turned out the little bus was also not waterproof and as passengers were all struggled to rearrange ourselves around the internal drips.

Inside the terminal, we managed to gather our bags and find a taxi to our hotel. The rain had slowed to a steady drizzle but it was gloomy as we headed into the city and everything looked damp and morose.

Apart from those startling moments where it was all suddenly overexposed by the lightning.

The lull was shortlived: soon thunder was accompanying the lightning, the rain returned to unrelenting pounding and the taxi sloshed through waves of water which washed over the streets.

Our taxi driver managed to pass our hotel twice, encircling the block ever more widely and it took some pretty stern pointing and insisting he stop. I was miffed - it’s one thing to get ripped off by a taxi driver when they take a long route but another for him to ignore you as you shout “it’s here” while he goes for another merry round of the block.

That was reflected in his tip. Sigh.

Anyway, when we had convinced him to stop, he first off almost reversed into another taxi behind us and it was only the quick wit of the hotel porter dashing out into the rain and smacking the back of the car that got him to stop. Once the second taxi had moved, the porter guided our taxi to reverse right up to the hotel steps on the pavement. He hustled us inside promising to get out bags and we were soon indoors out of the rain. Well played that porter! He managed to manoeuvre our bags and his umbrella inside all in bare feet to avoid traipsing the wet into the hotel. Wowsers.

We checked in and headed up to our room to take stock. We needed three things: laundry, money and milk. So we dug out our ponchos and had a quick Google for nearby facilities. Pete found a little grocers 2 doors down, we could see a bank across the street and we found a laundry slip inside the wardrobe. So we organised a few clothes that needed washing (the last wash we would need before heading home) and headed back down to the lobby.

The laundry was soon in the hotel’s capable hands and we donned our ponchos to embrace the rain. It had slackened somewhat for which I was grateful, but we definitely needed the waterproofs. The crossed the road and ducked into the bank: the security guard outside made us take our hoods down presumably because with our transparent plastic hoods up, we could have gotten away with a bank heist, but as we scanned the room, it was clear there was no ATM. Sigh.

We popped to the little shop next for supplies and it was possibly the most insane place of its kind either of us had ever visited. It was CRAMMED with stuff and food and junk and knick-knacks. It was almost as though the proprietors had forgotten that customers would need to get between the shelves; we had to shuffle sideways along them to get anywhere. It was an absolute warren of place, extending further back than anyone had a right to suppose, but they did at least have everything we wanted. We picked up milk, tea, Pringles and Oreos for Pete and some mini chocolate orange Kit Kats for me and while, after multiple laps of the shop maze, we couldn’t find water, asking at the til promptly produced 2 bottles. Goodness only knew from where.

We surveyed the surrounding area once we’d attained the relative spaciousness of the pavement and found a couple of ATMs on the other side of the block. The first one was nothing doing but the second supplies the ready and as we walked back to our hotel, we clocked a promising option for dinner too.

It was nice to dive back into our room out of the rain and we made tea and gave ourselves a little while to chill, Pete on his laptop, me with my book. It was an incredibly cosy novel which moved at a slow pace but in a good way that I felt reflected the pace of life. It was about three retired primary school teachers living in Yorkshire trying to solve a crime and that description right there was enough to make me think “this is a book for Kirsty” when I initially chose it.

At seven, we gathered our ponchos once more and set out for dinner. The rain had largely stopped and the little spatters that fell weren’t enough to warrant the ponchos, so we stuffed them away and walked more confidently into the evening. We headed for the restaurant we’d spotted earlier and it turned out to be an excellent shout.

Banana Leaf was an Indian restaurant (which also did a line in Malaysian, Singaporean and Chinese food) with an immense menu and a rather lovely marmalade cat who lay down and let me stroke her.

It took us a while to work our way through all the options and having done so, we were none the wiser really. We’d both zeroed in on the same dish, not because we knew what it was but because it had a promisingly curry sounding name. So in this end, we picked two chicken curries (or gravies as they were called) virtually at random, one from North India and one from the South, based on the potential of the name. Same principle as placing bets on a horse race. Then we ordered an egg fried rice to share (Pete was reluctant to go for the coriander rice) and a garlic naan each.

The first curry (not sure which one) arrived along with the rice and both servings were huge. The rice was piled high in its bowl and a tentative taste of the curry proved it had a very warming kick and a rich, intense flavour. Winning! Before too long, the second curry and the naans arrived, all giant portions, and we set to.

We’d each been given a plastic, rectangular tray (or plate?) covered with a banana leaf and I wasn’t sure if we were supposed to eat off this. No other crockery seemed forthcoming but it was also hard to tell what other diners were doing without really obviously gawping.

In the end, we decided not to put the food on the leaf, just in case it was a tray or mat and not a plate, and we pulled the small plates the curries had been standing on out from underneath the dishes. They were more side plate sized than anything, but it meant we could have little servings of one curry and then the next quite easily.

The food was incredible: the flavours had proper depth, the chicken which was on the bone basically melted off and the second curry also had bit chunks of onion and pepper which added a delicious crunch. I initially thought the first curry was my favourite - spicier and more sauce - but then switched my allegiance to the second - contained the tasty veg and flavour more complex. Although to be fair, if you can’t decided which is the best between two dishes, it speaks highly of both of them.

We finished off all the naan - it was super yummy - dipping into the curries with glee. But in the final count, we managed half to two thirds of the curries and rice. We absolutely would have been find with one curry to share. But hey ho.

We toddled back to our hotel and retreated to lie on the bed, feeling full and drinking tea. We managed to rouse ourselves just long enough to put a blog post together but then settled into bed with another cuppa, an episode of lost and our Kit Kat and Oreo snackos. Yum!

posts.title: Honeymoon Island
posts.content:
Day 36

At quarter last five, we were up with our alarms and beginning the swift - but tiredly quiet - procedure of getting dressed, packing up our few remaining things and heading out. Our taxi to Da Nang airport was already waiting thankfully and we slumped inside, eyes closed for the journey ahead.

This took slightly less than the predicted hour and the airport proved busy but efficient so long queues moved quickly and we were all checked in and secured with a little less than 2 hours to go before our flight.

Time to hunt for tea.

We checked any number of places but couldn’t find anything that resembled a cuppa - one place had lychee tea but it just didn’t sound the same to be honest. And fair play: why would the cafes and restaurants serve something that no one in Vietnam is drinking?

Fortunately, I then found DIA Fast Food, a tiny cafe that had “Lipton Tea Milk” on the menu. This sounded promising and as the place was empty, I engaged the lady running the show in a long dialogue: Lipton tea, black tea, hot, Lipton, milk, a little bit (hand gesture) no sugar, hot tea, little bit of milk, black tea, no sugar.

I think she thought I was a moron.

But I almost got results. The tea was indeed hot, black and had milk. The cups were tiny but we had to forgive that. However, the tea was sweet. Sigh.

However, whenever we’ve tried to buy milk in Vietnam, the default is sweetened and you have to hunt to find the plain stuff, so maybe it was the milk that was sweet. Hard to say.

It wasn’t as aggressively sugary as some things we’ve had though and I was grateful enough for a brew that I was soon contemplating ordering a second. Sugar be damned.

We mooched around in search of a breakfast-style snack and found a cafe where Pete picked a sandwich and I chose a chocolate muffin. At the till, they had a box of teabags and in a flash of inspiration, I had a quick rummage and found an English breakfast. So I ordered it. Hot. No sugar. Et cetera.

They heated both sandwich and muffin and, which is more, added only hot water to my teabag. Lush! Which gave me the opportunity to ask for a splash of milk, keenly observing the process over the counter, standing on my tiptoes like an obnoxious, back-seat tea maker. Apparently milk was extra, but I handed over the cash willingly and was given a little cup of milk.

Verdict? A proper cup of tea. Winning! Plus the muffin was very tasty to so good job all round.

Our flight to the island of Phu Quoc was scheduled for 8:30am and we were boarded in good time. We had been assigned emergency exit seats and so had extra leg room which was nice. The flight passed pretty smoothly and I read a bit and listened to some audio book, and we landed at 10:20 in Phu Quoc.

We did the usual airport rigmarole: retrieved our bags, embroiled ourselves in taxis at the exit and so on, but before too long we were driving across the island towards our hotel.

We arrived earlier than I thought, and we had checked in by eleven. Our room wasn’t ready as technically check in wasn’t until 2:00pm so we had a bit of time to kill and we sat and read for a while.

Moving out to the bar area, we started to research Phu Quoc a little more thoroughly. There were plenty of things that we could go and do on the island, but transport was once again the issue. Taxis were expensive and everything seemed to be on the West side of the island. Except our hotel, firmly ensconced in the east. If we wanted to get around, it seemed that we would finally need to cave and hire a moped to drive ourselves. We decided to give it a try later on in the afternoon.

It was very warm (33, but feels like 39, thank you weather app) and we were glad when our room was ready and we could head indoors for a bit.

Our room, by the way was an overwater bungalow. Booked way back when we were only on trip plan number 1 or 2 and we hadn’t even the remotest inkling we would be doing that in the Maldives, this has proved a relatively inexpensive way of getting the honeymoon overwater bungalow experience.

The bungalow was lovely - a little wooden hut with a palm thatch, a decking area to sit out on and even a little window in the floor to watch the sea. Amazing! And or course, the super extra honeymoon swan towel folding with leaves and petals and, in this instance, fairy light. Whaaaaaat!

We got settled in and then popped to the little hotel shop - it was approaching two and I was feeling pretty hungry, so we picked a snack each and bought some milk. Weirdly, the choices were “sweetened” or “less sugar”. Apparently it didn’t occur to anyone that “no sugar” is an option. I made myself a cuppa (Pete declined, soaking up some mad rays) and did a bit of sewing, looking out over the view of the sea. Wonderful!

We decided to have a little afternoon swim; the pool was nice and cool after a scorcher of a day, but after half an hour or so, more and more kids had descended to play and splash about and it wasn’t quite as peaceful as it had been.

We left the children to it and popped back to our room for a shower and change, before getting ready to go out for a bit.

And to learn how to ride a moped. We asked at reception if we could hire two motorbikes for the evening and it ended ip costing us less than £7. We were hoping they would turn out to be easy to ride and get around on as if so, that would simplify our travel considerably.

No one really bothered to ask us if we had driving licenses or anything trivial like that, but we did specify that we wanted helmets. Because safety first, folks!

About 10 minute later, 2 motorbikes were brought round to reception and the poor receptionist along with the chap who’d brought them had to teach us quickly how to ride them, using a combination of miming, poking random buttons and Google translate. In the end, we figured we had the gist of it (how hard could it be, really?), I googled which side of the road the Vietnamese drive on just to make 100% sure, and then we set off.

We started off slowly, gradually getting the feeling of the bikes and riding south along the road which followed the coast. Fortunately it was quiet and the little traffic that appeared gave us a wide berth.

Driving the bikes was not dissimilar to riding the e-scooters we’d rented in Myanmar, and was was a tentative 20km/h soon became a slight more confident 30-35km/h.

This established, we turned the bikes around and set off along the road in the northerly direction. We passed by our hotel and kept going towards our destination: Rory’s Wreck Bar. This has been recommended both by our hotel and a blog I read online as as it was only 4km away, it seemed like a good little ride that would allow us to properly test riding the bikes.

The going was relatively straightforward. There were areas where sand covered the the road or large puddles, but these didn’t seem to cause undue problems for the bikes and I gradually learned to just ride through them. No worries. The traffic remained quiet and it seemed that sleepy dogs were the main road users, pottering and scratching around at the verges.

We arrived at Rory’s bar after just the one stop for me to check the directions: it had indeed been a good test run. We parked the bikes, dropped the kick stands and stowed our helmets and then went to investigate.

Rory’s Wreck bar, it turns out, is actually in a wreck. You wouldn’t necessarily know straight away as it’s done up so nicely, but it’s all built within a ship with an outdoor decking and a covered space with wide, open windows. We opted to sit undercover at the long bar looking out to the ocean as the view was wonderful. A rock pool had been built between the sea and the bar, palms were dotted here and there, a little jetty reached out to sea and it was just a lovely place to relax and observe. We ordered a mango smoothie each and sat to watch the world go by.

It wasn’t long before Rory himself came to join us and have a natter. A genial Australian bloke, he regaled us with information about the island and stories of his experiences setting up the bar having moved over from Sydney. He was good company and it was interesting to get an ex-pat view of life in Vietnam.

In other news, Rory had also constructed an 18-hole crazy golf course behind the bar and I was half inclined to convince Pete to come back and play another time. Can’t resist a crazy golf.

Once we’d finished our drinks, we had a little stroll around the rock pool; Rory had said there were starfish in it but we couldn’t spot any. Mind you, he’d also said that in lockdown, they would pick up a starfish, flip it over and watch it right itself to pass the time. He called it starfish yoga. We wandered along the little jetty looking at the beautiful soft blues of the sky, the palest of pink tinges inking the clouds as dusk started to creep in. Lush, green mountains carpeted in forest rose behind the bar while out to sea, far away on the horizon, we could make our the edge of Cambodia and shadows of land that indicated the Vietnamese mainland.

We returned to the bar and ordered the signature dish: fish and chips. The chips were fairly average, being more in the French fries line, but the fish was wonderful! Smallish pieces barramundi (I assume a local fish) covered in beautifully light, crisp beer batter. With a squeeze of lime and a dash of tartar sauce, they were excellent. The fish in particular was juicy and flakey, with a mild flavour which was clearly ideas like for the purpose. Safe to say, I enjoyed my dinner very much.

We grabbed the bill ready to make our journey back; it was only half six or so but we weren’t sure how good the lights on the bikes would be or how easy it would be to navigate the dark roads.

It turned out the hard part was getting the bikes going. I couldn’t work out how to unlock my helmet and Pete couldn’t figure out how to get his started. Fortunately, a helpful chap in the car park - who I think was British from his accent - got us both on the road and we started the drive back.

There were perhaps 2 things that made driving in the dark more difficult than the day. The first was the dogs. They were hard to see slinking along in the shadows, but they were also completely unafraid of the bikes. They would watch us driving towards them and remaining standing quite happily in the road meaning we had to manoeuvre round them. Silly doggos.

The other thing was the bugs. I don’t know if the headlight attached them or we were just driving through swarms of them, but they kept getting on my arms and flying in my face. Not cool bugs, not cool.

We parked up back at our hotel feeling that we’d gathered some useful transport information, had a good dinner and also managed to teach ourselves how to ride a motorbike. Excellent. Job done. Heading towards our bungalow, we could see a huge, red super moon hanging low in the sky, literally casting a red glow down over the water. Photos didn’t really cut it, and by standing on the end of the pier trying to take one, I realised I was simply feeling more of the local insects so I gave it up. It seemed very appropriate though, given that it was Ghost Festival day.

That’s right folks: Ghost Festival lies within the seventh lunar month (which is in fact ghost month) and the Vietnamese believe that, during this time, the gates to the dead are open and they can enjoy the offerings left for them. Often food but also the burned paper items, which went some way towards explaining the massive number of street fires in Hoi An the day before.

It was nice to get out of the cloud of moths and mosquitoes and relax in our room, especially after such an early start. I worked on my journal for a bit and then did a little of my embroidery to Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, because why not?

As the evening wore on, Pete made a round of tea, I munched through a delicious Kitkat chunky - cookies and cream flavour mind, none of your basics for me - and we, of course, watched an episode of Lost.

And despite the inexplicable karaoke so beloved of the Vietnamese that continued wailing into the night, we both settled down to sleep early, luxuriating in the chance to make back the early morning start.

Day 37

I had set an alarm for 9:15 giving us a long lie in which was very much appreciated. I had nice new collection of bites as I rolled out of bed but I suppose that’s what being by the coast often bring with it.

We toddled over to the tail end of breakfast and scooped up some eggs and a few bits and bobs. I had some fried rice and toast, Pete opted for sausage and bacon but said they tasted weird.

As we ate, a little golden brown puppy sat at our feet and gazed hopefully upwards, even resting his front paws on Pete in anticipation of a snack. Then an older, black dog padded over and watched us for a while, eventually booping at my pocket with a wet nose. I didn’t think dogs were super fond of scrambled eggs on toast though.

Once we’d finished, Pete did offer the older dog his bacon, but even then, the dog munched it very half heartedly and had to be persuaded that there was food. Clearly not great bacon.

We popped back to our room to finish off with a breakfast cuppa. It was a warm day and while there was some cloud, the sun still peeked through to sparkle off the sea.

Our plan for the day was to visit one of Phu Quoc’s famed beaches and so we packed up a bag each, slung on shorts and t-shirt over our swimmers and popped over to reception. We hired a couple of motorbikes for the day so we could get about (we checked and the price of a taxi to the beach and back was almost £40 - no thanks).

I’m still astonished at how easy it is to rent a motorbike. The conversation goes something like this:

“Do you know how to ride a motorbike?”
“No”
“Here you go”

We jumped on our bikes undeterred and set out on our journey (once we’d figured out how to start them which seems to vary slightly between models). We also knew we’d needed petrol (or maybe diesel? Unclear) but we couldn’t find where to put it in or how to open the fuel tank, so we decided to just head to the petrol station and hope for the best. Either they would fill it for us as a number of them seem to do, or we could make sad faces until someone showed us what to do.

We rode along the quiet local roads for a few kilometres until we reached a small village where we turned off to use a petrol station Pete had found. Thankfully, the chap there took charge of our vehicles immediately, and clearly knew what to do. He took the cap off my fuel tank and dipped a finger in to show me it was full. While my fuel gauge had read about two thirds full, I wasn’t going to argue; if I didn’t have to buy any fuel for the days then no worries!

Pete’s tank was virtually empty though so the chap filled it and charged us 50 000 dong. A little under £2. Bargain. Which also meant that our entire transport for the day, including fuel, came to a fraction over £15.

We carried on towards our destination, Pete leading and navigating like a pro. The roads were mostly quiet but we stuck to the edge anyway, and you always knew when other vehicles were coming because they would beep at you. Which, once you remember that it’s not because they’re annoyed, does at least tell you that they’re coming and that they’ve seen you.

We pulled up at the side of the road every so often to check the route: we skirted one large roundabout where the road turned into a dual carriageway of sorts and if anything, this was easier as we could stick to the side of the road and leave ample room for the odd car or bus or truck to pass. Other bikes would just weave in and out with no bother whatsoever.

We zipped along between 40 and 50km/h although there was no indication what the speed limit was and Pete’s speedometer didn’t work so he had no clue how fast he was going anyway. We just figured if he left me way behind, he needed to slow down and I kept an eye on the speed.

We pulled up just before a junction to check where we were and it turned out we were exactly at the junction we needed. So we turned left across the lanes and dived down a much smaller side road which soon petered into a track and then turned into a selection of car parks. We could see the beach beyond.

The car parks were choc full of coaches - there were scores of them - but we beetled around until we spotted a bunch of motorbikes parked under a tree and left ours with them took. A car parking attendant made me move mine to a different spot (but not Pete’s?) but then he didn’t charge us anything to park so we snapped pictures of our numberplates (I would legit have no clue which was mine otherwise) and wandered off in the direction of the beach.

Sao beach proved to be busy: the scores of coaches were clearly dropping off their tour groups to have a set meal in the versions beach-side restaurants, you could pay to go on a boat, a jet ski, a banana boat and even that parachute thing where a boat pulls you along and the parachute drags you up into the air. Parasailing? Can’t remember what it’s called.

We walked along the little beach to find somewhere a little quieter and found one bar-restaurant type place with shaded loungers out the front. We paid to hire a couple of these and sat to watch the world go by for a bit. The beach was pleasantly sandy and the sea was shallow and blue, perfect for paddling. Pete set out to have a swim and found he had to go quite far out before it was deep enough. Scores of boats were moored up, some empty, some bringing in more day trippers and some pootling around with noisy engines with no evident purpose.

The Vietnamese conflict between having fun at the beach and avoiding any and all exposure to the sun that might darken their skin is an absolute sight to be behold. Perched on my sun lounger, I watched multiple women wearing long trousers, hoodies (with the hood up), shades and face masks wade into the water while holding umbrellas over themselves. Insane.

I lay back to write journal and read for a while, enjoying not doing anything. I felt a little sleepy and I had woken with a sore throat so it was lovely to chill for a while. I snoozed for a bit too.

We had a bit of a swim mid-afternoon. The water was only just waist high but it was far from cold and it was a nice to scull around and watch the tiny fish flicker in and out of visibility.

We treated ourselves to an ice cream after that, enjoying one of the not-a-cornetto ice creams that we’d sampled in Hue. They were yummy and cold and mine revived me enough that I went back to reading instead of dozing. Party on, dudes.

A chicken strolled past.

And then my ice cream energy ran out and I dozed a bit more.

Around half four, we decided to head back before it started to get dark. If anything, the beach was even busier as we dusted ourselves down from all the sand and pulled on our clothes. Even as we stumbled away from the sea, we found more people arriving to make the most of the slightly cooler part of the day without as much direct sun.

Our motorbikes had been well and truly parked in but the attendant from the morning manhandled various bikes around until we could wiggle our free. And he still didn’t charge us anything.

We did the journey in one go without stopping as the route was quite straightforward with a couple of junctions and a roundabout to navigate. There was more traffic as folk were done with their day’s work but it was manageable and we scooted along reasonably happily.

Back at the hotel, we had a shower each (which somewhat overwhelmed the limited capacity of the drain and flooded the bathroom) and then flopped onto the bed as dusk turned the sky from golden yellow to pinky blue.

Once it was dark, we stepped out to have dinner. We decided to stay in the hotel for the evening, mostly (on my part) because I struggled to summon the energy to go further afield. So we found a table in the bar area and perused the menu. There wasn’t a massive choice but we ordered - a club sandwich for Pete and a Carbonara for me. We also asked if they did chips on the off chance and it turned out they did. They just weren’t on the menu. A portion each then!

After a bit of to-ing and fro-ing (Pete’s sandwich already came with chips, so did we still want a portion each? No. There wasn’t any passionfruit juice and they were no longer doing smoothies so what would I like to drink instead) we got it all sorted and then Pete went to fetch our big spray. We both had a few extra nibbles and it never hurts to try and keep them at bay, even if the stuff is dreadfully sticky. It literally stripped the pain off Pete’s side of the table when he leant his newly-sprayed arms on it. Yikes.

The chips arrived first and Pete somehow decided we should share them. It’s not clear to me even now how that worked out. Then came my pasta which was tasty, and finally, a while later, Pete’s sandwich and chips.

As we ate, another couple were having a fancy, fairy-lit dinner on the beach and had set up a tripod with their phone to capture every minute of the meal. It was...weird. They didn’t seem to get much eating done as they had to keep going to check their photos. It was sort of mesmerising to watch.

Once we’d finished eating, we put the bill on our room tab and sauntered back to our bungalow. I showered to rid myself of bug spray and flopped on the bed in the vague hope that I wouldn’t need to get up again that day.

So, OK, I did have to go out again, but only to the little shop in reception to get some snackos and some milk so that tea would happen. Some things are important. We watched a couple of episodes of Modern Family and I chomped through my KitKat chunky (it was the last one in the shop and had involved the shopkeeper taking a photo of it, searching the shelves and then making some phone calls to find out what to charge us). After that, I was so sleepy that I just snuggled down under the covers to drift off, leaving Pete to enjoy some live-streamed gaming. Here’s to a good night’s sleep.

posts.title: Honeymoon Lantern
posts.content:
Day 35

I woke to my alarm at half eight while Pete snoozed a bit longer. Once we was ready, we wandered down for breakfast, the same as the day before, and discussed our options for sorting out the gaping hole in our travel plans.

Our consensus was we’d need to book the expensive flight home. We could get marginally cheaper ones a day or two later, but with the added cost of extra accommodation, it didn’t seem worth it. Equally, those flights were with Air Mauritius who’d cancelled our original flight and the last thing we needed was another plan home to be withdrawn for no reason at the last minute.

Reading into policies and regulations, it seems if they cancel with more than 2 weeks notice, airlines don’t have to compensate you for changes in travel plans, and they aren’t obliged to offer alternatives. So I requested a refund which apparently somehow takes 2 months to process and we supposed we’d have to just swallow the extra thousand pounds that new flights would cost.

I had contacted our accommodation in Mauritius to see if they would allow us to cancel. We had passed the point of free cancellation unfortunately but if they waived the fee, we could potentially cut out Mauritius altogether and fly home from Dubai a week early. It would be cheaper. But it would also truncate our honeymoon, the trip we had so carefully planned and waited for and replanned so many different times just so we could get something to work.

I didn’t hear back from the hotel and we didn’t want to wait much longer to book new flights. As Pete pointed out, anyone else who was on the flight we were on would also be trying to arrange alternatives. Which would drive up the price. I hadn’t even thought of that. Nightmare. I suddenly wished we’d just booked the previous night.

And so we sloped back to our room and made the booking. Absolutely top morning.

We set out to go and visit some more of the sights of Hoi An, this time with more of a plan to see specific places rather than just wandering round. It started raining as we began the walk along the river into town (because of course it did) but it wasn’t heavy enough to warrant the ponchos. It actually drizzled on and off all morning but we just decided to ride it out.

Technically to visit the ancient city of Hoi An, you are supposed to buy a ticket but this isn’t really enforced. However, there are numerous temples, tickets and points of interest you can visit, and you do need the ticket to get in. So we found a little booth in the corner of a square and bought our admission. Each ticket allows you to access 5 sights of your choice from a long list, and so we set forth to begin our visits.

As we walked through the street, we kept stumbling into fires (not literally) as almost every shop we passed had a bucket outside and was merrily burning the paper offerings we’d seen in Hanoi. Whether it was a special occasion or they do this all the time, we weren’t sure, but little bits of burned paper flurried in the air, and the wafts of heat and smoke were surprisingly regular.

Our first port of call was a temple we had walked past the previous day. An ornate pink gate led to a courtyard beyond which held a beautiful carp statue in a fountain. We surprised to find three ENORMOUS fish swimming in the small, murky green pond. Seriously, they were like the sharks we’d seen in the Maldives.

The pink gates were seriously impressive though with three, intricately carved arches and lots of Chinese characters. The courtyard held an incense burner, bonsai trees, the aforementioned carp situation and a small shop selling memory cards and batteries. Just what every temple needs.

We seemed to have arrived at an opportune time however as there was a ceremony going on in the courtyard with four figures in ceremonial robes playing instruments and singing a curious quavering song. One kept the beat with a wooden block and the main singer had a mic which was amplified throughout the whole temple. While we were there, the moved to different shrines within the temple and it seems that some sort of dedication or celebration was going on.

We stepped into the temple to find a small cafe in one side, a large table laid with offerings in the middle and various different alters and shrives in different rooms. The ceiling was clustered with spiralling wooden cages which we later released were immense incense sticks wound into coils and set alight. Ash drifted down from above at regular intervals.

Part of the ceremony seemed to involve scattering brightly coloured sweets over the ground and they crunched as we walked, and enormous pillar candles carved into little montages burned at every shrine. And still the music and the singing continued.

We found more statues, including a twining dragon decorated in a mosaic of porcelain and a carved wooden ship, brightly painted and laid with offerings of water and milk. Incense burned from numerous urns and Chinese characters decorated columns and archways. It was incredibly interesting to explore.

Sadly the next stop we were hoping to visit was closed - or at least the padlock on the gates provided a facsimile thereof. Our third stop, while marked on the map simply wasn’t there. We weren’t sure if the map was wrong or we were, or whether it was not actually possibly to visit, but the assembly rooms were clearly not in our future.

Instead, we ventured into one of the old Hanoi Houses: Quan Thang. Constructed and panelled in dark wood, it was interesting to have an insight into what the houses of old established traders would have looked like. There was a tiny internal courtyard with a little pool and the walls were covered in carved screens. Two shrines occupied two little nooks and while there was little to see in terms of furniture or set up, we could appreciate that it’s actually someone’s home rather than a museum.

Next we visited another temple, one that we had wandered past the previous day and hoped to visit. Mainly because, through the open gates and framed in an archway, we could see a colourful, twining dragon statue and we wanted to investigate more!

We enjoyed looking at the dark wood of the pillars with Chinese characters picked out in gold, and the dragon did indeed dominate the courtyard. It was beautifully posed with its coiling round and round, rising out of a fountain where real water met the stylised curls of rainbow coloured waves. The dragon was decorated in the ceramic pieces that seem to be a popular design feature here we sat on one of the benches to admire it until it started to rain more heavily.

We explored the main temple shrine and a couple of side rooms which contained beautiful paintings. Pete beckoned me out to the back towards a small garden area and said there was an entire pit of dragons and a crazy goat lord to see. This seemed a bit far fetched but actually his description was right on the money: numerous dragon head statutes reared from a fountain, jaws wide and scales gleaming. At the back of the garden, a huge white statue of a goat dominated everything. For reason or reasons unknown. We aren’t quite sure how the goat got involved.

We’d either seen - or tried to see - all the sights on our list now and so decided to head back towards our hotel, stopping enroute for a smoothie. On the way, we happened To past the Ming Huong Communal house and so stepped in to spend another of our tickets. While it was a little smaller than some of the other temples we had visited, it had an interesting history, being built in 1820 to honour the Ming Huong village community: a group of Chinese immigrants who had been ousted from China when the Qing dynasty took over from the Ming dynasty. Those who left China were welcome in Vietnam and given the right to trade and set up their own community, and while the communal house has been restored several times and is still in need of some work, it was nice to visit and see the ornate shrines and the detailed carvings.

We continued on our way back towards our hotel and eventually reached a cafe called Nourish that was recommended online. We fetched up just as it started to rain harder and ducked under the cover of the awning to grab a table and order a smoothie each.

We split a portion of sweet potato fries which were yummy. Sweet potato here is a different vegetable to the one we get in the U.K. and it was almost more like cassava. But the fries were lovely, freshly cookies and served with an excellent garlic dip. I also though my smoothie was possibly the best one I’d had yet, being a lovely thick blend of banana, oat milk, peanut butter, dates and, apparently, Himalayan salt. It was topped with little shavings of toasted coconut and peanuts and it was divine. Pete was pretty good too: a blend involving mango, pineapple and banana and we were both more than content with our order.

We wandered the last few minutes back to our hotel; the sky was overcast and it was extremely humid but the rain had stopped (ish) so we decided to go for a swim. We had the pool to ourselves and it felt nice and refreshing after our walk in the balmy air.

We had a couple of hours relaxing in our room, journaling, having tea and reading and then did a bit of research into our next destination: the Vietnamese island of Phu Quoc.

Somehow as we were looking into modes of travel and places to snorkel, dusk had fallen so we gathered our things and began the walk into Hoi An for the evening. While we loved the old town, I think we were both glad that this would be our last time tramping the half hour or so into the centre. We dodged around more lit braziers which lined the street and headed towards our destination: the Banh Mi Queen. We had loved the banh mi we had on the food tour and having established it was the best, we decided to go back for our last night.

Except when we got there, it was closed. Sigh. Definitely not our day. I had checked the opening times before we left so either Google lied to me or they were closed for some other reason. Either way, sad times.

We pondered our next move: we didn’t have another place in mind to eat, and lots of the central old town restaurants were very touristy and not especially authentic. In the end, we decided to go to the night market and do a bit of shopping, and if we hadn’t spotted a place we fancied by then, we would go back to Banh Mi Phuong from the previous evening. While not the best, they still made a very tasty sandwich, and we knew it was quick and inexpensive - and they stayed open later!

Heading to the night market, we had to pass over the lantern bridge. Something of a bottleneck, it was absolutely teeming with tourists, the busiest we’d yet seen it.
