However, we made it through to the night market and spent an entertaining half hour or so choosing some souvenirs. We bought ourselves a magnet for our collection in the hope that one day we will have a fridge we can stick magnets to. We even bartered down the cost because we are skilled and suave negotiators. And then we bought a celebratory ice cream as we were hungry and our dinner hadn’t materialised. We opted for a mango version of the frozen rolled ice cream, and it was fun to watch the guy chilling, chopping and preparing the mixture as it slowly solidified. Then they added chocolate sauce, sprinkles and a penny sweet in the shape of a crocodile. Because reasons.

We shared by the way, because I’m mature about stuff like that now.

Feeling sufficiently refuelled, we went to the one of the lantern stalls and selected a couple to bring home as a souvenir. Our ice-cream fuelled bargaining was once more successful and we ended up with a pair of the pretty shades to bring home. And to fit in our luggage, but one conundrum at a time.

Then we walked back through the night towards the banh mi shop.

When we arrived, we were surprised to find people queueing down the street, but Pete, ever the savvy diner, slipped inside and found it you were happy to sit indoors and eat, you could order straight away.

Problem solved.

Pete ordered a couple of banh mi - one beef and one “mixed” - and I went for my signature chicken and cheese. They were yummy and even with drinks our whole dinner cost us less than a fiver. Winning.

All that remained was to make the trek back to our hotel. We dodged the occasional rat, investigated some weird chirping that we kept hearing. It turned out to be frogs - who, by the way, did not like to have torch light shone on them - who constantly croaked in a way that sounded a bit like a duck and a bit like an angry cat. They responded to the barks of nearby dogs and it was the strangest noise. It was good to finally solve the mystery.

We passed a couple of bars and wondered if it was once more crate night in Vietnam, and eventually reached our hotel.

In our room, we had a shower to cool down and then Pete popped a bottle of Prosecco we’d been carrying around since Sapa. What with evenings out or the occasional lack of a fridge, there hadn’t been chance to drink it, and we figured we wouldn’t be able to take it on a plane the next day.

So teacups of Prosecco it was!

And then a little teacup top-up because it was our honeymoon after all.

We finished the evening in traditional style: tea and Lost in bed. Can’t beat a classic

posts.title: Honeymoon Birthday
posts.content:
Day 34

We woke a little before our half eight alarm and I wished Pete a happy birthday! And have him a card because he LOVES cards and they are his favourite thing in the world ever*

*inaccurate

We pottered down to breakfast and found that while the buffet accoutrements were present, you actually ordered your breakfast to be brought. We both ordered some scrambled eggs and helped ourselves to tea and juice, and I made some toast.

We were then brought plates of scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage and fruit platter. So that escalated fast.

We left most of the watermelon.

The tea was good though and we enjoyed a couple of small cups to prepare us for the day ahead.

We prepped some laundry to be done and then gathered our things to set out and explore the old town for the morning. I had thought it would be overcast - the weather forecast had been distinctly gloomy - but actually there was quite a lot of sun as we ventured forth for our riverside walk into Hoi An. We were back to a solid 33 degrees, feels like 39 with the humidity and sure enough, we were soon sweating.

We spent a pleasant morning pottering around amid the pretty yellow buildings, browsing the various stalls and poking our noses into this and that. And then retrieving them again quickly if the vendors proved particularly over keen. We visited the famous Japanese bridge which arced delicately over a small side river. Actually, we visited it twice as the first time it was so rammed with a tour group and people taking photos that we could barely get a look in. But having wandered around the block, it was then empty so we were able to get a better look.

Built in the 17th century, the carved wooden bridge was built by the Japanese to link up different parts of Hoi An more easily, and now stands as a monument to cooperation between the Japanese, Chinese and Vietnamese. The entrance to the bridge was guarded on one side by a pair of dog gods and by a pair of monkey gods on the other, and in the middle of the bridge there was a smaller temple off to the side. We saw a sepia-toned photos from the beginning of the 20th century and it was comical to see that, again, the bridge was crowded and that some people had climbed over the bridge rails while others stood on the bank to be in the photo. In some ways, nothing changes.

I picked up a few postcards in a print shop and managed not to buy some coasters even though I was tempted. However, the sun was starting to get the better of us and so we ducked into a cafe and had a sit down under a fan and a mango smoothie each. Which went down very well indeed.

This revived us enough that we went to explore the local food market. There were lots of food stalls, many occupied, and then these gave way to stalls which sold fruit and veg, or herbs and spices, various knick-knacks and then, finally, a meat section. We emerged from between the hacking meat cleavers back to the riverbank, and as it was quite scorching with the sun high in the sky, we decided to return to the hotel to spend the hottest part of the day indoors. Or possibly in the pool.

We picked up a few snacks on our way to make a light lunch and we were absolutely ready for some air con and a cold shower when we got back to our room. Phew!

After a bit of a nibble and some journaling time, we decided to give the pool a try. It was a little chilly but it was nice to splash around for a while in the water.

Back in our room, we clocked up another episode of Lost with a brew and then got ready to head out for and celebrate Pete’s birthday! We walked back along the river into town and found the market considerably busier than when we left it. Strolling up and down the water’s edge in the old town, we looked for a bar that looked like it had a good view and settled on a roof terrace overlooking the bridge.

We were right: the view was great and we ordered a cocktail to toast the evening. Pete when for a pineapple mojito while I out away a banana mojito. Now before you judge, bear in mind that I was a bit incredulous too and mostly ordered it because it sounded weird. But it totally worked and had an almost creamy, banana edge to it. Yum!

We felt a spot or two of rain but remained undaunted on our terrace while other, chicken-hearted guests scuttled indoors. Our intrepid natures paid off and it stayed dry for our first and indeed second drinks. Double yum.

We just ignored the lightning which split the sky at regular intervals. Instead, it was lovely to chat and reminisce and laugh, reflecting over the last year and our plans for the next one.

As dusk fell, the lights in the lanterns flickered to life setting a soft warmth emanating from the silk covers. Growing to a pleasant glow as the sky darkened, the lanterns were soon warming every shop front and the little boats began their nightly cycle up and down the river, reflections rippling in the water. While down on the street it was busy and bustling, it was so pleasant to be up on the roof observing from above.

We decided to take a boat ride for ourselves and so left our lofty perch to mingle with the crowds below. We plucked some cash from an ATM, thrust about £6 at a boat chap and were soon on our way down the river. It was the same journey as the night before (although this time we bumped into three other boats) but it was lovely to have the little vessel to ourselves and watched the night time dance of lantern light on the water. Blissful.

Once we’d been ejected from our boat, we were ready to eat and so we headed into the night market. While definitely a market for tourists rather than locals, we were nonetheless happy to wander up and down, looking at lanterns and contemplating buying one to take home and pondering what we fancied for dinner.

And that’s when the heavens opened.

We shrugged into our ponchos as there wasn’t much else we could do and made the distinctly damper walk up and down the rows of market stalls. However, neither of us found the stalls particularly enticing. There was a good deal of octopus on a stick (nope) and lots of banana pancakes and crepes and ice cream, but very little that said delicious Vietnamese morsel to us.

Pete hit upon a good plan though: he suggested we head for the famous banh mi place and try their sandwiches.

I was more than happy to do this and, as we knew they had indoor seating, it seemed a good option to get out of the rain.

So we trooped through the dark streets until eventually we came to the right place: Banh Mi Phuong. This banh mi joint became super famous after Anthony Bourdain visited but according to our guide from the day before, she thought it was super touristy, claimed other banh mi was better and that locals didn’t eat there. Well, we were about to find out.

To be fair, she seemed to be right on some counts: the place seemed to be filled exclusively with tourists and the fact that the first thing on the menu was a burger made us judge them a bit. Plus, they had a picture of Anthony Bourdain on like, EVERY PAGE and it was weird.

Not even a good picture: a screenshot from YouTube with the play sign over the middle.

Super weird.

However, it was fast and cheap: Pete went for the pork option while I chose chicken and cheese and for less than £3 our dinner was served. Speedy! I was asked if I wanted spicy, and had to have that ludicrous conversation again where I specified that I liked spicy food and the server looked at me pityingly and said “so, medium?”. Sigh.

The sandwiches were indeed tasty. And not very spicy. The cheese in mine turned out to be cream cheese and it seems Laughing Cow is the business when it comes to cheese in Vietnam. The chicken was tasty though: tender but not dry, the added herbs had a good flavour and the sauce was very nice. Overall, a very solid banh mi indeed.

Just not as good as the one we’d had the day before. Sorry.

Good enough that we both ordered a second thigh: beef for Pete and a second chicken for me. Omnomnom.

It was still raining when we left so we set out to walk back towards our hotel while keeping an eye out for a bar. We stuck to the river bank and while it was mostly quiet, there was the odd place here and there.

We ended up in a bit of a dive bar that Pete found: it was full of locals sitting round tables devouring food and drinking beer by the crate. It seems they would buy 24 bottles and after each one was finished, just chuck it on the floor. Great. However, there was also a big sign in gold on the wall saying happy birthday. Meant to be.

By heading inside I doubled the number of female customers but we pulled off our ponchos, decided to ignore the stray cockroach and ordered a Huda Gold beer each. Huda is a Vietnamese beer and apparently is favoured in Hue, but it’s also a Danish beer somehow. That’s all I know.

The Huda was tasty enough and gives you ample opportunity to make Huda man jokes, and Pete chased his first with a second.

In the end, we decided to leave the locals to it and head back to our room for the night. A shower to wash off the rain and dirt was appreciated and we settled into bed to chill. I checked my email and found one that caught my attention.

Our flight home from Mauritius had been cancelled.

We spent the next hour or so researching our options and feeling alternately angry, frustrated, upset and despondent. We were given the option to request a refund (damn right I’m having a refund if you’re cancelling my flight) but no alternative travel options. Looking into booking a new flight at short notice, we found it was going to cost us over a thousand pounds more. Ouch.

I’m putting it mildly on purpose. We had rage.

There were literally no good options available to us that didn’t cost us a fortune and we were feeling so depressed the we gave up for the night and settled into somewhat muted activity, Pete on his laptop, me trying to write a chirpy journal. We’d have to work something out the next day. But given the problems we’d already encountered with the trip, it seemed extremely unfair that this had now landed on us.

I know we’re very fortunate blah blah blah, but it didn’t feel like it in the moment.

And it very much put a dampener on Pete’s birthday.

We had a quite round of tea and then settled down to bed. And that was that.

posts.title: Honeymoon Rain
posts.content:
Day 33

We were up at 6:20 to greet a light drizzle and to hustle down to breakfast. By the time we’d eaten and Pete had packed himself some surreptitious bus sandwiches, it was absolutely pouring down. Great.

We packed up the last few things into our packs, checked out and then strapped our bags round us, pulling our billowing ponchos over the top. Then there was nothing for it but to step out into the downpour.

The torrent last just long enough to drench us through completely on our way to meet the bus. We sploshed along the street, puddles unavoidable due to the sheer volume of water that had called in the last couple of days and made it to the meeting point. This was another one of those buses where there isn’t really a bus stop or anything, just a vague address that doesn’t seem very promising when you arrive.

But arrive we did by 7:15 and we ducked under cover of a nearby hotel as the rain slowly petered out to a half hearted drizzle. We were stuffy and sweating under our ponchos, completely wet through and, admittedly, slight miffed. The bus wasn’t due until 8:00am, but according to the ticket boarding was at 7:30am and travellers were advised to arrive 30-60 minutes early in case the bus goes at a different time.

Like, really????

Anyway, we waited for half an hour, hunched in our waterproofs, and then crossed the road to stand under the awning of a tourist tat shop for a bit. There were two other backpackers there and we asked if they were also heading to Hoi An; there were and this seemed a good sign.

A fraction before eight, a bus pulled up and while it had a different name to the one on our ticket, the drive me had a list with our names on. Winner. We piled on in, we’re given a small bottle of water each and then settled down for the journey. We didn’t set off until after eight and while we were relieved the bus had come, as Pete pointed out, it would be nice if you could just show up at the ticket time. We would have missed the worst of the rain that way.

Hoi An was reportedly a little over 3 hours away and so I switched on my audiobook and passed the time listening and dozing.

We pulled up finally in a nondescript car park in Hoi An and clambered out of the minibus and into our ponchos. The rain continued. I’m assuming everyone is the enjoying the “it’s raining” content as much as the “my goodness it’s warm” content. We were hoping to find a taxi but the car park was empty apart from a golf buggy, and there didn’t seem to be anyone around to ask.

But, joy of joys, the gold buggy turned out to be a taxi, and after a quick negotiation with the driver, we commandeered the little electric vehicle to take us to our hotel for £4. Bargain! As we drove through the streets and then alongside the lake, we saw lots of the little carts driving around and I wondered if these were the taxis of Hoi An and the city had adopted an electric vehicle policy.

We arrived at our hotel and checked in and after a short wait, we were shown to our room. We were feeling a bit sleepy but a cup of tea perked us up and we decided to work on a blog post in the hope that the rain would stop in the afternoon and we would be able to head out in the dry. After all, my app said at one o’clock it would stop raining.

Of course it was still raining at three so we sighed and donned our ponchos and set out anyway. We had a good tour booked for the evening which we were very much looking forward to, but we thought the walk into town would be a good way to help us find our bearings and get a bit of a feel for the town.

Our walk took us along the riverbank towards the old town; the water seemed a bit grey and the rain, and we were obliged to dodge puddles l and the odd bike and moped along the path. Almost as soon as we’d stepped out of our hotel, we acquired a curious shadow in the form of a young woman who peppered us with questions as we walked. She wanted to know where we were going, where we were staying, what we planned to do in Hoi An and how long we were staying. She also spent a while telling us about the tailoring shop her sister ran where she worked and encouraged us to come and have new clothes made. Hoi An is famous for its reams of tailors and having clothes custom made us practically tourist requirement. Eventually, our new friend wished us well and left the riverside path while we plodded onwards.

As we reached the outskirts of the old town, the rain had pretty much stopped and while stray raindrops would persist in dropping off the overhanging stalls, awnings and trees, it was nice to shrug out of my poncho; being encased in plastic just isn’t ideal when it’s so warm.

We wandered through a market lined with a real mix of wares: some very practical fruit and veg stalls and other geared very much towards tourists with magnets and jewellery and lanterns. Impatient motorbikes tried to make their way through the throng and it was slow going but there was lots to look at.

Emerging from the market into the old town proper, we got our first look at Hoi An proper. And it really was a beautiful place! Probably the most famous tourist spot in Vietnam, Hoi An is filled with golden yelllow, French colonial buildings and while these days, most of the old town is given over to tourist cafes and shops, it is undeniably lovely. While loads of tourists did indeed flock about about, the atmosphere was cheerful and relaxed as people simply pottered around admiring the patchwork of streets and alleys. We crossed a bridge over the river just to see where it led, but on both sides, hawkers attempted to sell us boat rides, food stalls were cooking up of storm and riverside bars and cafes advertised their roof terraces. We were looking forward to exploring properly.

However, we had a food tour to get to: our guide had asked us to meet her at White Rose, which to me seemed a strange name for a Vietnamese food join and sounded more like a pub in Yorkshire. But Pete led the way and we were soon outside waiting to begin our culinary adventure. I was starving, having only eaten half a cereal bar since breakfast at half six that morning, and so even though 5:00pm seemed early for dinner, I was more than ready to munch!

Our guide, Vi, (Like the start of VIP, as she told us) came straight out of the restaurant to collect us and gathered us indoors to meet the third and final member of our tour group: a chap from Kuala Lumpur named Noel.

Time to learn a little more about the local dishes of Hoi An! The thing that was great about the tour was that it really focused on dishes that were important in Hoi An, either because they’re served on special occasions or because they’re local classics that people eat daily. White Rose it seemed specialised in the former.

Vi explained that a white rose (or banh bao) is the name of a Vietnamese pork dumpling - suddenly giving the name of the restaurant a lot more context - and while they are served at various places in town, White Rose is the only place that makes them to a secret special recipe. A filling of pork, prawns and spring onion is nestled inside a flowing white rice flour case - hence the name - and then steamed before being served.

Vi told us that production was down since covid, with White Rose only making around 1000 dumplings a day to serve their own restaurant and the other restaurants in town, and we saw a table in the back of the shop where a team of women sat engaged in various parts of the dumpling making process. They also made vegetarian dumplings (banh vac) but these were sealed rather than open, and Vi told us they weren’t nearly as popular.

We grabbed a table and it wasn’t long before a place of dumplings arrived. Each! We had 4 of the pork and 2 of the vegetable ones to try and they were topped with a scattering of crispy shallots and served with a slightly spiced dipping sauce.

Oh my goodness they were tasty! I have to say the pork ones were definitely superior, but the soft dumplings with the crunch of the onions was just superb and the flavour was excellent: well seasoned and moreish. The dip was very good too.

We wolfed them down pretty quickly which was a good thing as our next dish arrived: hoanh thanh chien, a crispy wonton topped with prawns, vegetables and a sweet and sour sauce.

The wonton was deep fried and brittle - exactly the same dough as the steamed banh bao - but rendered completely different by the frying. Formed into a flattish triangle shaped, the toppings were sort of spooned over the top and Vi told us to pick it up like a slice of pizza. A couple of fat prawns nestled in among the spring onion, peppers, mushrooms and miscellaneous veg, and there were also chunks of pineapple. Pineapple juice was used to add sweetness to the sauce and overall it worked very well. A good balance of crunch and topping.

It had been an incredibly promising start to the food tour - I was really pleased we had been able to try banh bao as I had read about them and they were new to us - but it was time to move on in search of a new establishment and a new dish.

As we walked through the streets, dusk was falling and Vi explained that most food places only offer the one dish; they specialise in doing it a particular way and often there will be a lengthy cooking process or a lot of ingredients to develop and establish. I’m Vietnam, she told us that locals are often suspicious of places that offer too many different food options as they assume they aren’t being made properly. And it’s a valid point: why have loads of places serving mediocre dishes when you can have one place that can whip you up an exquisite portion?

Our next stop was to try cao lau - another dish I had read about and was eager to try and another dish that’s completely unique to Hoi An. Cao lau is a dish of pork, noodles, greens, rice crackers and broth. But surprisingly it’s the noodles that are the special ingredient. That’s for two reasons: they must be made with water from a particular well and the noodles are made of rice flour and the recipe involves a special herb that only grows nearby. Yikes.

Vi told us that one guy makes the noodles and then sells them at the market. Then traders will buy them and make them into cao lau: the broth might differ and so forth, but you have to have these special noodles.

We received a bowl of cao lau each which Vi described as a small bowl of “mostly vegetables”. She was lying. She told us to add a squeeze of lime and some chilli paste and then to give the bowl a good mix: the broth was in the bottom of the bowl and it was supposed to coat and season everything.

The dish was delicious: the broth rich and savoury with a pleasant little kick from the chilli and the noodles were lovely: they were thick, a bit like udon, but with more bite so they didn’t go soft and mushy in the broth. Overall a strong dish. Yum!

Our next stop was for a Vietnamese favourite and we visited Madam Khanh. Otherwise known as the queen of banh mi. Promising. Now we were already fans of banh mi - fanh mi, if you will - but we had also read that the best banh mi of all is to be found in Hoi An.

Vi led us past the little cart at the front of the shop and into a small seating area behind. There we met the 87 year old business founder (Grandpa, apparently) who was busy preparing pickles and keeping an eye on his daughters and granddaughters who ran the stall.

So what made this banh mi joint special? According to Vi, it’s for a number of reasons. It’s wildly popular with locals as over the years, even thought it’s become relatively famous, they haven’t sold out and become touristy or large or - heaven forbid - started offering a menu catering to westerners. Additionally, their banh mi is always super fresh: the do pick ups of fresh bread every half hour or so from a local bakery instead of buying a job lot and letting it sit around all day. The bread itself is special and includes not just wheat flour but rice flour and - check this out - sweet potato flour. This means you get a lovely crunch on the crusty exterior, but a fluffy interior with air pockets ideal for stuffing with fillings.

Meanwhile, the fillings are made fresh throughout the day and so the end product is in theory nightly superior.

Vi grabbed 2 banh mi for us to share and we tackled half a sandwich each. They were the traditional pork banh mi but with the restaurants special way of preparing them, and so inside the fresh, warm bread we had pork, pork liver pate made with lemongrass, fried egg, pickled vegetables, coriander and some sort of sauce.

It was IMMENSE. Easily the best one we’d eaten and this is from someone who doesn’t like pate. The addition of the egg was a total treat, the flavours from the sauce and the herbs was fresh and spicy and complex and zingy and every good thing and the whole thing just SANG. I immediately knew I wanted to come back another time for more.

Fortunately for me, there was another half a sandwich left. But as we all expressed interest in sharing it, Vi simpler ordered a third banh mi and we ended up scoffing a whole one each. Heavenly.

There was another banh mi place in town that we had earmarked to try as it seemed to be the place to go. Vi mentioned it and said it was indeed very popular, but only with tourists. This place, it seemed, had done the unthinkable and expanded into offering a wider, diverse menu and she believed their product had suffered because of it. The stall had originally become famous after Anthony Bourdain visited, but Vi told us that during COVID, Madam Khanh did a roaring trade still with locals while the other place stood empty.

We reckoned we’d probably still try it, but it was interesting to get a local’s perspective.

At this point, Vi told us we’d had enough snacks and it was time for dinner.

Snacks? We’d already eaten 3 meals!

Dinner proved to be three different things at a little restaurant on the street of the famed well. Heading down a narrow alley festooned with lanterns, we popped into the little shop, guarded by a cardboard cut out of a lady holding a plate of food and scowling. We were given a big plate of food each and Vi talked us through the different components.

First up was banh xeo; these were the pancakes we’d tried in Hanoi and once again, we were advised to take a piece of pancake, wrap it with some salad in rice paper and eat it that way. I’m still going to say that in my opinion, the rice paper adds nothing and just means you make a mess everywhere. Rude.

The dipping sauce however, was amazing. It was a bit like satay, made with peanuts and happiness and sesame and Vi added to this some chilli paste and pickle lid shallots. If I’m completely honest, banh xeo doesn’t do it for me: it doesn’t have the flavour of so many other wonderful dishes we’ve had, and while a crispy pancake sounds really promising, the filling of beansprouts (too many beansprouts in my opinion) and a stray prawn is a bit underwhelming. Whereas I would eat the dipping sauce with a spoon quite happily.

The next food item on the plate was an old classic: spring rolls. Rather than having the usual minced filling, these had a single prawn inside. They were nice enough, and we ate them topped with pickled vegetables and sweet chilli sauce, but again, I felt I wanted more flavour. Plus we’d had the best spring rolls ever the night before so so Hoi An, but these aren’t going to cut it for me.

The final part of our dinner was barbecued pork. This sounds simple but was so beautifully prepared that it elevated a quick bite into something very delicious indeed. Pork belly had been marinated in honey, ginger, garlic, five spice and every food thing for goodness knows how long. Then a chopstick had been split down the middle, pieces of pork stuffed into the split and then the end had been bound with banana leaf. This was then char grilled and produced a resulting flavour that was smokey and rich and satisfying with meat that was incredibly tender and just melted off the chopsticks as we pried them apart. It was one of Pete’s favourite things of the night.

We left the little alley and made towards our final stop for tea and coffee. Vi had called ahead to ask the tea and coffee shop to prepare the drip coffee ahead, and when we arrived, I accepted the offer of dragon pearl jasmine tea instead. Drip coffee is the popular way to take it in Hoi An, a process which allows the coffee to slowly filter through; to me it tastes strong and dark - and extremely bitter but then I’m not a coffee fan. As we drank, we chatted, enjoying swapping stories about how we take out drinks. Vi told us that in Vietnam, the default for coffee is always iced (which might explain Pete’s iced coffee the other day in Hue) but we said we pretty much always want coffee hot. And tea, natch. We also shared our experiences of COVID; we’ve found that wherever we go, while everyone’s experience of the pandemic is of course individual, the very fact of living through it creates an expected but lovely shared bond. Wherever you’re from, being locked down just isn’t fun, and it’s fascinating to hear how people coped in different places.

Once we’d finished our drinks, Vi said that the weather was good so we were going to go and play bingo. This was a bit of a surprise for a good tour, but we trailed along in her wake and were soon back by the banks of the river, seated on little stools and holding bingo paddles. Each paddle had three worlds with an accompanying image and once all the paddles had been sold, the game began.

It was extremely odd. A couple stood at the front and sang along to a drum and stringed instrument played live by others, and as they sang, they drew words out of a pot. They would then finish the verse of the song with that word and if it was on your paddle, you waved and were given a yellow flag to hold. If you go all three of your words, you won.

We were a bit nonplused but the crowd seemed to be really into it and it was such a man unusual experience that mostly I just wanted to see what would happen.

Of course, two of Pete’s words came up fairly quickly and I could practically see him dying inside and willing his third one not to come up. Further into the song, first one of mine and then another came up so we were both clutching two yellow flags apiece. We had no real means of picking out the words ourselves, but they would hold up the picture on the paddles too so that we could follow.

When Pete’s third word came up, I think he would have happily pretended he didn’t have it and let someone else win, but Vi was having non of it, waving excitedly. And so Pete had to go and have his photo taken while everyone clapped and cheered and he was presented with a lantern as his prize.

Truth be told, it was a little tacky, and announced him as a winner of the Hoi An Bingo. Or, “the art of Bai Choi the intangible cultural heritage of humanity”. Not my words. It was hilarious!

For our last stop of the night, Vi took us on one of the little boat trips on the river. These were sight to be seen as in the dark, the water and sky were inky while the river reflected the bright, beautiful silk lanterns that swayed merrily from shops, the bridge and the little boats themselves. It was like a scene from a film.

We stepped down into a little rowing boat with a lantern fore and aft, and spent about 15 minutes being rowed around a little circuit, weaving around all the other boats and basking in the glow of the rainbow orbs of light. We set little candles floating on the river and made a wish and it was lovely to soak up the atmosphere. I didn’t care if it was touristy: it was beautiful.

After our boat ride, we said goodbye to Vi and Pete and I strolled along the river. We stopped at a bar to have a drink and enjoyed a cold cocktail each, looking out over the river. It was refreshing and delicious; my cocktail was full of lime and lemongrass and kumquat and mint and it absolutely hit the spot.

It felt much later than it was as we’d been out for a while, so we began our stroll home around nine, back through the little town towards our hotel. We stopped to pick up water and then at a second shop I decided to grab a packet of Oreos to go with our evening cuppa. Because 4 dinners is not enough (we didn’t even get dessert: rude).

Although, I should perhaps say in all seriousness, I enjoyed the Hoi An food tour more than the Hanoi one. I’m not sure if it was because the food was better or whether it chimed with things I really like to eat. Probably a bit of both! But it had been just excellent.

Meanwhile, back to the Oreos. I went to pay for them at the little counter and we were pounced on the owner who, in true Vietnamese style, had many questions for us about our trip and our plans for Hoi An. No matter how blatantly I proffered my money, she wouldn’t be stopped, giving us a map, explaining to us where to get Banh Mi (I told her we’d had it) and Cao Lau (again, she wasn’t put off by my assertion that we’d already had it) and where to get our clothes tailored. Apparently a personal recommendation was insufficient because this was followed up by a trip adviser search of the places she wanted us to go in order to prove they had five stars, and was accompanied by a general badmouthing of other places who were more famous and had five stars. She was indefatigable.

Some 45 minutes later (I think it must have been at least that) we stumbled out into the night clutching the biscuits. I wasn’t sure it had been worth it as while everyone we meet is invariably quite well-meaning, we just don’t want to buy all the stuff they’re trying to sell us. And it takes so long to put down the sales pitch, especially if you need something and can’t just walk away.

We made it back to our room and showered to rid ourselves of the night’s sticky humidity. Time to settle into bed with an episode of Lost, a round of tea and, of course, a hard won biscuit.

posts.title: Honeymoon Citadel
posts.content:
Day 32

We woke around 8:15am after a good sleep and got ready to go down to breakfast. And my goodness it was pouring down! We’d been pretty lucky with the rain during our trip as mostly we’d avoided it altogether, and the times it had rained, it hadn’t affected our plans. This day was going to be a little bit more interesting.

Breakfast was busy: loads of guests had come out of the woodwork and the restaurant was a hive of activity. I ticked into some eggs and rolls and egg fried rice because it was there and why not, while Pete loaded up on egg, bacon, sausage and bread rolls. He actually put the bacon and sausage into the rolls, claiming he was making banh mi. When I asked what made it banh mi instead of a breakfast butty, he held up his bread and explained “because this is banh and this is me”.

That settled it.

We returned to our room to have a brew and give the rain half an hour to ease, on the off chance. On the plus side, the temperature was a chilly 28. So, y’know, score.

The rain got worse, and one of the biggest thunderclaps I have ever heard exploded above us. The windows actually rattled, and lightening flashed.

So of course we deemed this a good time to gather our things and set off for the day. It didn’t look like things would get any better.

The hotel summoned up a taxi for us to make the short journey to the Imperial City - it was only a couple of kilometres away but given the downpour and the humidity, we decided to treat ourselves to the two quid for the ride so that we wouldn’t be already soaked and sweaty when we arrived. ROMANCE!

We jumped out of the cab at the entrance to Citadel (the Imperial City seems to go by both names) and dived into our super sexy ponchos. These seem to be the uniform here; on the roads, moped drivers were swaddled in them, many enfolding large sheets of the flapping plastic garments over the tops of their bikes and any passengers riding behind. It was almost comical to watch these colourful, amorphous shapes flailing down the roads, indifferent to the rain.

We bought our entrance tickets and were given a map of the complex, but we squirrelled these away inside our waterproofs before heading towards to the gates. How hard could it be to navigate an old palace?

Well, it turns out, quite tricky. The Citadel sits inside an enormous square moat and comprises so many different temples, pagodas, residences, pavilions, gardens and walkways that, by the end of our visit some 4 hours later, we weren’t 100% what we’d seen. Add in that much of it is constructed in a similar style and that the site is huge a sprawling and you have a recipe for confusion. We very much got lost.

We even tried using our maps app to navigate at one point, which is testament to the size of the place. So instead of running through a step by step tour of our experiences, I’m going to share a few overall impressions.

The Imperial City was founded in 1802 when Nguyễn Ánh ascended the throne of a unified Vietnam. He proclaimed himself Emperor (modesty chap) and declared that Hue, the ancestral seat of the Nguyễn lords, was to be the capital. Thousands of workers were ordered to build the walled citadel and ringing moat which ran to over 6 miles in length. The entire complex was the seat of power until the French took a pop at running the show in the 1880s. After that, the citadel became mostly symbolic. Then in 1945 the Nguyễn dynasty was ousted with the advent of the Proclamation of Independence of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.

The Imperial city suffered from neglect, termites, challenging climate conditions (including a number of cyclones) and warfare. A battle in 1947 led to the destruction of many of the key buildings and much of the city was burned down.

However, rebuilding efforts and restoration have been going on - and are very much still underway - and there was still a vast amount of explore.

Lots of the buildings were painted a lovely, buttery yellow with carvings adoring the corners of the rooftops and framing the windows and doors. Dragons appeared everywhere, and we spotted quite a few phoenixes too (phoenices? Is it fancy plural?). Apparently, the phoenix often made its way onto women’s clothing, used as icon to represent good fortune, wealth and prosperity.

And presumably longevity?

Buildings were often housed within their own walled-off sections. Some of these were connected by roads (cue more of the ubiquitous golf buggies) and others by walkways. We sploshed along the former but traversed the latter with a little more dignity. Or at least as much dignity as you can muster when you’re hunched inside a pink, plastic poncho. The walkways were usually protected from the elements by high, vaulted ceilings constructed from dark, mahogany-coloured wood and screened with intricate shutters covered detailed picked out in a golden yellow.

We passed numerous framed photos and drawings of the emperors who had occupied the citadel over the centuries, as well as large display of archive documents showing where different emperors had annotated official documents over time. The emperors’ notes were always made in red over the top of the black writing and these always looked so beautiful with the artistic Chinese characters and the stamped seals.

The rain continued unabated, sometimes slipping into a sullen drizzle and at other times working itself to a crescendo, accompanied by thunder and regular flashes of lightning.

There were lots of temples sprinkled through the citadel: these were in the style we were becoming familiar with: wooden carved pillars and screens painted red, gold Chinese characters, alters containing offerings and incense, sometimes to Buddha, sometimes to ancestors, and an endless parade of beautiful wooden lanterns, screened with panels covered in intricate blue dragons. To enter the temples, we had to take off our shoes and ponchos - no mean feat when your that damp.

After a couple of hours we stopped to regroup. We weren’t sure where we were or where we’d been so it took us a while to work out where we should head next. We must have figured it out as we did indeed end up in a new part of the Citadel but it may have been more by luck than by design. Hard to tell: Pete seemed to have a clearer sense of his orientation than I did.

We stopped for a break at a mini cafe sheltering underneath a pagoda. We grabbed a can of 7up each for energy and picked an ice cream: the Vietnamese version of a cornetto. Mine was pistachio and chocolate flavour, and my goodness it was tasty. Controversial opinion time: better than a real cornetto.

Despite having seen - and followed - several signs to the Purple Forbidden City, we weren’t sure whether we had passed through it or whether it was so forbidden we just couldn’t find it. I had imagined that you rock up to the gates and they say to you “Indigo!”

Trust me when I say that joke was brilliant when I said it out loud to Pete but that it’s somehow a bit pathetic written down.

We emerged from the cafe into the royal gardens and these were fabulous: manmade pools carpeted with lilies and lotus blossoms framed delicate wooden pagodas while coy carp poked their heads out of the water to meet the rain with little fish kisses. Small foot bridges arched sedately over the water, walkways allowed us to stroll without getting even wetter (although, let’s be honest, there wasn’t much wetter we could get) and we even found a pavilion that had its own mini moat. You know you’re succeeding in life when you have a moat inside you moat.

Pete commented that he wondered if it was so small because it have been de-moat-ed.

(Full disclosure: Pete actually thought of this pun a few minutes after we’d seen the small moat but I told him I would write it into the journal as though it had been spontaneous. However, I find that now it comes to it, I cannot bear the burden of misleading generations to come. So sorry Pete: it was a great joke, but I can’t lie to the people).

We also saw a well. Pete had a little go at winding the handle but there was no bucket on the string. “Well, well, well” was his contribution to the repartee we had established.

He meant well.

We had covered most of the Citadel grounds by this point (or at least, we thought we had: in all honesty, after you’ve been there for three and a half hours, it starts to look a bit same-y). Our last stop was at the royal theatre where we saw lots of costumes and photographs of cultural dances, all imbued with historical significance and which had names like “Gathering the best wishes for the Emperor dance” or “The four good fortunes and lanterns dance”. There was also a big drum and a large gong placed either side of the stage. I thought the presence of the gong would prove to much for Pete but I was wrong.

It was the drum that he couldn’t resist having a little go on.

Feeling a little weary after doing the museum shuffle for several hours, we headed for the exit. Partly because we happened to pass a sign for it and figured that might be our best chance of escape. As Pete pointed out: it’s tiring looking at things. Plus, it was so wet and gloomy, we sort of felt we were done.

On the plus side, we were able to hail a taxi right outside the exit and we’re soon ensconced in our hotel room once more. We hung our dripping ponchos up, pleased to discover that most of our clothing was relatively dry, and after a hot shower apiece, we settled down to watch an episode of Lost with a cup of tea.

We spent the late afternoon researching and planning our trip to Hoi An for the next day and once it was time for dinner, we peered outside to see if the weather had improved. While it was tricky to tell, it looked like it might be dry. Ish. So we gathered up our ponchos and headed out into the night to investigate.

It had indeed stopped raining: everything was sodden and trees and shop awnings and overhangs dripped on us relentlessly, but it wasn’t raining, so we stuffed the ponchos into our bag and strode forth with a bit more of a spring in our collective step.

I had found a place online called the Nook cafe that came recommended and while it took us a little while to find, when we located it, we found a cosy table with a bright, woven tablecloth and started perusing the menu. We split a frozen lime margarita which was yum, and ordered a beer each, and we started by splitting a portion of spring rolls.

They were the best spring roll we’d ever had. Fact. Oh my goodness, they were crispy without being oily, there was a great balance of filling and roll and the dipping sauce was perfection.

I told Pete I regretted sharing.

Pete ordered a chicken burger while I opted for a coconut curry. The waitress asked how spicy I wanted it and I said spicy. She seemed surprised and asked again: “Spicy?” And I concurred that, yes spicy was good.

“Soooo... medium?” She asked me again. Nope, I want it spicy! I’m not sure if she thought I was naive or if I would turn my nose up and leave the food, but I think I got my preference across. The curry turned out to be delicious and while it did have some spice, I wouldn’t have rated it more than a medium. So maybe I didn’t get my preferred across! Fortunately, it was delicious all the same.

Pete had a couple more beers while I ordered a banana, peanut butter and chocolate smoothie and a piece of banana cake with tapioca and peanuts served with coconut cream.

This was a little bit of a surprise: instead of being a cake with some tapioca, it was a slab of tapioca dessert. It was extremely glutinous and kind of claggy. A very strange texture indeed and definitely not cake. The flavour was good but I wouldn’t order it again. Pete was triumphant having been very anti any form of tapioca from the get go. Win some lose some!

After dinner we returned to our room for a cuppa. We had an early start to catch a bus the next morning and didn’t want to stay up too late. But then Pete suggested a final bonus cuppa and after a round of Milko Polo to establish whether we could find any more milk - we did - we snuggled into bed with our tea and an episode of Lost.

posts.title: Honeymoon Pagoda
posts.content:
Day 30

We enjoyed a lovely lie in until 8:45 and then went downstairs to grab our now traditional eggs, bread and pineapple. This consumed, we scurried back to our room for tea and a more relaxed morning. It had rained quite a bit overnight and day was overcast. While it was still a solid 27 degrees (feels like 33 baby!) it was good to be out of the glare of the sun.

I know this seems like a lot of temperature chat but a) you know you love it, b) don’t pretend you don’t also tell people a lot when the temperature is noticeable and c) this is an accurate representation of things I said to Pete regularly on the trip. I think probably half a dozen time a day, I would comment “goodness, it’s warm!” and after while, I was obliged to amend this to: “I know I say this a lot, but goodness it’s warm!”.

Fascinating stuff. Pete is spellbound by my commentary every time.

The morning passed in a little flurry of tea drinking, changing into appropriately respectful Buddhist pagodawear ready for our afternoon and packing our bags so that they were ready to be stored for the day, unstored for the evening and then slightly repacked to accommodate our upcoming sleeper train journey. There is an art to arranging packing and while some days I have the knack of it, this particular day was complex, requiring various iterations of stuff to be carefully placed so that they’d be accessible without needing to empty out my whole backpack.

Again, more spellbinding commentary.

We had one last tea for elevensies before leaving behind our room and hunting down the hotel lady to check out. We settled our bill and following some smiling and miming alongside our request, managed to secure the chance to leave our bags for the afternoon and also use the shower post our afternoon out, which was very much appreciated.

We sauntered down the main road in search of some lunch, paying another visit to the ATM to withdraw more cash, and while loitering in tbr street trying to connect to a restaurant wifi and check how much was in each account, a motorbike pulled up alongside us.

A boy of about 12 hopped off the back and approached Pete slightly nervously, calling him sir and asking if he could practise his English. Pete was a little taken aback but agreed, and there followed a short interview where Pete was asked his name, age, his thoughts on Vietnam, his itinerary, his home and various opinions. Then the boy got back on the motorbike and was driven away. Brilliant.

Money acquired, it was time for lunch and in the end we settled for the banh mi place we’d visited at lunch time the day before. This time we sat in to eat, and watched the busy trade the little banh mi cart was doing. It was a funny little place, with the banh mi cart out the front, a covered seating area behind it and a tiny spa in the back. A bit of a jack of all trades but the banh mi was super yummy, Pete opting for a pair of chicken ones while I ordered a garlic banh mi. Just seemed like a good idea.

I also had a banana passionfruit smoothie which was divine - so refreshing and sweet without being sickly.

I helped Pete out with his Wordle (I think that’s 3 of them I’ve got now, which isn’t bad for someone who doesn’t play) and then we walked back to our hotel to meet our lift for the afternoon.

The driver was already waiting for us so we were able to depart a little early on our way to Bai Dinh Pagoda. Situated some 20km away, Bai Dinh is the biggest temple complex in Vietnam, and while nowadays, most of the structure is new, being build between 2003 and 2010, the original temple from way back when is actually up a hillside a little way away. Bai Dinh is a pilgrimage site for Buddhists and we found out that it’s also a UNESCO world heritage site.

Our driver dropped us off at the ticket office, promising to be back three hours later to collect us, and we ventured inside. We were immediately pounced on by an extremely assertive ticket lady who took us through an immense number of ticket options very quickly, before focusing in particular on the VIP ticket. We hadn’t quite expected the onslaught so we had to slow her down and go back to cheap options: all we really wanted was a ticket to enter. In the end, we sprung for the entry and the return journey to the gate via electric golf cart.

Bear with me as I know that sounds mad, but the actual entrance to the pagoda was a mile or so along a road from the ticket office. It all seemed to be part of the land of the complex but as we perched on the back of the golf buggy, it was clear that literally no one was walking and that it would have been quite a long and tedious trek given the humidity.

So a good move to get the ride there and back, but a bit strange that they couldn’t just make that part of the ticket, or maybe even put the ticket office at the entrance.

Anyway, we arrived at the gates ready to explore the temple complex. And it was indeed huge as advertised: most of the complex was set between two parallel covered walkways, and these sloped up the hill, broken at regular intervals by staircases to make the ascent. Covered walkways is a misleading term though as these were pretty grandiose: open to the temples on one side, the other was completely covered in little nooks which contained golden Buddha statues, and these disappeared off into the distance along the wall as far as the eye could see. There must have been thousands of them. There were also a series of big stone carvings of Buddha, adopting various poses and expressions and we wandered along slowly peering at them and wondering what the significance was of their poses.

The long corridors were dim and quiet, piped music was playing to set the scene and the atmosphere was peaceful and dignified, serious and reflective.

Our first port of call was in the giant bell tower which contained, much to Pete’s delight, the biggest bell in the country. Sadly it was suspended out of reach and Pete didn’t get to dong it, but I think if he’d really wanted to, he could have unhooked the giant dingy thing that always chained up at the side. A tempting proposition.

The pagoda containing the bell was build of beautiful dark wood and had a lovely, tactile appearance, smooth and somehow reassuring. The temple complex in general didn’t seem to be big on signs or information; while I had heard the odd fact regarding the size of the bell, I couldn’t remember if it was the largest in Vietnam or possibly had a bigger claim to fame.

Our next stop was at the first of the temples: these were all similar in structure, the altars residing in huge, high-ceiling if wooden halls with the now-expected offerings of tons of biscuits and fruit and canned drinks laid out before them. Incense burned, we spotted the familiar crane statue standing on a tortoise, and in this temple, a giant golden statue of Buddha presided.

At least, we think it could have been Buddha but it had about 30 arms, so then again, maybe not.

However, this was dwarfed by the Buddha statue in temple number two. The largest in the complex, this one was definitely Buddha doing a classic pose and holding a lotus. The gold of the statue glimmered in the dark hall and ornate wooden screens carved into red and and gold twining dragons descended from the ceiling to frame it. The dragons had inlaid, glittering eyes and actually they were my favourite part of the temple.

Returning to the covered walkway, we continue to climb the stairs until we finally reached the last and biggest temple. A huge square was opened out in front of it and golf buggies beetles around dropping off tourists; it seemed that if you didn’t want to walk between temples, you could pay extra to be driven, that that seemed a step too far into crazy for us.

A large staircase swept up to the temple sporting lovely flowing dragon carvings, and in front was a tableau of a big laughing Buddha flanked by two large bonsai trees. I appreciate saying a large bonsai sounds like a bit of an oxymoron, but that’s exactly what these were: really enormous trees rendered in minute. Little model scenes had been set into them and they were charming and delicate. Definite future garden goals.

Inside the temple were the usual array of offerings, red and gold pillars and carved screens. But this one had 3 large, gold Buddha statues, each making a different hand sign. Pete explained that this represented three different ages of Buddha, my favourite being the final “high five” age. But equally, Pete may have been making it up.

He did have a mini ring of the large temple bell, but very quietly, and he found a large pot which he claimed he would fit into but was reluctant to prove it. I would have backed him though.

Behind each enormous statue was a big, gold backdrop, each of which featured lots of smaller Buddha’s in a circle formation. It looked a bit like they were all on a Ferris wheel. They all seemed happy about it though.

Flanking the statues were a series of carvings of warriors, rendered in dark stone. Each one looked aggressive, clad in armour and clearly meant to intimidate and impress with their power. It was interesting to see that each of the warriors had a large round belly and some extra chins: a decent quantity of bulk. Just shows how perceptions change of what is seen to be impressive and powerful.

We left the temple and moved towards the opposite walkway to the one we had ascended, this time heading back down the hillside. Our first stop on this side was the huge tower which dominated the complex. Some 14 stories high (or thereabouts) there was a lift inside that could transport you to the top for views over the whole complex.

At the entrance to the tower, our tickets were checked and stamped and we had to put little elasticated bags over our feet to protect the floor. Pete’s were in tow wildly contrasting fabrics and while mine matched, one had lost its elastic so it was like trying to walk in a carrier bag. Classy!

We had to shuffle up one floor of marble stairs to the lift; we wondered how necessary the bags were or whether they’d just hit on a great way to save polishing the floor. The lift area was very grandiose, all gleaming marble and bright white, chiselled walls. But it also had a slight hotel lobby vibe, there was no way around it.

The lift sped us up to the top and we stepped out onto a little balcony that ran around the top. We could indeed see the whole complex mapped out below us, and we gained appreciate for the size of the place. Other directions yielded views over lakes and the limestone peaks jutting out of the land here and there. There was a bit of a breeze which was a relief after the still, muggy, humidity-saturated air we’d been swimming through and we admired the scenery from all angles.

It turned out that we could go up one more floor, and in the top of the tower, there was a shrine with a Buddha carved from coloured stone, nestled in an alcove and surrounded by offerings. Atop the shrine was a multicoloured flashing disco light but we’ll forgive that lapse in taste. We also spotted the couple who had tailed us from Hanoi but they didn’t see us #stealthytimes

We finally descended the tower and began the walk back to the golf buggy station. On the way, we stopped at another smaller tower, took a detour over some grass to another shrine to three figures (probably not the 3 wise men but that’s what it looked like) and then, as I was saying to Pete that I thought we should probably stick to the path, a paved path appeared.

We wandered down to one final temple - featuring a rather nice teapot with two spouts, or at least something that looked like that - and then we came out at a large, square pool, sunk carefully into the stone. It was still and a small pagoda stood in the centre.

As we approached the edge of the water, hoards of fish swarmed towards us; there were loads of them in every colour and they ruffled the surface of the water - possibly hoping to be fed? We weren’t sure, but as we walked around the pool, they followed us in a large, thronging school, rippling and thrashing as they went.

We reached the golf carts and once enough other visitors had boarded our vehicle, we set off to drive back to the entrance. Of course, the buggy stopped short of the ticket office obliging is to walk through a passage lined with stalls all trying to sell various knick-knacks but we escaped relatively unscathed and I popped to use the loos, leaving Pete with the bag and my phone. I later learned he had snapped an odd set of pictures - why would he get a picture of me leaving the toilets??? - but at the time, I simply gathered up my things and pressed on as we found our driver ready and good to go.

We enjoyed the cool air con on the drive back to Tam Coc. We were dropped at our hotel and the hotel lady very kindly let us use her shower; even though the day had been overcast, the humidity still make us sweat profusely so it was a relief to feel a bit cleaner for the evening.

We gathered our backpacks and loaded ourselves up for the evening before setting out to find some drinks and some wifi. We decided to hit our usual drinks place - I love staying somewhere long enough to have a usual - as the wifi was reliable and the drinks were tasty.

We had a smoothie each and I also order a tea. Pete warned me not to as he was convinced I wouldn’t get what I wanted (occupational hazard of being outside the U.K.) but I felt like it was meant to be. So as per the menu, I order Lipton tea, hot, with a bit of milk.

What arrived was unusual: one of the most creative interpretations of a cup of tea that I’ve seen. It was served in a glass. With a curly straw and a cocktail stirrer.

To be fair, it was warm, it was a Lipton teabag so it was actually black English breakfast tea, and they had added milk. But there was also a metric shedload of sugar which made it sickly. I drank it anyway, but Pete was proved correct in his advice.

We worked on a couple of blog posts and then returned to the Farm restaurant for dinner: that had been my favourite of the places we’d eaten. The waitress recognised us and found us a table, eyeing up our backpacks and asking about our onward plans. We settled into a booth and we both ordered chips (they were consistently incredible) and then Pete went for spring rolls while I decided to go for chicken pho. I’d decided that we’d been in Vietnam too long not to have ordered some pho: it’s basically the National dish.

Pete is less keen on noodle soups, commenting that it wouldn’t be his “pho-st” choice but it was tasty and filling and while I think I prefer my pho spicier and with a greater depth of flavour, I enjoyed it. Slurrrrrp! It did, however, take quite an extended series of mimes and gestures at various cutlery to indicate I wanted spoon - chopsticks just don’t cut it when it comes to soup.

We had a couple of hours to kill until we needed to head for the train station, and so we lingered in the cafe, watching as the rain fell on and off, reading and catching up with my journal.

We had booked a taxi to take us from our hotel to the station at eleven, so at half ten, we laid our bill and set out into the dark, rainy evening to meet out ride. However, when we got to the hotel, the lady who ran it met us and someone had been looking for us to drive us. We were a bit surprised as we were a good half hour early, but she said not to worry and she’d call him.

And then she put up an umbrella and cycled off into the night.

We were a little confused to say the least. A few minutes later she returned, but then cycled away again; our only recourse was to sit and wait. After all, if nothing happened, we could always go back to the main road and see if someone could call us a taxi. The waitress at the restaurant had offered to so we were pretty confident we could work something out somewhere.

However, this was all unnecessary: our driver was summoned out of the night, we thanked our hostess and we were whisked to Ninh Binh station, arriving a little after eleven.

It was a little strange: after the continued hive of activity everywhere we went, the streets were deserted and mostly unlit. The station was quiet: everything closed and shut up and the platform gated off. As we ventured into the forecourt, we found a couple resting on the plastic seats; this was a little reassuring as at least we weren’t the only ones expecting a train.

I realised the platform barriers weren’t locked so we could in theory get to the tracks, but our train wasn’t due until half midnight, so plonked ourselves down to read and wait.

A family of four showed up a while later - again, encouraging - and time ticked slowly on. The forecourt filled up around us, the clock passed midnight, I swapped my sandals for shoes as the rain had made my feet wet and we waited.

A train rumbled into the station and stopped, awaking a flicker of interest and a mini flurry of activity as passengers can myself included, went over to the platform barrier to peer out. It was about 20 minutes early but even so, we wondered if it might be the one we wanted in the silent, unmanned station. But it was only a cargo train.

Around ten minutes before our slotted time, the PA system crackled to life and did indeed finally announce our train, first in Vietnamese and then in English. Not only that, 2 guards appeared out of the gloom beyond the platform to check our tickets and point the way.

We all shuffled along the damp platform hauling our backpacks and looking for the best spot to meet our carriages. A little while later, bright lights appeared along the direction of the track marked “Hanoi”, trundling slowly in the “Ho Chi Minh” direction. Our train was here.

Train conductors on board we’re busily flicking out little signs which marked the carriages and we found number 8, showed our ticket and clambered on board. Ours was the first compartment we came to, and after I’d worked out how to open the door, we found the allotted 4 beds inside, 2 occupied by 3 people who were almost asleep: a mum and her 2 kids. There was nothing for it but to squeeze our bags under the bed, pop quickly to the loo and then hop straight into our bunks. It was gloomy but the light from the corridors was enough to see by. There wasn’t a ladder up to the top bunk but I stood on the table to climb into bed, grabbing my hoodie for warmth as the train was quite chilly.

I told you packing things in easily grabable order was important: I would have been cold without my hoodie but there was barely room to move in the compartment, never mind institute a grand unpack. In the dark.

I kissed Pete good night and settled down. The bunks were small - my feet easily reached the end and lying on my side, my knee was wedged against the wall while my elbow was jammed against the barrier to stop me from falling out. The train was noisy: something of an ancient beast, it rattled and swayed and while I can’t honestly say it’s the nicest sleeper train I’ve been on (by quite a long chalk) I did doze off to the movement and pattern of shadow on the ceiling.

Nothing says honeymoon like sharing a cramped compartment for 4 among 5 people. Romance five!

Day 31

I slept reasonably well given the circumstances, waking up to turn over every so often before being jolted awake at six by an announcement that went on and on and on, repeated over and over by a stern-voiced guard. I had no idea what it was about. Unbelievably, this was then followed up by a series of banging Vietnamese pop tunes, blasted at full volume over the tannoy.

WHY???

After a time, the volume was reduced and a song or two later, the cacophony was switched off entirely. Thank goodness. I managed to catch a little more sleep, dozing on and off, and then awoke properly at nine thirty. I had thought this was around our arrival time and panicked slightly, but when I checked where we were on the map, we were still over a 100km from Hue.

Peering down to the bunk below, I found Pete was awake and reading and he helped me down so I could pop to the loo. It seemed the compartments didn’t do converting to day seats so I scrambled back to the upper bunk to read too.

The kids alternated between snacking and reading (the older was lugging around a Vietnamese copy of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix) and also running around and screaming, which I could have lived without. But hey ho: there’s always an upside and I found a Kit Kat in my handbag to eat. So winning.

I finished my book and set about editing a few photos from our time in Tam Coc until the train conductor turfed me out of my bunk to set it up for the next passengers. I perched alongside Pete in the bottom berth until we pulled into Hue, a little after noon and almost twelve hours after we’d set off.

Hauling our bags down to the platform and leaving the station, we were accosted by motorbike drivers all wanting to give us a lift. We turned them all away one by one; they were surprisingly insistent, telling us a taxi would be much more expensive, twice the price and so on. By my reckoning, I thought we could get one taxi for less than the cost of two bikes as our hotel wasn’t far away and I didn’t feel that my first time riding on the back of a motorbike should be when I also had 15kg of luggage strapped to me. Just an observation.

We did eventually swing a taxi - for quite a bit less than the bike drivers had prophesied - and we pulled into our hotel a few minutes later. It was scorcher so we were glad to duck inside and we were soon checked and given the keys to our room.

Apropos of nothing, if you’re ever in Vietnam and in need of wifi, literally every password seems to be either “12345678” or “weloveyou”. That’s a top travel tip brought to you by Kirsty.

We were quite thirsty by this point and devoured the little bottles of free water that had been provided, before indulging in a good shower to properly shake off the train and refresh us for the day. We did a little bit of Hue research and book our onward travel to Hanoi for a couple of days’ time, and then, as I was pretty much dead from thirst, we set out into the city.

We decided to stop by a cafe first, and I’d looked up a little coffee shop that apparently sold drinks and cakes. This didn’t disappoint and we were soon ensconced with an accidental iced coffee for Pete (he’d been expecting a latte) and a chocolate cookie crumble milkshake for me, which was divine. Pete opted for cheesecake, I had a banana muffin, and it all did wonders to perk us up and supply us with a bit of energy.

The city of Hue is based around the wide Perfume River which sweeps through it and so we decided to spend the afternoon walking along its banks and getting a feel for the place. It was - obviously - warm and sticky, but we strolled along anyway, starting by waking through a small park that lay along the bank, grateful for the shade the trees provided here and there.

At the first bridge, we decided to cross the river and continue our walk on the opposite bank. The roads were busy and crossing was a challenge but eventually we just decided to launch out into it, allowing it to flow around us. The key seems to be not to overthink things.

Once we’d crossed, we followed the pathway further upriver and I was surprised by how open it was. I had been half expecting a parade of shops and stalls, restaurants and bars, all attempting to ply a riverside trade, but instead there was a wide path divided for pedestrians and cyclists and we followed this onwards. We passed under a second bridge which crossed the river, wander past a little pavilion, dodged round kids on roller blades and watched the dragon boats tooling up and down the waterways, selling rides to tourists. And of course we had a little go on the outdoor gym equipment just to make sure we were in good shape.

At around quarter past four, we figured we’d gone far enough and turned around to retrace our steps. The sun was now partially obscured by cloud and had dropped lower in the sky so the heat wasn’t quite so intense. Through the gaps in the road we could see glimpses of the imperial palace we had decided to visit the next day and even though there was lots of traffic and an unrelenting chorus of beeping from motorbikes, the river walkway itself was peaceful.

We decided to cross back over the river on the second bridge and take in more of the river on that side. There was, thankfully, a pavement alongside the traffic. I spotted a road sign marking a fork for the vehicles which pounded their way over over the bridge. They could either turn right and head to a destination 1km away. Or they could take the left fork and go to Hanoi, 643km away.

That’s really not a decision you want to get wrong if those are your only options.

We followed a wooden boardwalk that had been build out over the river for pedestrians. Lots of locals and visitors were perched on the side posing for photos and we saw no less than three brides having photographs there as well. It must be a thing. More excitingly, I spotted a group of Vietnamese guides - I wanted to ask for a selfie (I got the impression that the request would have gone down pretty well) but they were in the middle of having a saluting sort of ceremony so I didn’t want to interrupt. There was a unit of younger girls too engaged in a singing and action song or game or something, and they had the most brilliant dungarees as part of their uniform. Envy.

We picked up some water at the nearest local shop we could find (the first two I had earmarked were either shut down or non-existent and the Greenmart, where we ended up, was underwhelming to say the least) and returned to our hotel. As we felt warm and sticky from the humidity, Pete suggested a dip in the pool.

It was empty when we arrived and we had a lovely time swimming about. The sun was low enough in the sky that while it provided warmth and light, we were in no risk of sunburn and we enjoyed having the whole pool to ourselves. Clearly other guests had the same idea: 15 minutes later, a dozen or so other people had come to swim, bringing children and floats and paraphernalia and it got quite crowded.

Returning to our room, I made a round of tea - my first of the day and I gave myself snaps for lasting that long - and Pete found a packet of Oreos in his bag. Because the white witch, while she had some problems in the morals and turning-people-to-stone department, was right when she said “it is dull, son of Adam, to drink without eating”.

I had a second biscuit.

Around seven, we ventured forth to hunt down something to eat. We hadn’t really had a proper meal, but equally, we were a little sleepy from our night time train adventure. Pete remembered spotting a pizza cart just beyond our hotel, so we pottered down the street and found it. It was one cart of three, comprising a tiny food court of sorts with a few tables and chairs set out for diners. We ordered a pizza each (it was either that or frog congee from the neighbouring stall and for some reason, neither of us were in the mood for frog) and attempted to order a drink. I say attempted: after picking a coke and a juice, the stall holder came back to say they had no soft drinks, so would Pete mind having water. Then she came back again and said there was also no juice. Water all round!

The pizzas were hot, cooked to order and pretty tasty, and we were glad to have found something quick, easy and cheap so nearby. Then we returned to our room at the grand old time of roughly 8:15pm to have tea and try and stay awake long enough to watch an episode of Lost in bed.

And to have another cup of tea.

And a bed time biscuit (see information concerning drinks and eating above).

posts.title: Honeymoon View
posts.content:
Day 29

We had asked to have breakfast at half seven again, although as in practise, this seemed to mean 7:45, we didn’t get up until 7:25, and being ten minutes late didn’t make a difference at all.

We split a pineapple and worked our way through some tasty eggs and bread before we popped back to our room and gathered our supplies for the day.

The sky was cloudy and overcast and the temperature was below thirty (29, it counts) so the previous day’s rain shower seemed to have done its job. Even the “feels like” section of my weather report reckoned that with the humidity, we’d be feeling like it was around 35. Noticeably more manageable!

With our bag packed, we stepped out into the street and discovered that a few drops of rain were coming down here and there. However, it didn’t bother us as we weren’t exactly going to be getting cold and damp, so we wandered up to the main road in search of bikes.

We were planning to visit the Mua Cave and viewpoint which was about 5km away, and as we’d been told the best way to get one was by bike, we first needed to find a bike. Actually, two bikes.

We’d only passed a handful of shops before we spotted the first bike rental sign and a whole bunch of bicycles lined up of the pavement. A lady came scurrying out of the back of the shop at our interest and hired us a park of bikes for the day for less than £4. Bargain.

Not so much with the helmets though.

She wanted a passport to use as a deposit but we didn’t have them on us, and seemed happy to take my driving licence instead. And so we raised the kick stands (they were on the rusty side so this was an effort and the bike lady had to beat mine into submission) and wheeled the bikes out into the road.

While the bikes were certainly old, they were cheap and worked perfectly well. There were no gears which I think Pete would have liked, but so didn’t really care as the pedalling was easy and the route was completely flat. In Vietnam, they drive on the right, so we pedalled to the right hand side of the road through the village and set forth on our mission.

I was navigating leaving Pete free to ring his bell at everyone who went past, particular then motorbikes who are incapable of riding their vehicles without also riding the horn. At least you know they’re coming, and Pete was having a lovely time dinging at everyone. My bell didn’t work, but I didn’t think that really mattered.

I’d looked up two possible routes: the first shorter and recommended by Google maps for people on food, the second longer and recommended by Maps.Me for cyclists. Google is often the more reliable when it comes to locations, whereas Maps.Me tends to do better when we’re off the beaten track, an indeed in this case, it was right on the money. While Google’s route might have worked on foot, the terrain would almost certainly have rattled our ancient bikes to pieces as road turned into I paved track very quickly. I backtracked us to the road and we stuck to our new route.

I had wondered if we’d find cycling difficult in the heat, but it was quite the contrary! Requiring minimal effort to get quite a distance, the bikes just seemed to roll along of their own accord and, which was a big selling point for me, because we could propel ourselves along at a pace much faster than walking, cycling created its own breeze! Blissful!

All this time, I’d thought the Tour de France riders had it so rough, and it turns out instead of putting in the hard work and hiking in the heat, they’re just winging along feeling all chill with nature’s air con. After 10 minutes or so on the bike, I was pretty sure that Tour de France would pose no problems for me whatsoever. May as well hand over that yellow jersey now.

The journey flew by as we cycled through the village into a more residential area, past a local graveyard, and a bus station that actually wasn’t a bus station but a parking lot where double decker buses had been parked up and turned into bars and karaoke venues. In fact, we passed quite a few karaoke places: seemed to be a thing in Tam Coc.

Soon we were out among rice fields, a herd of goats clogging a footpath as they dealt with the undergrowth, and several fields of lotus flowers, stretching out of the water. These often had signs and frames for people to take pictures with, but we also passed a large sign that said LOVE which backed onto an empty field of swampy mud. Takes all sorts.

Pete was of course super keen to stop at all of these points, but we kept true, barrelling down on our destination.

When we turned into the right road, there were lots of areas cleared on either side bike and motorbike parking, and as we cycled through, the proprietor of each one would stand in middle of the road, almost trying to physically block our bikes from going further in an attempt to sell us their parking.
