Pete was unperturbed by this and could not be diverted from his mission, and I just cycled after Pete - handy - so we made it to the entrance where we had to pay 20 000 dong each to leave our bikes. Fair play: less than a pound a go. Pricey by Holmfirth Coop standards though.

Our bottoms were a little sore but other than that, we felt good after our ride and were looking forward to exploring the cave and viewpoints. So we paid our entrance fee and ventured forth.

A path ran towards the jutting limestone outcrop ahead: the very one we would be climbing to get to the viewpoint. The path followed a small stream and at regular intervals, there were stepping stones over the small seating areas, or little shops and cafes. We passed all these until we reached the cliffs and after a brief debate, decided to climb to the viewpoint first before visiting the cave. We thought we may as well make the most of the cooler air.

The climb was steep and with almost 500 steps to conquer, no mean feat. But we set off slowly and steadily plodding upwards, and we gained height quickly as the steps zigzagged back and forth up the steep, jagged cliff. The views started laying themselves out beneath us and even thought the steps were uneven and often large, I didn’t feel nearly as wiped out as I did by our short temple climb the day before.

Roughly two thirds of the way up, the path split heading towards two different peaks which yielded two different views. We went for the taller of the two first and emerged at a platform a little way before the summit. We could see the green rice fields stretching out below us, some lush and ready, others sparse and new, with water ways snaking their course through the wetlands. Limestone mountains jutted suddenly from the flat, valley floor and we could make out some tiny rowing boats following a course through the lagoons.

Actually, I say tiny rowing boats: it’s more likely that they were normal size and far away.

Climbing up the final stretch, we made it to the summit of our limestone peak. It was ornamented with a long, stylised dragon statue and we clambered around the top of the rock, gripping into the black stone which was both jagged and angular, and yet worn smooth over time. The views really were incredible and it felt like we were getting the aerial perspective on the landscape carpeting the world below. Rice fields and lotus blossoms filled every available flat piece of land and the sharp angles of the limestone cliffs were in stark contrast to the smooth path of the agriculture. Just beautiful.

With one peak conquered, we set out to climb the second. This one was not quite as high, but we were still sweating buckets once we’d reached the top. Lots of people were sitting around enjoying the view on any available flat surface, and many of the women were in long, highly ornate dresses and appeared unruffled by the climb.

I had no idea how - I looked tired and bedraggled thanks to the occasional rain, the humidity and the exertions of the climb. I know I’m not the fittest person in the world, but surely this climb ought to at least raise a sweat?

One we’d drunk in our fill of the view, we began the descent, treading carefully down the steep steps. It seems pretty much every ancient civilisation going has carved some stone steps at some point, and to a person, they always make them extra steep.

They should think about that next time.

Back at the bottom of the peak, we went to investigate the caves. Following the sings, we found the entrance and ventured inside but if I’m complete honest, they were a little disappointing. There was one short passage with a door at the end leading to an underground pool - it was neither large nor particularly ornate, and there were more big vats of wine stored inside.

The larger cave wasn’t really a cave at all, but a short tunnel, arching through the rock out to the wetlands beyond. I think we’d perhaps been spoiled by our experiences of the caves in Trang An, but we’d had higher hopes.

Fortunately, the viewpoint was the reason we had really wanted to come and see the site, and that absolutely exceeded expectations so we weren’t disappointed.

On our way back to our bike parking, we ventured along some of the raised walkways through the lotus fields. Again, lots of people were clustered around taking pictures and Pete wondered if they were there purely to look picturesque. I wasn’t convinced and looking it up later, found that lotus seeds are harvested and used for all sorts of things in Vietnam. It’s a reasonably standard crop.

The blooms were beautiful though, stretching out of the water, big blousy petals opening of the sky, while delicate pools of water collected in the leaves, icy in their clarity.

We picked up our bikes and rode back into Tam Coc, Pete dinging his bell at regular intervals and even more so once we passed a sign saying no beeping of horns. But to be fair, every other road user seemed to ignore this too, and Pete had an excellent time ringing his bell at everyone who beeped at us.

We dropped the bikes off at the rental place, retrieving my driving licence, and returned to our room for a shower. It was nice to cool down, have a tea and work on my journal for a bit, but before long, we were ready for some lunch.

We popped back into the village picking up a few bits and bobs to eat and replenishing our tea stash (vital). Then it was time for Lost Lunch again and a bit of a rest in our room.

Late afternoon found us setting out again, this time to investigate the possibility of getting a massage locally. We sweet-talked the local ATM into relinquishing some cash and then ventured to one of the beauty spas that were dotted around Tam Coc. There was near our hotel that we passed each day, and there was incredibly a lady outside who tried to sell us a massage, so this time, we let her. It was only 200000 dong - a little under £8 - for a 45 minute neck, back and shoulder massage and so we figured we’d go for it.

We were ushered inside, leaving our shoes out in the street on a little stand, and we began with a little foot bath of warm water and rose petals, seated on big armchairs in the window. It seemed to be one young girls who was running the whole outfit, but after a while, a couple of other women arrived and showed us upstairs where there were beds laid out ready.

We were taken into the same room but only had to take our tops off, lying face down on the beds. As before, the Vietnamese really do not pull their punches when it comes to massage and there were times when I thought it was possibly that I was just being beaten up, albeit slowly and methodically. The strength in their hands was seriously impressive and overall, it felt good. You know you’re getting intense pressure when the bones in your therapists hands are cracking against your muscles. Eep.

I also had to hold in the giggles as she answered her phone - carrying on my massage one handed - and then sent a series of texts. I could hear her phone clicking away and figured for £8, you can’t really complain. Mostly it was slightly comical. The women were also very businesslike in their manner: they saw no need for a modesty towel or anything and we were pushed and pulled about as they worked.

We felt loose and stretched out afterwards. And in need of some dinner! But first, there were some errands to run. We visited the tour office again to arrange a trip to a nearby pagoda for the next day, and we also asked them to book us transport to the train station in the evening. With this sorted, we returned to our bar from previous night to grab a drink, Pete opting for a beer while I tackled another frozen mango daiquiri. Delicious!

We perused the internet for dinner suggestions and decided to go with the Family restaurant down the road. First however, we needed to check out the action in the town square...

As we’d been having our drinks, facing out into the street to observe the Friday night activity, we had seen a chap drive into the square with lots of small cars on the back of his truck. We didn’t think much of this at the time, but a while later, one came barrelling out of the square, across the road and down the alley beside us. And it was driven by a young lad who couldn’t have been more than six, with an even younger boy who must have been his brother.

No one seemed to worry - or even notice - that two small boys had just committed mini theft auto, but we peered over to the square and found that it was in full local party mode. Heading over to investigate, we found not one, not two but THREE party buses had pulled up and were serving drinks from on-board bars and doling our karaoke to the eager crowd. A large group of women were all dancing in sync to a pop version of ‘Stand by Me’ and the tiny cars were being driven around by tiny children. They seemed to have a handle on them - one performed a three point turn in front of us, others circled the parked cars - full size - that dotted the square here and there and several of the children were driving younger siblings around. It was wildly comical - like Dodgems Without Borders - but the parents were completely blasé about the whole scenario.

Having inhaled this quite unique sight and soaked up some Friday night atmosphere, we hit up our chosen restaurant for dinner. It was pleasant and the food was hot, but it wouldn’t be my favourite place we’ve eaten as ai found the flavours a little more bland. We split some spring rolls and some fries and then I went for vegetable stir friend noodles - a bit underwhelming - with a fried egg (runny yolk, cooked to perfection) while Pete opted for banh mi. He ordered two, concerned that they might be a bit small. They weren’t but he enjoyed them anyway.

We were also brought a bowl of plain rice as it came free with each meal, but sadly it was a bit of a waste as it didn’t really go with either of our menu choices. We also got a large hunk of pineapple each to finish with; another addition that came free with each meal. This we did eat, but when our enthusiastic hostess tried to bring us some extra watermelon to snack on as well, I managed to make convincing enough we’d-love-some-but-we’re-just-too-full faces and gestures and averted that particular fruit-based minefield. She brought us a free bottle of water each instead, which actually was useful.

On our way back to our hotel, we stopped by to visit Susu and buy a bottle of water, receiving many pleased licks as we rubbed her tummy and scratched her behind the ears. Then we settled back into our room for the rest of the night, a cold shower each very much in order and the air con doing its thing.

And because we like to party and mix things up, we finished the night with a round of tea, an episode of Lost and an episode of Modern Family. And a slight later alarm for the next day. Score!

posts.title: Honeymoon Boat
posts.content:
Day 28

We were up at seven fifteen to get ready for our day out and by half seven, we were up on the roof terrace waiting for breakfast. It was already 30 degrees, but don’t worry folks, my app informed me that the humidity made it feel like 37 degrees so the beating the heat plan was on fire.

Although we’d asked for breakfast at half seven, by ten to eight, it still hadn’t appeared and we went down to the ground floor to look for it. Our ride to Trang An was scheduled for 8:00am and we were going to be cutting it fine. However, I’m a master food shoveller if nothing else and so when eggs and bread appeared with 7 minutes to spare, we both were able to process this in three minutes, no messing. It was tasty, and would hopefully set us up for the morning. Our taxi pulled up right on time and we set off through Tam Coc, heading towards Trang An.

Trang An is the main reason that visitors come to Ninh Binh, but apparently there are more domestic tourists than foreigners. The main draw is the landscape: an incredible collection of jutting limestone mountains that rise out of quiet, still wetlands and rice fields, dotted with caves and temples. And a UNSECO world heritage site to boot. It’s often described as Halong Bay but on land and you pay to be rowed around the waters on one of three routes from Trang An.

We bought our tickets at the office and then headed to the large building beyond which the boats were moored. There were all the usual tourist trappings: videos playing, shops trying to sell you things and, of course, a long queueing system. We were behind a large tour group who shuffled along in a straggling clump and even though it was only half eight, there were still quite a lot of visitors.

When we emerged beside the water where the boats queued to pick up passengers, we were asked which route we wanted to do. Based on a hasty glance through the leaflet, I suggested route 1, as it seemed to have the greatest number of caves. And also, maybe it’s number 1 for a reason?

Logic aside, we settled on one and then had to wait for another pair to join us. The boats take 4 passengers and the staff match you up to ensure that each boat is fully occupied. Before too long, a pair of women completed our party and we hopped onto boat 1080 that had pulled up at the edge of the water.

The two women sat in the front with Pete and I behind, all of us perched on the little wooden planks that made up the seats of the rowing boat. In the back, the boatwoman gathered her oars, set up her umbrella to shield her from the sun and we were off.

The route around Trang An was around 3 hours long; we had been warned by the people in the internet that there would be no shade and the sun was indeed extending its ultra hot rays in a completely transparent attempt to sizzle us. But we are not so easily sizzled (or so we like to think) and had drowned ourselves in sun cream, donning hats and sunnies in preparation.

The pace was extremely relaxed and leisurely which seemed ideal and I almost thought so could detect a whisper of a breeze while we were out on the water. This lasted a sold two minutes until our boatwoman handed Pete and I paddle each and indicated that we should get rowing.

Right. Hadn’t read about that online.

Equally, none of the other boats seemed to require their passengers to paddle; instead the bamboo flotilla ahead of us was a veritable forest of umbrellas as tourists fought to give themselves shade. And also, to avoid a tan: while in Hanoi, we had asked a guide why so many locals were fully swaddled head to toe as we often saw people riding motorbikes like this. Which seemed to us swelteringly hot and also extremely impractical with all that fabric. The guide had told us that is was fashionable to be pale and so lots of women in particular cover their skin as much as possible when outside.

Yikes. A pasty high five to me though.

Anyway, Pete and I set about rowing, and a third oar was passed up to the women on the front. If I’m completely honest, I don’t feel like our efforts made a huge amount of different. The two women alternated paddling vaguely, putting in the odd strike when they remembered in their conversation, making it challenging to row in a rhythm. Pete and I could row fairly well together but heat and humidity meant our energy was quickly spent and I can’t honestly say that we made the boat go much faster.

We sweated more though. Lovely.

I tried not to wonder whether we had to paddle because the boatwoman thought we were too fat to be rowed. On a similar boat trip in Tam Coc, the boats will either take 4 Vietnamese people or 2 foreigners because, and I quote: “Vietnamese people are smaller than foreigners”. It was a little disheartening to think that I counted as two people.

The landscape however was spectacular: there was something amazing about drifting between the enormous peaks, seeing the forest-like density of green carpeting their slopes, interrupted by jagged shards of rock jutting towards the sky. The insects chirruped from their leafy abodes, small diving ducks were suddenly swallowed into the waters before bobbing up unexpectedly miles away, and fish of all sizes would appear here in there, flitting by in shades of murky khaki or occasionally bright gold. The water wasn’t deep, and a thick carpet of pondlife seemed to be growing from the lake bed. One plant looked almost like coral in plant form, extending thousands of intricate branches and tendrils below the surface, waving with the current, clustered in huge groups. They looked soft and inviting, almost furry as I pulled my oar through them.

As we progressed, more and more of the other boats which had set off alongside us peeled off to take either route 2 or route 3, and it was lovely to find that, for much of our trip, we were the only boat we could see on the water. My leaflet promised that “tourists who travel in traditional boats can experience the nature through different emotions that created by travelling inside different caves, discover the pure beauty of the origin of human life, reconnecting with deep spiritual space and discover oneself”.

That seemed like a lot to fit in so I though I’d better get cracking with some self discovery and whatnot.

I hadn’t realised that we would make stops on the journey, but our boat woman guided the craft into the steps at the bottom of a temple site - Den Trinh. The only way to access it seemed to be across the water, the way we’d come, and she indicated to us that we should climb out and go and take a look.

We had a little look inside, discovering some of the same features we’d first learned about in Hanoi: the incense and offerings, the crane standing on turtles and even a white horse. It was lovely. There were quite a few people around from the cluster of boats which had drawn up to the temple, but it was also nice to stretch our legs and stand up straight after being a little bit hunched on the boat seats.

We climbed back into our boat before too long, this time with Pete and I in the front. As we now only had one oar between us, I had more time to take photos and admire the scenery. I already thought that I preferred Trang An to Halong bay: it was somehow more peaceful and I felt closer to the landscape.

Although to give Halong Bay it’s due, the boat was comfier. And had a better tea set.

Plus they didn’t ask us to row.

We paddled onwards and soon reached the first cave we would visit. There were nine along our route in total, and each one was a natural tunnel-like passage through the rock to which brought us out into a new spectacular lagoon, ringed with peaks and all but cut off from the world.

The cave - Hang Toi - was much longer than I thought it would be and the craggy ceiling dipped down low enough that we had to draw in our oats and flatten ourselves into the boat. Lights illuminated the folds and sculptures that time had wrought in the limestone overhead and it was several long minutes once we’d lost sight of the opening before we reached the end of the passage. It was quite exciting!

We passed through two more stone caves before our next stopping point, each time finding ourselves in a new secret lake dwarfed by beautiful limestone spikes. It was an almost otherworldly landscape and the still water through back beautiful reflections of the views above us, punctuated by the leafy pads and blooms of waterlilies.

Stoping point number 2 was Den Tran: another temple that we clambered out of the bait to visit. At this location, we found a small stall selling fruit and ice cream and a number of benches - with backs!!! - along by the water and so we sat down, indulged in the luxury of leaning back, and guzzled some of our water as a peace offering to the sun. However, our indomitable boatwoman was gesturing to us to walk along the bank, so we got up and followed the path, finding that it led to some stairs up the mountain.

These were steep and alarmingly numerous and when we got to the top, sweating buckets and out of breath, we found the view mostly obscured by tree branches, and while there were a couple of small gazebos, there didn’t appear to be a temple. There was a different way back down so we followed it and found ourselves back by the water.

Only it was a different bit of water.

On the upside, we also found the temple: it was carved in stone and quite small but an information sign explained that it was 700 years old so fair play. A few offerings do flowers were placed inside next to burning incense and a giant bell hung to one side which Pete managed not to ring. Although it was an effort as he quite wanted to.

The downside was that we had to walk back up and down all the stairs again.

When we found our boat once more, not only was sweat dripping off my nose and chin, but it was running down my arms and legs, quite possibly leeching our the sun cream with it. We guzzled more water, resumed our seats in the back of the boat and took up the oars once more.

We drifted slowly on through 4 more caves, some longer, some shorter, and one which contained a large number of pots of wine, stashed on shelves in the rock to keep them cool. Spoiler: it was not really cool in the caves, but arguably it was out of the direct sunlight.

We stopped at one more temple on our tour, Khong Temple, and while there were some steps to climb, it was not nearly so many. We took in the large signs proclaiming the site’s UNESCO World Heritage status as of 2014, crossed a small stone bridge over the water and the presence of a second large bell proved too much for Pete whose self restraint broke so that he could give it a few dongs.

It made him happy.

Climbing the steps up and over a small rise, we found that this time there was no need to made a return journey as boats were able to get round and pick up their passengers. So we entered the temple for a look around. There were impressive, wooden temple gates adorned with beautiful carvings, ornate pillars painted red and gold framed the interior, offerings of beer, dragonfruit and family packs of biscuits were placed on the central table and we found some huge, blue and white ceramic urns.

Pete quite fancied one for our flat but reckoned it might be easier to look and see if we could get one at Ikea instead of carrying them home. My favourite urn was decorated with a pattern of intertwining dragons who twirled and prowled around the curved surface, rendered in beautiful detail.

It was our favourite of the temples.

All that remained was to complete our circuit and head back to the start of the tour. The journey took us through two more caves, paddling carefully to avoid striking the walls, and along wide, serene water ways, dominated by vibrant, green-clad rock sculptures, proud against the intense blue sky.

A few minutes before the end, our boatwoman pulled up to the bank and handed round feedback forms - just as I assume the boat crews have been doing down the centuries - and we passed back a tip with our form. After all, having been doing some paddling ourselves, we could appreciate how much effort was required to spend three hours guiding the boat around.

Back at the landing stop, we departed our little vessel, waving our goodbyes to the boatwoman and attempted to locate the exit. We spotted our driver waiting for us across the road and attempted to cross, but we were shouted at by a security guard who blew his whistle and made us troop through the long maze-like path of gift shops and so forth. Sigh. We indulged in some disgruntled muttering.

We were drenched in sweat and had just about finished our water, so it was a relief to pile into the air conditioned car and head back to our hotel. It was around midday so once we were dropped off, we headed for the little shop to pick up buckets more water and some lunch supplies. We were ruminating on which flavour noodles might be the best when Susu, the dog from the night before, waddled over and we spent a lovely few minutes giving her some nice scritches and giggling as she licked our legs and feet. She seemed pleased to see us and once again came around to the counter with us to pay.

It was blissful to finally collapse into our air conditioned room. I checked the weather: temperature 35, feels like 45 with humidity. Obviously. But we’d had an amazing morning and while that was possibly the most I’d sweated out yet, it was nothing that a shower and a cup of tea wouldn’t fix.

We made our noodles and watched an episode of Lost over lunch - we used to do Lost Lunch back in peak pandemic times - splitting some more Korean flavour fake Pringles. Then I worked on my journal, Pete quietly cursed the internet speeds and I made more tea.

Mid-afternoon, I started to hear thunder and found the sky had clouded over, lending a somewhat gloomy aspect to the distant peaks. And late afternoon, once we decided to step out for the evening, we found it was softly raining, barely more than a drizzle, but enough to make little puddles and take the edge off the heat of the day.

There was loud music emanating from somewhere nearby and we wondered whether there was some sort of local event on. As it was still warm and the rain was so slight, we decided to forgo waterproofs and just wandered through the village to investigate, looking out for a spot to have a drink. Undercover.

It turned out the music was coming from a house a couple of doors down: an old chap was sat by himself inside with doors and windows fling wide, warbling along to karaoke which was playing on a big screen. He was clearly in his own little world having a lovely time and we chuckled to find that the party tunes had such a sweet, wholesome source.

We ended up in one of the many open-fronted bar-slash-restaurants that seem to line the main road which we picked at random, reasoning that it would be good to try somewhere new. It turned out to be a good pick: we ordered a frozen mango daiquiri and a passionfruit mojito to split half and half, and found the that wifi was much faster than at our hotel. So Pete pulled out the laptop and we got to work on a few blog posts as we enjoyed our cocktails.

The drinks were probably the best ones we’ve had yet, the mojito laden with passionfruit and the daiquiri akin to drinking mango purée. I love it when a cocktail obviously has actual fruit in it instead of flavoured nonsense and these were a cut above! Plus they were a fraction over £3 each so we couldn’t go wrong really.

With two blog posts down, the sun had set and it was dark in the street behind the bar’s twinkly lights. Suddenly a high-pitched squeaky yapping rent the air. The lady who ran the restaurant then scooped a tiny puppy up from the floor who was hiding beneath a table as a couple of larger dogs walked by. He’d clearly been frightened and while the other dogs were curious rather than aggressive, the little pup made it clear that he was not up for being friends with them.

A large number of dogs wander about in Tam Coc - they all ignore us and are no trouble and we think they are mostly owned rather than strays. But this puppy was adorable and I went to ask the lady if I could stroke him.

She immediately plonked them tiny ball of floof into my arms and left me to play with him, so I brought him back to our table, gave him some nice cuddles and then let him sit with Pete.

I worked on the blog while Pete and the puppy became firm friends, the little doggo licking Pete’s hand, snuffling in his pockets, curling up beside him and then finally burrowing behind Pete where he seemed to feel safe and secure as he fell asleep.

He was a wriggly little creature and every so often would stir himself to move around, change positions, sit with me and yawn or snuggle in for some cuddles, but we had lovely time with our new pet and his very soft ears.

But after another round of drinks - an even better mango daiquiri and a beer - and another blog post while the internet was running hot, it was time for us to leave. We left the little bundle of fluff asleep on the bench but somewhat regretfully as the bar we’d selected at random had had not only excellent drinks and great wifi, but the best taste in furry friends.

We wandered back down the road looking for dinner and decided to try the Farm restaurant which I’d read was good on Trip Adviser. We had a flip through the menu on the pavement and then, to the delight of the waitress, ventured under cover for a table.

Again, the place was completely open, apart from an overhead cover to keep the rain off, and we placed our order. And then found a jenga set on the table and set to work attempting to topple each other. I won but barely; if the tower hadn’t collapsed after Pete’s final brick, I would have been out of options when it came to choosing my next block to remove.

Mid-game my portion of fries arrived and my goodness they were tasty: piping hot and crispy, crinkle but with a fluffy exterior. I dipped them happily in hot sauce and they barely lasted longer than the jenga tower.

Pete had a pork and pineapple stir fry with rice, I had chicken spring rolls and we enjoyed our food enormously as it was fresh and delicious. We also split a second portion of fries, because YUM. While we were eating, one of the couples from our Hanoi food tour appeared, taking a seat at the table across from us so we had a quick natter, and then another puppy appeared by our feet, clearly interested in our food. A little larger and older than the one from the first bar, the waitress said he’d suddenly appeared that day. He didn’t go for a chip but did enjoy a couple of morsels of Pete’s pork and while he did submit to a couple of little pats, as soon as he worked out the food was done, he was off. This puppy was certainly more single minded than our previous tiny friend.

We paid our bill and set off back to the hotel. The rain had stopped, we picked up some more water (although Susu was flopped under a chair and didn’t come out to say hello) and retreated to our room for the night.

I finished my journal, and had a quick shower - the evening air was still hot enough to warrant this despite the rain and the fact that sunset was long gone - and Pete made us both a cuppa. A small lizard let itself in under the door and immediately ran up the wall to hide the fan. Because as we all know, lizards love an appliance. We watched another episode of Lost and a Modern Family and then settled down to rest.

Because of course, there was the chance of beating the heat of the day if we set an early alarm. Just because it didn’t work the first time, didn’t mean it couldn’t work the next time!

posts.title: Honeymoon Minibus
posts.content:
Day 27

We didn’t get up until half eight and the zipped straight downstairs to catch the end of breakfast. We had some scrambled eggs cooked to order which was nice with a bit of toast and while the buffet wasn’t the best we’ve ever had, it still made a decent brekkie. And after all, when you pay £17 for the room for a night and it includes breakfast, you’ve absolutely got a bargain!

Back upstairs we sorted out a few bits and pieces, packing up, working on a blog post and I did a little research into our next destination.

Mid-morning, I felt a little restless and as Pete was happily ensconced enjoying some Commonwealth Games badminton in the air con, I decided to take myself out for one last Hanoi wander. I had one more cafe I wanted to visit and sometimes, you just have to go and get your elevensies.

The more time I spent in Hanoi, the more I liked it: the cheerful bustle of the streets, the shops and stalls spilling onto the pavements with lots to look at, the people heading here and there, locals and tourists alike. It was humid but I was quite happy strolling along, dodging motorbikes and enjoying that feeling that comes when you’ve stayed somewhere a little while and you start to know your way around. Hanoi gets two very enthusiastic thumbs up from me.

I found the Little Plan Cafe down one of the narrow alleys we’d learned about on our walking tour. Sandwiched between a motorbike repair garage which seemed to mostly operate on the pavement and another shop selling bits of hardware was the entrance to the alley, and just above it, the smallest of signs, easily missable, indicated the cafe lay within.

I ventured forth, found another small sign indicating a door off the alley with chap leaning in the doorway smoking. He moved aside to let me in and I found myself standing in an entryway, half of which contained a minute kitchen and sink, and the other half of which was occupied by a staircase. The chap from the doorway told me to go upstairs and go through the door on my right, which I did. I was grateful for the directions as I’d never have opened it otherwise.

Inside was a little secluded nook of peace, tranquility and tasteful, cohesive design. There was a lovely vintage feel about the little cafe: retro pieces had be placed artfully around the space, like old cameras and sewing machines. Prints and maps adorned the walls, ephemera decorated the empty spaces and the muted colours and cool air provided a beautifully secret contrast to the incessant activity and brashness of the city outside.

It was also clearly a bit of an Insta hangout and hipster haunt. There was an upper mezzanine where locals who I assumed were students worked at laptops, whereas downstairs it seemed to be more tourists. I was the only western tourist I could spot, but I think most of the rest of the customers were Asian tourists.

The little kitchen I’d passed downstairs was what served the cafe, and a member of staff popped in with a menu. I looked down the list, passing over banana cafe milkshake (no thanks coffee) and landed on banana cinna milkshake. Cinnamon and banana? Iced and cold? Thick and creamy? Yes please!

And I ordered a mug cake for food measure because they actually had mug cake on the menu. WIN! Although I did check what kind and then waitress told me it was chocolate. Always worth checking it isn’t something disappointing like watermelon or red bean. She warned me it would take a while to prepare, but I figured I had time.

Then I set about snapping some pictures of the room as when you’re somewhere this photogenic and carefully curated, you may as well take the photos to prove it. I accidentally befriended two other tourists who asked me to take their photo and wanted me to pose them against what I thought was the best background. At least, I think this was the question based on the mimes and smiles we used to communicate. The one word we did all understand? Instagram. Typical.

Then they kindly took a picture of me and then took a photo with me before we all returned to our tables.

My milkshake arrived and I sat down to slurp through it, editing a few of my trip pictures. I discovered pretty quickly that banana cinnamon milkshake did in fact also have coffee in it. Sigh. It was really delicious (if you ignore the coffee) and much of that seemed to sink into the bottom so the flavour was mild enough in most of the drink that I managed to consume it. And it was indeed cold and creamy which went a long way towards satisfying my intentions in ordering it.

It was about 45 minutes before my mug cake put in an appearance but it was completely worth the wait, and I was happily watching the world go by and reading. Served in a big teacup, the cake was beautifully chocolatey, slightly gooey in the centre and had a dollop of ice cream on top. Divine.

The Little Plan Cafe was easily my new favourite abroad cafe that I can probably never go back to but that I will think about every so often. Dreamy sigh.

Eventually I had to return to the hotel and find Pete so I dropped off my payment in the little kitchen downstairs and ventured back out into the sticky warmth of Hanoi’s streets. I picked up a couple of postcards as I walked back and then met Pete in the lobby, all checked out of our room and ready to go. We had a bit of time before we needed to leave which was just long enough to pop up to circle K and grab some snacks for our afternoon’s journey.

I was very much 50-50 as to whether we would actually make the journey we intended to make after my misadventures with the booking the previous day. But I asked the hotel reception to get us a taxi, and she didn’t seem surprised by the address of 58A Tran Nhan Tong Street so I figured that was something.

It was a cheap ride to the minibus pick up point, but it turned out to be a reasonably clear location rather than the random address it appeared from our ticket. I’d hedged my bets and gone with the supplied address rather than the map coordinates, and this appeared to have been a wise move. One side of the street was given over to coach parking, so at the very least, we were at a transport hub, and the taxi driver dropped us off outside the relevant address - there was a cafe whose name was 58A, scrawled on a large sign which helped - and pulled up behind a minibus already parked there. Another good sign.

We were about 40 minutes early for our 2:00pm departure which sounds insane, but the ticket advised us to arrive 30-60 minutes ahead of the ticket time as the minibuses tend to just go when they feel it’s a good time, and fluctuate based on traffic and goodness know what else. And sure enough, a little before half one our minibus showed up.

I checked with the driver that it was the right one - I took his nonchalant drug to be a yes - and we waited to board. This was delayed somewhat by the current occupants - all tourists - who wanted to go to the old quarter, including one particularly vocal French woman who was under the impression that the ticket she’d bought would take her to the hotel. We weren’t sure whether she’d been mis-sold her ticket or misunderstood what she’d been sold, but I knew from my research that the minibus didn’t go to the old quarter, and public transport definitely doesn’t do individual hotel drop offs. I did tell her that a taxi to the old quarter was only $2 but as she said she’d paid quite a bit extra to be taken to her hotel she wasn’t going to get off the bus. Great.

There followed a long series of phone calls between various parties as the driver didn’t speak English and none of us spoke Vietnamese but after twenty minutes or so, it seemed someone sorted her out a taxi and she left the minibus and climbed triumphantly into the waiting car.

We settled into our seats ready for our journey, and I was glad we had indeed been early as the minibus set off several minutes before it’s allotted time. We were amused to find that the seats had inbuilt massagers - what kind of bus was this??? - and then slightly taken aback with the degree to which the seat pummelled your back. It was a bit next level and so I switched it off.

I was feeling quite relieved that the whole transport scenario had worked out so well, right up until the point where the driver pulled into a car park and made us get off the bus. We were barely ten minutes into our journey so I wasn’t sure what the stop was for, but we didn’t seem to have much choice in the matter and so off we hopped.

Fortunately, another minibus appeared and after saying Ninh Binh repeatedly to the driver and receiving some more vague smiles, we piled on our bags and got on.

This one had more passengers but fewer facilities. Which is a fancy way of saying no massage chairs. I’d come to expect this as standard now, as of ten minutes previously, so clearly we were going to have to slum it in normal chairs.

I dozed for the most of the journey; the minibus had blowers but didn’t really seem to be doing much in the way of air con and the warm air made me feel drowsy. But true to form, the minibus pulled up outside the minibus office In Ninh Binh a little before half three and we had made it. We double checked with the driver as the office seemed to be in a nondescript suburb (and no one else got off which seemed odd) but he pulled our bags out of the back of the van which seemed to be a reasonably solid indication that our time in his bus was over.

I stepped into the office and found a woman behind a desk, so I mimed ordering a taxi and she kindly obliged. The taxi driver duly appeared and had me put our location straight into Google maps in his phone which conveniently got around any communication and directional challenges - well done that man. He dropped us off outside our hotel in the neighbouring village of Tam Coc and we staggered inside under the weight of our bags and the oppressive heat of the sun.

The place was deserted. They were definitely expecting us as the hotel had messaged only that morning to say they were ready for us to check in. But we roamed over 4 floors of the building to no avail.

Pete eventually found someone asleep in room on the fourth floor and managed to persuade them to come downstairs and check us in. By this point, we’d clambered up and down the stairs quite a lot - it was an outside metal staircase up the back of the building with the rooms coming off long terraces. We were shown up to the third floor and pointed towards a room with a key in the door before the lady left, shutting the door behind her. No check in, no passports, no payment.

Not to worry: the room was clean and a good size and we switched the air con on as we both felt quite hot and bothered. Mostly though, I was thankful we’d arrived!

We managed to get another blog post live and enjoyed a shower each to de-sticky, and then Pete got the kettle on to make a nice cooling hot cup of tea because that’s how that works. We were running low on teabags and creamer so I made a mental note to track down tea and, if possible, milk in the village.

After a while, a different lady passed our window, spotted us and knocked on the door and we had a slightly awkward half English, half mime conversation about what we wanted for breakfast and when. We hadn’t firmed up our plans but we were hoping to do our sightseeing earlyish the next morning, partly to avoid the hottest part of the day but also to beat the bus loads of tourists arriving from Hanoi on day trips. So we opted for a half seven breakfast, hoped that made sense and figured we’d just have to see what appeared in the morning. I think pineapple was involved.

Once it was dark, we set out to see a little bit more of Tam Coc. It was surprisingly touristy in a backpacker way: cheap and cheerful with twinkly lights, music, a good number of bars and restaurants back to back along the main road and very easily accessible. Probably the easiest place to get around yet.

Our first aim was to find a way to get to Trang An the next day so we could do the classic Ninh Binh boat tour. We stopped in the doorway of a tourist booking office with promising signs in the window and two lads were inside tucking into some dinner. When we asked if we could go to Trang An tomorrow, one of them assured us that we absolutely could: we could just go there whenever we liked.

Yes of course, we agreed. But how were we to get there and back.

He recommended we just drive on motorbikes or possibly bicycles and enjoy being outside instead of in a car, missing everything. He gave us a map and said his Mum would probably give us much more detail, but she wasn’t in.

We thanked him and left. Being in possession of neither bike nor motorbike - or motorbike licence for that matter - we were perfectly happy to go by car. And while hiring bikes was something we quite wanted to do, right that second wasn’t the ideal time to do it.

We had much more success at the second tourist office, and within minutes had arranged for a driver to take us to Trang An and collect us again afterwards, leaving at eight the next morning. Sorted! It was relatively inexpensive and convenient and feeling pretty positive regarding our trip booking achievements, we went in search of drinks and dinner.

We opted to eat at T-Pub which I’d seen recommended online. It had lots of lounger-type chairs scattered around an outdoor area underneath rows of multi-coloured strung lights, and it seemed to be doing a steady trade. We found a spot to sit looking out at the road and ordered some drinks, and we were quite happy to relax and watch the world go by: tourists on bikes, locals pulling a cart up and down with a dog riding up front and the usual sprinkling of motorbikes and cars honking at anyone and anything for no real reason. The traffic was comparatively quiet though when compared to Hanoi and shops and business festooned with lights made the street seems vibrant and inviting.

Pete sank a beer and a frozen strawberry daiquiri, I had an Oreo milkshake and a giant bottle of water from the little shop across the road. Most of the T-Pub clients seemed to be bobbing backwards and forwards to the little shop to pick up their water supplies.

We ordered dinner as well and although it took a long while to come, we weren’t in a hurry and were more than happy chilling for the evening while we waited.

I say chilling: it was of course well over thirty degrees and my phone informed me that the humidity factor made it feel like 37. So perhaps substitute the word “chilling” for the phrase “heatslumping”. That’ll do it.

Once it arrived, we tucked into our dinner with gusto. We had ordered a falafel burger each which came filled with salad and roasted pumpkin which was a surprising but welcome addition. The falafel was crisp on the outside and soft in the middle, there was hot sauce on the table to add a kick and the fries which accompanied it were homemade, chunky and satisfying.

As the night wore on, we settled our bill and popped to the shop across the road for more water. We also managed to score milk and teabags, and Pete made a firm friend in the chubby little shop dog whose name was Susu. Susu was practically grinning with pleasure as Pete scratched her head and chest and the shop owner chuckled. Susu gave us some little licks of thanks and came with us when we went to the counter to pay, leaning on my legs and licking my toes. She was very sweet, and so was her owner. Quite the sales team really.

Back in our room, it was absolutely air con o’clock and I had another shower to rid myself of the sweat and bug spray combo. Then I worked on my journal for a bit before we settled down for our nightly rendition of Lost. With a cup of tea.

We aren’t animals.

It was nice to settle down for the night in the knowledge that we had a new area to explore the next day. Here’s to adventure dreams!

posts.title: Honeymoon Bay
posts.content:
Day 26

Our alarms pinged at six and we stumbled out of bed in the dark. Actually, it wasn’t dark, and even though our room was chill with air con and gloomy from the heavy curtains, once we opened them, it was light, and stepping out onto the balcony revealed a warm and muggy morning, if somewhat grey with cloud cover.

We got dressed and headed upstairs for breakfast, billed as a light affair before our morning’s activity. First breakfast, if you will.

We had a pastry each and a round of tea. And a second round of tea. Pete popped back to our room while I finished off my second, and when I returned, I found him curled up back under the covers, guarding the bed. He’s such a good guard-husband.

We got ready to kayak and when the announcement pinged over the intercom, we were ready to go and find ourselves a boat.

We hopped into the kayaks straight off the back of the ship and pretty much had free reign to paddle about and explore. Despite the thick cloud, it was still warm and humid, but it was nice not to be in the direct sun and we paddled about quite happily.

We investigated a small nearby shore at the base of one of the rocky structures and then kayaked around the ship in both directions. It was nice to see it from the outside. We could see what we thought was a little fishing boat across the water, but we didn’t go too close in case it was a snack boat and we’d were hounded into buying beer and Oreos. You have to be careful when out on the high seas.

Paddling up close to another limestone outcrop, we were investigating the worn base where it protruded from the water. It seemed to be covered in barnacles and sharp, sticky-out protrusions and as we got closer, it started to move. It turns out there were loads of tiny grey crabs scuttling around, getting on with all their sideways business and snacking on whatever it is that crabs snack on. We could see little flashes of purple pincers.

We paddled a little further on - when we got into it, we could get up a pretty good speed - and then started to feel a few drops of water. Deciding to quit while we were ahead, we slid our kayak in to dock back on the ship and climbed aboard, keen for a shower as the oars had splashed lots of water over us.

Pete jumped into the shower first while I hid balloons under his pillow and in his bag, and then I showered. When I came out, Pete was once again guarding the bed, oblivious to the extra balloons he was lying on, and before long he was asleep. Which is presumably how he does his best guarding.

It has never been clear to me exactly what Pete is guarding the bed from, but he seems to feel there is a very real and present danger as he had to guard the bed a lot.

I read for a little while, watching the peaks of Halong bay retreat through the window as the boat started its return journey. And by nine, we had packed up all our things and were ready to check out of our room.

We settled our bill, giving ourselves points for honesty as we pointed out we hadn’t been charged for a coke and fruit juice we’d had the night before. And then we got double honesty points when we were given 100 000 dong in change instead of 10 000.

We wandered upstairs a little early for brunch but people seemed to be already seated and tea was out so we ventured in and took our seats. It was a lovely spread and I enjoyed a freshly cooked vegetable omlette with a crusty roll, some very tasty fried noodles and then my usual cake and fruit platter. There are reports that my cake got topped up as it was the tasty fruity one from lunch the day before. Omnomnom.

Three teas down and feeling pretty full, we moved to lounge and read until it was time to depart. The little tenders took us back to the mainland, waving a path through the beautiful peaks and rocks as we absorbed our final moments in Halong Bay.

Disembarking was all very efficient: we unloaded ourselves, found our bags, and our transfer back to Hanoi was already waiting for us outside. We had a smooth journey back to the city, alternating between snoozing and audiobook listening. And also sometimes falling into the intersection of the that particular Venn diagram which meant I had to rewind my book to the last point where I was conscious.

We were staying in a different hotel this time - a bit of shame as we loved our previous Hanoi haunt, but it had jumped in price for this night and so we’d booked a cheaper alternative.

It didn’t have nice teaware.

Having said that, it was again a perfectly nice place with a spacious room and air con and we opted to chill out for a little while, catch up with ourselves and sort out some admin for our journey the next day. I had a lovely old time on arguing with the internet; I downloaded a bus ticket for the transport we’d arranged the next day, and the address we’d be given was not in the same place as the Google maps coordinates. So where were we meant to go? In the end, I assumed that worst case scenario is that we’d go to the bus company’s office which was between the two points and ask them. Not ideal, but manageable.

In fact, not even the worst case scenario which I suppose would be never finding the pick up and missing it entirely.

Or being eaten by a basking shark or something. That would be way worse.

Public transport woes aside, we had a nice evening ahead planned and so at half five, we upped and outed to go and visit the last sight that I’d really wanted to see in Hanoi: train street!

I’d seen pictures of train street and I guess in many ways, it kind of does what it says on the tin: there‘s a street and every so often the trains go down it. However, street is an optimistic word for narrow alley, and the alley in question is lined with little shops and bars so you can wander the tracks and grab a drink and then should a train come through, everyone just has to get out of the way and businesses reel in any chairs and tables that might be in the train’s path.

When we arrived, there were of course quite a lot of other tourists there, but we could see why: it really was quite charming with the open fronted small businesses, lanterns strung over the balconies, locals perched on the rails and lots of people sat out enjoying a coffee or beer. We picked our way along the sleepers, skipping over stones and watching all the people. There was such an uplifting atmosphere and while I appreciate that tourism has massively transformed what was previously a small residential snicket into a bustling hotspot, it did seem to be upbeat and thriving.

We reached the point where the tracks reached the road and then turned back to wander up the rails again: I would have loved to have spent an afternoon people watching and waiting for a train to go by.

However, we had to depart as it was time to search for food. We’d decided to go back to Banh Mi 25 as we’d really enjoyed their sandwiches on our food tour, and it didn’t hurt that it was nearish to our hotel, cheap, and had a menu we could work out. Plus it was DELICIOUS so there’s that.

We found a spare table and claimed it, taking in the local artwork peppering the walls; I enjoyed the vintage-style Tiger Balm adverts in particular. There were pot plants, the shop front was completely open to the night air, and the infamous conical Vietnamese hats had been repurposed into light shades with little felt decorations hanging from them.

I ordered a chicken and avocado banh mi, and Pete opted for the traditional pork with pate. And it’s course we both had them with everything: cucumber, chilli, carrot, coriander and mint. They were super delicious, the baguette having a lovely crisp outer and fluffy middle and a dash of hot sauce just bringing all the lovely, vibrant flavours together, cut through the the fresh zing of coriander.

I’m a coriFANder.

The sandwiches were actually made at a little stall on one side of the street, while the two seating areas inside different shop fronts were situated on the opposite side of the street. Meaning that the staff had to dodge and weave between motorbikes and general street traffic to deliver the food. It was quite comical to watch.

We devoured our meal quite rapidly. In fact, they were so delicious, Pete had a second banh mi, opting to try the chicken and cheese. He let me try and it did indeed have many top yummies inside. I asked Pete how the traditional pork and pate lined up against the chicken and he reckoned in the final tally, the type of meat didn’t make much difference as the real flavour comes from the extras. Which was interesting; I’d expected him to say the pork was better. Pete’s other comment was that the bread plays a starring roll, especially for the texture and I absolutely agreed: that fresh baguette vibe is all-important.

We settled out bill - 3 sandwiches and 2 drinks for less than £7 - and headed back for our hotel, going via circle K for supplies. I had been hoping for another chocolate fish ice cream but they only had red bean filled ones which I just didn’t fancy. But we got some milk for real tea and some biscuits so it was a pretty solid effort.

posts.title: Honeymoon Cruise
posts.content:
Day 25

We were up a little earlier, shortly after seven, and it was time to pack our bags and prepare to leave Hanoi. Again. We breakfasted on eggs, bread, fruit and a cuppa and then returned to our room to collect our things and do a final sweep for anything we might have missed.

We hauled our bags downstairs, settled our bill and found our ride ready and waiting, a minute or two early, which is nice but did mean we had to scramble. At the appointed time of 8:20, we were already seated in the back of the minibus rumbling through the streets! We would miss the hotel though: it had been an excellent base with lovely staff, a super convenient location and, of course, top teaware. Who knows what mugs or teacups we might be forced to partake of in the future?

When the minibus had collected it’s last passengers we began the drive out of the city towards Halong Bay. There were 8 of us on board: 3 retirement age couples and then me and Pete. The minibus was comfortable though and after a little natter with the other tourists, we passed the journey quite happily with iPad shows for Pete and audiobooks for me. We had a brief stop at some services and then continued onwards and eventually the curious limestone shapes that are synonymous with Halong Bay appeared on the horizon.

I wasn’t sure initially if they were where we were heading as they seemed to rise out of the land, but as we got closer and the minibus started to negotiate the labyrinthine docklands roads and passages, it became clear that they were indeed out to sea.

The minibus pulled up outside a little cabin for us to wait in until it was time to board our boat at noon. When the moment came, a small tender pulled up to the pontoon and we shrugged into lifejackets and squashed into the little benches. We had assumed that we would just be going a few metres to the ship moored nearby, but we were mistaken, instead heading out towards the rearing limestone monuments in the sea.

Pete joked that this was our entire cruise ship and I figured if that was the case we would need a refund. We pondered the idea of passing snacks down from the front of the boat, taking turns to nap on the little benches above giggling over the idea of the poop deck.

Blame Pete, he went there.

But when we coasted between two mountains erupting from the ocean, we emerged into a bay where another series of ships were moored, and were soon clambering aboard our boat.

Time to cruise! We were shown to the boat’s sitting room and given a nice chilled glass of passionfruit juice to enjoy while we waited to check in. It was lovely to see views of Halong Bay out through the huge picture windows. A baby grand sat in the corner with a little sign on top that said “only for competent players”.

A chap went for a bit of a tinker. He clearly had not read the sign and would have struggled to even see competent with binoculars. Everyone clapped when he’d done though as clearly everyone is nicer than I am.

We were introduced to the key staff on board and talked through the schedule; we had barely 24 hours on board so it was good to know that we could make the most of them. Then it was time to collect our keys and find our room.

I chuckled when I stepped inside and found that they’d really gone to town on the bed. Pete, coming into the room behind me, commented that I laughed the laugh of someone who’s just seen a decorated bed.

Whenever possible, I had informed places that we were staying that we were on our honeymoon, just in case that smoothed the path to an upgrade or a cheeky freebie. On the boat, not only had they folder the towels to look like swans, not only had they scattered rose petals to kingdom come, but they had also laid out heart-shaped balloons. It was admittedly quite comical and we enjoyed it.

Our room was lovely: surprisingly large with a great bathroom and a bath with a view, plus our own balcony where we could sit and watch the beautiful landscape slide by.

At half one, we went up to the dining room to sample the lunch buffet, and tucked into some salad, soup and rolls. There was also an enormous quantity of seafood but I was happy to stick to something a little lighter. We sat in the window, watching the craggy limestone sculptures, moulded by time and the elements, vegetation clinging on wherever it could and the blue sky above reflecting in the sea below.

For dessert there were two kinds of cake (although one turned out to be coffee which threw me as it looked like chocolate) and a big vat of something I thought was a berry compote. I almost ladled some over my cake but decided not to at the last minute. Which was wise as it turned out not to be berries, but red sticky rice. I ate it but it was a bit weird.

After lunch, we had a little wander around the boat, taking in the top deck, baking in the sun, and the pool on the lower deck, looking out to the bay. It was once again incredibly warm, and so after we’d explored fully, we decided to go and sit on our balcony and watch the views drift past while we we shaded from the sun and the light breeze was pleasant. It was peaceful and relaxing, just a wonderful way to enjoy and embrace the environment.

Until the air was split by a loud guttering engine. Our initial confusion regarding the source of the noise soon turned to surprise as we found a small wooden boat with an ancient, rattling motor pull up alongside our ship. The boat was guided along by a woman who was attempting to sell her wares to guests on board, and her boat was absolutely crammed full with food and drink of all description. While she had a selection of local fruit and so on that might be expected produce, she also had bottles of wine, cases of beer, Oreos, instant noodles, crisps and pretty much any other snack you could imagine.

I was torn as on the one hand, our peaceful oasis was shattered by the impertinent engine and the persistent shouts of the woman trying to sell us things. But equally, I guess she was just trying to make a living.

We retreated indoors for a bit to enjoy some air con and to escape the unrelenting sales pitch, and then we returned to our balcony. I made a pot of tea as, in true Vietnam style, the teaware was top notch, with cups, saucers and a pot all wrought in a pale jade-green ceramic. And so we had a brew amidst the excellent scenery of Halong Bay.

The boat manager announced over the intercom that it was time to get ready for our trip excursion, so we donned hats, suncream and sunnies and went to hop back on the tender.

We departed promptly and then had to circle back to pick up some guests who had literally missed the boat. And then we were off to visit the Bright and Dark caves.

This involved being dropped off at a floating pontoon and transferring to wooden boats. These fit around 6 to 8 passengers and were rowed by a a local standing on the back with long, slender oars that reached down to the water. It was quite an impressive feat and while the little vessels wobbled and twisted as we arranged ourselves along the little benches, we were soon slipping through the water towards the cave.

It was wonderful to be able to see the limestone rocks up close and they jutted like infant mountains out of the sea. The sun was beginning to hang low in the sky, filtering through the greenery and we could see the layers and textures in the rock as we bobbed steadily onwards

Before long, we came to the cave. It was actually more of a short passage through the rock, but weird and wonderful craggy shapes hung in rocky curtains from the ceiling and bags fluttered and roosted in the cracks and crevices. Water dripped from above and it was gloomy but before long, we were emerging from the end of the passage into what presumably is the bright cave.

Unfortunately, Pete’s sunglasses made a bid for freedom overboard which was frustrating.

The bright cave isn’t a cave at all: it’s a section of sea that is completely concealed and cut off from the rest of the sea, ringed with limestone protrusions and accessed only by our passageway in and one or two much smaller tunnels through the rocks. Our rower allowed the boat to simply drift in this secret lagoon so we could take in the surroundings. The vault of the sky gleamed blue above us, little waves gently rocked the boat and we drank in the view. It was marvellous.

Eventually, it was time to leave and so we were paddled back through the tunnel as the bats flew and skittered and returned to the pontoon, the sun dipping and weaving in amongst the peaks.

Back on the boat we got changed, I pulled the balloons all out from my side of the bed where Pete had hidden them, presumably hoping I wouldn’t spot the giant, mysterious lump under the cover, and we went for tea and cookies up on deck. Because tea time must be observed even when you’re on a boat cruising through mysterious landscapes in foreign lands a world away.

We then headed out to the pool and bar, where I discovered even better snacks than the ones we’d found. Sadly the chips were pretty much gone, but there were prawn crackers so I munched a few as I circled the deck snapping pictures. We decided to treat ourselves to cocktail each, and so we ordered a mojito and and mai tai and retreated to the upper deck to take in the sunset.

As the sun relinquished it’s fiery grasp on the day, it was cool enough to sit out quite comfortably, and a little bit of a breeze helped to stir the air. Lots of boats were mooring up around us, their lights dancing and twinkling in the water, and we sipped our drinks and watched the yellow in the sky fade out to pale blue and then inky darkness. Beneath the surface of the sea, we spied a huge jellyfish undulating past and debated the merits of swimming the next day.

At half seven, it was time for dinner and so we popped to our room to freshen up, I pulled balloons out of the bed again and we headed to the dining room. We were served a set menu with a surprisingly large number of courses. There was an appetiser of pickled prawn (fine but didn’t love) and squid cakes (yummy) followed by a seafood soup that was strangely gloopy. The flavour was fine, just mildly savoury, but we were intrigued as to how the texture had turned out so slimy.

Then we had some steamed seabass with red rice and mushrooms, and then Pete had a steak while I opted for chicken, served with mashed potatoes, veg and some sauce.

Pete read out the menu to see what was for dessert. “Flan. That’s not a good starting word. I feel like nothing good begins with flan.”

I had to agree. However, before we could explore the flan plan further, the manager of the ship asked us all to applaud the staff for servicing the meal which we did, and then said that there was another reason to be celebrating too.

At which point, she announced that Pete and I were con our honeymoon and had us wave to the room at large. Then the lights were turned off and we were given a giant cake with candles to blow out, and a bunch of flowers. Yikes!

We asked the staff to cut the cake and share it round with everyone and in the mean time, we attacked our flan which was served with watermelon (because flan and watermelon deserve each other) and tapioca balls. I ate mine but Pete refused.

The cake on the other hand was excellent: soft sponge, piles of buttercream and chocolate icing. YUM!

Feeling pretty full, we went back to our room for the night. We had an early start the next morning so we showered, made a pot of tea and settled down in bed to watch an episode of Lost. Rearranging my pillows part way through, I found that they made a funny squeaking noise. As Pete was shaking with silent laughter I pulled even more balloons out from under my pillow. Pete was quite upset that they hadn’t popped when I’d leaned on them.

I was going to need to work out my counter attack.

With our alarms set for six and the boat moored up for the night, we settled down for a good sleep at eleven so that we’d be ready to make the most of our last morning in Halong Bay.

posts.title: Honeymoon City
posts.content:
Day 24

We woke to our alarms at 7:45 and pottered down to breakfast. We knew the hotel did a decent spread and we helped ourselves to eggs and little bread buns alongside plenty of fresh fruit. Pete’s stomach was still playing up a little and while it wasn’t causing him pain particularly, he was trying to eat a little more carefully and stick to plain things.

I dropped off our laundry at reception - they offered a very cheap same day service that we were keen to take advantage of - and found our guide for the morning already waiting for us.

We had booked a free city walking tour as we’ve found that these have been really excellent for getting to know new places in the past, especially when you have a local to share their insights and give you a bit of history. While there isn’t an official charge, the guides are paid in tips and we’ve always had incredibly enthusiastic and knowledgeable leaders in the past.

This was a bit different as it was just the two of us and the guide came to meet us at the hotel. This had initially surprised us, but it was nice to know we could go at our own pace, ask questions, take photos and rest if we needed to.

Our guide told us that his nickname was Sunday - the fun day as it’s everyone’s day off - and he beamed at us constantly. He was a mine of information and clearly had a lot of love for the city, keen to ensure that our experience was positive. He explained our intended route and then we stepped out in the warm city streets.

First of all, Sunday wanted to make sure we could cross the roads safely. After our experiences in Indonesia, Hanoi was proving pretty straightforward, but he advised us that we should walk slowly and confidently across the street, waving our hands down at the traffic. This lets the drivers know you’re crossing and to go round you. The important part is not to panic and run as it becomes much more challenging for the drivers to predict your path and avoid you. They aren’t going to stop so you kind of just have to be confident and deliberate in your intentions.

Our first port of call was the White Horse temple. We chatted on our walk through the streets, practising crossing the roads and flapping at traffic. I wondered if it might just be a good idea to constantly flap my arms while I walked as we’d often be in the road, pavements being crowded with parked bikes and food stalls.

I refrained however. I think it would have embarrassed Pete.

The temple dates back to the 9th Century although it’s purpose had shifted in that time. The white horse refers to a myth that Sunday relayed to us, that the the then king had apparently spotted. The temple was really beautiful; Sunday leant my a shirt to just lay over my shoulders, but we could go inside without paying and see the intricate carvings and the extravagant and flamboyant offerings and displays.

There was a big Chinese influence in the the architecture and some of the wooden pillars were decorated with carved characters which apparently these days, the majority of people don’t read since Vietnam switched to the Latin alphabet. To enter the temple you had to step over quite a large barrier in the door, designed to keep out snakes and floods. A higher barricade further in was to prevent women entering, their clothes meaning they couldn’t manage the step over, but that custom us apparently outdated now.

Yay.

In the inner sanctum, we saw the statute of the white horse, lots of statues of cranes standing on turtles symbolising the way they work together to each benefit the other, and lots of offerings to the gods. This includes the burning of incense and fancy decorations, but also everyday things like cans of coke and beer. The Vietnamese acknowledge the gods used to be people and therefore still enjoy and appreciate the things that mere mortals do. Which is quite nice actually.

One of my favourite bits was a beautiful carving of a dragon. Sunday told us that this represents a legend telling of the way land animals came to be. All the fish were told that if they could complete a series of challenges, they would become dragons and live on the land. They had to try and swim up a waterfall and eventually all the fish gave up.

All except the carp who tried over and over again, a thousand times, showing great resilience and eventually making it, becoming a dragon. Top work that carp. This story is often used to inspire students to succeed in their studies.

Although Sunday also told us that the incentive, especially for boys, it’s pretty high. If you do well enough in your exams at age 18 you can go to college and avoid military service. Although it seems you can also avoid the service by paying “coffee money” to the right people.

I googled this later and it seems that “coffee money” is a disarmingly cute name for bribery payments in Vietnam. These can be big payments used to secure land in the cities or prestigious public positions, or small payments which it seems many families offer to their children’s teachers. The average rate in Hanoi is apparently $30 a term.

Which leads me to believe I am owed quite a lot in bribes now in my 12 years of teaching.

I think I would prefer tea money though.

Meanwhile, back on the tour: we left the temple and Sunday led us down what he called a narrow alley. And he wasn’t kidding: just about wide enough for two people to pass, these passages were long and dark but surprisingly hide prime real estate as it’s thought to be very lucrative if you live in Hanoi’s Old Quarter.

In the past, 60 to 100 people would have lived in small rooms off the alleys, sharing a kitchen and bathroom. Now however, wealth is increasing and families have their own facilities and we passed security cameras and air conditioning units which looked almost out of places in the dark little passages.

We also learned the reason for the length of the passages: in times past, buildings were taxed based solely on their width. So of course as the city was constructed, properties favoured very narrow street fronts but when back a long way to give enough space. Hence the intricate network of long passages which cross cross the area.

We emerged from the alley and passed the last remaining city gate - defended so valiantly by Vietnamese soldiers that the French decided to leave it standing when they took over. Apparently guards at the other gates surrendered quickly and the gates were destroyed. Then we turned into a street lined with market sellers: we had reached the outdoor market.

Sunday told us that all the stalls were illegal and that none of the sellers paid rent or had licences to be there. However, if you pay coffee money to the shops, you can set up in the road in front of one and this the sellers had down in abundance. There was lots of produce and meal, spilling in every direction and motorbikes squeezed up and down, parking up briefly to choose their wares before loading them onto the bikes and moving on to the next stall.

Apparently the police don’t come down the road very often (coffee money again) and on the rare occasion they do, they’ll call ahead to warn the market sellers who simply pack up their things and wait for them to pass before laying everything out again.

It was fascinating to see, but Sunday told us that markets like this are in decline. He told us that he and his generation preferred to used shops like Winmart and Circle K where you are guaranteed a certain standard of produce and a fixed price. I was surprised to hear this as I would have assumed the loss of the markets would have been a bad thing, but Sunday said he hoped that in 20 years or so, they’d be gone entirely.

In fact, he was very keen for us to shop at Winmart and mentioned it several times.

From the outdoor market, we went to the official indoor market, constructed by the French over 100 years ago and split into two sections. Once we’d passed the guy carving up a very recently deceased turtle in the entrance, we in amongst the seafood stalls. We also passed stalls selling dried fruits, seeds, herbs and spices, dried mushrooms and various other foodstuffs.

The second hall contained the “dry goods” which meant clothes and shoes, hats and underwear and lots of homeware stalls too. There were wholesale stalls upstairs, but we had a bit of a wander around the ground floor to see things for ourselves and the amount of stock was kind of insane. You could pretty much buy anything.

Leaving the markets behind, we strolled back through the Hanoi streets towards the lake. On our way, we passed several stalls selling paper facsimiles of loads of items and Sunday told us that these to burn so that your ancestors could use them in the afterlife.

He told us that actually most people in Vietnam aren’t religious, but that people do pray to their ancestors, usually twice each lunar month. Shrines are made in homes and the things that are burned then pass to the late ancestors to enjoy. This can be anything from paper models of houses and cars to clothes, iPhones and iPads.

Sunday told us he didn’t believe in this. He grinned and said he couldn’t understand the point of burning an iPhone but not a charger. It would be useless to the dead without one!

We arrived at the lake we’d walked around on our last evening in Hanoi, and as it was a Sunday, there were more people about that ever. Additionally, the roads were all shut for the weekend and the area becomes pedestrianised which made things nice and easy for us. Fewer hands to flap.

However, before we hit the lake, Sunday took us down another little alley, up a hidden flight of stone steps and into a first floor coffee shop. This was apparently the place where the famous Vietnamese egg coffee originated and while I confessed to Sunday that I don’t like coffee, I was happy to give this a try in the name of research. I kind of think you have to when you’re abroad!

The room was littered with low tables and tiny wooden stools - the sort that make your knees bend up to your chin. We decided to share an egg coffee - while I’m happy to taste one, I didn’t think I’d be jazzed enough to sing a whole coffee - and Sunday ordered one for us.

So what’s egg coffee? Well, it wasn’t at all what I thought, but I’m not quite sure what I expected, short of seeing an egg yolk bobbing in the top perhaps. An egg coffee is apparently a bit like egg nog - there’s coffee in there, egg, some condense mills and a bunch of honey to sweeten it. When it arrived, there was a beautiful design swirled on top and the coffee looked thick and creamy, not unlike a cappuccino. In fact, that’s what the coffee’s creator had been attempting to emulate, but without milk which was expensive and difficult to get hold of back in the day. In fact, it doesn’t seem to be commonplace now.

Taste-wise, it was actually pretty good if you ignored the bitter coffee taste. In fact, if an egg hot chocolate was a thing, I would happily have slurped one up. But we finished it between us, and the thick, foamy liquid was pretty satisfying. It was good to have sampled such a Vietnamese staple.

While we drank our coffee, Sunday gave us a sticker with his details of and a little gift each of some balm that apparently soothes mosquito bites and prevents seasickness. More than happy to give that a go.

Our tour finished with a stroll along the lake down the side of the French corner, stopping at the massive Russian monstrosity that jarred with the more elegant buildings around it in an attempt to instil communism.

Then it was time to head back to our hotel. We’d had a great morning, learned a lot about the city and been lucky in our guide. We waved goodbye outside our hotel, tipping generously, and then headed indoors for a bit of a air con and a cuppa.

We chilled for a while, worked on a couple of blog posts, had more tea and I started on my day’s journal. Then I popped out mid-afternoon to go and visit a little coffee shop called The Note Cafe.

I will confess up-front that I had seen this place on Instagram and that even if Pete had been in the best of health, I feel like he would have declined to join me. So I set out on foot to walk back towards the lake and seek out my destination.
