It was a muggy afternoon unsurprisingly, but I dodged and weaved quite merrily through the traffic and soon found where I was going, the cafe having the advantage of a shop front and a clear sign. The premise is simple: the whole cafe is absolutely plastered in sticky notes with little handwritten messages that previous visitors have left.

A chap waiting in the doorway walked me up two flights of narrow stairs to a seat at the bench in the window and I ordered a cookie crumble Frappuccino (which I checked did not contain coffee!) and took my seat. It had a cracking view down between trees over the lake, the road below was quiet as traffic had been banished for the weekend and as there was no glass in the windows, a very slight but welcome breeze disturbed the heavy air. I amused myself reading the notes stuck to the bench in front of me and pondering what to write on my own. The messages from other guests varied: some were heartfelt, sweet and sincere, some moronic and others were clever. I chuckled at one which quoted a favourite TV show (I’m not going to say, you’ll have to look at the pictures and work it out because if you know, you know and I salute you and if not then it isn’t going to be funny anyway). I also found notes from other honeymooners which was cute.

In the end, I settled on leaving a note for Emily as she seemed the most likely to swing by this way in future, and I wrote a bit more of my journal and read some more notes while I slurped my drink.

Which by the way was incredible: like a big ice creamy milkshake with lots of crushed cookies. YUM! I actually think Pete would have enjoyed the cafe after all.

With my drink finished, I set our back into the sunshine, topping up our cash reserves at a handy ATM and even making a trip to circle K to collect some more water and buy Pete a coke, as I thought he might enjoy one.

Back at the hotel, I found Pete happily ensconced watching his laptop and I made another brew to see me through to our next outing.

We prepped one last blog post and then threw a few things in a bag ready to head out for the evening. Food tour time!

The meeting point for the food tour was less than five minutes from our hotel. I had an address (not especially helpful to us usually as we can’t usually find street names or numbers), a name and usefully, a picture of the place we were looking for sent by our guide, Hanh.

It was the picture that helped us identify the location in the end. Not because the shop looked like the picture - it didn’t as it’s sign was gone and they’d moved things around in the front - but because the picture showed a small slice of the next door shop which did look like it’s picture. Phew!

Hanh emerged from inside and shepherded us through to the back. The shop had a women cooking over a stove in the very front and the rest of the space was a long cut narrow room with plastic tables and tiny stools for perching on. It was busy with tables being turned around quickly and Hanh perched us at a table, got us both a drink and some dipping sauce, and went back to the street to scout for more tourists.

We were a group of 8 in the end, and it was lovely to meet some other travellers, partly to be able to swap stories and chat, but also because it took the pressure off with the food; we didn’t want to feel watched while we ate!

In the first place, we sampled Banh Xeo. These are like crispy pancake shells folded around beansprouts and possibly other unidentified fillings. However, what surprised us was that this isn’t eaten directly: instead, you wrap it in a sheet of rice paper along with some green leaves and herbs, dip the whole thing in the sauce and eat that.

Well, we had somewhat limited success with this as the rice paper was a bit brittle and snapped around the pancake rather than rolling. While we had a good go, we ended up finding that we were better off just munching on the pancake, especially as the rice paper didn’t seem to add much flavour.

It was a good dish to try though and new to us, although we did have to dock a few points for the cockroach that ran over Pete’s foot. Win some, lose some.

We moved off for the next stop on our tour: it turned out to be the Banh Mi place that Sunday had recommended to us that morning. I love it when a plan comes together!

We all huddled around a table in the shop - this one was a little bigger and more cafe-like, but the food was made and delivered from a stall across the road. It was also clearly more geared for tourists as there was a menu with information in English. Which was handy as we were given the option to pick whatever banh mi we fancied and I would never have known to pick Banh mi Thit Ga & Bo qua thai lat otherwise.

Banh mi is a hybrid dish developed by the Vietnamese with French influences. It’s a sandwich made in a baguette traditionally with pork, pate, pickled veg and various sauces but other varieties exist too. The sandwiches are chunky and sizeable so Hanh suggested we share one between two. As I’m not the biggest lover of pate, Pete agreed to split a honey roast chicken and avocado banh me with me instead and we placed our order, along with some fruit juice, and waited with anticipation.

Our fellow tour members were a friendly bunch: there were three other couples (two from London and one from Oregon) and it was lovely to hear about others’ travel plans. Even though we’d only been in Vietnam for 4 days, the other seemed to be right at the very beginning of their trips and we were all excited to get a bit of insight into authentic Vietnamese cuisine.

The banh mi arrived and it was wonderful! Crisp baguette with a fluffy inside, tasty veg which added a bit of crunch, and we sampled the various sauces on the table which claimed to be hot but were rather just pleasantly piquant. The banh mi quickly shot to the top of our yummy list and we very much intended to sample more on our trip.

The next stop on our trip was to try Bun cha - a dish of chargrilled pork belly and rice noodles that I had read about but never tasted before. Hanh took us to a place that initially seemed to be a few plastic seats out on the street - all occupied by hungry diners - and instead turned out to sprawl over four floors of the building. At least, we climbed 4 floors to find a set of unoccupied plastic tables and stools.

We were given a beer each and the food started to appear rapidly. Bun cha is served in a bowl of broth: you get chargrilled pork belly but also some more meatball-style pork wrapped in leaves. The broth is clear-ish and has green papaya in it, and into this you dump rice noodles from your plate alongside a squeeze of lemon, some garlic and some chilli.

I will admit that this wasn’t our favourite dish, not because it was bad, but just because it wasn’t to our taste. The broth was surprisingly sweet and I prefer more punchy flavours with spice. Im also not someone who loves to eat meat, so while the smokey, charred flavour of the pork was good, it wasn’t enough to make the dish for me. That being said, it was nice to try a Vietnamese classic in a proper local spot and I’m glad that we had the experience.

As we ate, Hanh kept up a cheerful patter, sharing tidbits of information about life and food in Vietnam and, specifically, in Hanoi. She marshalled us impressively, making sure we all got seated, could navigate the kamikaze traffic and got to try lots of dishes without being beset by enthusiastic hawkers.

Our next stop was a more unusual one and, as Hanh told us, was not for everyone. It was duck egg.

Except not like a tasty egg ready to eat. Not, it was one of those where it’s almost ready to hatch and instead of a nice white and yolk inside, you have a duck embryo, fully formed but soft and unborn. You could see it’s feet.

We opted out. Baby duck = baby yuck.

3 of the group did try. It looked quite grim but apparently just tasted of egg with a slightly meaty flavour, and of the ginger broth it was served in. We were almost convinced enough try except not.

Fortunately after that, we moved onto a slightly less controversial foodstuff. If a slightly more controversial premises in that we were set to partake at one of the illegal street joints where plastic chairs and tables are scattered into the road and lightweight and easy to remove if needed.

Although I guess if you’ve paid your coffee money, you’re OK.

The dish we were there to try was called Banh Cuon - and it was banging. My second favourite after the banh mi. Banh cuon are apparently breakfast snacks: chopped pork and mushroom is wrapped in rice paper, the little rolls are then steamed until the rice wrap looks gelatinous, white, wobbly and unappealing (bear with me) and then topped with crispy onions and herbs. Served with a dipping sauce.

I forgot to take a picture because once I’d tasted it, I just wolfed it down. But not worry as it wasn’t the prettiest dish anyway. However, it was super tasty, warm and savoury with a lovely crisp from the onions and a bit of tang from the sauce. We had two each but it’s possible I had one of Pete’s as well. Rumours abound.

The stall we were patronising also sold pho, and whole we weren’t there to sample that particular dish, the ladies brought out a bowl of the broth the pho is served from. They were keen for us to try it as it’s simmered for roughly 15 hours to imbue the dish with its famous flavour. It was indeed delicious and much more to my taste than the bun cha: rich and savoury and with a greater depth of flavour.

We also split a French brewed beer using a German recipe with a Vietnamese twist because when doesn’t that sound like a winning combination. Pete was unimpressed. It was cold though and as we were feeling hot and sticky after being out in the unrelenting humidity of the night air, cold gets you some brownie points.

We had two more stops left to cover on the tour: our savoury morsels (and giant face-sized bowls) were consumed and so we set about trying some sweetie treaties.

Our next stop was an ice cream place: WINNING! Hanh told us the shop was very popular in summer as it was so hot locals would often seek out the chilled desserts. I didn’t blame them! This was another illegal set up and my tiny plastic stool was so far into the road that if a car tried to make its way down the crowded narrow passage, I had a to stand up, gather up my seat and move to the side until it had passed.

Fortunately this only happened twice.

Hanh ordered 4 different desserts for us to try: first there was a bowl of mixed fruit with ice cream and shaved ice. I liked this mostly as the dragonfruit and mango were tasty and refreshing. Shaved ice always seems a bit flavourless to me, but soft serve vanilla swirled on top was good. Then there was a bowl of pandan sticky rice with ice cream and dried mango. This was called kem xoi and actually turned out to be my favourite. I really love the flavour of pandan - it’s basically cake flavour - and the sticky, glutinous texture of the rice was a good foil for the soft ice cream and the crispy hit of the dried mango.

The third dessert was durian and jackfruit serviced floating in coconut milk with chunks of jelly. It wasn’t the prettiest desert you’d ever seen but so hadn’t tried durian before so it was a good opportunity to eat some. Overall, I would say I felt ambivalent towards it: it was fine, but I wouldn’t seek it out. And given that it’s most famous for its truly disgusting smell, I didn’t think that was going to be an issue. Although I couldn’t really smell anything bad in the dish we were eating. The jackfruit was better: I’d only had it in a savoury context before as it’s often used as a meat substitute, but it worked well as sweet.

This was the dessert plonked at our end of the table while the other two had disappeared towards the others. After a while, I felt a bit disenchanted with our bowl of milk with fruit bits floating in it, and was more than happy to trade for the delights of the kem xoi. Yum!

The final dessert that appeared was like an Oreo sundae: lots of shaved ice was topped with ice cream, tapioca balls, Oreo biscuits and Oreo crumbs. It was tasty but we didn’t manage to finish it between us.

For our final stop of the tour, we wandered into the weekend car-free zone of Hanoi at the north end of the lake and found the city in full party mode. People flocked the streets, kids played with light up toys, there was music and dancing, lights flooded the lake and Hanoi was full on letting loose. It was amazing to think that the city does this every weekend as the atmosphere felt like something you might get a summer festival or maybe bonfire night with the food stalls and light-up gadgets.

We ended up in the exact same egg coffee spot that Sunday had taken us to that morning; clearly this was the place to go. So we creaked up the hidden staircase and found ourselves seated on some little stools while Hanh explained egg coffee to the rest of the group and they looked as confused as I had felt that morning, wondering what egg coffee would be.

Given that our earlier egg experience had involved premature baby ducklings, I think people felt a little bit wary. And yes, I thought about putting “eggsperience” then but I decided that this journal is too sophisticated for such nonsense.

Hanh said that she thought we might find the coffee quite strong and that we wouldn’t sleep if we drank it (seemed doubtful to us, but fine). However, she said if we liked, we could swap the coffee for hot chocolate.

Egg cocoa??? Now you’re talking! That absolutely seemed like my kind of drink.

So I did just that and it was magic! Incredibly thick, foamy and creamy, full of chocolate richness and happiness. I wondered if I could learn how to make egg chocolate when we returned home as I would be more than happy to consume one from time to time. Lush! It was more like a dessert than anything and I had to spoon the foam from my cup. Which I did gleefully.

And that was the end of the tour! Our little group said goodbye, thanked Hanh and we dispersed into the night, emerging from the little coffee shop into the thriving square to begin our walk back to the hotel.

We were back in our room at around half nine and we were very much in need of yet another shower to wash off the sweat from the sticky night air, and the bug spray. I had acquired some shiny new bites so I gave Sunday’s balm a whirl, and then we made tea and watched our nightly episode of Lost.

Somehow time had drifted on to midnight so we packed away our nice clean washing ready for the next day and settled down for the night. It was time to move on again and after we’d packed quite a bit into the day, we were ready to slumber.

posts.title: Honeymoon Infinity
posts.content:
Day 23

We had a much appreciated lazy morning; while we had set an alarm, I actually woke before it and read a little bit in bed with a cuppa. When we’d both come round and felt ready to face the day, we sauntered outside to go and investigate the buffet breakfast.

It’s becoming a bit of a theme for the lodge but the food was spectacular again. I suppose in many ways not that different from most of the breakfasts we’d had, but I’m a sucker for a good DIY yoghurt set up and loved making up a bowl loaded with peach, passionfruit, muesli and some sort of cinnamon nutty spread (think biscoff but not). In fact, I went back for seconds of that as it was so delectable - even the yoghurt alone was super smooth and creamy with an almost vanilla tang.

I also sampled the fried noodles, a spring roll and some of the breakfast cakes: there was a delicious banana bread affair and I scone where I initially thought they’d absolutely gone nuts with the raisins until I bit into it and discovered they were chocolate chips. Oops! Slathered in pineapple jam though, you can’t really go wrong.

We sauntered back to our room for the last time, packed up our bags and donned our swimwear. While we had to check out of our bungalow at eleven, we weren’t departing the lodge until 2:30. Definitely time for a swim in the infinity pool. Swimfinity. And some last minute photo taking. Sapa is too beautiful not to and the clouds were reflecting in the water and it was pretty much peak honeymoon stuff.

It was hotter than the day before - ouch - and even just walking the little paths around the hills to reception to drop off our keys made us sweat. We were therefore pretty thankful to finally slide into the pool. The water was far from cold but it was more refreshing than the sticky air!

Clouds billowed above the mountains, wreathing the views in haze and reflecting back into the water of the pool. The insects chirruped their way through elevensies and we swam for a bit before retreating to the shelter of the large parasols to read.

The pool has good showers so we could rinse off the chlorine and get changed, and then we headed for a light lunch before our journey back to Hanoi. Pete’s stomach had been feeling a bit delicate for the past couple of days - the unremitting heat definitely didn’t help, making everything feel quite energy sapping - and so he had some vegetable rice as a bland option, while I went for some falafel bites and some vegetable spring rolls. These were cold ones with strips of raw carrot, cucumber, purple cabbage and rice noodles, wrapped in a thin rice casing. They were light, refreshing and summery and it never hurts to get in a bit of veg.

Plus they brought some more of that amazing pesto so winning. I was going to really miss the pesto. And the mountain views and whatever, but really: the pesto.

It’s the besto.

After lunch, we set off up to reception to meet our minibus back to Hanoi. Even this short wake up the hill made us sweat again and we had taken to using the big umbrellas the lodge provided as parasols. We had gradually started to appreciate why the staff used them all the time.

I changed into my leggings for the journey in anticipation of the chill blast of air con and we piled into the minibus. We were one seat short so I sat up front next to the driver which on the one hand meant I didn’t get one of the comfy spacious seats but did mean that I got a great view out the front of the bus as we descended from the lofty heights of the mountains.

The journey was quite long and ultimately just a bit boring. I often sleep on long journeys but for some reason on this one, I felt wide awake. So I finished my audiobook, started another one, we had a stop after two and a half hours or so, and then finally we started approaching Hanoi. It was getting gradually darker and once we headed into the city outskirts, rain started to fall and I could see lightning flashing across the sky.

We were dropped back at our hotel around 7:45. It had stopped raining and it was a bit of a relief to get out of the bus and stretch our legs. The hotel staff were just as friendly and attentive as before and we were given a lime flavoured drink each and told that our room had been upgraded; a favour we graciously accepted.

We are also prepared to graciously accept mansions, yachts and piles of gold, just in case anyone is keeping count.

We dropped our bags in our room and we (I) were excited to see that the same lovely teaware was still present for evening cuppa purposes. We checked our map and found a branch of Circle K was only a couple of streets away and so we dived into the dark streets of Hanoi.

It was busy and there were lots of people about but we scurried past the stalls and restaurants, evading bikes and pedestrians and soon made it to the little shop. We picked up some noodles, milk (hurrah!), water and a couple of snacks. I bought a packet of “Cosy Wonderfulls” which are possibly the best named biscuits I have ever come across. They claim to be cashew and butter flavour which sounds promising, but not as promising as the name “Cosy Wonderfulls”.

Back in our room I had a nice hot shower and we settled in for the night. It had been a quietish day but a longish one and as Pete wasn’t feeling 100% we figured an early one wouldn’t do us any harm. So we made up our noodles and watched an episode of Lost with a cup of tea.

And in my case, some Cosy Wonderfulls.

I know you’re all dying to know, so here’s the verdict: Cosy Wonderfull is a round biscuit akin to a shortbread, on the thin side and crisp rather than crumbly or chewy. Possessed of a definite snap. On the top are a few pieces of chopped cashew but not enough to create a properly cashew-based flavour. They dunk well. So overall, they biscuits are quite nice but the name is the best thing about them.

They don’t compete with my favourite Indonesian biscuits, but as Pete pointed out, it’s probably not fair to expect Vietnamese stockists to keep in a stash of my Indonesian snack favourites.

The whole experience however was worth it for the chance to say - and write - Cosy Wonderfulls extremely regularly.

At this point, I assume it’s clear to everyone that I’m ekeing out content for the sake of it so perhaps I’d better call it a night. We had had a busy time planned for the next day and so turn in early for a good night’s sleep was the wise decision.

After just one more cup of tea with a Cosy Wonderfull.

It’s just too fun to say!

posts.title: Honeymoon Terraces
posts.content:
Day 22

Our alarm woke us from a good nights sleep at seven fifteen and we burrowed out from under the enveloping film of the mosquito net to get dressed.

Breakfast was delivered to our door at half past and my goodness what a breakfast it was: a big hamper - each - filled with scrambled eggs, sausage and bacon, yoghurt and fruit, cereal, pancakes and honey, cheese, ham, salami, toast, pastries, and apple and a banana. We also had an orange juice each and Pete put away a cappuccino while I tackled a quite exceptional hot chocolate.

We had no idea how anyone was meant to eat it all and while we did our best, I think we barely managed half of what was in there.

The glass of champagne to finish off was a bit of a treat however.

I made us a tea each in the room and we used a little of the milk we’d been given for the cereal. The only slight issue being that Pete has mistaken it for yoghurt and dumped some peaches in syrup into it. But who doesn’t want tea with peach milk?

The cloud was low obscuring they mountains but we could still see down into the valley below as we got ready for a hike, suncreamed up and swung on our day packs. Then we walked over the hill to reception for eight thirty to meet our trekking group for the day.

It was sweltering in the sticky air and after a huge breakfast, I don’t think either of us felt 100% jazzed for a day of walking. But that’s what we’d come to the mountains for and so hiking it was going to be.

We met our guide and it turned out we were the only ones foolish enough to venture out on an expedition. She explained to us that we would drive to a local village about 45 minutes away and pick up the trail from there, hiking about 7km in total and having a BBQ lunch half way.

And off we went! Actually, the drive helped: we got to see amazing mountain views, it was cooler in the van than outside and, crucially, we had time to digest our breakfast! As we drove, our guide told us a little bit about the different ethnic groups who live in the region; there are 5 main ones including the Hmong and the Dao and there are also lots of cultures within these groups, such as the Black Hmong who have roots in Laos, and the Red Dao. The lodge employs most of its staff from local groups so that it operates in partnership with the people and their way of life, and our guide told us lots about her daily life and experiences too.

The mountain roads threw up wonderful vistas over rice terraces and up to soaring, cloud-topped peaks, but they were also tricky to navigate. Bumpy and single-lane, it was often a challenge to squeeze past when we met other vehicles. At one point we came head to head with a truck and the drivers all got out (including a van behind us) to have a very serious and important discussion about how to proceed. They managed it in the end but it might have been the narrowest gap between passing vehicles I’ve ever seen. We applauded our driver!

We arrived in a small village and started our trek through mountain passages. The heat was immense and we were soon sweating through our clothes and sun cream as we toiled uphill. Yikes! We also acquired two local hangers on: two women who trailed us for at least half of our hike in a vain attempt to sell us things. They peppered me with questions as we walked and it was a little strange.

After a while the path flattened out and we could admire the wonderful views down into the valley as the river snaked on through. We often had to jump to one side to let motorbikes pass and cows and little calves regularly clogged the way, ambling off slowly when given a bit of encouragement from our guide.

She showed us lots of different local plants: yellow ginger which smelled amazing, one that was super poisonous to everyone, people and livestock, with the exception of goats, and one that we could chew which had a sour, citrus-like flavour.

After about 3km, we reached a small riverside hut and had a short break - even though we’d walked for barely and hour we were totally grateful for the sit down as the heat was energy sapping. It had been 29 degrees when we left the lodge at half eight, so we could only imagine what the temperature had reached as the sun got stronger and burned through the clouds.

We had a little further to go up to a nearby waterfall. Standing in front of the spray was lovely and cooling and we enjoyed being next to the water on the shade.

The rest of our route was back the way we’d come. We chatted with our guide and she was equally curious about us: how long had we been married, how old were we, why didn’t we have children and so on. She told us she had married very old (at 21) as she had wanted to learn languages and get a job first. She had two children - she showed us their pictures - and it was also interesting to swap stories of how we’d managed the pandemic. It seems the stay at home order had been very similar in the Sapa region and she had had to keep her small children at home.

She told us a lot about her culture but we didn’t quite follow it all: there were various rituals involving buffalo, rice wine and kidnapping and whether families will join together depending on if the woman wants to get married. She also showed us a leaf you could blow into to make a squeaky noise to show someone you’re attracted to them. Pete couldn’t get a sound out of his but I managed a few squeaks. Not quite the virtual tune our guide could manage, but a sound at least.

Pete blamed his leaf. Until I made it squeak.

Not to worry, it’s nice to know I have marriage options in Vietnam, but I figured I’d stick with Pete for the time being.

We arrived back at the river hut and our guide took us down to the river. A group of men were hard at work moving supplies around as recently, lots of pools were being built beside the water for salmon farms. Apparently this is a relatively new industry but popular and lucrative.

There was an extremely dilapidated foot bridge over the river that our guide insisted we test out, so I took one for the team and venture out a few steps for a quick photo before returning to safety.

We stepped up through the rice terraces towards the hut, hopping over stepping stones to avoid the water pools through which the rice grew. The crop was a couple of weeks off harvest and we could see the slightly yellowing grains waving from the tops of the stalks. The leaves were such a luscious green and the rows of rice looked so beautiful in their orderly progression up the slope.

We could smell lunch being prepared as soon as we arrived at the hut and we were sent upstairs where we could sit on the little balcony that overlooked the river. Before long, enormous plates of barbecue appeared and once again, we found ourselves wondering how much of the feast we’d actually be able to get through.

This question quickly became more relevant when yet another plate appeared to accompany our meal. And so we tucked in: there was sausage, beef and fish, long chunks of cucumber and apple, chargrilled courgette, aubergine and mushroom and to go with all this, we had some sweet chilli sauce and an amazing thick, dark, dipping sauce. We had no idea what it was but it tasted amazing on everything. (Except the apple: I didn’t dip the apple into it). We also had some crush peanuts which we could dip into after the sauce and they added a lovely nutty crunch to each mouthful.

One of our favourite things one the plate was the sticky rice. It sounds daft as I suppose this was the accompaniment rather than the meal, but it had been cooked inside tubes of bamboo and so had a appearance a bit like polystyrene packing chips. But it held its shape perfectly, was ideal for hoovering up the dipping sauce and peanuts and consequently was fabulously tasty.

I did enjoy the moment when Pete tried a chunk of an unknown vegetable and made a face: he wasn’t sold. I tried it and identified it as mushroom - big solid, almost meaty pieces of mushroom - which made sense because, as Pete pointed out: he doesn’t like mushrooms.

The feast of course defeated us and we hoped that the men who had been working the river could perhaps enjoy the rest. We thanked the cook and set off to walk back the way we’d come to the village. It was hotter than ever and we sweated buckets as the sun reached its zenith. We passed even more cows munching the greens along the side of the path and played guess the age of the tiny calf: Pete was way off with a month, I was bang on with 2 days. #knowyourcows

The tiny ones were super cute and spindly though.

We made it back to the village much more quickly than the journey out, but we didn’t really pause and there was more downhill for which we were thankful after toiling upwards on our way out. To end out walk, our guide took us for a break at the Riverside Lodge: the budget sister hotel to ours situated in the village itself.

We walked through the village and we could see lots of locals in their brightly coloured, red head scarves which looked cheerful and festive. Children waved and called hello, chickens scratched around looking for tasty morsels and people were hard at work, laying out corn and herbs to dry in the sun. Our guide told us that different crops are grown at different times in the year: when the rice is done, corn can grow, and lots of different herbs and plants are harvested from the jungle which costs the upper slopes of the mountains above the rice terraces. Lots of the locals are farmers and families often pitch in together to work the land and gather the various crops in different seasons.

Once we reached the lodge, crossing a somewhat sturdier footbridge, we were more than happy to plonk down in the airy dining room and order a fruit juice. Decorated in similar style to our hotel, the design was minimal but beautiful, the room was open to the river where small children played and swam and it was blissful to be in some shade with a cold drink and rest.

We passed the time quite happily until the van came back to pick us up and so we wandered back through the village with another couple of guests who were hitching a ride and made the journey back up the snaking mountain roads to our lodge.

We were extremely happy to dive into a cool shower back in our room and Pete made us a round of tea. Minus the peach milk this time, but I almost think the morning tea was better with the fruity milk rather than the creamer powder which just isn’t the same. The brew was very welcome however and we lounged quite happily enjoying the drink while I got to work on my journal.

When 5:00pm rolled around we stepped out of our bungalow and made our way to the spa: massage time! We were having an hour’s treatment each and when we’d skirted the hilltop and entered the spa, I was immediately put into the unique spa-zone feeling that places like that have. The air was scented, everyone smiles and speaks very softly, we were given a chilled drink and tinkly music played while the insects provided a live nature track in the background. Blissful.

We both chose the same treatment - an ayerverdic massage - and we were given 4 scented oils to choose from. I went with lavender while Pete chose chamomile. Then we were shown to our treatment room by the therapist.

The two tables were draped in soft towels and were set up facing a huge picture window looking out of the misty mountaintops which was incredible. We put on the comedy disposable pants and lay down fully ready to start relaxing forthwith.

The massages were amazing - out therapists didn’t pull their punches so to speak and I actually think my arms got longer. They kneaded our muscles in our legs, arms, back and shoulders, finishing with an intense face and scalp massage. I felt loose-limbed and boneless afterwards; we’d both enjoyed it and Pete felt that for once he’s actually been able to get the firm pressure he really likes.

We decided to ignore the advice about not washing off the oil for a couple of hours, and instead went for a shower and swim in the pools. Quite a few people were enjoying the view and taking pictures in the upper pool so we headed down to the lower one which was empty. It was lovely to just chill in the water and paddle about as the sky deepened to a slightly darker shade of dusk. The insects were performing a cracking dusk chorus and yet not a single one disturbed the water of the pool. We were stumped as to how they keep the pools big free.

After our swim, we wandered back through the terraces to our bungalow for a shower before dinner. I was actually starting to get a bit peckish and so I was jazzed to find housekeeping had been and left us a banana leaf which read “sweet dreams” and a wooden box containing a little square of cake each.

We think it was maybe banana, but it had a very squidgy, dense texture that was more brownie-like than cake like. Whatever it was it was yummy and I thought I could get used to nightly cake being brought to me. I mentioned this to Pete in case he was eager to do this for me every day, but he wasn’t keen. Shame.

We popped over to the Stilt restaurant for dinner around eight, spotting a little frog en route, and once again sitting upstairs under the thatch and high beams. We selected a variety of little dishes off the tapas-style menu and found the food to be exceptional. We shared some prawn crackers and were brought some bread with the amazing pesto-style sauce again, and then I opted for roasted cashews and some crispy mushroom spring rolls while Pete went for pumpkin soup and crispy pork spring rolls. We also got some falafel each and it was all superb: fresh, hot, great textures, amazing flavours and with dips and sauces that just enhanced the whole experience. Truly delicious!

So much so that we also picked a dessert each. I had a chocolate concoction which did look a bit of a splodge on the plate but tasted fab, and Pete had frozen white chocolate cheesecake. This came in a jar which he was miffed about as I’m given to understand that it was tricky to prise out, but nonetheless we enjoyed our meal enormously and I was already looking forward to our next meal with anticipation.

We stepped out into the dark night and wandered slowly back to our bungalow. Flashes of light flickered across the sky every so often and we wondered what they were: lights? Flash photography? But then a rumble of thunder sounded distinctly and we realised we were looking at far-off lightning bouncing off the clouds. It was quite something. There was no rain to speak of and evening was warm with a faint breeze which made it hard to imagine thunderstorms taking hold.

Back in our room we pretty much just flopped. We were full, hiking in the heat of the day had worn us out and the massages had caused our muscles to surrender. Basically, we just needed tea and Lost in bed.

Actually, there was something really immersive about watching lost in Sapa: cocooned in our mosquito net den and with the insect orchestra tuning up outside as a counterpoint to the thunder, it felt like exactly the right environment to allow us to dive into a mystery island adventure.

Once Lost and tea were finished we settled in to read a little bit, unwinding after a full day in the mountains and slowly drifting towards sleep. Sapa really was a magical place and I found myself wishing it wasn’t our last night at the lodge. However, I knew there would be more adventures to come and more locations on the horizon and with that thought, I snuggled down under the blanket to enjoy a comfortable night.

knowyourcows

posts.title: Honeymoon Mountains
posts.content:
Day 21

Three weeks into our adventuremoon and we had another early start - this time 6:00am. I had slept a little fitfully, my brain waking me up every so often in anticipation of my alarm, and I dreamed of sleeping through it and missing our wake up call.

However, our alarms did go off and we got up, dressed and packed and were out of our room in approximately 9 minutes. While our lift wasn’t arriving until half past, we had to check out of the hotel and pay for our stay, and scarf down some breakfast.

The hotel had kindly to offered to open breakfast a bit early for us at 6:15 and it turned out we weren’t the only guests with an early pick up as several people scurried to partake. We munched down some eggs, bread rolls and fruit - including passionfruit, hurrah! - and finished just in time to be collected by the minibus. Win(ibus)!

The seats in the bus were large and comfy, we were given a banana and a cereal bar each and then we set off. We picked up 5 more travellers around Hanoi and then departed the city to make the journey to Sapa.

According to a brief video presentation, this was a journey of around 5 hours, most of which would be on a highway which headed northwest to China - Sapa is in fact only 50km or so away from the Chinese border. And so we had a bit of a doze, listened to music, podcasts and audiobooks and generally let the world go by. We made a stop to break the journey and were entertained by a small puppy gambolling around and generally having a lovely time playing, and then it was back on the bus for the end of the journey.

The last hour was up, up, up into the mountains; the sky clouded over and we really climbed. The mountains were green, often cut into steep rice terraces and streams wound their way through the bottoms of the valleys. We passed the occasional dam and an awful lot of large cows meandering the roads, sluggish in the heat. As the valley floor dropped away further and further, clouds started to wreath the tops of the peaks and haze meant that the mountains marched away blurring into the distance. And still we climbed.

Until finally we arrived at our destination: Topas Eco Lodge: a paradise in the mountains.

We were met at reception with a cold drink and a cold flannel (which my sleepy brain initially took to be a giant muffin as it was chocolate brown and coiled up into a bun). We ran through the things we had booked as part of our package and then we were escorted to our room.

The lodge is situated across two peaks; even though we were high up, plenty of other mountaintops reached for the heavens around us in every direction, stacked one atop the either until they were indistinguishable from the mist and cloud. We had both thought that it might be cooler at altitude but we were wrong with a vengeance: it was fiercely hot.

Must be because we were closer to the sun #physicsinnit

We followed the concierge along a series of winding stone paths between rice terraces and she pointed out the spa, the pools, the restaurant and reminded us to keep our room door close in case we wanted to share with lots of bugs. And actually we could hear them chirruping and chirping all around, hidden among the lush greenery. A couple of chicken stumbled across the path, we spied exotic birds too and we walked through the lodge vegetable garden and past the solar panels.

Our room was a little stone bungalow which was beautifully appointed with a comfy bed, chairs, tea making facilities (yay!) and best of all, a balcony with insane views across the peaks. We’d also been given a bottle of fizz for our honeymoon. Whoop!

Once we were settled and sorted, it was almost one and we decided to hit the restaurant in search of a light bite before hitting the pool. The restaurant - named the Stilt house - was a lovely wooden building and we sat upstairs under the thatched beams in the quiet cool. A quick skim down the menu landed us both immediately on the same dish: falafel banh mi. Genius: we ordered 2 and after a quick debate, decided not to order anything else.

Which was a wise decision: despite the menu recommending 2-3 dishes per person, the banh was enormous. It was also FABULOUS.

A large soft baguette had been jam packed full of falafel and salad, topped with sauces and coriander and there were chips on the side as well. We reckoned double cooked at least from the combination of fluffy and crunchy.

I traded my tomato for Pete’s coriander because marriage means that you can, we we both attempted to get our faces around these extreme sandwiches. Challenging but worth the attempt many times over and even more enhanced by the garlicky, pesto-like herb paste that we’d been given.

I had a fresh juice with orange, mango, carrot and turmeric to wash it all down which was very refreshing and while we were pretty stuffed, lunch boded well for the remaining meals in the lodge.

Time for a swim and so we gathered our things and hit the pool.

And by pool I mean: infinity pool!

It was stunning: the water seemed to stretch across to the very mountains themselves and it was quite warm to swim in. We bobbed at the edge, gazing out over the view and enjoying being in the water...and of course getting some photos because it’s one of the most photogenic things I’ve basically ever seen. Fact.

It was pretty quiet with just one or two other people and I had a swim in the lower pool as well. This in theory being the cold one but it was barely any cooler than main pool above.

Even with the cloud cover, the sun was quite intense for the middle of the afternoon and so we eventually got out and popped back to our room for a shower. Then it was time for our included picnic because out schedule is nothing if not jam packed.

The staff had set out a little spread for us on the grass, laid on a blanket under a tree. It was possibly the most love island thing I’ve ever seen. We kept hats and sunnies on against the sun, and leaned against the cushions, kicking off our shoes and investigating our treats. We had a large fruit plate, a pot of chocolate dipping sauce and another bottle of fizz to enjoy (I swear we were collecting them) but as the sun was making us feel fuzzy, we decided to save the bubbles. We tucked into apple, watermelon, melon and pineapple, cut into pretty shapes and I devoured the chocolate which Pete declined to show an interest in. There were also some tiny sour plum-like things: they were bitter and green and once we’d had an experimental nibble, we decided they were a no.

It was lovely, sitting among the greenery and munching on refreshing fruit. But after a while, the sun got to be a bit much and we decided to retreat, leaving behind the ants and a curious grasshopper, snacking the fizz bucket as we left.

We decided to spend a couple of hours resting in our room as we were both pretty tired. And when I thought about it, we’d had a series of days travelling, the night ahead would make it six nights in six different beds and the heat and humidity were also taking no small toll on our energy levels. Pete was battling a headache that wouldn’t budge and we didn’t want to push ourselves to do things just for the sake of it.

And actually, it did us a world of good. I caught up on some journalling, we could still see the mountain views from our room and it felt wonderfully luxurious just to lounge in the air con. Sometimes you just have to give yourself a bit of time.

As the sun was setting, I popped out to fill up our water bottles at the bar and to get some pictures of the mountain glowing in golden hour. The views were truly staggering - it seems daft to keep saying the mountain views were good but a) they were indescribably beautiful, b) they changed and shifted with the weather and the light and c) I don’t think I’ve ever stayed anywhere quite like the lodge where the panoramas are staring at you from every and all directions.

Behind the lodge, one pointed peak rose like a child’s drawing of a mountain: steep sides and pointy tops. The wind rippled the rice parading in its order rows up the terraces. Peaks faded out into ever more abstract grey lines in the the distance, losing detail to the haze and eventually vanishing into cloud. And the sun glowed, illuminating the sky and the horizon with soft golden light. The word lush didn’t do it justice.

I sat on the terrace outside the bar for a while, drinking in the scene and writing a little more in my journal. Trying to work out if the lodge was indeed the most beautiful place I had ever stayed in.

I returned to our room and found Pete on the balcony. Housekeeping had dropped round some biscuits - nice! - and we sat for a while, munching and enjoying our own private mountain landscapes.

Dinner time rolled round and we loaded up with all the bug spray we could muster and stepped into the dark evening. We would be having a barbecue dinner in the pavilion that evening, and we made our way to the little outdoor seating area, each little gazebo sheltering two or three tables. The insects where making an absolute racket, seemingly competing over who could make the most noise and we could pick our cicadas, grasshoppers, all manner of chirrupy things and we also thought probably frogs. I mean, there was plenty of water irrigating the terraces to keep them happy!

We took our seats and the waitress showed us the menu; it was a set dinner which was just as well as we couldn’t understand a word of the Vietnamese written on the page. We figured we’d just wait and see what appeared.

Candles were lit and while the odd moth flickered past and an enormous grasshopper rested its legs on the beams above us, we weren’t that bothered by insects. We could hear them get fried by the light machines every so often but as long as they didn’t besiege us with bites, we were game.

Our started arrived and it was huge: Vietnamese snails in a sticky chilli sauce, a big platter of ceviche and prawn crackers with some sort of dip.

We’d both had snails before but not Vietnamese ones and while I knew they were a thing from a food program I’d watched, it wasn’t a dish I had anticipated seeking out. Nevertheless, here was our chance to try them! Verdict? Well the sauce was yummy but the snails were so chewy that I felt like after a while you had to sort of give up and just gulp them down. Each one was two or three time the size of the ones I’d eaten before; they took quite a bit of wiggling to get them out of their shells and the flavour was mildly fishy, a bit like a prawn or a mussel.

But with so much more chew! And the problem with that is when you’ve had to prise it from its shell and spend about 45 minutes chewing it, its really hard not to be very aware that you’re eating a snail. So not bad, but I don’t think I’d choose them again. We ate two each - they were big! - and both opted out of snail number three.

The ceviche was good however as we’re the prawn crackers but I feel like they’re kind of a given.

The main was another huge serving, and perhaps somewhat less Vietnamese. We had barbecued aubergine, sweetcorn and veggie skewers (chargrilled and very tasty!), a green salad, a bowl of mash and a steak. I opted out of steak - it’s not something I love anyway and I assumed quite correctly that there would be enough food without it. Pete enjoyed his though.

They also brought us a little bowl of the awesome garlic-herb-pesto stuff we’d had a lunch which I dolloped liberally over everything.

Dessert was a fruit plate and a passionfruit cream mousse served inside a passionfruit. That was particularly delectable and I could have eaten about six of them as it was light and silky with perfect balance between sweet and tart.

After dinner we picked our way through the darkened paths, past the little open air cinema which seemed quaint in principle but which probably involved a huge number of bugs in practice, and filled out bottles at the bar. Then we headed back to our room to have an early night.

I made a round of tea and fell in love with yet another tea set. There were jars of loose leaf tea, mini teabags to make yourself, a carved wooden teaspoon and a pair of beautifully tactile ceramic mugs.

I get that the point of going to Vietnam is not the tea sets, but seriously, I feel like they’re onto a good thing here. Best hotel tea set up EVER.

Except for the lack of milk, but if you’re providing proper loose leaf tea, you’re allowed a bit of grace there and so I just filched some creamer out of my bag. We showered to remove the layer of bug spray, watched an episode of Lost and by half ten we were tucked up in bed under our mosquito netting canopy hoping to get a very solid night’s sleep, catch up with our rest and feel full of the joys of the mountains the next day. And so we drifted off to the symphony of the insects.

physicsinnit

posts.title: Honeymoon Airport
posts.content:
Day 20

Strangely enough, the airport hotel room turned out to be one of the nicest ones we’d stayed in. There wasn’t a window which didn’t really matter, but it did mean that the room was dark and quiet. It was also relatively spacious, had tea making facilities and an excellent shower. Lush!

The wifi was strong too so we looked into booking a taxi from Hanoi airport to our hotel. Our hotel had actually messaged Pete a couple of times to ask about this and we’d tried to take them up on the offer as the price was reasonable. But as they didn’t get back to us, Pete spent a frustrating 20 minutes wrangling with various online booking systems, finally achieving success and sending the payment. Handy as we didn’t have any local currency.

Of course, as soon as he’d done this, the hotel got back to us. Too late folks, sorry!

Once we were up and ready, showers showered and tea drunk, we emerged back into the airport in search of breakfast. A bit of wander showed us that there were loads of options if you’re after a slap up Chinese, but if you want a cuppa and pastry, you aren’t going to be lucky.

In the end we opted for subway, grabbing a breakfast sandwich each and a tea, which was hot and reasonably tasty and cheap. Problem solved.

Of course, it was after breakfast when things got all twisted up again. We queued to go through passport control but our boarding passes wouldn’t scan and we were sent to the check in desks where the queues were enormous. No amount of haranguing the queue automatons would get them to help us, the check in machines were worse than useless as instead of doing anything, they told you to check in online and even though I tried to do this, the website said our flight had already departed. Which, yes, the first leg of our booking, but the second hadn’t.

ARGH!!!!

The stupid thing is: we were checked in, we had printed boarding passes, we had dropped our bags: all we needed to do was go through security. And yet we were made to go through the entire rigmarole for NOTHING. Suckfest.

I will admit that perhaps my irritation was disproportionate to the situation but seriously. If we missed our flight because of this, I felt like I would actually need to scratch somebody’s eyes out.

We split up to join different queues, but we’re both sent off to join yet another queue in a different part of the airport. Which made no sense. We joined different queues again and crossed our fingers. There was still an hour to go until boarding but the queues barely seemed to move and none of the check in staff seemed willing or able to to anything to help or answer our questions, just telling us to queue.

Eventually I reached the front of my queue and we had to go through the rigmarole of passport, vaccine status, proof of flight out of Singapore all over again which was also ridiculous as we were already checked in. But eventually we were given new boarding passes and could go back to rejoining the passport control queue.

Then there were two rounds of security for reasons unknown but at least they were relatively snappy, and finally, after a miserable hour and a half, we were at our gate. Time to put on a shiny new positive attitude.

We did another round of passports, boarding passes and visas, and then a second round of passports (technically about our 28th go round of passports but they sure love looking at them in KL) and then we slumped in seat to wait for boarding and I polished off the last of my favourite Indonesian biscuits. YUM.

We boarders the plane and took off: the first hour or so was pretty turbulent which always makes me nervous. I felt like the bottom dropped out of my stomach. Things seemed to calm down a bit after that and I buried myself in the next Harry Potter film to try and take mind off things.

We landed in Vietnam at 3:00pm local time - only about 2 years and 4 months later than originally planned! We cleared through immigration quite quickly, grabbed our bags and went to look for our ride. Interestingly, border control in Indonesia and in Malaysia had demanded to see our Vietnamese visas, but Vietnam never asked about them. Classic.

Pete managed to get in touch with our driver via WhatsApp and we arranged a spot to meet. Before long, we were bowling along to Hanoi towards our hotel for the evening.

It was interesting watching the city slide past the windows. It had lots of the same features of cities in south east Asia we’ve visited before - crowds of motorbike, lots of stalls which spill into the street and so on - but it just looked a bit more put together than Medan and Malang, and the Indonesian cities we’d left behind. There were some quite obvious colonial nods here and there and we were looking forward to exploring and making our first foray into Vietnam!

We pitched up at our hotel which was very welcoming and the receptionist gave us lots of useful information. We clattered up to our room to regroup and plan our evening and before too long we were changed and ready to dive head first into Hanoi!

It was already gone 5:00pm and as we hadn’t eaten since our breakfast subway, we were pretty eager to get chomping. But first we needed cash. The first 3 ATMs we visited that were listed on our map were non-existent so Pete decided we should aim for a bank instead. There we had more luck, found a functioning ATM and withdrew about 4 million dong. RICH!

Our next port of call was for a pre-dinner snack as we were eager to try banh goi: little pasty/samosa/empanada type goodies stuffed with pork and whatnot. Our map let us down again though and we couldn’t find the morsel in question. Instead, we ended up at the side of Hoan Kiem lake and decided to walk around it. It was super hot (36 degrees) and we were already sticky with sweat but it was so nice to be out after a long period of travel that we didn’t really mind.

It was golden hour and loads of people were out enjoying the last few rays of the day. We walked past 3 groups of ladies doing a sort of combo of dancing and exercise - a bit like a slow motion zumba, or possibly tai chi to music - and actually they weren’t the only ones using the lakeside path to get active. However, possibly our favourite moment was when a small girl approached us and launched expectantly in with “Hello what’s your name?”.

She must have been around 6 or 7 and clutched a sheet of paper and a pencil. I told her my name and spelled it for her and she wrote it down carefully.

She then proceeded down a list of questions that she had on her sheet: where was I from, how long was I in Hanoi, what was my favourite thing in Hanoi (I was frantically grasping for any local knowledge from what was approximately one hour of personal experience) and where was I going next. She also asked who I was with and carefully wrote down “huspand” in the box as I couldn’t find a way to communicate the letter B.

Pete is now my lovely huspanda and he can like it.

In fact, midway through my interview, a small boy cautiously approached Pete and started asking him the same list of questions.

They had clearly been tasked with approaching a particular number of foreigners to practise their English and to write down the information in the grid. But they were so sweet and polite and unerringly earnest that it was really fun to help them out. I asked the girl interviewing me if it was a school project which she confirmed.

While Pete was finishing up his questionnaire, two more girls hovered in my vicinity looking hopeful, so I answered questions for them too. Probably this is what it’s like being famous.

Assuming all reporters are basically really adorable primary school children with excellent manners.

Once we’d answered all the questions put to us, my huspanda and I wandered on around the rest of the lake, enjoying the colours in the sky fading through pale blues, pinks and yellows and admiring the bridge over to the central island. Greenery surrounded the water, pink grasses and reeds waves softly and fruit sellers started to populate the area with their stall and wares.

Time for dinner! We were starving and headed off to find Cha Ca Thang Long. I had read about this place on a food blog a few days ago, and it was also on the list of recommended places our hotel had given us. Add in that it was within easy walking distance and we were sold.

Cha Ca is in fact the name of the dish we were after. We were a little confused when it came to finding the entrance, but a chap outside helped us and we were soon inside and gesturing for a table for 2. It was busy but they shuffled us into the back on a table by the counter and the waiter that served us just held up 2 fingers to check we were both eating. We confirmed yep, food for 2 and without having seen any sort of menu or anything, we hoped the right thing would come.

And boy did it ever! Cha Ca is a catfish dish cooked and served at the table, and as lots of little pots of extras and toppings started arriving, the waiter lit up the gas ring between us and got to work. He added the catfish to the pan where it cooked and sizzled, coated in turmeric and other spices to make it super delicious. The smell wafting across to us was immense. On top of this he added a huge pile of dill and spring onion which gradually cooked down, and he stirred it with chopsticks occasionally. Every so often, he’d pop away to sort someone else, gesturing to us not to do anything, and then coming back again.

Once it was ready, he showed us how to serve ourselves. We each had a little bowl into which we first put some sticky vermicelli. On top of that went some of the fried greens and a chunk or two of catfish from the pan. Then we used the condiments, adding fresh spring onion, coriander, peanuts and finally, a spoonful of fish sauce infused with chilli.

Scoff and repeat until your pan is empty. YUM!!!

It was so good - possibly my favourite meal of the trip so far! - and after the challenges we’d faced trying to get places and try food in Indonesia, it was a welcome buzz to be able to wander round a new city and access some of its tastiest delights. 11 out of 10 would recommend.

This feats plus a drink each set us back £12 which were pretty happy with and we ventured back out into the now-dark streets feeling very satisfied.

We decided to go and find somewhere for a drink and Pete led the way to an area the hotel receptionist had described as “beer street” where apparently there were lots of bars and you could sit in the street, enjoy the night sir and put away a cheeky beverage.

We weren’t exactly sure which was the right street so Pete picked a place at random in the end. I say at random: there was a big red sign saying Peter so maybe he was a tiny bit unknowingly subconsciously influenced or something.

But probably not.

We ordered a beer each and perched on the tiny plastic stools at the side of the road. This is a classic part of pretty much any Vietnamese business: child-size plastic chairs and stools at low tables filling up the edges of the streets to pack in the punters.

The place wasn’t busy and it was so lovely to just sit and evening the evening, chatting and laughing. We’d kind of missed doing this in Indonesia we realised, as it hadn’t really been possibly partly because lots of the places we visited didn’t serve drink, and partly because I was such a pain to get anywhere. It was fun to watch the world go by too: young tourists labouring under massive backpacks - our favourites being a couple where the guy carried his own massive backpack and pulled his girlfriend’s suitcase. Street sellers tried to flog us bits and bobs, a couple of guys delivered some live crabs and crayfish to the tanks behind us and motorbikes trundled past, weaving this way and that through the street clutter.

It was still very warm even though the sun had long since set, but a bit of a breeze was welcome. We finished our drinks, made a quick stop at Circle K and headed back to our hotel.

Circle K is the Vietnamese equivalent of Indomart, which is the Indonesian 7 Eleven and so we figured it would be good to get the May of the land and choose some snackos. We opted for a packet of ice cream flavour Oreos, some M&Ms and an ice cream sandwich each, strawberry for Pete and chocolate for me.

We ate the ice creams as we wandered back and it was lovely to munch on something cold. Plus they were super yummy: the ice creams were shaped like fish, had a layer of flavoured syrup inside and were enclosed in a soft, wafer-like coating. I knew I would be on the look out for another one during our time in Vietnam!

Back at the hotel, I got up to day with my journal before making a round of tea. The hotel room came with really beautiful teacups and o developed secret designs on them. To distract myself, Pete and I watched an episode of Lost and attacked our snackies: the verdict was a thumbs down from me on the Oreos, while Pete thought they were OK, and the M&Ms were just averagely fine, as M&Ms usually are. I’d just fancied a bit of chocolate really.

Around half eleven, we gathered our things together and got ready for bed. We had another early start in the morning as we would be leaving Hanoi for a couple of days to visit Sapa. And with a 6:00am alarm, it’s always a good idea to try and prioritise a bit of sleep! So with bags mostly packed (and the teacups still safely in the possession of the hotel) we settled down for the night.

posts.title: Honeymoon Mansion
posts.content:
Day 18

I woke before our alarm and watched the lizards play on the ceiling until one hid inside the light fitting and one hid inside the air conditioner. They flipping love an appliance do those little lizards.

I read a little, enjoying lounging in bed and eventually Pete woke too. It was nice to shut off the alarms and just lie for a bit.

At nine we headed over to the lodge for breakfast, ordering tea and scrambled gags on toast again. The scrambled egg sandwich was just as delicious as last time - seriously epic stuff - but the tea had been completely drowned in sugar which the waitress proudly announced when she brought our drinks.

It set our teeth on edge! We drank it anyway, leaving at least a spoonful of sugar floating around in the bottom of the cups undissolved (seriously, how much sugar was in it?) and looked forward to brewing up a better cup ourselves that evening. There was also the lurking possibility of acquiring milk...

We packed our bags ready to depart Bukit Lawang and waiting for our ride to begin the journey back to Medan. The same driver as before showed up bang on time and we checked out, shaking hands and saying thank yous before loading up our backpacks and hitting the road.

We hadn’t gone far when we had to stop at the side of the road to give the driver the address; he didn’t seem super confident about this but figured I could help with navigation if necessary nearer the city.

A motorbike overtook us and pulled up in front and it turned out to be the chap from the lodge who’d chased us down. He had a rapid conversation with our driver through the window and they both laughed before turning to us and saying he’d forgotten to hand over petrol money to the driver. The driver in turn laughed, explaining to us: “He forget, I forget! No petrol, no drive!”

He wasn’t wrong.

The first couple of hours we slow and over the little rural bumpy roads peppered with potholes. I listened to my audiobook and dozed a little - I have a hard time staying awake on transport it seems - until a little after midday when we stopped for the driver to have a smoke.

Then we were on our way again, rumbling through the outskirts of Medan in heavier and heavier traffic.

We pulled up to our hotel at around half one - we had managed to direct the driver for the last section of the trip and he told us the name of the hotel had changed which was why he hadn’t known where it was.

We were a little early to check in so plopped down in the lobby to wait for our room. However, it didn’t take long for a room to be ready, and while we had to faff around with the lift for a while as our key cards didn’t work, reception sorted us out and we we able to shrug off our bags in our room and slump onto the bed. Phew!

We sorted out our trek laundry which needed doing badly enough that we decided to pay the inflated hotel prices and get it down overnight. Meanwhile, a quick recce of the surrounding area online revealed a few Indomart and so forth within walking distance, and we were soon off out in search of some sustenance.

Of course, we had neglected to consider that walking distance is a meaningless term in these wretched Indonesian cities where you can’t get anywhere on foot. There’s no pavement, the traffic doesn’t stick to its lanes - or the road - and anything that might plausibly be a gap is instantly filled with motorbikes buzzing around wherever they like.

HOW DOES ANYONE GET ANYWHERE EVER???

We traipsed around, for a bit, walking in broken gutters and dodging an unpleasant smelling stream of water and trying to make progress, but it was about as effective as banging our heads against the wall. The place we were initially aiming for was across a 4 lane road and after standing forlornly next to it for a while with no visible means of crossing, we abandoned that. Pete had marked a couple of other places on his map, but after tramping around for twenty minutes or so in the rain - because of course it was raining - we had to abandon these places and decided to go back to the hotel and regroup using the wifi. Nightmare.

Fortunately, our route back happened to take us past an Alfamart. Not quite as good as Indomart in our opinion, but still able to supply tea, milk-like liquid (we still aren’t sure what it is but it does the job), our favourite biscuits, some noods and some crisps. Plus water. Shopping list complete.

We trailed back to the hotel with our spoils and made a bit of DIY lunch. The noodles were a different brand to the ones we usually buy. On the up side, they came with their own forks and mine had 4 sachets of different powders and sauces to add, but they weren’t as good as our usual. However, they were perfectly tasty and filled us up, and with a cup of tea and a biscuit or two down as well, we were ready to make a plan.

We both agreed we were kind of done with the noise, pollution, general grime and chaos of massive Indonesian cities. That didn’t meant we hadn’t had a great time or that Indonesia isn’t amazing and fascinating. But as backpackers who want to be able to trot along to places on foot or hail a cheap ride in whatever passes for local transport, we were thwarted at every turn and it made even simple tasks just seem so much more complicated. It was draining. Unless you can fork out for a driver for the day to ferry you back and forth, it’s just a nightmare.

So we gave ourselves permission to spend the evening in, after the frustrations of our earlier short jaunt. We decided to work on the blog for a bit, have a hot shower apiece and another round of tea, have dinner in the hotel and save venturing out for the next day. We made a plan, it involved only one round of desperately seeking some means of transport and it meant that would be able to make something positive of both our last day in Medan and our last day in Indonesia.

That decided, I think we both felt much better: a combination of satisfaction in a plan worked out and relief that we would need to battle Medan until the following day. Hurrah!

I think it’s easy while travelling to think that every minute has to be filled with important and meaningful experiences. But our round the world trip taught us that kind of pace isn’t sustainable for more than a couple of weeks. We were on a 7 week trip, we had already had loads of incredible experiences and spending one afternoon in the hotel wasn’t a bad thing at all. We were working together on our blog which brings us both considerable joy and satisfaction, we were loving being together and we were both much happier and more relaxed having a quiet day than pushing ourselves to tick off some boxes for the sake of it.

With 4 blog posts under our collective belt, we decided to head for dinner. We had some confusion with our key cards in making the lift work again, but given that there was another chap in the lift having similar issues we started to figure it wasn’t on us.

The hotel restaurant was on the 7th floor. It was a bit strange as the carpet down the whole corridor was wet and 3 large fans were finding out a lot of noise and presumably, a lot of air to dry the carpet.

The restaurant was virtually empty but when we went to take a seat by the window, the waiter told us we couldn’t sit there as there was a private party.

We look around: there was literally one bloke sitting eating by himself. In the whole place. A very private party indeed.

Instead, we went and sat around the corner in a different window and this seemed to be OK. We split a portion of spring rolls, I had a bowl of pasta and Pete a club and sandwich and it was pretty tasty, even though the ambiance was somewhat odd. There was also quite a gap between things arriving: my pasta first which I’d finished by the time the spring rolls arrived. Then eventually Pete’s sandwich. But hey, how often do you actually get to sit and watch each other eat? That’s not weird.

We paid and left and as we did, one of the kitchen staff wheeled a giant fridge through the restaurant. Again: somewhat odd.

Back in our room, I made a round of tea

Day 19

The hotel, while a bit... odd?...had the comfiest bed we’d slept in for a while and it was lovely to feel properly relaxed again. Admittedly I could have lived workout the pre-set alarms on the room clock radio - trying to work out how to shut it off at six and then again at seven was a little trying - but I dropped off again quite easily both times.

We got up and went for breakfast a little after nine. Again the restaurant was empty apart from another couple, but we took in the buffet and set to.

I got us some scrambled eggs from the egg station and I added some fried noodles and prawn crackers to my plate. Pete however had managed to locate the cake station (my initial sweep had missed this) and brought me a banana muffin. Winner!

In fact it was so yummy that I popped back for another and ended up snagging the last one. Plus some pineapple and a slice of toast with peanut butter. Covering all the major food groups.

Tea was a bit of a lost cause however so we pottered back to our room and prepared for the day, showering, making tea, packing our bags for the day, figuring out what we’d for our flight later and pushing another blog post live.

It was handy not to check out until noon and we’d enjoyed a good lie in and having the time to get our things together. With everything ready, we settled our bill at reception, asked them to store our bags and got a taxi to our location for the day: Tjong A Fie Mansion.

The Mansion was, unsurprisingly, home to Tjong A Fie, the chap who became the leader of the the Chinese population in Medan in the 1900s. Sumatra at the time was a bit of a cultural melting pot with Chinese and Malaysian workers arriving from Singapore, Dutch Colonial rule, strong Indian connection and an English link somewhere in there as well because the flipping British can never keep their sticky fingers to themselves when there might be a pie they can shove them in.

Consequently, while Tjong A Fie was part of the Peranakan culture, this culture had a number of influences: Portugal, the Netherlands, Britain, India and China. Many of these influences can be seen in the mansion which has been described as being built in the “Chinese-European-Art-Deco” style. If that’s not a combo, I don’t know what is.

Visiting the mansion and wandering it’s rooms is a great way to get a bit of an insight into the old Medan and it cost us a fraction over £2 each to get in. Or 70 000 rupiah in total.

The mansion was beautiful: we started with the ground floor and took our time, slowly exploring and admiring the details which drew from so many different world influences. While the decor and structure were perhaps looking a bit vintage with age, there was still a kind of Venetian grandeur to it. The rooms were enormous with high, crafty ceilings, the windows mostly free of glass to let in the breeze, and courtyards filled with plants and lined with intricate wooden shutters created an airy feel.

We learned that Tjong A Fie was a Chinese immigrant, but that he rose to power and prominence by acting as an interface between the Dutch Colonialists, the Chinese workers and the Indonesian natives. While this undoubtedly required a fair bit of savvy and diplomacy, he also seemed to have done pretty well for himself out of the situation and made a fair whack of cash. He was apparently the first person in Medan to own a car.

While he must have been a pretty slick operator, it also seemed that he managed to keep a pretty neutral stance between the conflicting interests of the different parties. For example, he maintained strong friendships with the Dutch while still opposing the working conditions forced upon Chinese immigrant workers.

We admired the paintings and artwork - Pete especially admired the inlaid pieces - and there was a pretty amazing collection of teaware which I would happily have helped myself to had I thought it would fit in my luggage.

Also, I suppose it would be stealing, so there’s that too.

Chinese influences could be seen in the carved screens and the hanging lanterns, the blue and white shutters let in lovely light filtered by green plants and the rooms were decorated with striking colours: vibrant yellow and bold reds. It was a great place to spend the afternoon and gave us an insight into a very different side of Medan’s history and culture. A far cry from the noisy, industrial city of today.

Once we’d left the museum, we played roulette with various cash machines until we persuaded one to cough up some money (and even then, it told us to get a new card, weird) and then headed down the road to get a bite to eat. This sounds innocuous, but the fact that we were able to head down the road is a testament to the pavement. There actually was one!

We were heading for Tip Top cafe and ice cream parlour which was a few doors down. We’d read an article recommending it and it was a bit of a Medan institution, having been founded way back in 1934. It has a properly old-school colonial frontage, photos showing allied troops marching past during WWII it seemed like the ideal place to have a little rest from the head of the day.

Of course we both ordered ice cream: I opted for a slice of Neapolitan and Pete had a peach Melba sundae. We accompanied this with a mixed fruit juice: no idea what was in it but it was tasty and refreshing which was mostly the point.

In fact, we enjoyed this so much that Pete opted for a second ice cream, this time managing to pic a slice of Neapolitan ice cream that also had a cherry on top, a layer of sponge cake and a couple of pieces of fruit inside. I was slightly miffed that he’d managed to out-order me.

Finding a pavement had made us cocky so we decided to see if we could walk up the road to a nearby park (and maybe even grab a cup of tea at Starbucks because sometimes I’m that basic). We made a pretty decent lick of it, getting all the way there on foot and having to cross only one insanely busy road. In fact, there was a ti y pedestrian island in the middle where some influencers were filming fashion type content so that gave us a break from the incessant vehicles.

The park proved to be a disappointment. First we had to walk most of the way round it to get in, and then it proved to be largely featureless and a bit run down. There was an abandoned skate park, a sad-looking pavilion where some kids were practising their dance moves, quite a lot of litter and weird smell. Not top park attributes really.

One of the dancing kids came over and showed Pete his phone where he’d translated “can I get a picture with you” so we posed for that, but I was very much a spare part and it was a picture of Pete they were more interested in.

And then we shuffled away again. The Starbucks was not where the map said it was, so we figured we’d pop back to the hotel lobby and wait for our flight time there.

As always, getting back to the hotel was not straightforward. We managed to find the train station which was near the park, and there were some taxis but all were driverless. Another very strange taxi rank. Maybe you’re supposed to just take one and drive yourself?

We mooched up and down the full length of the station locating neither a cafe nor anywhere to find transport. We decided to try back at the taxi rank again and this time we had better luck: a driver was relaxing across the street, but leapt up and dashed towards us when he spotted us coming. We had a ride!

So of course then we felt horribly guilty when it turned out we didn’t have the right change for the journey. The driver couldn’t break a note so ended up taking all our small change, driving away a couple of thousand rupiah short of his fee. Eep.

We had a couple of hours to kill in the lobby - journal time and photo editing time ahoy - and then summoned a taxi to take us to the airport. We had looked into a train but at 100000 rupiah apiece, it seemed the airport train worked on the Heathrow Express principle of only being a good option if you don’t know any better. If you do know better, you appreciate it costs about 7 times what it’s worth for a journey that won’t take you much longer if you go by tube.

Given that if we went by train, we’d need to get a taxi to the station, it seemed to be about the same price just to get a taxi to the airport. This six o’clock found us bowling along the streets of Medan in a cab.

I speak figuratively. We were jammed in traffic in the streets of the Medan but the end goal was the same.
