We pulled up at the airport a little after seven, the taxi driver inexplicably added 40000 rupiah to the fare which ate up most of his tip as I didn’t have any extra change after that. Sad face.

We had arrived at the airport at the recommended 3 hours in advance, figuring we’d check in, stash our bags and grab some dinner. The airport had other ideas, and we were told that check in wouldn’t open until eight. However, Pete had spotted a Starbucks and so we trotted across to find some tea and wait for the desk to open.

There was a slight snag in that Starbucks had sold out of tea. But after some acrobatic miming, I convinced them to give me two cups of hot water and some cold milk (which turned out to be free: score!!!) and then I secretly pulled out some teabags stashed in my luggage to make our own tea. So not checking in the bags turned out to be a good thing!

I also grabbed a scone and Pete had a panini - I was actually obliged to pay for these - and we whiled away the time until our flight with a slightly more caffeinated spring in our step.

We checked in, and there was a slight hiccup when the airline chap told us we could only stay in Vietnam for 15 days. Which was weird as we had visas for 30 days. After some rummaging, I was able to produce our paperwork and he agreed that it would be OK. But things like that always throw you for a second!

Our bags disappeared to meet us 2 lights later in Hanoi and we went through security. Time for dinner!

Except we hit another mini snag. At the advanced hour of 8:15, all the airport eateries had closed. There were a couple of small shops open but they wouldn’t take cards. So once we’d managed to stretch our remaining currency to a packet of crisps and some biscuits that was it for the night.

We kind of wished we’d had more at Starbucks, but I suppose they wouldn’t have taken our card either.

This has been a recurring feature of our time in Indonesia: shops invariably have a card machine on the counter but at least 2 times out of 3, they tell us they don’t take cards. We assumed we would be OK at the airport, but apparently not,

So we sat in our gate to wait the hour to our flight. As we boarded there was no small amount of confusion as people kept changing seats, but once that was sorted, we were off.

It was a short flight through the dark skies, and in just over an hour’s time, landed in Kuala Lumpur. We shuffled off the plane and made our way through the airport, hunting out the signs for our airport hotel. We weren’t actually planning to spend any time in Malaysia, but we had a 12 hour layover. It had been cheaper to get from Medan to Hanoi overnight including a night in the airport hotel than it had been to travel at more sensible times with shorter transfers. And given that we weren’t all that bothered where we slept as long as there was a bed, a night in the Kuala Lumpur airport hotel worked a treat.

Finding the hotel proved a little more tricky than we thought though. We got through immigration and passport control without incident (a relief as we hadn’t been able to get the Malaysian covid app to work properly despite repeated attempts over the last 3 weeks) and followed the signs to the airport train. The instructions the hotel had sent me said that we would be able to find them on the right of the train station on level 2.

We found level 2. We found the train station. Pete spotted an enormous sigh for the hotel. And yet there was no actual hotel that we could see.

We did a few laps of level 2, visiting the closed food court, a bank of ATMs, the station and a various retail outlets in the mall section. It was starting to get ridiculous: it was 1:00am, we wanted to go to bed and we ended up standing right under the hotel sign wondering how to get in.

Pete spotted a security guard and fortunately he was able to put us right: the hotel was on level three.

I feel like we would actually have managed better without the stupid instructions the hotel sent us. If we hadn’t been told to be on level 2 we might have tried other floors ourselves. Sigh.

I mean, why bother taking the time to send out information to guests if it’s not accurate????

It’s OK: I’m over it.

We did indeed find reception on level 3, summoned a member of staff and got checked in. We wandered through the maze of corridors to find our room, only to discover that the key card didn’t work. We hadn’t been having much luck with key cards lately.

Back to reception: it took a little longer to summon up a member of staff the second time round, but we managed, and she escorted us back to our room with a new card. Possibly to check all was well, but also possibly because she thought maybe we were too moronic to use a key card.

The new card worked, I made a cup of tea and we settled into our room. It was dwell equipped and handy now we knew where it was and we had plenty of time to rest, have morning cuppa and a hot shower. The hotel had an interesting but practical reservation system where you got the room for 12 hours from the time you check in. Ideal as it works around whatever weird and wonderful flight times you may have. And so we tumbled into bed, Pete to sleep and me to finish the end of this journal entry.

And to start planning my #bringbackkeys #downwithkeycards campaign.

Sweet dreams!

bringbackkeys downwithkeycards

posts.title: Honeymoon Rafting
posts.content:
Day 17

We had another reasonable night’s sleep and despite a few wake-ups to turn over and try and find a more comfortable spot to lie in, we got a good few hours kip. I was awake by half seven and read under the mosquito net for a bit, listening to the river which had dropped back to the level of the previous afternoon.

Eventually I got up, slipping out from under our mosquito net, leaving Pete asleep and wrapped in his blanket. I went to put on my trekking clothes and discovered that they were sodden. Not just from the previous day’s trek but because clearly where we’d hung up our clothes to dry out wasn’t as sheltered as we imagined. I did put on my sports bra but it was so went and clammy that I couldn’t face wearing the rest of my gear and figured I’d just stick to wearing the dry t-shirt and leggings I’d been sleeping in. It was our last day in the jungle after all.

I could see our guides laying out the mat by the river for breakfast; the morning was a little cooler than the previous ones which was nice, and it was dry, with the sun peering through the cloud here and there. I woke Pete and wandered down to the side of the river.

When Pete arrived, there was a jug of tea waiting for us and we have the packet of biscuits a miss, remembering the breakfast onslaught of the day before and saving room. Breakfast was indeed another feast - the same triple decker sandwich with egg, cheese and salad and garnished with a selection of fruit: lychees, passionfruit, banana and orange.

It was lovely to sit by the river listening to the rush of water and the occasional squawks from small birds, while large butterflies drifted around without any clear aim beyond the desire to flutter.

We had the option of doing another small hike in the morning, but given the state (and, let’s the honest, the smell) of our gear and the fact that the hike would just be slogging up the ridge and back down again, we opted out. Time to return to Bukit Lawang.

We retreated to our shelter and packed our wet things away - my towel was the worst affected item as it seemed to have positively absorbed water, sponge-style. I get that a towel is supposed to absorb water to some extent, but I figure it’s meant to absorb water off me when I’m wet, not somehow suck in an entire jungle storm.

As we packed, a small monkey wandered along the ledge in front of our shelter. Spotting us inside, it peered curiously at us before clambering up one of the poles to the roof. It’s face soon appeared again as it looked in at us, upside down from above, teeth bared. We hissed and flapped at it until we convinced it to wonder off. Seriously: monkeys.

We ventured back to the river bank with our bags packed, our swimmers on and our few remaining dry items wrapped securely in our dry bags, stuffed inside our packs. The way back to Bukit Lawang was down the river!

But first, it seemed it was time for a fruit break as we were summoned to the kitchen tent and each handed a huge platter of fruit - our 195 a day - to eat before the journey.

It was approximately 15 minutes since we’d finished breakfast. And trust me when I say our journey back to Bukit Lawang was in no way going to be strenuous. But we propped down on the mat and tackled the fruit as best we could: melon, watermelon, orange, pineapple, passionfruit and lychee piled up and we were even offered a sachet of condensed milk to pour over the top.

We munched as much as we could while the guides and some of the other campers took it in turns to throw rocks at a target on the other side of the river. It was quite a distance to fling the rocks and nearly all missed, bouncing harmlessly off the far bank and rolling into the water, or scything through the ferns into the undergrowth.

We managed perhaps half a plate each before our fruit tolerance gave out: we were were just going to have to try and survive and avoid scurvy on about 128 of our 5 a day.

I had sealed my phone inside my dry bag inside my bag, otherwise I would have taken a picture of the fruit plate. It defied imagination.

As we ate, promising never to utter the phrase “but what about second breakfast?” again, the guides were busy preparing. They loaded our shoes and bags into strong, double lined plastic sacks, lashing them closed and then tied the bundles securely to our boat.

Boat is an optimistic term. So is raft really. Our ride was in fact three rubber rings lashed together. We were going to float back!

Pete and I sat together in the largest, middle ring, the water cold and fresh as we sank into the hole. Our feet dangled over the front as we wedged in tight. Then with one guide in the front ring, one guide it the back, and one perched on the side by me, we were ready for off! The two guides in the front and rear had long bamboo poles to push our makeshift raft along and we began to float downstream.

Despite the rain the previous night, it was dry season and so the river level wasn’t particularly high. It was enough to mostly keep us afloat though and our dashing captains guided the little craft through the right channels. We splashed and bounced over little rapids, waves of water splashing over us, the sun shone and we watched the immensity of the jungle slide slowly past. We saw a family of tufty grey monkeys playing by the river, most of whom scarpered as we paddled on past. The alpha stayed sitting on his rock though, so show he was not afraid of such trifles.

As we slipped and slid (and once or twice got stuck) downriver, the guide in the lead sang, teaching us a catchy song to the tune of jingle bells that even now is reverberating around inside my head:

Jungle trek, jungle trek,
In Bukit Lawang.
See the monkey, see the birds,
See orang-utan!

Jungle trek, jungle trek,
In Bukit Lawang.
See the monkey, see the tiger,
Everybody run!

It took us around 45 minutes to get back to the village we’d left behind. We passed quite a few people on the river banks either hiking or trekking rubber rings and equipment out to the camping stations. We waved merrily, enjoying the ride, the rush whenever we splashed over white water and the sensation of just lying back and gliding through territory that had previously demanded an enormous effort.

When we reached Bukit Lawang, we were surprised to see that most of the population seemed to have turned out to play in the river. Little stalls lined the banks, families and groups clustered on the shore or played on the rocks in the water and sound systems played out pop hits. It was definitely party time and there was an almost bank holiday feel as everyone turned out to enjoy the sunshine and the cool water. Lots of people called and waved to us and it was really fascinating to watch a community making the most of their day. We laughed and waved back.

Finally we pitched up on a shallow, stoney bank and climbed out of the little vessel that could. Our packs were freed from their plastic protection, and we shouldered them and picked up our boots before walking back the five minutes or so to our hotel, dripping slightly in our swimwear and slapping along in flip flops.

All in all, it had been an amazing few days, but it was also lovely to be back to somewhere where a shower is a possibility rather than a vague concept. We got the keys to our room in the lodge, retrieved our packs from storage and said goodbye to our guide.

Then we stumbled inside and surveyed our things.

A shower did wonders for both of us, and feeling much cleaner and perkier, we set about sorting out our backpacks and our trekking bags. I divided up my gear into two piles: things that smell bad and are wet, and things that smell bad and are dry,

Pete just had one pile: things that smell bad.

We very much hoped we’d be able to get a little bit of laundry done the next day, but we spread out the damp things as much as we could, hoping they might at least air out a bit and the collapsed onto the bed. Even though we’d had reasonably long nights in bed, jungle trekking still seems to be quite demanding, especially with the added heat and humidity, and we were suddenly hit with weariness now we could relax. So we spent a quiet hour or so with a cup of tea, some journal time (for me) and some Star Trek time (for Pete).

We ended up watching the end of the Chamber of Secrets together before wandering out to the lodge’s garden. The river party was still in full flow with live music and loads of locals swimming and playing in the river. We leaned over to watch from the verandah and we were met with a chorus of “Hello mister, hello miss! Swimming! Cold!” as people waved.

We sat in the open upper floor of the lodge to read and rest, passing the afternoon quite happily.

We succumbed to the heat and the lure of air con as the sky began to darken for the end of the day, and so we headed back to our room to watch an episode of Lost before dinner. Enroute, I could hear little staccato bird noises which seemed to come from the trees and vines beside me, but I couldn’t locate the author of the noises. That is, until I rounded the corner and spotted the local rooster strutting about. He continued his mild clucking for a while, before finally indulging in a proper cock-a-doodle-doo as we let ourselves into our room.

For some reason, it kept this up for a while. Muppet bird. Also, if it made that noise to start with, I would have known it was a chicken.

Meanwhile, as we watched Lost, a small lizard emerged from goodness knows where and turned the ceiling into its own personal playground. It was clearly having a lovely time so we let it be, figuring if it got in, it could let itself out when it wanted to.

It was completely dark when we emerged again, nightfall doing what it says on the tin in these parts and properly falling suddenly upon you. None of this gently fading in nonsense. We crossed back to the lodge for dinner and ended up order the same dishes again: Pete’s chicken in sweet sauce, spicy fried noodles for me and some fries to share. I tried to order my own plate to avoid this but Pete was having none of it, and then had a little strop when I took a chip that he deemed to be on his side of the plate.

This is why sharing food is a BAD IDEA PEOPLE.

We enjoyed it very much - Pete in particular had been looking forward to ordering that dish again for a couple of days - and we managed to get rid of some annoying bits of change when we paid. Score!

Back in our room, we settled down for our now classic evening routine: I dug into the stash of creamer sachets that I’d been collecting from various rooms we stayed in because Mike just isn’t a thing here, (current count: 2. We were running low) and we popped the kettle on, confident in the knowledge that in 45 minutes to an hour, we’d be brewing up (it’s a slow, tiny kettle). And thus the evening’s itinerary could commence: Lost, a cup of tea and then a more lighthearted episode of modern family to finish with.

It was lovely to settle down into proper beds for the night and we finally switched out the light on our last night in Bukit Lawang.

posts.title: Honeymoon Jungle
posts.content:
Day 15

We woke up to our alarm at half seven on our first trekking day. Pete complained about this as he didn’t think we should have to get up until 7:45. I disagreed, reasoning that we had to shower, go for breakfast, pack up the final few bits for our trek, check out and put our bags in storage so that we were ready for nine.

Consequently, I was obliged to go and have the first shower - again - while Pete remained curled up under the covers to “guard the bed”.

This his all-time top saying which means he doesn’t want to get up and I can basically lip-sync along with this now when he says it.

To his credit, the bed has never been stolen under his watch, but equally I have never found this to be a particularly likely proposition.

One we were both ready and I had bemoaned the three new bites on my foot, we ambled over for breakfast and picked the “toast scrambled egg” off the menu. This turned out to be more of a scrambled egg sandwich but it was also somehow unutterably delicious and while I have no idea what they did to it to make it so fabulous, I scarfed it down extremely rapidly. YUM!

We topped up our water and returned to our rooms to pack our final few things and ready our backpacks to be left with the lodge while we were trekking. It seemed that we had to pay to leave our bags behind, but better than lugging them with us I suppose!

Our guide was ready and waiting, our water bottles were full, and after a quick setting-off photo, we began our trek.

We actually had two guides: the second was the son of the guy in charge and he tended to bring up the rear, carrying some of the supplies. We crossed the river and struck out into jungle territory, crossing first through a rubber plantation where the trees were tapped and dripping their sap into little bowls. We actually passed two men hauling their rubber crop to the market, the lumpy mass swinging from a pole which stretched between them.

It was 16 minutes in when we got to see our first orangutan. Pretty impressive work from our guide already! This was a juvenile, aged around 5, and he was sat up in a tree snacking on rubber fruit; apparently orangutans like the seed inside. We were told that his mother would almost certainly be in the vicinity as orangutans don’t mature and become independent until they are seven or eight.

Moving on, we entered the jungle proper, occasionally encountering other trekkers and swapping information about where to find the jungle’s most famous residents.

The jungle was a constant shift and slide of challenges to be negotiated. The only consistent thing about the going underfoot was that it was never flat: we were either climbing steeply upwards or slithering steeply downwards. Roots crossed the paths constantly, trees and vines erupted from the earth everywhere competing for canopy light and the loops and twists of curly-fry hanging branches and air roots made for pretty promising band holds. Often vital when heaving our selves up stepped roots around a tree, climbing over rocks or trying not to slip and slide down muddy inclines. And it was muddy, when it wasn’t stony or leaf-strewn: very red mud that was occasionally slick with recent rain. This stood out in sharp contrast to the brilliant, vibrant green form the almost audibly growing rainforest.

It was noisy too, in the way that nature often is in the background, but once you tune in to it, you can’t help but here the cacophony of life. Cicadas buzzing and droning, gibbons hooting to each other in little song-like whoops, the rustle and sway of huge leaves and the occasional crash as something makes it’s way through the canopy or undergrowth. We heard the squawks of hornbills, the occasional rush of the river and myriad other sounds that were unknown to us. It was a magic all of its own.

While the going was challenging in places, we got to see some wonderful sights. First you was a white faced gibbon, responsible for the little cooing calls we could hear. They were furry and inquisitive, staying up in the canopy but looking down at us as a couple more appeared: our guide told us they stay in groups of 4 or 5 and their calls are to alert other groups to their territory. They guard this fiercely from other gibbons and will fight for it, but are happy to share with other monkeys.

After a couple of hours or so, we were tiring a little. The temperature wasn’t crazy hot as there was cloud cover and we were under the trees. But the humidity was intense and we were sweating buckets. And thus it was time for a fruit break!

The guides cracked into their bags and produced a veritable feast, covering the ground with a couple of ferns and laying out bananas, lychees, oranges, pineapple, strawberries and passionfruit. It was all wonderful and I think we both demolished our 5 a day in about 5 minutes. YUM! After we’d scorched through around 5 passionfruit, our guide said people in Indonesia by and large weren’t keen on them. Funny: there a favourite for both me and Pete and we almost never have them as they’re so expensive.

Moving on, we encountered another orangutan, this time a mother with a one-year-old baby. The mum was very much chilling out and relaxing up in the trees, immense arms stretched to keep her stable, while her infant buzzed about practising her climbing, sometimes on branches and sometimes on her mother. In fact, the mother’s face had a very put-upon expression but she tolerated the excessive energy of her offspring.

Orangutans tend not to have more than one infant at once because they are quite the handful, and as they’re solitary creatures, they don’t get much child support. Tough gig.

The next creature we spied had no qualms whatsoever about making her presence felt; a monkey (I’m not sure what kind) sat in the fork of a tree as we topped a little rise and encountered another tour group having their fruit break. (They had watermelon - suckers!) The monkey was peering dolefully at them, alternating between making little mooing noises and pouting, duck-face fashion, with her hands up. We weren’t sure what that meant but it was extremely comical and expressive nonetheless.

We stopped for lunch around 1:15, plopping down on the massive trunk of a fallen tree on the top of a ridgeway through the jungle. Some time back there had been a landslide down one side of the ridge and we could see down the valley to the jungle on the other side, the gap already being filled with saplings making a bid for the sky.

This afforded us top views while we tucked into little pre-wrapped parcels of egg and fried rice (nasi goreng). To these were added prawn crackers, cucumber and tomato (Pete ate my tomato though, thanks Pete) and we scarfed our lunch down with gusto: it was delicious.

The rest of the morning’s pineapple had been sliced up and laid out too, but while we ate our rice, hoards of ants and flies decided they fancied some sweet fruit and even a large butterfly landed delicately in order to partake.

Our second guide eventually noticed the dinner party going on and to be fair, he did pick off most of the ants before handing us the fruit. I only had one extra to pluck away.

After lunch, we were entertained by more gibbons performing acrobatics through the trees above and also by a series of ants who came to claim bits of dropped rice. It took two ants to carry a single grain (one at the front, one at the back, Chuckle Brothers style) and they marched it solemnly along the fallen tree to goodness knows where. Clearly the colony would have having a take away that evening.

As we were gazing out over the jungle, we heard more of the hornbill calls and our guide suddenly pointed to the bird perched in a tree. As the tree was growing further down the valley, we could actually see the bird below us, despite the height of its perch off the ground. It was big - much bigger than I’d imagined - and I was surprised by just how bright and prominent it’s beak was. Clue’s in the name, I guess. Our guide told us this was a rhino hornbill, one of six kinds who live in the jungle, and that they were often tricky to spot.

This one took off in big clatter of wings; it didn’t seem to be a particularly graceful flyer, but it allowed us to see the brightly coloured beak and the flash of white on the black tail. A second hornbill unexpectedly flapped after it a couple of moments later so we got to see the spectacle twice.

There were also loads of plants to admire as we tramped further along our way. There were loads of beautiful, twisted, unnamed vines and trees, and speaking of trees, there were a number of enormous specimens with giant, buttress roots taller than we were. We came across a ficus or strangler fig, having cloaked its victim tree in long, slender roots creating a knotted, impenetrable cage, and we passed coffee plants with berries green and red.

Our guide also found a quinine tree - he carved a small piece of bark for us to try chewing and sure enough, it tasted grim: incredibly bitter, reminding me why I’m not a gin and tonic fan, and it left a taste in my mouth a bit like paracetamol.

We had one final orangutan encounter, another mother and baby, hanging out above us. Again, the little one was full of beans while the mother slumped in the way only an orangutan can, keeping an eye on her energetic charge. It was fascinating to watch her when she did move: it was so effortless and muscular but also soft with her flowing red hair. She could use her feet as effectively as her hands to grip the branches and it seemed as little effort to her to hang by one arm as it did to sit perched in the nook of a tree trunk. Orangutans live a solitary existence - their lifespan being roughly 40-45 years - and for most of that time, it seems they quite like to chill. Staying mostly in the canopy for safety, they build a new, leafy next most days to snooze in, needed about 7-8 hours a night kike humans. And after all, they are our 4th closest neighbour, genetically speaking. Our guide told us they also sometimes build day nests if they want to stay somewhere and chill for a bit.

While in general, orangutan numbers are sadly in decline, the National park is clearly having a positive impact as their numbers are slightly on the increase. The orangutans are protected from encroaching farming and plantations and tourism seems to ensure that locals can still gain an income from their local area while maintaining conservation practices.

We descended the final hill down to the river, grabbing on to tree trunks for dear life in my case, and then we traded our boots for flip flops for the last few minutes as we had to wade across the water in a couple of places. It was deliciously cool on my aching feet and Pete and I were keen for a bit of a swim.

We came to the little shelter beside the stream where we’d be putting up for the night, and inside the bamboo and canvas structure, a couple of camping mattresses had been laid out under a mosquito net.

Thank goodness: having managed to avoid bites mostly for the first two weeks of our trip, I was now plastered in them: there were up and down my legs and on my feet, they itched like crazy and I was pretty sure they were from the night before. Which is unfair because I wore a long skirt and lots of mosquito repellant.

Yet another brand to add to the “bug spray that doesn’t work” column. Rude.

To be fair, I don’t think any of them work. I seems to get eaten alive no matter what I do. Even through my clothes.

Pete and I changed into our swimmers and paddled a little way upstream in search of slightly deeper water. The stream flowed quite slowly and was barely more than knee-deep but we found the deepest patch we could and settled down on smooth, wide stones under the water so that we were at least in the water up to our waists. If we leaned back, we could be mostly submerged!

It was blissful to soak my aching feet and stinging, overheated bites in the cold water and once we’d adjusted to the temperature, we just sat and chatted, listening to the noises of the jungle, watching the swaying trees and spotting tiny fish swimming through the crystal clear water flows.

We spotted a tiny rodent-like creature trot across a branch over the river and after a while, monkey came strolling down the rocks which lined the river bank.

A second one followed and suddenly I didn’t think it looked quite so cute and friendly.

I hopped out of the water sharpish and onto the opposite bank hoping it would go away, but while the second one did climb a tree and head back into the forest, the first one kept its eyes trained on us as it walked further along the bank.

Suddenly it was across the river and running towards us, teeth bared: we yelled and I screeched as loud as I could to frighten it and while it stopped it was still close. It got bolder and we yelled some more: I stumbled over my flip flops and fell - idiot - but Pete had the presence of mind to throw a rock at it, which finally convinced it to back off.

It wasn’t massive, but it still had more teeth and claws than we did and I didn’t fancy seeing who would come off best in contest.

I was a bit shaken and I’d managed to cut the underside of my food and scrape my knee. Our guides appeared around the bed in the river and threw things at the monkeys until they had well and truly cleared off and we pottered back to camp.

I got back in the river quickly to wash the blood off my legs and I think Pete would happily have swam for longer as he’s much braver than me, but our guides had prepared tea and snacks and I figured I may as well have it while it was hot.

I wrapped my towel around me and sat on a mat by the river, while Pete changed and came to join me.

The food laid before us was an interesting mix. The tea was self-explanatory, but we also had some fritters which the guide said were sweet potato but which I think were something similar to but not quite the same as sweet potato. More like cassava? Whatever they were, they were delicious, lightly battered and served with onions which is all well and good by me.

We also had some crackers sprinkled with sugar and a cut up lime. We weren’t sure what this was for so in the end, we squeezed it onto the crackers. This actually worked a treat and was reminiscent of lemon and sugar on pancakes, but as Pete pointed out, maybe the lime was for the tea. Perhaps the guides would come around to our shelter and wonder what on Earth we were doing with the lime. Possible.

It was still early, maybe half four or five, and we had time to kill, so I worked on my journal and a Pete read a bit. It was a little bit uncomfortable sat on the floor after a while, so Pete went to lie on the mattresses while I stayed out and drank more tea, obvs.

But I wished I had joined Pete as suddenly, a guide behind me yelled, there was a skitter and a crash and a monkey dashed past me, having made a break for the leftover crackers. I shrieked and jumped in surprise, hopping to my feet, but the money was off and again, the guides did all they could to persuade it not to return.

I very much hoped that they didn’t prove nocturnal as there was all sorts of mischief they could get up to in the night.

I decided to join Pete in the shelter after all.

I finished my journal and looked up outside the shelter and suddenly spotted a monitor lizard strolling by. I roused Pete and we hopped over to the water, but it didn’t seem keen to have the company and slipped into the stream with its funny waddling gate and glided along with the current. It was still lovely to see though.

In other news, monkeys continued to plague our camp; our guide kept up the occasional rock chuck in their direction and told us that it was a big, aggressive male and that they’re often after food. He suggested trying to act big and not be afraid but given that I was afraid and that hollering at the offending beast had yielded no results, I didn’t fancy my chances.

In fact, when I went for a jungle wee, I took Pete with me to keep watch and potentially be ready to throw ALL the rocks.

We read for a bit in the shelter, taking advantage of the mosquito netting and dark descended rapidly as it always seems to here. After a while, our guides called to use that dinner was ready, and on a groundsheet outside out tent, they had laid out a pair of candles and a veritable feast of treats to enjoy. Plus a big bottle of water each which was very welcome.

We all ate together, passing round plates of rice and then adding to it from the dishes before us. There was tofu in a sticky sauce (yum), chicken rendang (double yum), vegetables in a curry sauce, potato cakes and fried tempeh (double yum as well), prawn crackers and crispy noodles. Far more than we could eat but we tucked in with gusto to clear what we could. And very tasty it was too!

We chatted with our guide for a bit and he answered the questions we peppered him with about the vast array of different languages, cultures, customs and religions that make up Indonesia. As a dispersed country, different islands have quite distinct identities but even within islands, there are vast differences. Our guide said that, for example, he couldn’t understand the language of the people who lived at Lake Toba, in the centre of the island. However, he did say that overall, Indonesia is very accepting of a wide diversity of practices, opinions and customs and that at the end of the day, everyone is Indonesian. It was a lovely sentiment.

After dinner we had a big flask of ginger tea sweetened with sugar (very tasty indeed) and bit plate of peanuts in their shells to pop open and consume. We managed to get through the whole meal without any monkey attacks (score!) and even though a leaf fell on my at one point and I assumed a giant big had ambushed me, we remained relatively unscathed for the rest of the evening.

I did swallow a moth though. By mistake when it flew into my face, attracted by my head torch.

It was absolutely pitch dark, we couldn’t even see the river a few feet away and stars speckled the areas of sky that weren’t hidden behind the leafy outstretched arms of the trees. We slipped back into our mosquito net to read and even though it was barely half past eight, we felt a little sleepy.

Eventually we decided to call it a night, ventured out into the dark jungle to clean our teeth and do a final loo run and then settled back under our mosquito net. Ten pm and all’s well.

Day 16

I woke at around half seven but Pete stayed obstinately asleep so I read quietly, leaving him to it. While we’d had a long night’s sleep in terms of hours, we’d both woken up a number of times feeling a bit stiff on the hard rocks; the floor mattresses helped a lot but they were thin and not completely forgiving.

My bites itched like nobody’s business.

Around 8:15, I crawled out of the netting and started gathering a few of my things. We’d hung up our sweat-damp clothes following the previous day’s trek and they were, of course, exactly as damp as they had been the night before thanks to the still, moisture-saturated air.

Not to worry! I figured they’d soon be damp again anyway once we started walking. As I rustled about, Pete emerged properly from his sleep and we both got ready for breakfast.

Stepping out of our shelter, we sat on the mats by the river and our guides brought round some breakfast. First came tea and biscuits (they clearly knew their audience) and this was followed by a huge fruit plate each which, yes, OK, had some watermelon, but also had mandarin, passionfruit, lychee and pineapple which more than made up for it. Yum! And once again: got our fruit quota in. We were starting to think that our jungle adventure would be the time on the trip when we ate the most nutritious food!

And it turned out the like we had been given the previous day was definitely to add to the tea and not the biscuits. I added some to my tea and regretted it. Better without.

We watched what looked like a chipmunk scamper through the trees and a dragonfly hum down gently onto a twig over the water. It was very peaceful. I snacked on a couple of biscuits while I finished cup of tea number three (or four?) and had just grabbed another when another plate of food appeared: a triple layer sandwich with 4 slices of bread, an omelette-style egg in the bottom, salad in the middle and a slice of cheese in the top.

It was filling to say the least - and tasty - and instead of feeling like going trekking, it felt like it was time to lie down. Although just as I was finishing my last couple of bites, one of the monkeys from the previous night crossed the river and approached us. I hastily jumped up swallowing the end of my sandwich and some more rock throwing commenced.

Pete, thankfully, guarded me while I went for a jungle loo.

We set off on our day’s trek around ten with roughly six hours of hiking ahead of us. The first part of our route however, took us upriver. And by upriver, I suppose I mean mostly inriver. We had to wear our flip flops and splash through the flow of water, skipping over stones and occasionally scaling the sandy root systems of the bank. My flip flops are like a thousand percent not made for this and I slipped and slid and was the definitive unhappy bunny as I banged my feet on rocks, pebbles dragged through the soles and I lost all sense of grip both between me and my wretched flip flops as well as between the flip flops and the ground. I was pathetically slow but with dogged plodding, we eventually reached a point where the river deepened and forked, flowing from two tributaries.

We had a little rest here as even though we hadn’t been going for very long, it was the point where we could finally don our shoes and commence actual walking. Properly shod. Lush.

However, it was nice having a little rest and soaking my poor abused feet in the cold water, soothing away the aches.

When it was time to move on, our guide jerked his chin up on of the tributaries and said we were going up there, so we dried off our feet, slid them into the luxurious comfort of supportive, enclosed walking boots and prepared to go.

Except I was wrong. He hadn’t gestured upstream. Instead he’d gestured at what looked to me like the cliff face separating the two forks of the river. We were climbing up there.

I will as I’d to exaggerating a little, but not but much. The fact that I hadn’t even seen the path because it seemed so absurd to be scaling such a steep mudbank says it all really. But scale it we did, using our hands to pull ourselves up on rocks and tree roots. We were panting for breath and covered in sweat but we kept on climbing and gradually, the gradient evened out,

Actually, that’s a lie too: it didn’t really even put, it more sort of became just like a normal steep climb that you don’t need to use your hands for, we jungle types are pretty hardy and that practically counts as flat to us.

The rest of the hike followed roughly the same pattern of the previous day: ups and downs, through jungle thickets and around tangled trees, pausing for our morning fruit break (taking us up to or 46 a day) and hunting for animals to spot going about their daily business. The morning was fairly quiet on that point. Unless you count the ants. The jungle is crawling with them, naturally, and they’re always so busy, from the tiny ones which constantly march and swarm in huge crowds to the big, hulking ones, the size of my little finger, who always seem to be alone. Lots of brightly coloured butterflies fluttered lazily around and the chirrups of the cicadas were a constant presence.

However, as the day wore on we had more luck, first catching sight of some more white-faced gibbons far off in the canopy, and then, a little further along as we’d started a slightly tricky descent, our guide spotted a little group of black gibbons. They aren’t as common and as it happened, we were able to follow them for a quite while, watching them swing their dark, furry little bodies through the trees, hang effortlessly by one hand to grab snacks with their feet and eat and every so often, peer down at us on the floor below.

We reached a small stream at the bottom of the incline and as we stepped onto stones to cross it, we found 3 or 4 of the black gibbons poised in trees overhanging the water, watching our passage. Our guide said we had been going to have lunch here but that the food would attract the gibbons and we we’d have to wait for them to go away. Apparently they can get aggressive.

While we waited by the stream, we spotted a little turtle having a swim. It was surprisingly well camouflaged against the stones at the bottom of the shallow water. It was also unbelievably adorable with a reddish head and neck and a very pointed snout. Our guide sprinkled sand over the surface of the water and the little turtle swam after it, thinking the small plops of sand were insects.

After a few moments, a smaller one shot out from underneath a rock and it was kind of awesome to see mother and baby.

In the end, our guide suggested we walk for a bit along the stream, rounding a few bends to ensure we’d put some distance between ourselves and the gibbons, and then have lunch. This we did with reasonable success and we were tucking in to fried vegetable noodles, egg, prawn crackers and some tomato with some gusto when another monkey appeared. Our guide pondered it over his food and told us it wasn’t one that would be bothered about us rustling papers or getting things from our packs so we could carry on eating.

We kept a steady eye on each other, humans and monkey, as it came closer and closer, shimmying half way down the nearest tree to get a better look at what we were doing. It had a fluffy, black and white face, it’s fur ringing it’s eyes giving it a slightly surprised, inquisitive look. It had very soft looking grey fur, a long silky tail and a fluffy white tummy. Pete commented that he would like to give the monkey belly wubs and he was on to a pretty good thing. It had the look of a super cuddly creature.

Of course, looks can be deceiving, and our watchful visitor seized its moments, dashed to the picnic spot and grabbed a lunch bag with chicken in it and made off again.

Not very far though: it was cocky enough to sit just up on the bank of stream, not even bothering to climb a tree as it opened the bag and pulled out the pieces of chicken inside. It discarded the bag (although don’t worry, we carried it away with us).

We spent the rest of our meal watching each other until it was time for us to hike onwards. There was an hour or so further to go until we reached our camp for the night which basically involved climbing up and over the next ridge.

So on we marched, hauling ourselves up, sweating profusely and climbing through the vegetation and the sticky air. We each carry a little face towel gifted to us by our friends Maja and Maciek, but mopping the sweat off our faces just seems to make way for even more.

It does prevent it from dripping in your eyes though.

The last section of the hike was a very steep down, and our guide warned us to concentrate and go carefully. He wasn’t wrong: we were obliged to cling to roots and fallen trees to make big steps down: one good thing about the jungle is that it tends to give you plenty of things to hold on to, and most of it doesn’t bite. We just had to keep an eye out for things with spikes or things crawling with insects.

We came to one section which practically required you abseil down a steep mudbank, holding a rope and a selection of roots in order to keep your feet on the face of the incline. We had to pause here as we’d caught up with another group of trekkers and the slope was giving them some problems.

Mostly so was just glad there wasn’t also a waterfall flowing down over the hand-holds.

We reached the bottom without incident coming out next to the main river. This was a much larger affair than any we’d come across on the rest of the trek and had a reasonable current. There was decent shore made of rocks and boulders and we hopped over these past a number of camps, eventually leaving them behind. Apparently we were going further.

To get to our camp, we had to cross the river. Our guide said the river wasn’t very deep and the current was OK, but the going was quite slippery underfoot. And therefore Pete and I And all our belongings were loaded into a large rubber ring and towed across. Luxury!

Climbing the opposite bank, we found our camp and clambered up to our shelter for the night. We dropped our bags inside and changed into our swim things, returning to the river for a soak.

Again, the icy water felt blissful as we were hot and sweaty, sticky with bug spray and jungle dirt and my insect bites were hit to the touch and itched. Sliding into the water was just what we needed, and even the initial bite of the cold was welcome. Pete was straight into the current, swimming with it downstream before turning and swimming back up again with a side eddy. I perched on an underwater rock for a bit and watched before joining him for a couple of rounds with the current.

Our guide called that our tea was ready and so we hauled out of the river for a bit and put away a jug of our usual, alongside some more sweet crackers and lime. I don’t care if that’s not what the lime is for: it tastes great. We were also brought some more sweet potato fritters, pipping hot and crispy. YUM.

As we were getting back into the river for another swim, a few raindrops started pattering down. The second swim didn’t have the same pull for me as I was no longer blisteringly hot and sticky, so after giving my legs another quick soak, I decided to get out of the water and get dressed. The guides had kindly rescued our towels and put them under a canvas shelter and so I gathered them up and climbed into my evening clothes.

Pete had a good rainy swim but when other trekkers appeared who would be sharing our camp, and a family of four started swimming and splashing around his rock (rude!) he called it quits too.

As we got dressed in our shelter, the rain foot harder and harder, thundering down without the faintest sign of let up. I wrote my journal in the half-light under the mosquito netting as the clouds dimmed the sunlight. It made an almighty racket on the canvas.

All in all, it rained pretty solidly for a couple of hours as outside the shelter, the world got darker, fading through grey and finally to inky black. Our guides came to call us for inner in a shelter down by the banks of the river that was not swollen and roaring with rain water. We tucked into another enormous feast, this time featuring sweet potato sambal, a pumpkin and vegetable curry and chicken alongside the rice, prawn crackers, potato cakes and tempeh that we’d eaten the night before. Moths and flies were attracted to the light in the shelter, buffeting themselves about and we all perched on roll mats over the floor and chatted while we ate.

It was perhaps half eight when Pete and I returned to our shelter. Jungle evenings are a little bit funny: it’s pitch black and there’s not much to do per se, other than read and even that’s a little bit awkward because you need to be sat on the floor and there’s not really anything to lean on. I settled for sprawling under the mosquito netting, mentally cursing my bites and our useless bug spray, chatting quietly with Pete and finally, reading. We had an early night, turning out for one last, somewhat drizzly visit to the completely dark jungle loo - there’s actually a designated spot behind a tarp in this camp - and then we settled down to catch some sleep around ten. I very much hoped that our exertions from the day would enable us to sleep soundly and long, but I was also prepared to take sweet dreams of an actual shower on the morrow.

posts.title: Honeymoon Roadtrip
posts.content:
Day 13

We got up at eight and moseyed down for breakfast. A bit of a mixed bag overall: I opted for fried noodles and egg which was nice except the egg was stone cold and a bit rubbery. Pete’s experience was similar, but we filled up with some extra prawn crackers and treats from the pastry table so no harm done. We could also have lived without the graphic surgical procedure that was being screened on the TVs dotted around the dining room. Like, if you just have a TV at all times, maybe change the channel?

Back in our rooms, we made a tea, polished off the last of the biscuits I’d nicked from breakfast and the donut Pete had swiped and then packed up our bags. We’d been leaving it as late as possible thanks to the damp state of our gear from the previous day. Once we were ready, we did a sweep to swipe the loo roll and headed down to reception. We paid our laundry bill which came to a little under £3 making us wish we’d thrown in some more items, got our flight itinerary printed out (we’ve been caught out by this before at airports who then made us pay £25 a pop to have tickets printed out) and hunted for more loo roll. Success was found in perforated papery form in the lobby toilets and we collected big, before sitting down to wait for our ride.

Sitting down in the lobby, not the loo.

The our free airport transfer turned up early and so we were soon on our way. The drive took about 20 minutes and took us away from the city instead of on our usual route through it. We drove through what was definitely the Kensington and Chelsea equivalent of Malang where massive, decorative mansions lined the streets with ostentatious columns and pillars and turrets behind tall, gleaming gates. Once we arrived, we tipped our driver and headed into the airport.

I will confess to being a slightly paranoid airport arriver and I would rather be super early than play fast and loose with the boarding time. Consequently, we found at at 10:10, the desks were checking in the 10:45 flight people and were nowhere near getting to our 12:30 flight.

A helpful chap at the desk sorted us out anyway, checked our bags through Jakarta to arrive for us to collect in Medan and we moseyed on through to the waiting area with a couple of hours to wait before our flight. I very much hoped it was going to go on time as we only had an hour’s transfer window.

The airport had significantly better wifi than the hotel so I spent most of the time editing and uploading photos, and trying not to think about the fact that as 12:30 rolled around, they hadn’t even called our flight to board. Our only hope was that everything would run late.

Our flight was finally called half an hour after take off - classic - but it was still another half an hour after that before we left. An hour late. Our entire transfer window.

Goody gumdrops.

The flight passed smoothly enough, and even though it was only an hour and a half or so, they brought everyone a small pot of water (I accidentally exploded mine) and a bread roll filled with coffee-flavoured paste. Not bad, but I don’t like coffee so meh.

We landed in Jakarta just after three, silently screaming at the slow hoards taking their time shuffling their hand luggage about so we could get of the plane and look for our next flight. It didn’t really matter how fast we ran though: we’d already missed it.

However, examining our tickets, we found we’d been re-booked already on a flight an hour later which was awesome. I just wish we’d been told this earlier as it would have saved a lot of hassle.

We skipped through security, grabbed a bottle of water each - I guzzled mine down as I always seem to need extra - and we sat down to wait the half hour until our flight to Medan.

Of course boarding time came and went and at the supposed take-off time, a scuffle of movement near the desk alerted us to the fact that it was time to board.

Except no, no it wasn’t. Big crowds of people, us included, were sent off to a different gate instead. We hot-footed it through the airport, arrived at the gate and waved our tickets, well aware that we were after the close of gate time. But the staff didn’t seem unduly worried by details like schedules or tickets or the time and simply gestured for us to wait.

The logical part of me understands that every culture is different, time is a human construct you just have to roll with it when you’re in another country, embracing the local way of doing things.

Every other part of me was mentally screeching HOW DO YOU EVER GET ANYTHING DONE EVER WITHOUT A COLOSSAL WASTE OF EVERYONE’S TIME AND ENERGY.

But I’m British so I kept it bottled and Pete and I waited quietly as instructed, tutting to one another occasionally (out loud!) and commiserating with a German family who found themselves in the same frustrating position.

Time ticked on and the staff boarded passengers for a plane to Bali. Then they announced our plane and we all sort of tumbled together into the same tube. How were we meant to know which plane to get on?

We ambled across the tarmac in the late afternoon sun, and managed to get on our plane around half four. Pete commented that he wasn’t going to fly with Indonesia any more (he’d evidently forgotten that last time we tried this, we had been delayed every single time and once for so many hours that the airline were obliged to provide us all with food).

In fact, Pete did come up with an excellent contribution for the day’s journal when he noted that it’s all well and good going off the beaten track, but the thing about the beaten track is that the track is beaten. Which just simplifies everything really.

Apropos of nothing, can we also just take a second to appreciate the identikit immaculate beehive hairstyle sported by every member of the cabin crew for Air Batik? Kind of mind blowing.

I settled down into my seat, completed an on- board sudoku as we took off and then pulled out my iPad to watch a film. The flight was pretty turbulent which kept knocking the bottom out of my stomach. I was watching Harry Potter and the chamber of secrets and to feel the plane lurching as Harry and Ron flew the Ford Anglia to Hogwarts and crashed into the whomping willow was a level of immersion I could have lived without.

We were given a warm cheesy roll and a mocha muffin as a snack and another small cup of water so that helped to pass a bit of time.

I was glad when we landed and could just leave the plane behind, shimmying round to grab our luggage and watching the live stream of the baggage handlers sticking the luggage onto the conveyor belt behind the curtain. Amusing.

I had been half convinced that what with all the plane shenanigans our luggage wouldn’t make it, but sure enough it turned up and we schlepped out of the airport to find a taxi. This was the usual round of subduing hecklers, finding our way, arguing with drivers and staff and eventually settling on an option at random because really, in these situations, what choice do you really have but to decide to trust someone? I showed our hotel address to the driver, and after a short consultation with 5 other drivers, they all eventually concluded that we wanted to go to hotel Sentika.

Which is what it said on the paper I showed him but which didn’t seem to register. We’re never quite sure why, but as long as the driver knew where we were going, it was all good with us.

No sooner had we pulled out of the airport than an almighty storm started flinging itself around in the general vicinity: heavy rain poured down, doing battle with the taxi’s wipers, and forks of lightning split the dark night sky every few seconds. It was dramatic and intense.

Or at least I thought it was intense until we drove into a flash flood. Now that was intense. It was hard to tell how high the water was but looking at the vehicle in front, the flood came at least as high as the wheels. People riding motorbikes held their legs out, flip-flops dangling as they urged their machines through the water. The engine of the taxi whined and groaned as the taxi driver argued back with it out loud in a language we didn’t understand. What had been a street was suddenly a river and cars were beeping, rain was coming down and we were cocooned in our little tin box waiting to see what would happen next.

Well, nothing really happened next. The driver coaxed the car along, occasionally bumping into underwater pavements and obstacles, until we drove out of the flood and normal service resumed. Just like that.

I say normal service: I did think the taxi driver was giving us a bit of a runaround as the route we took wasn’t super direct and he stopped twice to get out of the car and sort something out while the meter was running. However, we did indeed make it to our hotel and the rain had pretty much given up by that point so we hauled our bags inside and staggered up to reception,

We checked in, dumped our stuff and set out to find the nearest Indomart. We both felt tired, we had arrived a good couple of hours later than planned and neither of us felt like we had the energy to go out for dinner. So Indomart provided and we had spicy noodles and crisps in our room, alongside a cup of tea with real milk.

And a couple of biscuits.

Snuggling down to watch Lost in bed, I felt pretty sleepy but also relieved to have got to the end of our journey. Made it!

Day 14

We got up around half eight, showered and went to investigate the hotel breakfast. Jackpot! It was a huge buffet and so we located a table and entered attack mode.

The dining room was busy: the hotel was a large convention centre in the centre of Medan and while we hadn’t really taken it in before, it seemed to be a pretty fancy one. I love when that works out as we just tend to pick something that’s in roughly the right place and within our budget (under it where possible) of £40. So when you end up in a 4 star jobby with an epic breakfast spread, you darn tooting make the most of it!

I went with my now traditional mie goreng (stir fried noodles with veg and chilli) and 2 eggs Sunny up which were cooked on the raw side of runny but never mind. I also grabbed a side of prawn cracker because I love that here you can have crisps for breakfast and it’s not being childish, it’s just the norm. Yay crisps! I also had some star shaped cereal to which I added some raisins and chopped nuts because it seemed like a good idea. Pete went for a general pick and mix across everything and managed to locate the fruit buffet which I’d somehow missed.

So when I went back for my daily breakfast cake (a donut on this occasion) I also hunted this out. Well that proved to be a treat! There were the usual platters of disappointment fruit (watermelon) and melon and so forth, the very welcome platters of pineapple (lush) but also a fruit salad station with a variety of fruits in jars. I pulled out a bowl and went to town, topping it off with a slice of starfruit, partly because I wanted to see what it tasted like, and mostly for the aesthetic. I took Pete a slice too.

Back at the table, I investigated my fruity spoils with glee. Starfruit we have a ten out of ten for looks but a 2 for taste. Not unpleasant, just didn’t really taste of much, and so finished off Pete’s. I mean, it was better than watermelon, but then that’s a very low bar.

I also had in my bowl some snake fruit (yum!) some strawberries that taste like they’d been infused with cloves (unnecessary as strawberries taste amazing and need no seasoning to support their favour of sweet happiness) and pineapple in chilli syrup.

The latter was a win! The chilli was an amazing complement to the slightly sour zing of the pineapple. Must try this at home.

Buffet well and truly demolished, we returned our our rooms, had a last cuppa and packed up our things. We checked out and found our driver waiting for us in the lobby - he had a sign with our names on which always makes me smile! - and we wiggled on out to the car ready to make the journey to Bukit Lawang.

We had booked to spend 3 nights trekking in the Sumatran jungle but of course getting there is quite the journey. Some 4 hours or so by car. Our driver was a cheerful chap and we chatted a little about London and Medan, comparing traffic at rush hour (he was delighted we had asked to leave at half ten as it meant he could avoid the worst traffic!) and the respective temperatures, which given the UK’s recent heatwave sending the temperature over 40 degrees, was a cause for some surprise, Medan tending to average around the low to mid thirties.

We rumbled on through the busy city, watching a range of streets go by from shiny, well-kept edifices sporting signs spelled out in flowers to the more usual stalls and shops which spilled out onto the roads.

We eventually left the city behind, ploughing on into greener spaces and eventually jungle. Row upon row of palms marched in ranks away from the car creating cool, green alleyways and the road was cracked and pot-holed as we bumped and swayed over it.

To our surprise, we arrived in Bukit Lawang a little after one. We had both read the advice that the journey took 4 hours and performed the same mental calculation of upping to to around six hours. Barely two and a half was unprecedented!

We were met at the eco lodge by our guide for the next couple of days and given a bright pink welcome drink while we sorted out the payment (which they’d asked for in Euros for some reason?) and chatted about our upcoming trekking and our previous visit back in 2018. He told us that 80% of the locals worked in tourism so the pandemic had been rough on the area. It was only in the last couple of months that tourists had started to return for the summer holiday.

We headed to our room to get settled in and have a quick shower to freshen up, and then sorted through our bags to re-pack for the following day’s jungle expedition. Then we wandered over to the lodge and settled on the upstairs sofas to chill. The room was completely open to the outdoors: sunshine streamed in, lizards pottered about the roof, the off moth fluttered through and the succulent jungle greenery leaned their leaves over the ledges. To our surprise, there was even a bit of wifi, but we were quite happy reading and passing the time quietly in the still, humid air. One side of the open room looked down over the rice which ran through the centre of the village, and the otherwise looked into the lodge’s courtyard. A small troupe of monkeys mucked about over the rooftops, munching on fruit, playing and antagonising each other, while small birds fluttered and came to rest for a moment on the vines which twined beside us.

After a while, we grew too warm however, and so headed back to our room and watched some Lost on the laptop.

Evening soon drew on and we returned to the lodge in search of sustenance. The day has clouded over somewhat and while we perched at a table inside the lodge, the heavens suddenly opened and a downpour commenced. Rain makes such a huge noise in the rainforest, slapping off leaves, drumming onto rooftops and swelling the river to a more insistent rushing. I remembered wistfully our guide telling us earlier that this was dry season. I was glad we’d decided to throw our ponchos into our trekking packs just in case. The trails were going to be muddy!

After our while, our hunger spurred us on to look for someone to order food from and eventually we caught the attention of the kitchen, found a menu and placed our order.

The food was fab! I went for my classic Mie Goreng but the kitchen offered a spicy version which I lapped up eagerly. And they were not wrong - it was super spicy and really tasty! I split a portion of fries with Pete (which were also fab and which I regretted offering to share but possibly that’s what married life is about) and Pete ordered a chicken dish in a sweet, fruity sauce with carrot and pineapple. He massively rated it.

As we were reaching the end of our meal, the local cat twined around my ankles mewing incessantly and while she was a pretty little thing, I highly doubted that she’d enjoy spicy noodles. I told her that Pete was the soft touch, assuming that he would offer her some of his chicken, and so he did.

She wasn’t sure initially but perked up once she’d tried it and her little mews turned into expectant sitting on the bench, paws on the table and finally standing next to Pete on the table as he offered her morsel after morsel.

One of the lodge staff came and whisked her away at this point, plonking her down unceremoniously pointing towards the outdoors. But of course she was having none of that, what with all the rain, and was soon back under my legs, before returning to Pete.

Pete by this point simply offered her his chicken bone so that she could nibble off the chicken herself (he had actually finished and there was very little left on the bone) which she attacked eagerly. She was then scooped away again by the staff before dashing back to us the third time without even pretending to go outside.

When the staff transported her away the third time, we don’t know where they took her but she didn’t reappear.

We filled out water bottles and headed upstairs to the open sitting area to read for a while after dinner. Even though it was pitch dark, it was only just half seven and with nothing pressing to do, it was nice to have a quiet evening. Lizards skittered across the ceiling, a bat flew through the room and the rain gradually slowed and stopped.

We headed back to our room for a round of tea in the - somewhat unexpected - heart-shaped mugs the lodge provided, watched another episode of Lost and then settled down for a good night’s rest before our trekking adventures of the morrow.

posts.title: Honeymoon Waterfall
posts.content:
Day 12

We upped and readied and left our room in well under 15 minutes following our delightful 5:45am alarm. Top honeymoon lie in action right there.

We were being picked up at six to go and spend the day visiting the Tumpak Sewu waterfalls and Goa Tetes, a nearby cave. We’d had a quick debate about whether to bring our swimwear as Pete thought swimming was a no, but I was sure I’d read somewhere that you could swim at the cave. In the end, we decided to bring it all on the off chance.

Our driver turned up promptly at six and was a jolly chap, and while he didn’t seem to speak any English (not really an issue) he had a nice comfy car which was a relief after yesterday’s trip! And consequently, I spent most of the two and a half hour journey asleep - I think we’d accrued a bit of a sleep debt.

I woke up to find our driver sort of tooling around in a lost fashion, and this was confirmed when he pulled up at the side of the road and wandered off to find some directions. However, a handy local plus various assorted phone calls seemed to sort him out and we arrived within a couple of minutes. Bingo!

We were introduced to our guide whose name was Dian, and he explained that we would see the waterfall from the top, walk to the bottom and see the view from there and then go to visit the cave. All in all it would be about 3km. He mentioned that it would be wet under foot and checked that we didn’t mind our shoes getting wet - no problem, I’d worn my walking boots for this exact reason - and we asked about swimming and he said yes, we could. However, I’d already got a bag full of camera equipment, and I didn’t fancy bringing along an extra carrier with towel and swimmers and so on, so figured I’d just leave it in the car. I could paddle easily enough if I wanted to.

And so we set off for a nice chill waterfall walk.

Spoiler alert: we could not have been more wrong about the nature of this trip. It was insane, borderline death-defying, adventurous and demanding.

It was also the best thing we’ve done in Java. Unanimously.

The start of the trip was tame enough and we strolled for ten minutes or so along a concrete path through the encroaching green jungle, emerging at a viewing platform at the top of the waterfall.

Tumpak Sewu is magnificent, there are no two ways about it. It’s huge, falling in multiple streams around a crescent shaped gorge, emerging from dense green undergrowth and trees to plunge 120m to the rocks below. Pretty stunning.

We spent a while admiring the view and Dian offered to take some photos for us - this was handy as it turns out he has a great eye for a picture, but I suppose he does this pretty regularly for tourists.

Then we began the descent to the bottom. To say it was steep is an understatement. The path was a bit steep in the same way that Mount Everest is a bit tall. Dian also told us that it had rained the previous day too, so of course the way was treacherous and slippy with mud and I had to go super slowly to keep my footing.

At points there was an identifiable path, at other points, random metal walkways had been bolted hastily in place and the occasional chunk of scaffolding pole speared to grab onto. However, these were invariably not very stable and it seemed safer to clutch onto rocks.

We picked our way ever downwards, slowly and steadily, until eventually, the path itself became a waterfall. Dian was undaunted and simply started climbing down it. There was a rope to hold onto so clearly no biggie (???) and there was nothing for it but to get down on hands and knees, clutch onto slippery boulders and feel around with my boots underwater until I found the next stable foothold.

I was kind of exciting though.

In this manner, we eventually made it to the bottom, coming out onto a grey sandbank, a little downstream from the waterfall, sandwiched in a huge, deep gorge. Even though the falls themselves were out of sight, we could still hear the cascade and spray misted the air. The sides of the cliffs were immense, carpeted with ferns and vines and it was very much like being in Jurassic park, as Dian pointed out.

In fact, we can keep count of how many movies and TV shoes we re-enacted.

Movies we lived: 1

Dian took some pictures of us - he was quite animated in his direction and in the end, I just let him keep hold of my phone for the duration as he snapped pictures all the time for us.

To get to the falls themselves, we had to wade through the river which had a decent current but was little more than knee-high. There was a rope to hold onto, the ends of which disappeared into a rugged pile of rocks, and we were soon scrambling up and down boulders on the other side of the river.

And then a short way upstream, we had to cross back again.

My boots were well and truly full of water by this point, and I was already quite glad I’d opted for leggings over shorts. They seemed to dry out pretty rapidly but usefully kept me from scraping my knees.

Emerging out at the bottom of the waterfall was pretty spectacular. The air was saturated with spray and we climbed up a rocky outcrop to take in the immensity of the view: blue skies, reddish rocks, dense green vegetation and crashing white sheets of water all harmonised to make an incredible natural spectacle. Pete spotted a rainbow up in the mist and Dian snapped a quick picture which he later showed us. We could easily be characters in Lost.

Movies we lived: 2

In fact, I pointed out to Pete that even if we had gone to Hawaii, I don’t think we could have hiked in rainforest or jungle any more dramatic than that which lay before us. It had been an effort, and goodness only knows it was going to be a pull back up the side of the gorge, but when you have 120m of cascading river, topped with a soaring distant volcano, I reckon you’re basically onto a winner.

We posed for a bunch of photos, because obviously, and then set off back the way we’d come. We had seen surprisingly few other tourists - maybe half a dozen in total - and a lot of the time, we couldn’t see anyone else around, which is always kind of magic when that happens. Reading up later, it seems that Tumpak Sewu isn’t on the main tourist route, and given that Java doesn’t seem to be inundated with tourists anyway (people tending to opt for Bali) that left a relatively small number of visitors for such an impressive location.

We crossed back through the river back to where we’d first dropped down from the cliffs, and then began our walk to the Cave.

If I’d thought the path was tricky before, this was a whole new level. It was less of a walk and more of a scramble over rocks and boulders, steeply up and down, and most of the time through little waterfalls. I was completely drenched from the waist down and pretty damp all over, and Pete fared similarly. It was, as ever, awesome to have him there though to steady me when things got extra slippery.

We plopped out eventually by the river again, and there was another sizeable waterfall splashing down above us. The rock seemed to pour down the cliff alongside the water, sculpted by the torrent into wonderful fluid shapes, twisted spindles and delicate overhangs. In places, it was hard to distinguish between the vines that spread long fingers over the ledges and the stone sculptures carved by the inexorable passage of time and water. Pete pondered the geography and evolution of the area aloud and it would have been interesting the learn about how such places are formed.

We’d reached a group of locals who were busy taking pictures and setting up cameras and we of course did the same, posing at the base of the cascade while Dian did his thing with the camera.

And then suddenly he was yelling at us to run and pointing up behind us - Pete grabbed my arm and we dashed forwards towards Dian. I didn’t look behind me but heard a huge crash and when we reached the water line, I turned to see a giant boulder rolling towards us. We hopped out of the way as it’s impact with the sandy floor had slowed it’s progress but we were definitely pretty shaken.

Another guide appeared from somewhere in response to all the noise and yelling and we all just stared at the boulder which had hurtled over the top of the falls.

I know what you’re thinking: Indiana Jones.

Movies we lived: 3

Dian and the new guide warned us to stay back but there seemed to be no imminent landslide and eventually, they waved us on. Dian was actually incredibly apologetic, bless him, but it wasn’t his fault: these things happen and there’s no way of controlling them. And if he hadn’t be watching and warned us out of the way, we would have been in serious trouble. Just: yikes.

Anyway, it doesn’t do to dwell on such things and despite slightly shaky knees, we pressed on and reached a small pool at the side of the river. The locals who were taking photos grinned at us and commented “Lucky!” which I think was a consensus all round.

They’d brought a bunch of fruit with them: little scaly-looking brown things, about the size of a kiwi but with a pointy tip, and we’d been seeing them everywhere. We asked what they were and Dian told us they were called Salak (or, as it turns out, snake fruit due to their scales - very apt. Very asp.) He asked the group if we could try one and they happily obliged, so he popped one open for us and we snacked on the fruit inside.

The interior looks a bit like 3 giant garlic cloves: each one contains a large, acorn-like seed and the surrounding fruit is smooth and dry, a bit crisp like an apples, but more rubbery than wet. However, it crunched up rather nicely and tasted a bit like pineapple and pear. Yum!

And actually, as all I’d had to eat up to that point was half a cereal bar, it was very welcome.

It was time to begin the climb to the cave, and it was no surprise to either of us at this point that the route seemed to be directly up through the waterfall. We just had to make the best of it, and try not to think about the fact that when we climbed a waterfall in New Zealand, we’d had to wear hard hats, a harness and be attached to bolted down safety lines in two places at all times.

It’s all chill. Ish.

When we had almost reached the cave, Dian indicated the last few steps were straight through the waterfall flowing freely beside us, and suggested we leave our bags at this point so that they didn’t get completely submerged. A wise move as the torrent of water was unrelenting and by the time I’d clambered through the falls, I may as well have had a shower fully clothed. Pete’s experience was similar. It was exhilarating though!

Dian hoped through the falls in a manner that was nimble enough to be embarrassing - he wore sliders for the whole trip naturally, the terrain presenting zero obstacles for him - and joined us as we ducked through a curtain of water and entered the cave.

While the cave wasn’t enormous, it was extremely intricate. It seemed to be formed from draping sheets of velvet which, when you pressed your hands to then, were of course textured rocks. Stalactites hung from the gloom above, some dripping water on us, some slender and soundly and some grasping the floor in enormous columns. We were almost up to our knees in water and our footsteps disturbed the silty sand, sending it dancing into murky clouds. Despite this, Dian pointed out the tiny fish which swam about and we laughed, attempting to scoop one up in our hands before pouring them gently back into their home.

There were lots of little nooks and crannies in the cave, with weird and wonderful organic shapes and as we splashed about and explored I was constantly compelled to touch the rocks as they were so tactile; their feel was often completely different to their appearances. Pete wondered aloud if bats lived inside the cave, and said he felt like Tomb Raider.

Movies we lived: 4

We scrambled up a rocky slope towards the back where a waterfall came from nowhere, gushing out over the stones lost in darkness above it. It was surprising how little the light penetrated given that the cave was quite small,

We emerged back through a curtain of spray to begin our climb back down the gorge. Crossing over the waterfall, we collected our bags and climbed and slithered down the way we’d come up.

However, we didn’t go all the way down: just far enough to connect to the “path” back up the gorge to the start of the trail. Dian told us that was the end of the water crossings so we plonked down and emptied the sand, grit, small stones and rocks that had found their way unbidden into our shoes.

We poured plenty of water out too.

The climb was steep and quite the effort but fairly uneventful. Going up is easier than going down, but also, it’s harder. Fact. IYKYK.

And if you don’t know, going up always feels more stable and steady than going down. However, it makes you much more out of breath.

Anyway, we trudged along behind Dian and plodded our way methodically up the steep, rock-cut steps that marked our passage. The steps were often knee-high and above requiring legs to put in a solid effort, but they got there in the end and after a couple of short rests, we achieved an actual paved path near the top.

We stopped at a small stall for a break and Dian asked the lady if we could eat a couple of her snake fruit, she gladly obliged which was very kind and refused to take any money for them, so Pete paid her to use the loo instead. Dian had a good chuckle over Pete trying to open the Salak, the skin refusing to give and then seeds popping willy-nilly out of the cloves. But we enjoyed the snack and it revived us for our final walk.
