It was only another ten minutes walk or so back to where we’d left the driver and we turned down the offer of a motorbike ride and stepped it out. We were both keen to ditch our footwear at this point: Pete reckoned he had half the river still swimming about in his shoes. Which was funny, because the other half was in mine.

While I couldn’t really change, I did manage to swap walking boots for flip flops and was able to dry off a little with my towel, which felt good, Pete swapped his soaking shorts for his unworn (and therefore dry) swimmers and then we settled into a table at the little lunch stall for a bite to eat.

The lady brought us chicken soup, rice and some sort of salsa. I scooped up a spoonful of the latter to taste and was surprised to find it to be absolutely fiery hot, so I used it quite sparingly after that. Tastes great though!

The soup was also delicious, being more a sort of broth with shredded cabbage, noodles, chicken and some unknown veg, but really well seasoned with tasty spices and lemongrass. Absolutely hit the spot and it was so nice to be able to tuck into an actual local dish.

Take that, Burger King.

Once we’d finished our lunch, it was time to head back to Malang. I spread my towel over the seat to avoid transferring too much damp to the car, and we made the journey back to our hotel. As we set off, Pete said I could have both of his thoughts (which seems imply that he only has two but I’ll give him the benefit of the doubt and assume that he has more).

Thought one: “This gorge? It’s gorge-ous.”

He was quite proud of that.

Thought two: Pete was struck by how people living in really remote parts of the world - like the Indonesian jungle - whose living conditions seem relatively simple to us, are still whipping our their iPhones to make a quick video call at the drop of a hat. And I get what he’s saying: you don’t think “shack in the jungle” and immediately picture high speed internet. But it does kind of show how much of a necessity the technology has become and it’s ever more becoming the single biggest factor which unites humanity.

I alternated between listening to my audiobook and dozing and we arrived back at about half two, stumbling inside clutching damp bags and sodden gear.

Back in our room, we unpacked, peeled off soggy clothes and aimed to wash our boots in the shower. The irony being, I pointed out to Pete, that the only dry piece of clothing to survive the trip was my swimming costume.

It has been an energetic day so we were quite happy to chill for a bit before dinner, enjoying being clean and dry, checking out everything we needed for the next day and working on editing photos and journaling.

And tea and biscuits. Equally important to work on those.

We decided to try dinner at the hotel and set forth, armed with our hunger and short list of errands. We first popped over to Indomart (traffic defeated) and picked up some more milk. And biscuits. Because somehow, inexplicably, we were out of both.

Then we returned to the hotel and hit the restaurant. The waiter came to meet us as we entered the dining room and we asked for a table, miming two people. He looked taken aback and unsure, but we repeated our gestures and mimed eating until he seemed to cotton on that we wanted to dine. Mission accomplished.

There were two other occupied tables but otherwise the room was quiet and empty. After a while, we wondered if the restaurant wasn’t serving food at all as no one was eating and the other two tables seemed to be deep in consultation. Eventually though, one table finished what they were doing and the waiter brought us a menu. It seems the restaurant only has two and they were both in use.

Having said that, the menu wasn’t massively useful to us as we didn’t really understand what was on it. So I ordered mie goreng as I knew what it was, and when I’d told Pete that I was pretty sure that “ayam” meant chicken, he picked a dish at random that had chicken in the name.

The complete and utter failure of the sporadic-at-best wifi didn’t give us a chance to decipher anything really.

The food was a long time in coming, but come it did and was pretty tasty. I slurped up my noodles, the omelette pieces on top were lovely and light and I got some prawn crackers with it which I call a win.

Pete’s dinner turned out to be fried chicken pieces and a sweet-and-sour sauce which he was actually pretty happy with. The man loves a nug and that’s basically what he got.

After dinner we totalled up our cash, did a quick back-of-envelope calculation to try and work out what we’d need for the next week, and then popped to the cash machine over the road to top up our supplies. The ATM pods are always air conned to the max and we accidentally disturbed a tiny lizard. Good times to be had all round.

Back at the hotel, we collected our laundry and they promised to deliver it to our room, and we checked how long it would take to get to the airport the next day. Errands finally complete!

Our laundry did indeed show up to our room and as we were having a cuppa (with milk, baby!) reception rang and said they would shuttle us to the airport for free! Mega win.

So all told, with a little light packing, more tea and some biscuits, it was a successful evening’s effort. All that remained was to watch and snuggle down for a good, sensibly timed, sleep.

posts.title: Honeymoon Volcanoes
posts.content:
Day 11

OK, so technically it is day eleven and arguably it is Monday, but when you’ve barely slept and your alarm wakes you up at 00:15, it doesn’t really feel like it. Even thought we’d aimed for a solid 4 hours of sleep (party time) I got significantly less than two.

This volcano business better be worth it.

We had booked a sunrise trip to go and see Mount Bromo, an active volcano a few hours away from Malang. And if you want the sunrise baby, you’ve got to get up early.

So we dragged ourselves downstairs with our daypacks and slumped in reception waiting for our ride. Despite some misgivings about the driver possibly turning up to the previous mystery hotel, our ride showed up 37 minutes late (again, just within IST - Indonesian Standard Time) and we set off. Would have liked the extra sleep though.

The ride in question was technically a Toyota Landcruiser although I just thought of it as the jeep, and Pete and I clambered into the back in the dark. It was extremely cramped: there was a short bench on either side of the van and a French couple occupied one of them leaving Pete and I to take the other so that I was pressed against the driver’s seat and Pete was jammed against the door. We arranged our legs in the limited available space, alternating with the French couple and figuring out the most mutually beneficial system, and the jeep bounced and rumbled off into the night.

So, it’s worth saying it was not comfortable! I had naively thought I would drop off during the drive and catch a bit of kip, but that was a non-starter. The jeep was loud, and while it wasn’t super quick, it was powerful and never gave up. It was also jerky and bumpy and in order to stay perched on our benches Pete and I ended up squeezing together tightly, holding on to each other, the driver’s headrest and some convenient(ish) canvas straps nailed to the ceiling. It wasn’t long before our bottoms were quite numb.

In the end, I decided to listen to the end of my audiobook (the excellent London Rules from the Slough House series) and that proved a solid distraction. And in many ways, the journey passed relatively quickly. After a couple of hours, leaving the city of Malang behind and gradually ascending narrower mountain roads, we passed the point that “ordinary” cars were permitted to drive: the sheer gradient of the road coupled with the twists and turns proved the jeep very much a necessity. I had to keep myself in my seat using my legs and hanging onto the strap in order to not completely slide down the seat and squash Pete on the steeper inclines. We made a brief pit stop and we all piled out of the jeep to stretch our legs. We learned that the other guy in the jeep was a fellow Londoner but as he was travelling solo, had had the enviable position of riding shotgun. Fair play.

Pete and I switched positions for the last hour of the drive - having tested both seats, I rated the back spot more highly as I could lean against the door. The road gave out, and we drove across country for a while, bumping over sandy dunes and rutted muddy tracks, throwing up clouds of dust. Eventually we reached more road and started to climb again; I could feel the altitude in the popping of my ears.

We passed the first lookout point and the second, each crowded with jeeps and shuffling tourists making their way through the dark. Our driver explained to us that we would be going to the final and highest viewpoint to watch the sunrise; he seemed to think this the best, and who were we to argue?

He found a space to wedge the jeep in between scores of others and, advising us to stick together, led us up the road. We climbed a short way before taking a footpath through an array of stalls. We were ushered into one - brightly lit and full of chattering tourists - and our driver called friendly greetings to the owner. We were brought a hot drink each (tea for me, coffee for the others) and a plate of fresh, hot fried bananas also landed on the table.

And it was all delicious! Because sometimes when it’s 3:45am, it turns out what you really need is a hot cup of something that thinks it’s tea and a tasty fried banana with a thin, crispy, battered shell. Until this point, I hadn’t really noticed it was cold, but having a got drink to hold certainly put the shivers at bay, even though I think they were more due to tiredness than actual cold.

As we munched, our driver explained to us that he had a special strategy to help up make the most of our visit. Instead of joining the throng heading down the mountain after sunrise, we would hang back, visit other viewpoints that would be empty, and go to see the volcanic crater a little after everyone else making it less busy. A strategy indeed!

Our morning snack consumed, our driver led us up to the viewpoint. You would think it was Arctic, the sheer quantity of clothes and hats and blankets and gloves that most people seemed to be labouring under. As we got to the top, a series of big concrete steps formed seats for the hoards waiting. But our driver had different plan in mind. Checking out a special area at the front first which was full, he then proceeded to the barriers between the cliff top and seating. Looking back over his shoulder he called “I have a secret spot!” And then he swung himself under the railings and jumped down about 5 foot to a ledge below.

And so we followed him. Lemmings.

To be fair, there was a sizeable space in the dirt underneath the barriers and with no other barriers or tourists to get in the way, our view would be uninterrupted. It was 4:30am with sunrise set to occur around 5:00am. Our driver said we should catch the sunrise, take some pictures, hang around a bit and return to the jeep for half six. And off he went.

That left us with a bit of time to kill so Pete and I plopped to the floor and nestled together to keep warm. I was reasonably snug in my hoody - apart from cold hands - but Pete’s clothing was lighter than mine and in the end, he borrowed my waterproof as an extra layer. We were out of the wind which was good and Pete wrapped his arms around me so that he could also warm his fingers in my hoody front pocket. We watched the stars overhead and waited for shapes to appear out of the darkness of the landscape below.

It began with a red tinge to the sky in the east and this gradually brightened to orange, showing up the purple-grey splashes of clouds over the horizon and distant mountain tops reaching out of low-lying cloudscapes.

As this grew stronger, we could see more of the view mapped out below us: the jagged line where lush, green fields suddenly dropped away to grey, volcanic lands. The sea of sand, stretching below us as a flat, almost featureless plain. And the cones of the volcanos jutting forth, Mount Bromo a gaping crater, smoking quietly.

The sunshine gradually bathed all this in golden light and we enjoyed watching the illumination, taking pictures and drinking it all in. As other tour groups started to dissipate, we scrambled back up and over the barriers to enjoy the views from the seating area above. The sun soon had heat in its path and my chilled fingers started to defrost, while Pete spread forth his arms in welcome, calling to the solar orb “Absolute rays! Heat me up, rays”. He was quite animated and it made me laugh.

Local women wondered around trying to sell us bunches of dried edelweiss, including some blooms that were dyed and shaped to look like teddies. Pete was suitably baffled and appalled by the sheer tat factor, and while they seemed strange souvenirs to us, they were undeniably popular.

Just: why?

We headed back to our jeep as commanded, arriving as a little bunch to hop back into the vehicle and begin our mountain descent. We stopped at two other look-outs on the way down giving us slightly different perspectives on the volcanos, and the driver who was clearly a dab hand with the old holiday snaps, took some photos for us. Even though it was only just gone seven, the sun was getting hot, and we started needed to shed our outer layers and plaster on hats and shades.

We were also getting peckish and so we were all quite happy when our next stop was down in the sea of sand for a picnic. Up close, we could see the valleys and crevasses carved into the slopes of the volcano - from above, they had seemed to be small scratches, but level with cones themselves, we could see that each rise and fall had the magnitude of a hill in its own right. We munched through our breakfast boxes while we contemplated our geological companions, and I enjoyed an orange, a cheese and boiled egg sandwich (although I couldn’t get my egg to crack so I had to bash it on the jeep in the end) and a jam sandwich. Works for me - it was tasty and perked us up for the next and final phase of the day.

But was it breakfast? On the one hand, we ate it around half seven. On the other hand, we had been up for seven hours. Does that make it lunch? So confused - we’d had an awful lot happen before eight in the morning.

The driver let me sit up on the Jeep’s bonnet for a few intrepid explorer type pictures - fun times, am obvs v powerful and impressive and should lead expeditions and whatnot - and then we packed everything back into the van to drive to the start of the crater hike.

I say hike: our driver said we might need two hours to visit the crater, saying it was about a 45 minute walk to the top. Pete and I didn’t exactly hurry but we made the distance in 25 minutes easy.

The walk set out over the sand first off: dark grey, dusty and heavy with volcanic cast-offs, we were soon coated in fine powder, trudging through the soft, cloying stuff. A short-ish climb followed and while it was relatively steep, it should have been easy. However, the altitude was making its presence felt and I was gasping for air remarkably quickly compared to how I should have been feeling.

Locals with horses were constantly looping around attempting to sell us a ride to the steaming crater, but we resisted and finally made it to the last stretch. A couple of hundred steps led up to the volcano’s rim (236 give or take, according to Pete) and we plodded up then slowly, starting to feel a little too warm under the beating sun and taking a couple of little rest breaks.

Reaching the crater was quite impressive: we looked down into a hole sunk deep in the heart of the volcano and as smoke twisted and curled in little puffs from the abyss, I felt like I could almost make out hot, bubbling sulphurous water. The sides of the crater had patches of poisonous yellow and dark lava flows had cooled and locked into brilliant textures.

We pondered going for a walk along the rim, but as the safety rail gave out fairly quickly, we decided not to risk it. I think we are gaining in maturity.

Which was true until I felt the need to sing “He was a crater boy” to Pete who I think was enormously impressed and amused at my wit but managed to suppress his response quite effectively. It’s the only explanation.

We trailed back across the sand following our visit to #therealmountdoom having successfully avoided throwing any of our rings into it and gratefully received a water bottle each from our driver. Once the rest of our crew appeared, we piled into the jeep for one last time to journey back to Malang.

We actually dropped the French couple at a nearby village which gave Pete and I loads of space in the back of the van. Initially this seemed great, but we soon found that being wedged in does actually help you stay in your seat and we crammed back in together for part of the way so that I could lean on Pete.

When we reached actual roads again, I returned to my own side of the Jeep with half an ear on a podcast and managed to doze a bit. Pete reckoned it would be impossible but I was pretty sure I could achieve slumber.

Back at our hotel, we slumped into our room, made a pile of our dusty gear so as not to infect the cleanly made bed and both had a much needed and much appreciated shower to remove an accumulated layer of grime. A cup of tea and an episode of Modern Family fortified us enough to sort out some laundry and head out for a bit to eat.

We ended up at Burger King again due to a dearth of local options and neither of us could face the battle with taxis and the insane city traffic required to get anywhere. We put away a burger each, tried on a cardboard crown which we decided not to keep, and the headed to Indomart to pick up a few bits for dinner. We were both eager for a relaxed evening in and and early night and so some spicy noodles were just what we needed.

I was going to pay with cash but Pete insisted on trying my card first. Indomart never take our card despite having a machine, and Pete takes this as a personal insult. I bet him 1000 IDR that it wouldn’t work and when I eventually had to hand over cash, after unnecessarily elongating the payment process, I won my bet.

Pete: you owe me 6p. I’m going to spend it all at once because you can’t stop me.

Returning to our room with our spoils (after playing and winning Road Cross 2: Attack of the Mopeds - now with real, completely irrelevant traffic lights) I made tea and we spent a chill couple of hours catching up with admin and, in my case, journalling.

Speaking of the journal, Pete would like the following observations to be made: “I’m sleepy”.

Noted.

I tried and failed to get some tickets booked for Vietnamese trains, made tea WITH AN ACTUAL MILK-STYLE PRODUCT and we made our spicy noodles to enjoy alongside an episode of Lost. A winning combo.

We were aiming for an early night and given the minimal sleep we’d experienced the previous night, we were reasonably hopefully that we’d drop off early. So with bags packed, another round of teas made to enjoy with a biscuit - my favourite Vietnamese peanut butter jobbies, natch - we settled down

With our alarms set for 5:45 the next morning because why not?

therealmountdoom

posts.title: Honeymoon Organisation
posts.content:
Day 9

I slept better than I thought I would on the train, waking every so often to change positions when my legs cramped up or my neck cricked. Mostly I was just happy to shut my eyes and relax.

Around six, Pete poked me awake. The stewards collected our blankets and we proceeded to pull into a station that was similar name to the one we expected but not quite right. We weren’t sure if we should get off or not, Pete was consulting the map and the clock, realising that we weren’t quite in the right place, but also slightly concerned that the train might not stop at the next station.

In the end, I waved my ticket at a member of train staff who gestured that we should not in fact get off the train. This seems to be the go-to way to get around on Indonesian trains: if you show your ticket to enough people, they’ll help you get on and off the right train. Winner!

When we arrived at the right station, we hustled off with the crowds and made our way to the main concourse and exit. We needed to find a taxi to our hotel, but try as we might, we couldn’t locate a taxi rank. Loads of people were getting into pre-booked cars but the normal swarm of punters who normally try and flog you a ride weren’t present.

We used our standby of asking a guard, but he mimed using a phone to book one and without a local sim or any wifi, that wasn’t going to work. Pete asked another guy who was manning the traffic, but he indicated the same thing. No go.

How was there no taxi rank at a busy station?

Pete reckoned it was an hour and a half’s walk through the city to our hotel which felt like a no with the heat and our bags. Our next idea involved walking out of the station and trying to flag down a taxi on the road beyond.

We didn’t even make it to the road before we realised there was no pavement and just insane, kamikaze traffic which is proving to be a staple of each city in Java.

We went back into the station and mimed to the security guards that we wanted to go back in and investigate the exit on the other side. We mentioned the word taxi and he seemed to think this was a good idea. Would this work?

We climbed up the walkways to the bridge over the platforms, walked around the back of what I can only assume is the Indonesian equivalent of Zumba class which was attended but a large number of ladies wearing head scarves, and trekked back down to find the station’s other exit.

We were immediately pounced upon by a chap trying to sell us a lift. We were so grateful we didn’t even haggle. We hopped into the back of a rickety van, whose windscreen had so many stickers plastered to it that the driver couldn’t see out properly and kept having to contort into awkward angles to look for traffic lights, and some 15 minutes later, we clambered out again at our hotel. Phew!

Not an adventure you want to have when you’ve had scant sleep on an overnight train.

The hotel looked lovely - a top find from Pete - and at reception, they said for an extra 200000 IDR, we could have the room immediately. Given that this equates to £12, we were keen to grab some shuteye and so we toddled on up to our sleeping quarters, dumped off our bags and fell asleep.

We did set an alarm for around nine in case we fancied breakfast, but actually when nine came, what we fancied was two extra hours of kip. So it was more like eleven when we finally surfaced and felt ready to take on the world.

We had a few errands to accomplish for the day, namely to plan and book a couple of excursions we wanted to do, and to acquire food and water. We did a bit of internet research but would rather book direct with locals. So we sorted ourselves out, got ready and left the hotel around one in the afternoon.

This immediately proved to be a poor decisions and after ten minutes of stomping around and getting nowhere, we hadn’t spotted any taxis or means of acquiring one. So we returned to our hotel and they ordered one for us. Fair play.

Pete had identified some tour companies on Google maps he thought looked promising and so we took the taxi to a nearby park and set off on food to investigate. It was a bit of a shambles to be honest. The pavement wasn’t so much a pavement as a heap of dust, rubble, building projects and weeds. You had to walk in the road half the time and then if felt like we were fair game for the jostling motorbikes. We did find one of the agencies but when we asked a chap inside about booking a tour, it was clear he had no idea what we were talking about. Fair play. We thought maybe it was more of a travel agent for Indonesians instead of a tour office for tourists.

We walked all the way along the street, crossed the road and picked our way back down it without finding anything that looked promising. I was just about done figuring we’d have to book through the big internet tour companies after all, when Pete spotted a shack that said Tourist Information. It looked dark and shut up and distinctly unpromising as we circled it, but the fourth side yielded a door and lady inside, sitting in front of posters advertising tours. So chalk one up for Pete for showing top notch perseverance!

The lady was able to book us the Mount Bromo tour we were hoping to do for less than half the price of the internet, and gave us information about the waterfall visit we were interested in too. We decided to ponder this over lunch, and Pete - who is never one to miss a trick - had already clocked a Korean BBQ place over the road. It seemed popular with lots of tables full and as we entered, various staff scuttled about, debating who was going to try and deal with the foreigners.

In the end, one of the waiters stepped up to the challenge, took us to a table and explained the menu. We opted for the “deluxe” which sounds fancy but was the most basic deal meaning we would just use the grill and we would stick with chicken (instead of chicken and beef - that’s apparently more deluxe). He then lit our grill pan, spread it with butter and indicated that we should help ourselves to food from anything in the fridges with blue labels. Simple enough.

And so we made a very tasty lunch, sampling chicken marinated in a range of different sauces - Inferno was the best in my opinion - and tasting one or two of the extras. Onions fried up quite well and I added them to some noodles I found, but slightly less appetising were various fish balls and things. They were just a bit bland and, well, odd. With several glasses of chilled squash and a soft serve ice cream each to finish, we made a good meal!

Actually, the ice cream nearly didn’t happen as Pete couldn’t get the machine to work. However, I got one of the waitresses to show me, and she pushed a button and then it worked fine so I could pull my own ices cream. I also added a scoop of nuts but they went pretty much everywhere except on my ice cream so that was a fail. Once I’d eaten a bit more of my ice cream and there was space in the tub, I managed to sneak back for extra nuts and I do not regret it because yolo.

After lunch, we popped back to tourist information and booked the waterfall tour, having a lovely chat with two students who were interning there and hoping to become tour guides when they graduated. They were so friendly and welcoming and we discussed the challenge of understanding English in a range of accents. They reckoned Australians were the hardest to understand, but also the Dutch.

The lady who’s booked for us ordered us a taxi and this caused no end of trouble as she couldn’t find the address in her phone. She suggested we walk but again, we were a solid ninety minute’s walk away in a city which is definitely not pedestrian friendly. A local cat hopped into the room and jumped up onto the table to stick its paw and nose in, pretending to help but really just after some nice strokes, and eventually, the lady said she’d ordered a car on her phone and it would be with us shortly.

When the car pulled up, she told us it would be 12000 IDR which seemed suspiciously cheap, and sure enough after about 5 minutes, the driver pulled us into the wrong hotel.

We spent an unproductive few minutes arguing, him saying it was our hotel, us saying it wasn’t, until the hotel porter came to the car and backed us up, saying this wasn’t the hotel we were looking for. Fact. I mean, there was a totally different name plastered across the sign.

Another round of negotiations ensued and we lost, agreeing to pay 70000 to get us back to our hotel. We couldn’t really do a lot without the app and the whole thing was a bit of a disaster. Clearly just getting a taxi isn’t really a thing here.

So a little before five, we found ourselves back at our hotel having paid over double what the fee should have been. Sigh. Win some lose some.

We spent a bit of time chilling in our room. It was satisfying to have the next couple of days planned and organised and we sorted out our budgets and cards, pondered when and where to do our laundry and put together a blog post. Plus we had a cup of tea and some biscuits because you can take us out of the U.K. and give us mediocre teabags and powdered milk, but you can’t take away our unshakable belief in the power of a brew and a biccie to pick you up.

In fact, Pete was so overcome when we reached the end of the biscuits that I performed a short haiku of lament. I only turned in for the end as I was concentrating on writing my journal but it was terribly poetic and finished on the phrase:

“Light, empty, sadness”

And was punctuated by Pete hefting the empty packet in a forlorn way. He refused to repeat the full haiku though so that will be lost to memory, and a great sadness to mankind that will be.

I feel like womankind will get over it.

Eventually we roused ourselves to head out in search of some evening snacks and to top up our cash reserves - Indonesia is very much a cash economy and very few places will take cards. We set out into the now dark evening and played chicken with the traffic, trying to get to a shop that was about 2 minutes walk away but nestled on the wrong size of about 6 death traps. By which I mean roads filled with Indonesian Drivers. After about 45 minutes or so, we wiggled through a tiny gap in the onslaught and made it over to Indomart. We were become Indomart regulars: patronising these portals of convenient snack foods that kept us fed.

We spent an enjoyable time selecting our spoils for the evening, playing noodle roulette with all the different coloured packaging that we could read. Our game plan works on 3 basic principles:

1) The noodles should come in packaging you can eat out of, hotel rooms rarely supplying crockery for such a purpose.

2) They should be spicy AF. Angry black and red colouring on the packet and extra spiky fonts are usually a good indicator of this.

3) If the writing looks like it might be sort of Korean, you’re on to a winner.

We found some noodles that fit this principles, I stocked up on my new favourite peanut butter biscuits and my new favourite BBQ potato flavour crisps, and we picked up an apple each because it felt like we ought to eat a nutrient.

Apples were crazy expensive again. But it’s worth it for the scurvy avoidance I suppose. We also found a pack of black tea which was handy as our hotel only supplied green. It’s not the same. And my personal stash of teabags purloined and saved from various establishments was running low.

We made it back across the traffic with our haul intact, topped up our funds at the cash machine and retreated to our room to make noodles and watch Slow Horses.

The noodles did not disappoint, and we were both silently weeping into our respective pots. Tears of joy, naturally. Meanwhile, we had to eat them away from the bed as blood-red chilli sauce and clean white sheets do not a combo make.

While I do enjoy having meals out, I enjoy it more when it’s something we do for fun, instead of something we have to schlep around and figure out every night. Eating out is awesome, but I also totally love the evenings we spend hunkered down after a good day, just relaxing, reflecting on our adventures and tearing up over ridiculous chillis. Get yourself a travel partner who will eat insanely spicy noodles with a spork in bed with you while you watch Netflix. That’s living, right there.

And yes, we did bring our sporks with us for exactly this occasion.

We sampled the rest of our snax relaxing back against the pillows and it was soon time for one last tea (for me, Pete somehow declined) and bed. An actual full night in a proper room. Luxury!

Day 10

We got up around eight and headed down to investigate the breakfast buffet. It was the now-familiar Indonesian breakfast spread - although to be fair, we aren’t sure what’s traditional and what’s just bonus buffet material.

Anyway, I had noodles and a vegetable omelette, a tiny banana and some cornflakes and to finished, a donut.

I suspect the latter of not being traditional, but everywhere we go for breakfast has a cake platter so it seems rude not to indulge.

Pete opted for boiled eggs, some chicken, rice and a slice of a curious egg and vegetable omelettey thing that had a crispy outer coating. It was pretty good - I think I liked it more than Pete did.

Neither of us could bring ourselves to try and opaque and faintly luminous jelly slabs that faded from bright pink to an aqua green. There’s something about food that wobbles and glistens in that way that just says to you: no.

No idea what it was.

The only downside was that tea isn’t really a breakfast thing here, but I soldiered on impressively anyway.

Once we’d got ourselves ready for the day, we headed down to the hotel lobby and asked them to ring us a taxi. As we waited, loads of people were coming and going and we thought there was probably a wedding taking place as everyone seemed dressed up. Not that our shorts and tees weren’t super glamorous of course, but we couldn’t compete when it came to beading and sequins.

Our taxi arrived and whisked us off to our destination: Jodipan.

Jodipan is a small area of Malang with an interesting recent history. Condemned for destruction but the government, and thought to be an unhygienic and run-down slum, a group of students banded together to save the area by painting it in bright, bold colours.

Partnering with a paint company, each residence was painted different rainbow shades, and meanwhile, the students worked with residents to develop better sanitation practices and installing rubbish bins and toilets.

Living conditions were drastically improved and the explosion of colour started to attract tourists. The small entrance fee to visit the area feeds directly back into the community, and also the visitors afford locals the opportunity to sell drinks and snacks and so on.

Jodipan is actually a cluster of three separate villages. Our taxi dropped us at the side of the road on a bridge over the area, and as we walked across it, we could see the brightly coloured rooftops below.

We started off in Kampung Warna Warni (Village of Colour) and paid our 5000 IDR to enter. Which is about 30p. We spent the next hour or so wandering happily among the houses, squeezing between little alleyways and exploring the beautiful and cheerful decor. We found murals, painter stairways, passages hung with umbrellas and signs made from plastic bottles. The paths were clear and free from rubbish (unlike most of the rest of the pavements we’ve attempted to traverse) and steep staircases had ramps down the middle so that residents can get their motorbikes in and out. We saw a few people here and there but it was mostly quiet.

We crossed a foot bridge over the river and then entered Kampung Tridi (3D Village), paid another 5000 IDR each, accepted a souvenir elephant keyring and continued to explore. The village on this side of the river was similarly decorated, and we once again enjoyed the murals, spotted scrawny kittens slinking about, hens being expelled from doorways and loads of pot plants and seedlings planted in cut-off plastic bottles creating a leafy feel. We found a couple of view-points featuring classic, honeymoon heartshaped frames, and it was fun to take some pictures.

We were slightly struck by the strangeness of the situation: we we wandering around gawping at other people’s lives to some extent and it made us think about whether this was exploitative. In the end we decided no, mostly because it seems as though visitors are actively encouraged and because the ticket money funds developments in the villages. But it’s a find line nonetheless.

Returning to the road, we crossed the bridge once more, taking in the views of the village on the other side, this time decked out all in blue. Kampung Biru Arema (the Blue Village) had seen how their neighbours had fared following their paint job and figured they may as well do the same thing. This village has focused on one palette however, and the shades and tones of blue on blue are cool and inviting. Again, we say many murals, most notably for the football team, whose mascot featured around every corner and whose portraits adorned one wall. We also saw two or three murals advertising the outdoor paint that had presumably played a key role in the transformation.

This village had a slightly different character: there was no one to pay at any point and it seemed a little bit more like invading someone’s private life. A gaggle of small children followed us for a while, calling “Hello! Hello Mister!” and giggled, turning away shyly and hanging back whenever we returned their waves and hellos.

We began to feel more like we were thrusting ourselves into a small local community after a while, and so we decided to head out of the village. I think not having paid to enter did make it seem more like we were treating people like zoo animals and without an explicit invitation to poke around, it was starting to seem a bit like an invasion of privacy. So we ducked out, wandering beneath the hanging lanterns and the lovely hanging orbs constructed from plastic bottles (a craft for the Guides to try, I reckon!) and returned to the road.

Given the challenges we’d faced finding taxis, we figured we’d pop back to the train station and get a ride from there as it was barely five minutes up the road. After a couple of false starts, we found ourselves in the spot where we’d picked up a taxi the previous morning, but there didn’t seem to be anyone obvious around to ask.

Eventually, an older man who’d been lounging in the front seat of his vehicle offered to drive us, and we accepted willingly. Ish.

I say ish, because the back half of his vehicle was a motorbike and in the front was an open seat big enough for maybe one and a half people. But we decided to give it a shot, showed him the hotel address, squashed ourselves uncomfortably into the seat and set off. At least it was cheap.

It turned out not to be as hair raising as I imagined as the streets he took weren’t super busy. And while there was the obviously risk of simply tipping out of the front of the seat, we did at least get a good look at where we were going.

In fact, the streets seemed a deal smarter than most of the ones we had seen. And then they started to look familiar.

Because sure enough, this driver had also brought us to the wrong hotel. The same wrong hotel as the day before. Like, HOW???

We all confused each other merrily over payment - we decided not to even both explaining that this wasn’t where we wanted to be - and instead went inside the hotel to ask them to ring us a taxi.

It was a posh affair, 5 star, and with a wedding in full flow. The guests were dressed to the nines and then some - to the twenty-fives at least when you added in the tall hair feathers - and the buffet had just opened. Inside the lobby, we found reception (next a table manned by three identically dressed wedding guests in flowing gowns who were organising vast numbers of gifts and goody bags) and the staff proved good-natured and friendly. They laughed at our predicament, offered to order us a taxi through the app and asked us about what we were doing in Malang and Indonesia. They also giggled when they found out we’d come in the crazy bike cab, and told us it was called a Becak.

Quite why they couldn’t ring us a standard metered taxi wasn’t clear, but they were super helpful and we figured that if we start at the wrong address, the car would at least know not to bring us back here. A small win, but one we were prepared to take.

I felt a little out of place in my slight grubby shorts and T-shirts, sweating into the hotel’s nice chairs. After a while, we were sent off on a tour of the hotel with one of the porters, taking in the pool, the outdoor restaurant, the Italian restaurant and the gift shop. We were a bit non-plussed but were prepared to go for it if they could help us get back to the hotel.

When our tour finished, the car had arrived and fortunately, this time we were conveyed to our actual hotel. It had taken us over an hour to get back - seriously, how is anyone meant to get around here? It was like a 15 minute drive!!!

We decided we were in need of a cuppa and decided to treat ourselves to a proper one with real milk at the Starbucks over the road. Feeling much more fortified and with a sandwich and a raisin scone inside Pete and me respectively, we hopped back to the hotel and decided to go for a swim.

My prediction that the pool would be chilly was bang on the money and despite the warm, muggy air, we had to swim laps to keep from getting too cold. As we swam, we discussed how this trip has thrown up so many memories from our last trip and we wondered about what that meant: were we living in the past? Were we drawing comparisons?

In then end, we thought no, but it was interesting to think about. I think it highlights that we’re in our element on trips like this, but also the fact that we’re away perhaps automatically makes us think of similar previous times. And that, by reflecting on older memories, we’re building bridges to new ones, enriching them all by drawing the threads together.

Equally, thinking of trips we want to take in the future doesn’t mean we aren’t enjoying the now, just that the present is beautiful and inspiring and it’s natural to dream.

Deep thoughts for quite a shallow pool.

Post-swim, we pooped back up to our room, posted on our blog and settled down to watch an episode of Lost. We worked our way through most of the series last time we travelled and the combination of mystery and adventure seems to work well on the road. So we started from the very beginning and as this was my second viewing, I was interested to see if I would pick up on any of the clues or foreshadowings along the way. This would be Pete’s 3rd viewing and he was deep into the internet, looking up the significance of tiny details to share.

We set out for an early dinner before six wandering the area around the hotel (we had no desire to get a taxi anywhere) and with slim pickings in the vicinity, we ended up at Burger King. The restaurant was doing a roaring trade in delivery orders, and once we’d managed to communicate our order (harder than you’d think given that the menu is entirely in English) we sat back to wait.

We’d both ordered a Black Busan burger - beef for Pete, chicken for me - and as Pete pointed out, we should have been in Busan at this point for real. However, I doubt that we could have had a more authentic experience than the burgers we munched when they arrived. They had black, seeded buns, some sort of unidentified fritter in them, spicy sauce and, inexplicably, a small pot of rice crispies. Because reasons?

The food was tasty enough, the jasmine ice tea I ordered was frankly disgusting being so packed with sugar it made my teeth rattle (I didn’t drink it) and while we can’t claim to have eaten traditional Indonesian food, we did at least eat like locals if the sheer number of Burger King orders were anything to go by.

Back in our room, I caught up with my journal, had a tea and watched and episode of Modern Family with Pete, and then we settled into bed. By 8:00pm.

Why? Because we were getting up at quarter past midnight.

posts.title: Honeymoon Temples
posts.content:
Day 8

We woke to our alarm at eight, feeling a bit sleepy but otherwise none the worse for wear. A shower was particularly welcome and we stumbled down for breakfast to investigate the buffet. It was a huge spread and we had no idea what most of it was, but we tucked happily into noodles, an eggy thing that was a bit like a teriyaki vegetable omlette slice, chicken and prawn crackers. Plus some small cakes, because apparently that’s a thing?

Anyway, this revived us a little bit and we set off down the street to find the nearest cash point and stock up on food and water for the day. To our surprise, the first ATM we found was both a) where the map said it was and b) in good working order and so we availed ourselves fully of its services and then went across the road to a small shop to spend our spoils. We picked up a rag tag collection of crisps, biscuits and water and Pete picked a small cheese cake - we had no idea if it was cheesey or cakey but he was game - and we scuttled back to the hotel.

We packed up our bags, sorted our day packs for the trip ahead and leaving our backpacks with reception, we waited for our driver for the day.

After about 20 minutes he appeared - pretty prompt by local timekeeping lore - and we set off through the jostling, bustling city. It was another scorcher idea the day and the humidity had skyrocketed, but inside the car was cool with a welcome blast of air con. I watched the tangle of the city go by as mopeds with multiple passengers swarmed around us on all sides. It’s an impressively chaotic dance where everyone ought to crash and no one does.

The city itself is chaotic: very lived in, shops and stalls and carts spill out onto the street, shiny, well-kept buildings are interspersed with half-collapsed structures and run-down shacks and greenery takes every opportunity to sprout and grow in the lush climate.

After I while, the motion of the car and our recent dearth of sleep made me feel dozy and I half nodded off as we made our way towards Borobudur.

Borobudur is a 9th Century Buddhist temple which crowns a hill in a pyramid-like formation. It’s covered in reliefs and carvings, huge numbers of statues of Buddha and hundreds of stupa, leading up to the largest ones on top. Borobudur was mostly abandoned by the Javanese following the conversion to Islam in the 14th century but when, in the 19th Century, British chap Raffles on his jolly colonising mission heard tell of the place from locals, he instituted a bit of a clean up and made Borobudur more widely known.

I had visited back in 2015 but it was Pete’s first time on Java so everything was new to him. I could see differences too - you were no longer allowed to climb the huge structure which I suppose is a win for preservation but a lose for being able to see any of the statues or relief detail. Plus I had been looking forward to the views from the top! We spent a while debating this: who and what is preservation for if no one can see any of the thing being preserved? Pete was strongly in favour of restoration so that people can get up close with ancient monuments. I think I’m team partial restoration: restore bits so that you can see how something was supposed to look back in the day, but also leave plenty in its natural state.

I’m not sure there’s a right answer but we were intrigued.

We found a lovely carved Lion statue guarding the bottom of one of the staircases. Lion? Possibly lion, monkey or dragon-dog? Whatever he was, he had a lovely big smile indicating that he was clearly a very good boi and Pete felt we should give him many treats and belly wubs.

I’ll let the pictures do the talking for the temple; suffice to say, we spent a couple of hours meandering around it, had our selfie taken with some locals as the toke foreigners, and then headed back to meet our driver. We were both feeling quite sweaty and the humidity was making us feel weary so we were quite ready for some air con and some snacks.

Indonesia takes the exit-via-the-gift-shop concept very seriously however, and we first had to navigate an intense array of stalls as an impromptu marketplace has sprung up around the exit. We had no need of tiny model stupa - unless, as I suggested to Pete, we bought 126 of them and made a Minibudur at home - and so we were undeterred in our press to the exit. Each time we thought we’d reached the end of the stalls, a new turning would land us in amidst another tightly pressed row of vendors.

We did make it our eventually though, and our driver collected us and drove us on to our next destination: Prambanan.

It was over an hour’s drive away but we munched through some crisps and cookies, Pete learned that his cheese cake was mostly a sort of soft, cake-flavoured sponge, and once again, I found myself feeling sleepy.

Pete poked me awake as we hit Prambanan and once again, we gathered our things and followed our driver who sorted our tickets and set us off into the temple complex.

Prambanan was built in the 9th century and is the second largest Hindu temple complex in Southeast Asia - after Angkor Wat. And actually, the temple buildings did remind us of the bud-like structures that dominate the Angkor Wat skyline. We made for the largest temple structure first: the 47m high curved, pointed central tower drawing everyone towards it. This was flanked by two slightly smaller ones on either representing Shiva, Brahma and Vishnu. Another three towers stood in front and this formed the main platform, and we spent a good while wandering between them, enjoying the carvings. Highlights being the cheery creatures grinning over the tops of the doors and the dragons which roared from the end of the stairways with little bonus demons popping out of their mouths.

Surrounding this central platform is the rubble and ruin of what we’re originally 240 smaller temples, but most of these are now simply heaps of stone thanks to earthquake damage and the passage of time. Walking among these, marvelling at the striking central towers, is quite a powerful experience and again, while I had visited before, it was brand new to Pete.

Once again, any climbing up the levels of the towers is now forbidden, but we’re able to circle around a couple of times and wander through the lush, green grounds surrounding the temple. We came across one or two small structures away from the crowds of the main site (Pete gave one of them 5 temple points), and the oncoming sunset turned the sky a hazy orange as we were treated to short but heavy rain shower.

Pete awarded Borobudur 10 temple points but I’m not sure what that means, except that I think he liked it. And fair play: it’s impressive.

With closing time at 5:30, we were obliged to return to the car and our driver trundled us back to our hotel. We once more popped to the cash machine and the little shop and then settled into a couple of chairs in the lobby to pass the time until our night train. Because why have a good night’s sleep when you can ride a train?

The hotel seemed pretty accommodating, the patchy wifi held out long enough for us to get a couple of blog posts up and we sampled some more of the local junk food. I had a steamed chocolate sponge cake (tasty) and a packet of potato barbecue flavour crisps - lush, I will totally buy them again.

We also had an apple each which was ludicrously expensive compared to the processed rubbish you can by, but pretty much necessary by this point. We retrieved our bags from storage, I made friends with the fish in the water feature who wanted to give me little kisses and I got up to date with my journal.

Finally, oh-so-slowly, the clock reached half eleven and so we hoisted our bags and set off for the train station. Re-tracing our steps from the night before and dodging mopeds and scooters and tuk tuks and cars, we rambled round to the entrance and waved our tickets and passports at the security team.

We wandered on towards the platforms and then shuffled shuffled back again as we had no idea where to go. The security chap proved quite helpful though and advised us to get on at platform three.

We clambered across several tracks to the waiting area. The station was busy, but with people rather than trains. There was a general air of sleepiness as all present simply wanted to get on their train and close their eyes for the night, and the warm, sticky air made everyone feel drowsy.

After about 45 minutes, a promising looking train pulled into platform 3. We joined the general throng moving towards it, but the guard waved us away and said this wasn’t our train. Which was weird as it was the right time, the right platform and seemed plausible. We asked one of the smartly turned out train staff just to be sure, but she confirmed that it wasn’t our train so we had nothing to do but dawdle around for a bit.

Fortunately another train pulled up about ten minutes later and this time the guard seemed satisfied that we had an acceptable ticket. He waved us down the platform for the right car, and piled on in, stashing our bags and sliding into our seats. Finally!

The trusty train crew brought around blankets, the air con started to cool us down a little and the train trumpeted on repeat - it seems to be a thing here, as they sound the horn pretty much constantly - as we rolled out of the platform.

posts.title: Honeymoon Transit
posts.content:
Day 7

H learned roughly nothing from our previous extra long travel journey, we had embarked on a second. Our flight left Male a little late, some time after midnight and landed in Singapore just over 4 hours later. However, with a 3 hour time difference, this made it almost 8:00am so somehow we’d lost the night time.

Plus we discovered our gate for our flight on to Jakarta was MILES away.

We set off walking, feeling a bit dopey, alternating between travelling on foot; riding the tramelators and even taking a small train ride at one point. Singapore Changi is an incredibly cool airport, but it’s just that it’s slightly less so when you have to walk across it all in a transfer window.

Once we’d reached the approximate area of our gate, we decided a cup of tea was in order and we we joined the queue for Starbucks. As did pretty much everyone else in the far reaches of the airport so it was half an hour before we were able to claim our cuppa and found led it was just one guy trying to take orders, make drinks and serve food. Yikes.

Drinks in hand, we then hustled to the gate, knocking back the scalding liquid as fast as we could before submitting to the rigours of airport security which in Singapore, happens at each individual gate.

I do not regret the tea though. That was GOOOOOOOOD.

Despite the fact that the flight was under two hours, they woke us up to feed us some sort of rice and yam and mushroom dish. I could take it or leave it, but the chocolate cookies were tasty! And what with take off, food and landing, that pretty much filled up the whole flight.

It took us a while to navigate Jakarta airport. We had to visit a set of desks with our vaccine certificates and check in on the Indonesian health app, we had to visit the visa payment counters and then the visa counters, we had to go through passport control and through customs and between every step would be another set of airport security staff looking for a particular stamp or piece of paper. We were only sent trouping back once as the health check people had given Pete the all clear but not stamped his boarding pass, but we finally made it to baggage claim and out into the warm, sticky arrivals halls. We waved off the mob of taxi and hotel hawkers, found a cash machine and made ourselves millionaires (for the tune of about £70) and then we gritted our teeth and approach the over enthusiastic taxi crowd. We were offered a ride for 350000 IDR which is steep according to our research so we declined and decided to take our chances outside at the taxi rank, despite the chap calling after us that he would offer us a discount to 300000.

This proved to be a good decision - credit to Pete - as the chap manning the taxi ranks offered us 215000 for a ride to the city. Sold!

Although it must be said, probably what the extra hundred thousand or so buys you is seatbelts and a driver who drives on the road instead of bombing down a hard-shoulder/type gap at the side of the road approximately the width of a cycle lane such that the gap between the concrete barriers and the queue of traffic is slightly narrower than the taxi.

But we made it unscathed and finished the journey by having a bit of a set-to with our driver who wanted extra money for parking which we refused - we’d included a decent tip with our payment partly because fair play, but partly because we had no change, so we weren’t going to add a couple of extra thousand for parking as well.

We stumbled into Gambir train station, slightly disappointed to find it completely lacking in air con and consequently extremely hot and humid inside. A security guard helped us swap the train booking voucher Pete had acquired for actual tickets and then we high-tailed it to the station Starbucks because apparently we’re those people.

Say what you like about Starbucks: when you’ve got a four hour wait for a seven hour train, it’s nice to know you can wait somewhere with wifi, a cup of tea and a seat you can chuck your luggage on.

After a couple of hours and a film, I ventured forth to find us some sustenance. Pete had spotted sandwiches and snacky bits in a little convenience shop, plus water that wasn’t at Starbucks prices, so I picked up a giant bottle (necessary) and a sandwich for Pete.

The whole experience was a bit of a reminder of what life of the road is really like after the not-a-care-in-the-world Maldives. Just little things like navigating squat toilets in leggings without much give, the constant presence of smoke around us in Starbucks, the fact that the second round of teas I ordered was really a cup of hot milk with a teabag floating in it - occupational hazard for a tea drinker in a non-British country where you don’t speak the language and we drank them anyway without comment - and the unforgiving, relentless humidity melting us into puddles.

Having said that, it was also a proper launch back into travel and life on the road, and I wouldn’t swap it!

OK, I would swap the tea, but the rest? I’ll take it for the chance to travel.

We took it in turn to pick up train snax from the various little convenience shops in the vicinity and the hauled our laughed across the station concourse to find out platform. We had to take a covid temperature check (we were melting; how we passed this I have no idea) and show our passports and then we found our train mostly by eye smiling behind our masks and waving our tickets in front of people to point us in the right direction.

Half an hour before it was due, the train was already waiting in platform, so we shouldered onto our carriage - eksecutif 1 - and found our seats. Fortunately the luggage racks overhead were big enough to accommodate our backpacks, and there was plenty of leg room for our day packs and snack bag. Plus the air con was on and they’d furnished each seat with a blanket which promised the train would be cool later on.

The train was pretty full and Pete pointed out when he’d booked our tickets a week ago, that there were very few left, and standard and business class had already sold out. There was an even more fancy train class above ours - eksecutif luxury - but for quite a lot of extra money you didn’t seem to get much more benefit. Our seats reclined a decent way, we had foot stools and little fold out tables, and we were pretty happy to live the semi-cama life for the next seven and a half hours.

I set an alarm on my phone in case we fell asleep before we rolled into Yogyakarta and I also plotted our destination station on my phone so that I could see roughly how far we’d come mid-journey if necessary. Ready for business!

The journey passed relatively comfortably. We sampled the tortilla chips we’d bought - spicy for Pete and BBQ beef for me (Pete’s were better) and I nibbled on biscuits which were a bit like lemon flavoured ritz crackers. A bit weird, but they sort of worked.

I spent the first four hours catnapping, watching Jakarta slip by outside the window, giving way to less and less “organised” streets and buildings into more suburban seeming little communities. Every so often the passage of the train held up the traffic and throng of mopeds would be swarming the barriers, itching to resume their journeys. At one point, several small children were playing on the next track over, one of them dancing and waving ferociously at the passing train.

In the end I abandoned my audiobook as I kept drifting off for a few minutes and suddenly finding I’d lost the thread. However, just before nine, I found myself awake, a little cold from the air con and a bit restless while still feeling tired. Pete was in full slumber mode with his eye mask on and earplugs in, and so I figured I’d watch a film and keep an eye on the time. So I consumed the rest of my tortilla chips, knocked back a few more lemon Ritz and watched Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone. Perfect.

With the film finished, there was a little over an hour to go on the train and I pushed the alarm I’d set a little later and listened to some more of my audiobook. However, this time I caught myself drifting off and abandoned the pursuit earlier. That makes it sound like a bad book: it’s actually excellent, one of the Slough House books, and it’s because I’m enjoying it so much that I don’t want to miss it. But equally, once again it’s been nearly 36 hours since we had a proper night’s sleep and it’s hard for anything to cut through that level of drowsiness, especially a well-narrated audiobook in a smooth voice that you’re listening to with your eyes closed. It invites too much temptation to sleep.

At midnight, the train staff confiscated our blankets, presumably in readiness for pulling into the station, so there was nothing for it but to prepare our bags and wait to slide into the platform. Which we did at around half past midnight. Time for a hotel and bed!

OK, so it took us a little longer to sort that out that we’d hoped for as we could only get out of the station on the wrong side of the tracks. Literally. And this in spite of climbing backwards and forwards through our train and climbing up and down over other train lines. That’s just how the station works.

Anyway, Pete figured it out eventually and after a bit of a walk round - and a wait while a fright train went through and they closed the barriers across the road - we made it to our hotel for the night. Which was actually really lovely, with a giant, meandering fish tank behind reception, a big water feature and best of all, a room with air con and a cold shower.

A quick blast of fresh, clean water from the shower and a round of teeth cleaning and we were ready to sink into bed, leaving tomorrow for tomorrow.

posts.title: Honeymoon Travels
posts.content:
Day 6

Our last day in the Maldives dawned sunny - again. This is more surprising than it may seem as July is very much off season for the Maldives as the weather is prone to rain and thunderstorms. At a resort whose entire premise is built around being outside and open air, storms are of course less than ideal.

But we’ve had none of it: off season deal, high season weather. Winner!

We had been told we didn’t need to check out until 6:00pm which was handy as we could therefore still spend the day swimming and so on, before returning to our rooms for a proper shower and pack. We would then get a speedboat back to Male ready for our flight which wasn’t until 11:25pm. That’s right folks: another series of overnight transport complications as we began the proper “travelling” part of our honeymoon.

But first things first: breakfast. Our all-inclusive access ran out at noon so we hatched a cunning plan to help ourselves to extras from the breakfast buffet to feed us at lunchtime. Goals.

We rocked up with a secret hidden ziplock bag concealed in a bag for life - double subterfuge - and tucked into the usual array of goods. I had some top banter with the omelette guy who was simultaneously knocking up four different omelettes and running a steady stream of innocuous chit chat. My favourite bit was when he asked if I was enjoying the weather - and I said it was beautiful - he laughed and said it was like my smile.

I was wearing a mask.

Ludicrous waffling aside - and actual waffles consumed - we started adding extra pastries, cakes and fruit to our plate. Anything that could reasonably be assumed to survive being smuggled unceremoniously into a bag and saved for later.

We had a reasonable haul and would be sorted for lunch so when breakfast closed we wandered through the insane heat of the morning back to our villa and clocked up some paperwork. We had to check in for our flight, download the Indonesian vaccination proof app and log all our medical info and, unsurprisingly, this was a little time consuming. However, once we’d got that sorted, we were ready to don swimwear and enjoy our last few hours in the sea.

But not without getting one last mango slushy from the swim up bar before our all inclusive ran out.

We idled away the day beautifully, swimming in the sea and the pool and relaxing in the sunshine reading or chatting and just trying to soak up all the beauty around us. The Maldives is picture perfect beautiful, and even that seems cliched in a way that doesn’t do it justice. The unbelievable aqua blue of the crystal clear sea, the perfect, powder white sand and the brilliant blue skies alongside a daily routine that asks you simply to be seems too good to be true and yet it’s here, quietly existing, rolling each day into the next.

Around half two, we were flagging in the heat and decided to head back to the villa, but having trouped all the way there, we found our key cards had stopped working. Sigh.

Fortunately, a passing gold cart took mercy on us and gave us a ride to reception where they updated our key cards and we began the trek back to our little home over the sea.

We couldn’t resist one final swim though - as Pete pointed out, you so don’t often get to jump into the ocean off your own balcony and so it seemed silly not to take more advantage of this. And the water was so cool, a beckoning shade of crystal turquoise, so we hopped in and splashed about, enjoying our last few Maldives moments.

We would definitely be sad to leave, but I suppose that only means we made the right decision to come, to recapture some honeymoon magic and to enjoy a slice of paradise that was just for us.

We spent our last couple of hours in the villa packing and sorting, munching through our breakfast time spoils over a cuppa, and catching another episode of Slow Horses. Then with a final cuppa and a sunset selfie our our villa deck (a bit of a fail as my hair was constantly blowing in Pete’s face and his attempts to hold it out of the way were ludicrous) we checked out.

We made our way to the lobby, settled the bill and then had an hour or so to kill in the lobby bar, which I passed sorting through the various pictures I’d snapped and getting bits and pieces arranged for our blog. At half seven, we ventured to the jetty to meet the speedboat and were whisked across the dark ocean with the other passengers, the flashing lights of Male and the airport beckoning.

The airport run was reasonably smooth and we were able to check in without incident and most of the right paperwork. Proof of a flight out of Vietnam nearly stumped me without wifi but the app I’d booked with seemed to have some sort of residual memory and came up trumps.

Once ensconced in departures, we grabbed a Burger King, splitting some onion rings and tucking into a burger and fries apiece with an abundance of ketchup as Pete got a bit over enthusiastic dispensing his own from the pump.

As we munched, I commented that I was really glad Pete was up this. Which I then realised sounded like I meant sharing a portion of onion rings. While they were the best thing about the meal - both alone and in my burger - what I meant was that I was glad Pete was up for a honeymoon with a backpacking feel that let us explore and venture out instead of staying in one place. Being on this trip definitely made us reflect more on our round the world adventure and it was so magical to recall favourite moments, draw parallels and be reminded of some of our best times.

We shimmied down to the gate soon afterwards and waited for our flight to be announced.

When the time came we boarded, settled down into our seats as much as we could and prepared to sleep for as much of the flight as possible while the kids behind us screamed and kicked the backs of our seats. Honeymoon life, baby!

posts.title: Honeymoon Seas
posts.content:
Day 4

Despite a lovely long sleep, we both still felt a bit snoozy in the morning - I think recent events were still catching up with us a bit - but we ventured forth for breakfast undeterred. A couple of pots of tea and a spread which included omelettes, potato wedges, donuts, chocolate muffins and granola soon perked us up.

It was incredibly warm - it seems that mornings here are particularly muggy which makes for calmer waters, but that when the wind stirs up a little bit, ocean swimming is more of a challenge but the breeze is invariably quite pleasant,

After breakfast, we changed into our swimwear and hit the quiet pool again, because apparently that’s our rhythm now, and we spent a lovely morning swimming in the sea, swimming in the pool and lounging betwixt the two. We watched a couple of fish meander through the water, a heron we keep spotting alighted on the sea wall to intimidate the local crab population and tiny lizards occasionally skittered over the sand. All while the startlingly blue sea did its thing and the sun shone down. Welcome to paradise!

We continued our now tried and tested rhythm with a final quick sea swim before a quick shower and change and off to lunch. I munched happily through a plate of Thai green curry - I’m loving my daily lunch curry - while Pete tackled his standard bit of everything with fish and chips on the side. We have no idea what the fish is though. Then we continued playing rate that dessert, determining that the best of the day’s cakes was Pete’s tres leches cake and that the banana chocolate thing was weird. I looked like cheesecake but the creamy bit was weirdly gritty and extremely soft, as I found out when I tried to slide out a little piece with the tongs and only succeeded in splatting it round my plate. The flavour was fine but overall not convinced.

Fortunately I was able to console myself with a chocolate brownie, a blueberry parfait and a pot of tea. Sometimes you just have to look for those silver linings.

We opted for our traditional afternoon snorkel after lunch and so got kitted up, carefully prepping our masks with soap as we learned from our diving qualification, and headed back towards the quiet pool. Pete reckoned if we slipped out over the sea pool wall, we might find some good bits of reef to explore. And so we did, being only slightly startled by a shoal of tiny fish who chose the exact moment we slipped into the water to jump out of it, making a small splash and a slightly larger commotion.

Also, despite our careful mask prep, they fogged up immediately and so we abandoned protocol and had to settle for flushing them out with seawater. Which worked. Sigh.

Pete’s instincts were as even unerringly accurate. A few moments swimming off the shore out into the lagoon we did indeed come across a feast for the eyes. The reef suddenly dropped away turning the shallow azure waters that ringed the island into an inky blue depth. Think the drop off, a la Finding Nemo.

Anyway, the edge of the drop off was covered in rocks and coral and swarms of fish were busying about, swimming, drifting, nibbling at things and pouting at one another. They all ignored us supremely giving us ample opportunity to drift slowly along edge of the reef, spotting fish both familiar and new and caching brief glimpses of larger specimens sliding in and out of the darker depths beyond the reef. These mostly remained shapeless, being just occasional glimpses silvery scales as they happens to catch a solitary stray sunbeam, but mostly, we couldn’t make out what lurked below.

In the shallows, there was wonderful visibility, and the colours continue to be dazzling. We saw fish with black and white spots, leopard print, bright yellow and black stripes, iridescent purple greens which shifted colours as the fish scales undulated and one particularly impressive orange and pink striped specimen.

Pete managed to catch sight of a pale silvery squid writhing near the surface and I saw it for just a few seconds before it whisked away. I was also super chuffed to have found a couple of tiny clown fish peering carefully out between the fronds of a coral. Or possibly not true clownfish, but something very similar.

Once we’d tracked the end of the reef back towards the sea villas, we swam back into the shore, which proved quite a strenuous task against the current and we were a little out of breath when we bobbed through the feeder gap of one of the sea pools. Feeling tired but happy, we flopped onto a couple of loungers in the shade. Our best snorkel yet!

Somehow the afternoon drifted to early evening so we had a quick shower and change, wandered past the mini sharks enjoying their snax and settled into the Viu bar.

The sun was setting, slipping in and out of the clouds which dappled the horizon and we each ordered a MRS to sip on as we gazed out over the sea. It was incredibly warm, there being no breeze that evening to stir the sticky air and the cold drinks were very welcome. The occasional bat circled overhead, the bartender presented us with a second round of drinks and a cheese sandwich each, and Pete was able to accurately identify it, so winning.

(Side note: I just paused in my journaling for a moment as Pete wondered if I fancied watching another episode of Slow Horses. I asked if he could give me five minutes to finish the journal and he said no. I suggested he make us both a cup of tea and he replied “Noooooo, I’m lying here!” So he’s had a hard day. I then asked him if there was anything he would like to add to the day’s journal and said “Nice snorkelling” which I feel like I’ve already sort of covered so now he’s making tea and I have used most of my bonus time in sharing this anecdote. Mostly because it made me laugh.)

We had one more round of drinks #makingourmoneyback before heading over for dinner at half seven, these evening’s buffet theme being Smokehouse. So of course I had pasta and Pete did the assorted dead animals full justice. Actually, he let me try both his chicken and fish, both of which had great smokey flavours but the former particular was strong with a crispy, chargrilled outside and a tasty barbecue sauce.

Puddings were necessary, naturally, and alongside a pot of tea we tackled white forest cake, almond cake, fresh pineapple, vanilla cheesecake and, my favourite, lemon meringue pie. I had two of those. Not sorry. It was definitely the best. Pete also rated it, and agreed the cheesecake was a good attempt but could be creamier and would be nicer with a fruit element, but then I always thing that about vanilla cheesecake. Like, what’s the point?

After dinner, feeling pretty full, we popped back to the bar for a cold drink as the air was still very hot and clammy despite the appearance of the dark evening. We stuck to soft drinks and lounged on one of the nets stretched out over the sea; I even spotted a shark snaking silently through the waters below. Say what you like about the bar, you can’t argue with the setting.

Eventually, the lure of the air con proved overwhelming and we returned to our room to cool down, journal (in my case) and then enjoy an episode of Slow Horses with a brew. Classic.

Day 5

We woke slightly startled to our 8:30 alarm both having been in the middle of quite odd dreams. But we managed to surface anyway and clear off the table in our villa as this morning was our room service breakfast!

An in villa breakfast was one of the perks I managed to score when trawling the internet for hotel deals in the Maldives, and we’d selected a bunch of options each on arrival. We got dressed and ready and sure enough at nine, our breakfast was delivered, brought into our room and balanced on a tray. The chap who brought it offered to lay it out and somehow that single tray kaleidoscoped out into a huge spread including things we didn’t even remember ordering.

We’d gone for eggs sunny up - two apiece, mostly ordered on my part because it’s fun to say “sunny up” in foreign parts. Fried eggs is just a bit uninspiring in comparison. We’d also got beans, toast, croissants, pain au chocolate, orange juice, muffins - vanilla and chocolate - a fruit platter and yoghurt. Phew!

Oh, and of course a pot of tea each.

Winning!

We put paid to as much as we could, stashed a few leftovers in our fridge, fed some of the watermelon to the fish because it is basically the most disappointing and underwhelming fruit on the planet, and got ready for our bait morning ahead.

Time to paddleboard! The resort lets you take our stand up paddleboards whenever you like so we trotted along to the water sports area and grabbed a board each. They were light weight and easy to slide into the waves on the beach but we soon realised that made them extra challenging to balance. I’m no expert, but I’m perfectly comfortable standing while doing SUP. However, on these boards with the waves going up and down, I struggled. We both did! Even kneeling up, which is normally steady as a rock, I struggled a bit and in the end we both found it easiest sat cross legged a paddling out against the waves as the boards rose and fell.

Having burnt my parting over the past couple of days, I was determined to stay on my board so I could wear my hat against the sun’s scorching rays. It was after all, another scorcher, already over 30 degrees and humid. In fact, it was unbelievably lovely to have the water wash over the board and keep me a little bit cool. So I determined to stay seated if that’s what it took to remain out of the sea, hat intact and I had a lovely time paddling out to sea and then driving my board back into the shore, the waves behind me carrying me faster. It was lush! I even spotted one of the reef sharks swimming past on one of my runs.

Pete however was soon getting down to business. Returning hat and shades to the beach, he was going to SUP if it was the last thing he did, being slightly less willing to embrace the SDP life.

SDP being sit down paddleboard, obviously. I’m embarrassed for you that you couldn’t figure that out from context.

And so he ploughed cheerfully out into deeper waters and got to his feet.

And tipped straight off the side into the water, the fall shooting the board away from him. An energetic swim after it as the waves gently nudged it out of reach eventually put him back in possession of his vessel and he started all over again.

To his credit, while it took him multiple goes - and some ridiculously comic tumbles into the water - he did eventually achieve some sort of mastery over the SUP, managing several reasonably lengthy paddles between subsequent immersions. I have the pictures to prove it. After a while though, the sheer exertion of balancing an uncooperative board in a mocking ocean seemed to pall, and he abandoned his board in favour of snorkelling.

I paddled around for a while longer and then decided that before I too abandoned my board, I’d give standing a go. I slung my bad and shades onto our lounger and returned to the sea, determined to win.

It seems my resilience does not last as long as Pete’s. My first two attempts resorted in sideways collapse and a cartoon-style backpedal over the back of the board. Both ocean plunges also caused me to inhale a large amount of salt water. Yuck.
