The third was a little better and I got a paddle in before I cam crashing down, and my fourth which seemed optimistic also ended in watery failure. In fact, I was neatly deceived as when the board starting tipping to the right I managed to prevent it by leaning left, but of course over compensated and my elation in preventing my fall was quickly snuffed out upon my descent into the sea. And another large shot of sea water to the digestive system. Double yuck.

I figured four goes was enough, and we decided to leave our boards to the experts and Potter round to the quiet pool for the rest of the morning.

I had a swim in the pool, and the sea and then the pool, and Pete went for another snorkel around the reef drop off before we both returned to our loungers for a bit of a chill and a read.

A quick change before lunch and we were ready to take on our final lunch buffet. We had been saying the night before how time has a weird way of passing here. It’s a strange cycle of swim eat swim eat and suddenly it’s the end of the day and nothing has really happened. It’s not a bad thing at all, but I think a few days is probably enough for us, as somehow being in the resort isn’t like being in the real world. Everything is done for you and while there’s a certain simplicity in that, it also sort of removes your choice.

Anyway, lunch was yummy, the desserts being particularly strong across the board so that even though my favourite - the lemon meringue of the previous night - didn’t feature on the plate, the average rating of all the desserts was it’s highest. In fact, honourable mentions go to the chocolate Swiss roll, the pineapple upside down cake and a particularly delectable almond cake with nut brittle topping. Tooth-crackingly tasty.

It was still incredibly hot though - obviously - so we decided to retreat to our room for a little post-lunch air con reprieve. Much appreciated.

We opted to hit the sea for another snork about in the afternoon, so we headed back to the quiet pool, ditched our things and splashed off the little sea wall into the lagoon, sending the little crabs who were out snacking on sea gin scuttling for cover. We had soon paddled out to the drop off and we spent a happy hour floating along over the enormous deep blue aquarium of the ocean, admiring the colours and diversity of the fish and bustling serenity of the coral reef as little creatures snuffled about, floated around and wiggled around each other.

Pete spotted an enormous sea cucumber, I found a sizeable starfish and as we were swimming back to shore, a flurry of small black fish scooted beneath us. Turning, we spotted a good sized shark snaking past on its way. It was both amazing to see one so close and a bit unnerving as even though it couldn’t have been more than 4 feet in length, there is something sinister and predatory about the way sharks swim: with a hunter’s intent and none of the endearing, harmless and gentle bobbing most of the reef fish engage in.

It ignored us entirely, swimming straight and true through the water and we paddled back it into the sea pool through a gap in the sea wall.

We swam a couple of lengths of the pool to rid ourselves of a sticky salty overlay - the pool had absorbed the heat of the sun no end and was bath-like on temperature after the pleasant cool of the sea - and the we reclined for a while on our loungers for good measure.

It wasn’t long before a round of drinks was in order and so we decamped to the pool bar. Or at least I did while Pete returned our snorkelling equipment, there being hefty fines to pay if you leave it in your room. However, as I arrived at the pool, I found it was quite busy: the warm day had brought everyone out, the lure of drinks in the water proving irresistible and while most loungers were unoccupied, they were all claimed. In fact the only available spots I could find were two of the reclining boat seats within the pool, so like a veritable lightning ninja, I made a beeline for them and threw all our possessions into their beckoning - and mercifully dry - cushions.

Then I swam up to the bar because swimming up to things is life. I grabbed us a MRS each before wading happily back through the pool with my prize and we officially commenced pool lounging - not to be confused with deck lounging, beach lounging or even poolside lounging.

Know your lounging, people.

Anyway, we were were on track with our hectic lounging schedule and I was nearing the end of my book and I was definitely at the end of my cocktail. In an unforeseeable plot twist, the rabbi and the porn star had got together and then complications had ensued and they had broken up. With about 15% of the book left to go and no way of predicting how the end would turn out, I reasoned that more drinks were very much going to be in order. I was of course accurate. Pete concurred and I selflessly offered to swim up to the bar and retrieve them.

I swam my little heart out and perched on a submerged bar stool, chatting to another guest and swapping travel anecdotes while the bartender blended ice and mango and happiness.

Also rum.

In fact, I was half way down my cocktail before I remembered I had only fulfilled half of my drinks duty. One must always remember that if you want the reward of swimming up to the bar, you must accept the responsibility of swimming back from the bar. So I excused myself from the chit chat and delivered Pete his slightly melted cocktail.

The sun had started to drop behind the fronds of the beachfront palms and it was a lovely spot to chill and watch the world go by. The beach was being set up for a seafood BBQ with twinkly lights and hanging lanterns, along with an impressive kitchen set up and a stage for the musicians and it was quite impressive the way a restaurant seemed to have sprouted where, a mere couple of hours ago, there had been only sand.

As evening started to draw near, we headed back to our villa as we were both sporting a little bit of sunburn and the heat coupled with cocktails and glowing skin was making us feel a bit woozy. A shower and a cup of tea perked us up though, and we ventured forth for dinner at half seven.

We’d booked the Thai restaurant again for the evening - the $105 per person price tag of the seafood BBQ putting us off somewhat - and it was nice to sit out on the beach, enjoying the live music and the soft breeze coming off the sea. From our table, we had a good view of the twinkly lights and lanterns and enjoyed the live music while we ate - we’re imaginative souls and ordered the same food as before. Because hey, if it’s tasty, it’s tasty!

We followed up our meal with a drink at the bar - just soft drinks though as I think we were both feeling done for the day - and then we wandered back to our villa to chilla.

Couldn’t resist.

I worked on my journal for a bit, Pete did incomprehensible things with his laptop, we complete our Maldives departure forms and we would have checked in for our flight the next day except that the Singapore Airlines website was down for maintenance. That could wait then.

Finally, it was time for a cuppa, a little slice of Slow Horses action and the chance to find out if the rabbi and the porn star would ever find happiness together.

posts.title: Honeymoon Vibes
posts.content:
Day 3

This is our first time ever doing the resort, all-inclusive thing. So are main goal for the day was to live the resort all-inclusive life and make our money back. Ah, romance!

We slept for over 12 hours in the end, which after minimal sleep and a 4:30am get up, followed by pretty much 36 hours on the go, we needed by like a thousand percent.

Every then, it was a slightly sleepy stumble to breakfast.

Two pots of tea down though, and a tasty breakfast tucked away, we felt more ourselves. To be fair to Pete, he totally smashed it and went full crepe, which he reported to be excellent. I was feeling a little delicate and so decided to play it safe with granola and some banana bread.

Although when I found that Pete had located fresh passionfruit, I went back for a couple of halves of that queen of fruits and we split a plate of passionfruit over our second pot of tea.

We booked a table for dinner in the resort’s Thai restaurant and then decided to walk back to our villa the long way round and see the whole island.

I should just clarify that the long way round takes maybe 10 minutes, and the word island is an optimistic word for small heap of sand which is holding up the resort.

We walked across a couple of beaches complete with beach bungalows and beautiful areas for swimming in the sea, we found the quiet pool - no bar and no music, just a serene swim and a decking by the sea - and then we wound up back at the main pool and bars.

The sun was fierce and by the time we’d clopped along the pier to the decking we were both feeling quite sweaty in the warm, humid air. The sea was calmer though than the previous day and we had scouted out some snorkelling spots, so we decided on a quick shower, a brief chill to allow our suncream to soak in, and then we’d hit the sea and visit the fish.

Within five minutes of this plan being planned however, the wind picked up, storm clouds rolled over and the little undulations of the sea around our villa turned into foam-topped ways. In fact, the noise the wind made whipping and whistling through the wooden stilts and planks was quite dramatic!

With the red flag flying for dangerous swimming, we decided to postpone snorkelling for the afternoon and instead pottered along to the quiet pool.

We enjoyed a swim, both in the pool and in the sea, the beach being protected by a stone barrier which absorbed the biggest waves. We were amused by the line-up of crabs perched up on the rocks, balanced on their tippy toes and watching our progress through their water in an imperious fashion with unblinking, beady eyes. And somehow the morning drifted by in a heartbeat and it was time for lunch. Sweeeet!

Lunch was a banger today, the buffet featuring a chicken bhuna that was top notch with a solid level of spice, and alongside some salad, rice and poppadums made for an excellent meal. The lemon cheesecake on the dessert buffet also happened to be my favourite pudding to date.

After lunch, wandering back to our villa, a few drops of rain plopped out of the sky, but the weather struggled to show any real commitment to this, managing at best some slightly sulky cloud cover. Undaunted we decided to give snorkelling a go after all and this time we launched off the beach to explore the reef. There were plenty of fish hanging around to be peered at and pointed to, and drifting around the bay, bobbing in the surf, we saw lots of brightly coloured fishy friends. A brief search on Google enlightened us somewhat as to what we’d spotted and included parrotfish, moorish idols, powder blue surgeonfish, convict surgeonfish and picasso triggerfish.

I obviously knew all these names instantly upon spotting the fish and googling was just for Pete’s benefit. Cool cool cool no doubt no doubt.

Pete also managed to spot a black tipped reef shark and swam after it but it was too quick. I was facing the wrong way and so missed it - standard.

Anyway, the marine life was abundant and we saw lots of other fish that my internet research as yet to identify. I like the little black and white one that buzz in little groups around the coral, and we saw a huge yellow chap bumping around along the bottom sticking his pouty snout into this and that, raising little sand clouds.

After about an hour, I climbed out and left Pete to it, opting for a little swim in the completely empty main pool. I felt like I was in one of those hotel adverts, stepping lightly down the pool steps and arcing into a graceful breaststroke at exactly the right moment.

It’s possible it didn’t look like that but who will ever know?

When Pete pried himself from the sea, we visited the swim up pool bar for a bit of a day drink. I opted for the mango slushy of the previous evening and then asked on a whim if the bartender could chuck in a shot of rum. He happily obliged, Pete ordered the same and while in this bar, they were more drinkie than slushy, we enjoyed our drinks very much, watching some of the guests play beach volleyball and the palms wave in the breeze.

After a brief micro swim and a chill on the in-pool loungers, we decided to relocate to our beach loungers, because we are nothing if not constantly busy and on the go. Seriously, we’ve hardly stopped! Pete reckoned we should get another drink first however - wise chap, first rule of all inclusive: make your money back - and so we headed back to the bar. Pete walked because having used the swim-up feature he is now too cool for it, but I swam because I will never get tired of swimming up to a bar. Like literally never. If I could also swim up for breakfast, lunch and dinner, I totally would.

Note to self: open a swim-up tea room. It would be lush, with floating tea trays and inflatable biscuit platters. Also, bobbing cake stands.

I digress.

So I swam up, ordered our drinks, stoutly refused Pete’s offer to carry my drink to the beach - if I’m going to swim up to the bar, I’m damn well also going to swim away clutching my drink like a tiny liquid prize - and we settled into beach loungers.

By the way, Pete had opted for a beer, but I went for a lime and gin-based concoction called a Gimlet, purely to increase our experience of the full cocktail menu and help us know what to order. It was reasonable and better than some of the previous day’s drinks, but not as good as the rum mango slushy combo with the name that is impossible to recall when your a few drinks down.

In fact, I’m now going to think of it as the MRS - Mango Rum Slushy, and perfectly named for a honeymoon, no? As long as we don’t mind a bit of patriarchy with our liquor.

Eventually we wandered back to our room, pausing to watch the sharks feed again which is undeniably entertaining. Pete pressed on, keen for his shower, but I perched on the side of the pier, dangling my feet over the edge and watched the little black tip reef sharks swimming around with gusto. Once the feeding was over, they dispersed remarkably quickly. When of the other guests asked if they somehow knew it was the end of the feed, and the staff member simply smiled and said “oh, they know”.

A shower and a cuppa revived our energy and we sat out on our decking, listening to the ocean wash up and down, reading, journaling and gazing out at the incredible aqua blue. The sun slipped slowly down over the horizon, concealed behind clouds, and a sea breeze made it beautifully pleasant.

And BOOM! Time for dinner!

We had booked for the resort’s Thai restaurant and so meandered down the decking towards the island. A golf buggy passed us and the stopped to give us a lift - hilarious - and so we caught a ride to the pool and thence to the snax.

I say snacks: it was a tad more elevated than that. We were offered an outdoor table and jumped at the chance, seating ourselves beneath a gently waving palm, listening to the waves lap against the beach a short distance away and bathed in the soft glow of a couple of up lighters. Dark had come on rapidly, and the nearby pool was lit with little green sparkles making me think of bioluminescence or possibly a disco ball. Try as we might, we couldn’t spot the source of the dancing green lights so we abandoned the attempt, enjoying the live band and perusing the menu.

I opted for chicken satay (winner!) followed by Thai red chicken curry, and Pete went for spring rolls followed by Thai red beef curry. It’s like we’re meant to be together. We convinced the waitress that we did indeed want it to be spicy, and while she questioned whether we’d had spicy food before, she was eventually won over by our enthusiasm. Hot stuff.

The food was fab! I washed mine down with a glass or two of Cava while Pete sank a couple of beers and I dabbled delightedly in satay sauce, rich with peanutty happiness, and a curry which did indeed have a potent kick.

We both polished off our portions though, and while I cannot claim to have eaten delicately in the dark, I did at least consume my plateful with gusto. Our waitress seemed satisfied with our efforts, checking one last time that we like spicy food, and we rounded off the meal with a scoop of sorbet apiece, mango for me and strawberry for Pete.

We popped around to the overwater bar after dinner and enjoyed another drink each, a beer for Pete and a MRS for me. We lounged on the sofas hanging over the sea and gazed at the moon and the island, debating whether the moon itself offered enough light to see by if the electrics all went out. I thought no, Pete was more positive.

We also learned that the Maldives is the world’s most dispersed country. Fun fact!

Around nine or so, Pete suggested returning to our room and sitting out on our verandah, sinking our bottle of arrival fizz. I figured we may as well give it a go and so we tottered happily back out along the pier over the sea and reclined accordingly. Lush!

Pete popped the cork on our Cava and we worked our way steadily through it, toasting the moon and dreaming up retirement plans because apparently post honeymoon, that’s our next goal. Dream big people, dream big.

Actually, it was completely lovely with the dark sky meeting the darker dear, the moon glowing here and there through the patchy clouds which revealed the odd star and cava fizzing pleasantly in the flutes. We listened to the quiet shushing of the waves against the villa and the cool breeze off the sea stirred the warm air perfectly. I started a book - something suitably trashy which was honeymoon-resort appropriate, and if I tell you that three chapters in, an incredibly attractive former porn star has met an incredibly attractive rabbi and they’ve agreed team up to work on a lecture series about modern relationships, you’ll know exactly the sort of book I mean. It’s excellent and I of course have absolutely no idea what the possibly outcome might be.

I started telling Pete about it, but when the phrase “a rabbi meets a porn star” doesn’t grab you, possibly he’s just not going to be into it. Weird.

Approaching midnight, we shuffled back inside our villa, enjoying the cool air con and watching a couple of episodes of slow horses. Or at least, finally finishing the first one and watching the second. It’s great, nuff said. And then we turned in, a beautifully long night of luxurious sleep beckoning.

posts.title: Honeymoon Plan #36283
posts.content:
Day 1

Well we did it! Goodness only know what version of the honeymoon plan we’re on now. All I know is that we’re a long way from where we started, but that finally, it’s actually started!

A 4:00am wake up, followed after some tossing and turning by my 4:30am alarm, an early morning covid test - NEGATIVE BABY! - and an early morning cuppa apiece and we shouldered our backpacks, luggage tags bobbing merrily behind us, and set out into the mellow dawn for the tube.

Our route to the airport had been the subject of some back and forth, as the first district line train for us wasn’t due until 5:24am which meant our airport ETA was 6:40am.

Which means that because I am neurotic, I was nervous about cutting into our 3 hour airport arrival window for our 9:30 flight.

However, with an Uber and Elizabeth line option as a back (an expensive one, but there) we decided to chance the normal tubes and it mostly worked. Even though it was relatively busy, we got a seat and trundled our way across London arriving at Heathrow only fifteen minutes later than we should have done, which isn’t bad by public transport standards these days.

And then we saw the queue to check in and I immediately wished I’d been less tight-fisted regarding the Uber.

Anyway, we joined the queue to join the queue, shuffled along and eventually reached the point where could join the official queue. Cue various officials shuffling people around between different barriers in a way that makes you inwardly screech at them to stop faffing about and check people in instead of telling us when to step forward.

Outwardly, I smiled politely.

It seems that apparently there’s a bonus check in procedure which you could do to upload various documents online and skip to a shorter “verify to fly” queue. But we’d been completely unaware of this option and by the time we uploaded our documents on the hoof in the queue, it made not one blind bit of difference. So we queue shuffled, made friends with an Australian lady who tried hard to convince the queue guards to let us join the quicker queue, and stewed silently watching the shorted queue be efficiently managed by 4 open desks while the immense main queue was served by 2 counters. Logical.

Have I mentioned, it’s annoying to queue early morning? I wanted my airport honeymoon cup of tea!!

Anyway, after an hour and 20 minutes, we were able to drop our bags, and with another 20 minutes to duffle through security, we were airside, to find our flight was about to start boarding. But Pete is a maverick and reckoned we should break the rules and push boundaries and so we went to get a cup of tea anyway, me manfully holding our position in the queue in Costa while Pete ventured out in the field for a speedier option.

He found Pret virtually empty so we grabbed a cuppa each and hauled off to our gate where our bags were sniffed by a very good boi with a waggy tail and fluffy spaniel ears. Which we did not touch because it’s not allowed but it was tempting nonetheless. We inhaled our tea, somehow did not get upgraded to first class - weird - and took our seats on the flight.

All passes pretty smoothly. We both watched the Friends reunion, I was provided with two cups of tea, and I had a snooze and watched half of Moana. Also strong recommend the chocolate mousse which came with the meal, and the pizza lattice hot afternoon snack which had a promising Gregg’s vibe about it.

We landed in Abu Dhabi around 7:00pm local time and settled into some comfy chairs in one of the gates to while away our 6 hour transfer window. I went to find us some tea but it wasn’t until after I’d bought it that I realised it cost £9 for two cups, which practically finished off our honeymoon budget. Still, it hit the spot and with a packet of Maltesers buttons I found with my bag, we happily whiled away a couple of hours.

When people ask how to keep up with a travel journal while away, this is the secret: spend your six hour layover jotting down unnecessary detail.

Also, send repeated emails to your hotel asking them when and where to meet the transfer you’ve booked.

With a couple of hours to go, we had a brief debate over whether our next flight would feed us. Given that it departed at one in the morning and landed around 6:00am local time, we figured probs not, and so set off about the airport in search of some sustenance. Burger King came up with the goods, and after a burger for Pete and some chips for me, we satisfied our hunger and then wandered off to find our gate.

Boarding the plane behind a group of drunk, off-key Spaniards who entertained the whole gate with tortured renderings of a range of songs which I suspect will never recover from this enthusiastic treatment, we settled in ready to get the rest of the way to our destination.

Day 2

The overnight flight from Abu Dhabi to the Maldives passed smoothly; at just over four hours, it wasn’t hugely long and we both slept through as much of it as we could. Pete in particular cut a do-not-disturb figure with his face mask, eye mask and neck pillow obscuring almost all of his head.

We landed in Male feeling pretty drowsy. It was coming up to seven in the morning as we checked through passport control, but our body clocks said three in the morning, meaning we’d been on the go for nearly 24 hours and now it was time to start an entirely new day.

However, we had a cunning plan of staying awake until the evening in order to smack our body clocks to order and the passport stamp we got at immigration had a small turtle on it so things were looking good.

Some of these thoughts don’t seem particularly connected but I’m functioning without sleep so roll with it.

The one final thing that needed to happen before I felt I could slide into pure trip fun mode was getting from the airport to our hotel. I’d booked a speedboat transfer to the tiny island when I’d reserved our hotel - less than 48 hours ago, yikes! - but had no information about the transfers, where we needed to go to meet the speedboat and what time the boat left. Having sent 3 emails, a Facebook message and an Insta DM to the hotel and received no reply, I had definitely moved into viewing this as another problem that needed to be overcome before relaxing could commence.

Emerging into airport arrivals with our bags revealed lots of envoys carrying signs for this or that resort, but nothing for us. The only thing for it was to add credit to make international calls on my phone and try giving the hotel a ring. I spotted a large number of desks dotted around the arrivals hub, again each for a different resort, and so I decided to do one last-ditch circle around these just to make sure there was no one to ask.

And the very last desk proved to be the one. Not only that, the woman at the desk was indeed expecting us and showed us where to wait until the speedboat transfer came to collect us. Perfect!

It turned out the boat was bobbing up and down on a mooring right outside the airport - kind of insane - and before long, we were kitted out with lifejackets, handed bottles of water and being zipped across the sea.

The journey took about 15 minutes or so, and we flew over the waves, spray erupting around us as we passed big container ships and left the bustling industrial vibe of Male behind.

We were helped off the boat and taken to reception, our bags spirited away to be delivered to our room. It was still well before 9:00am at this point, but a welcome drink of cranberry and lemongrass plus a lovely cold, wet towel to wipe our faces refreshed us and helped wake us up a bit.

Given that check in wasn’t until three, we were of course a tad on the early side, but we managed to sort the paperwork and payment necessary and score an upgrade to a sunset villa - winning! We aren’t sure what the difference is between a sunset villa and a normal villa but they are more expensive so we decided we were cool with that.

The resort reckoned our room would be ready before too long and to pass the time we were shown to the chill room where tinkly spa music played and we could help ourselves to a cuppa. We started watching the Slow Horses series which I’d been super keen to see since reading a few of the books, and by ten, we were collected and told our villa was ready!

When I say collected, I’m being serious: waiting for us was a little golf cart and our driver took us on a small (tiny) adventure round the island to see the different bits of the resort: the restaurants, the dive centre, the spa, pools and bars before finally driving us out along the wooden pier where the villas were located. Apparently you can drive on it. Who knew?

There were 80 in all, blooming either side of a long, snaking boardwalk that stretched out over the sea.

The sea which was, by the way, that absolutely unreal shade of cartoon turquoise blue that you see in pictures but not in real life.

Our room was lovely - the bed laid with flowers around heart-shaped sheets, a great shower, massive picture window overlooking the ocean and our own private little deck projecting out over the sea and complete with loungers. Lush!

We’d also been given a fruit platter and bottle of fizz - winner - and it was lovely to have a sense of arrival, our trip and indeed our honeymoon properly beginning!

We both felt pretty tired and ropey, but we were determined not to go to sleep until the evening to make sure our body clocks were slammed into the right time. Even though we’d now been on the go for over 24 hours. But sleep and jetlag are for losers and weaklings so with that in mind, we hopped into our swimwear and set off to test our the pool.

The pool was lovely if a little chilly, and right by the sea which we also tested out. The sea proving a bit warmer in the final reckoning. There was a little beach swing, recliners in various shapes and sizes including some boat-shaped ones that were actually in the pool, and a swim up bar. I had honeymoon swim up bar ambitions to fulfil, but as our all-inclusive package didn’t kick in until noon, these would have to wait.

Instead, we realised we were both starving not having eaten since Burger King over twelve hours ago. Time for lunch.

We popped back to our villa to shower and change and then set off for our first food experience at the main restaurant which served a buffet daily for breakfast, lunch and dinner. We were hungry and very much ready to do it justice!

It turned out to be a vast and delicious array and we each opted for a variety of different bits and bobs. Highlights included sweet corn fritters with sweet chilli sauce, a rather tasty daal with poppadums and a great papaya salad. Plus the fact that there was a dessert buffet didn’t hurt, the walnut and honey cake being a surprising favourite.

We wandered back to our villa and I sat on the bed before immediately flopping over with exhaustion. We proved that if we weren’t going to fall asleep, we needed to keep moving. Time to snorkel!

We visited the dive centre to pick up snorkel gear and peruse the trips on offer. We immediately deemed them all too expensive and quite happily settled for snorkelling for free around the house reef - Pete has eagle eyes in the ocean and had already spotted various fish and a couple of reef sharks.

Carting our gear back to our room, we suited up for snorkelling, pulling on a T-shirt each over our swimwear. We’ve been burnt before snorkelling and find this does wonders for protecting your back from the sun. Then we clambered down the staircase straight off the end of our villa’s decking and plopped into the sea. Blissful! We had hung various bits and pieces out off our decking so we’d know which villa to climb back into but it turned out to be unnecessary as some enterprising soul and anticipated this challenge and numbered them all on the seaward side. And so we pressed our masks eagerly into the water and set our flippers a-paddling.

The water was surprisingly choppy with a decent bit of swell, but we figured 80 villas gave us 80 potential emergency escapes if necessary, so we swam along the reef on the outer edge of the peer. And there was a surprising amount to see! Lots of fish bobbed and twirled about over the coral and the rocks, in all different shapes and sizes and colours. We swam and floated down most of the length of the pier - a bit inconsiderable distance - and enjoyed marvelling at this hidden underwater world. It’s always curious to me how clearly you can see the teeming life through a snorkelling mask in the water, but you can’t really see much of anything when you peer at the sea from above. Even the brightly coloured fish are well camouflaged.

Swimming back to our villa was a challenge as we had to swim against the current. Thankfully the flippers gave us a little more swim power but it was still with a slightly grateful and relived slump that I finally hauled myself out of the sea and onto our decking.

We had yet another round of showers - necessary and also lovely - and then decided to explore one of the bars.

I was keen to try the Viu bar, perched as it was over the sea with sofas to recline on all around the edge and even those nets you can lounge on suspended over the water. Excellent! Additionally, it turns out the circular structure is open in the centre and you can sit in the middle and look down into the swirling sea.

The bar happened to be serving afternoon tea and canapés - a few sandwiches, some choux buns and some cookies. I felt like a sweet treat so opted for the latter two and the cookies in particular were yummy! Although tiny and barely even bite sized so I had to have four.

As I was still feeling incredibly sleepy - if not dopey - I decided to order a mocktail when the bartender came round. I went for a Fini Anbu which is a name I immediately forget every time I try and remember it and I have to look it up on the menu.

So what’s a Fini Anbu? I’m glad you asked: it’s an insanely lovely mango slushy with lime and grenadine. And it’s lush! It was like slurping you tasty sorbet in the heat of the day and once I’d realised that the red swirls around the glass were part of the pattern and not the grenadine waiting to be devoured, I finished it off pretty quickly.

And ordered another.

Pete manfully started tackling the list of cocktails in the name of research, sinking a Singapore Sling and a Daiquiri. Neither of which were as good as my mango slushy.

The drinks and the bar and the sea and the sun whiled away time quite happily, but I started to feel like I was going to fall asleep where I was sitting. It was opportune therefore that it shark o’clock.

Well, mini shark o’clock anyway.

At five each day, the resort feeds the fish, chucking chunks of something that is clearly dead over the side of the walkway and into the sea. The fish pounce upon it eagerly with a thrash of tails and fins and the most eager of the predators is the black tip reef shark.

The ones in the shallows are only little and while we’d seen the odd one swimming when peering into the sea, it was nothing like the swarm that congregated for feeding. As they’re juveniles, they’re about half the size of fully grown sharks who reach about 7m in length and can weigh up to 30lbs. Hefty,

Even though these mini sharks were young though, they still had an unmistakably shark-link prowl, their signature fin breaking the surface, their movements sleek, sinuous and predatory. Apparently they live in the shallows when they’re young, teaching themselves to hunt as their mothers have zero maternal instinct. They’re apparently inquisitive and curious but mostly harmless and it was quite something to stand above the water as they zeroed in on anything that landed in the sea.

Once the sharks were satisfied, we popped back to our villa to get changed for dinner but as that wasn’t until seven, we moseyed on back to the bar. I was absolutely shattered by this point and with over an hour to go until we could grab our evening meal, we hoped another round of drinks would keep us awake. A mai tai for Pete and a piña colada for me. Then the bartender appeared with a plate of food, offering us a canapé each and explaining they were cheese sandwiches. Fair play.

Pete took two bites out of his before commenting that it didn’t have a lot of flavour and tasted funny. I thought mine was fine and a quick comparison revealed that Pete was under the impression he was eating pineapple.

Pineapple!

I laughed like a drain before realising Pete had mis-heard the word canapé, not heard “cheese sandwich” at all what with masks in the way, and that he had quite confidently worked on the assumption that the finger sandwich he was attacking was somehow constructed from dried pineapple and possibly some sort of bready cake. Unreal.

That right there shows exactly how drowsy we were. If you can’t tell the different between a cheese sandwich and a chunk of pineapple on sight, never mind two munches in, you need to sleep.

But we managed just about to hang in there until seven, dawdling over to the restaurant and grabbing a bit of buffet. I struggled to raise any kind of appetite at all but was delighted to be offered tea in a vague bid to get through the evening. Pete managed an impressive buffet spread with a beer and entertained me thoroughly by eating the dessert selection he had picked. In case you’re wondering, while he thought the chocolate tart was objectively the best, he’s not fond of very rich chocolate things and preferred the lighted cheesecake-esque thing. Although felt it could have had more flavour.

So now you know.

I asked Pete to rate other aspects of the buffet but he refused point blank, explaining that he only does desserts.

He also pointed out that I looked so tired as to appear drunk which was accurate - that was practically how I did feel - but unfair given that I’d had one cocktail all day and he had worked his way through half the menu. Still, given that it was me slumped back in my seat concentrating on keeping my eyes open, I had to hand him that one.

And so it was that we staggered back to our room, arms around each other for balance, heading finally for some sleep.

Except that Pete thought it would be nice to watch the rest of the slow horses episode. I was game and we gave it but after about 5 minutes, I realised Pete was a sleep and while I could follow the plot having read the book, I doubted Pete’s chances. It took me three goes to wake him but I managed eventually and we put the laptop aside and hit the lights. Half past eight. Party on, honeymooners!

posts.title: Honeymoon Fail
posts.content:
Today we're setting off on our honeymoon!

Except no. No we aren't.

#plottwist

Because genius here is nothing if not consistent and despite wearing my mask for the last week and shunning all company and activities over the weekend, I have still managed to get COVID for the holidays. Again.

My main symptoms are rage and a crushing sense of disappointment.

Add in a hefty chunk of inescapable guilt that I'm dragging Pete through this as well, and you've got a pretty honeymoon-trashing combo.

But, you can either float around and wallow in that mess of feelings, or you can proactively pull yourself out of the swamp and do something about it. I choose the latter. So aided and abetted by my incredibly supportive and thankfully healthy husband, we have scrambled around to cancel things, claim refunds, consult our insurance, develop alternative options and book some new plans.

To be fair, I have also done a small amount of sheer frustration crying, but Pete has not only put up with this, but has made me feel infinitely better which is no easy feat when you’re spending almost all your time in different rooms and are concealed behind masks and distanced when we have to occupy the same space. Namely, the space around the kettle.

So, long story long (you know the drill around here), here's what's gone down over then last couple of days...

I had a bit of a cold over the weekend. Nothing major: a cold is a cold and they are not uncommon at the end of a school term. A quick check for COVID on Sunday night revealed I was negative so off I popped for the final few days of school as per usual.

Tuesday morning rolled around and I was up early in the sunshine. I had my pre-departure PCR test booked - a requirement for entry into South Korea - and I figured I’d take a quick test before leaving the house just to make sure all was well and good.

Except all was very much not well and good and the naive hope and optimism I put into my second test confirmed the worst: I had COVID. Pete was still asleep, being blessed with a job which doesn’t require 6:00am starts, and so couldn’t really think of much to do. My brain was on a bit of a go-slow due to disbelief: I’d check and I was definitely negative - how could I now have covid? The day before our honeymoon?

SERIOUSLY HOW???

I figured Pete may as well get the bad news on a full night’s sleep instead of in an early morning flurry from yours truly so I did the only things I could do: made tea, planned and set my cover work for school, emailed all the rearrangements I needed to make for the end of term - an inconvenient time to be off school - and started a deep dive read into our insurance terms and conditions.

Pete did appear just before nine, stumbling into the kitchen and surprised to find me slumped on the sofa in a heap, dressed for school and worked on the laptop, but not there.

The bad news propelled him back out of the room until we both had masks in place and I filled him in with as much info as I could.

My thoughts had pretty much circled around South Korea and I couldn’t think of a way it would be possible for us to go now. In order to enter the country, you need a negative PCR within 48 hours of departure, another negative PCR at the airport upon landing in Seoul, a visa stating your dates of travel and proposed address in South Korea, contact details in case of positive testing and a full health check along with vaccination information and proof of negative tests in the online healthcare system. I had no idea how long it would take me to test negative, never mind how long it would take to be confident I could get clear PCRs. I also had no idea how long a replacement visa would take, or whether Pete would catch COVID from me.

Whatever way I looked at it, South Korea was off the table.

I figured we had 3 options

1) Pick up our honeymoon from the start of the Vietnam section in three weeks time, as they didn’t require any proof of negative tests.

2) Head to Vietnam early.

3) Visit somewhere else with low covid requirements and then pick up with Vietnam as planned in three weeks.

Option 1 seemed like a waste of valuable honeymoon time. Option 2 had some merit, but we’d already planned and booked our route through Vietnam. We didn’t really want an extra two weeks there as a block - while an extra couple of days in each location would have been wonderful, a two week block just wasn’t that helpful to us.

So we quickly landed on option 3.

But first things first: Pete tested for covid (negative, thank goodness) and as he had a haircut booked, we agreed to regroup in separate rooms having spent the intervening time thinking up possible alternatives. And calling our insurers to find out how much we could claim back.

So Pete left to ponder locations, I jumped in and out of doing my school emails and vaguely browsing the internet for ideas and eventually, having finished scouring our policy, I called the insurers.

To my immense astonishment, the insurers were genuinely helpful. I know it shouldn’t come as a surprise that a service we’d paid for actually worked, but I just struggle to raise any optimism when it comes to insurance as when it comes down to it, you seem to covered for everything except the things that actually happen. However, the lady I spoke to on the phone listened carefully, was helpful and advised me on making a claim and I felt pretty confident we would indeed be able to claim back the costs that couldn’t be refunded

Although ask me about that again when the claim response comes back.

Most of the rest of Tuesday morning and afternoon were taken up with cancelling South Korea bookings, collating paperwork for our insurance claim and, most importantly, country research. Our criteria were specific if not completely straightforward; the destination in question needed to satisfy the following:

1) Have no COVID testing requirements on entry or in advance.

2) Not require a visa or be able to supply a visa on arrival.

3) Be geographically located so that we could get to Vietnam relatively easily.

4) Be not too expensive to get to.

Also, ideally it would be somewhere we were excited to visit that we hadn’t explored before. But this was a much harder criteria to satisfy given that it had only been 2 years since we backpacked through south-east Asia and visited most of Vietnam’s neighbouring countries.

And therefore, on various grounds, we eliminated Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, China, Taiwan, Jordan, Madagascar, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar and India.

In fact, we eliminated a lot of places so it’s almost easier to say that we narrowed our choices down to three places: Sri Lanka, the Philippines and Indonesia.

Sri Lanka was easily the most promising. While I had been, Pete hadn’t so it would at least be new to him, I had loved Sri Lanka and there was a great blend of culture, wildlife, scenery and food to be explored and enjoyed. The flights there were also inexpensive, and we also flirted with the ideas of having a couple of weeks in Sri Lanka and then a couple of days in the Maldives nearby. Couldn’t hurt...

Further research however revealed that rioting had recently been a bit of an issue as had fuel shortages. We ummed and ahhed over this for a bit, trying to find accurate information, which is hard when you have locals and tour companies screaming “please come, we need the business” but news reports saying it’s inadvisable. Each time we decided we could make it work, we then learned something that changed our minds, but the final clincher was finding a news report that estimated Sri Lanka had basically enough fuel left for a single day and that it was being rationed for emergency services.

Definitely a no: even if we could get there, we’d struggle to get around, and it felt morally wrong to try and get ferried around as tourists when people’s daily lives were becoming harder by the minute.

Sri Lanka was out.

We considered the Philippines briefly but the flights there were hugely expensive. We had in fact planned to go there on our round the world backpacking trip before COVID made that impossible, but when we looked at the route we’d planned and the things to do, they were mostly sea and beach based which was a) quite similar to Mauritius and b) not much of a replacement for South Korea.

Indonesia then. Pete had never been to Java and I was happy to return so he set to work to see if he could plan a week’s travel there. I meanwhile started investigating Sumatra - a little more off the beaten track, decidedly non touristy and a place we had both enjoyed visiting before.

By the time the evening arrived, we were sorted: we had a workable itinerary, a back up plan, and if we weren’t necessarily ready to feel excited yet, at least we knew we had a trip that made good use of our time.

Around nine, I started looking into flights and costed up a range of different itineraries. Eventually I found the most effective combination and while none of the flights were direct, most were overnight and one required a 12-hour layover, they would at least get us where we needed to be within a reasonable budget and time frame, and we wouldn’t have to transfer anywhere that caused us covid issues.

Plus, we discovered that it was cheaper after all to go via the Maldives so we thought screw it, let’s start off with a couple of days chilling on a paradise-style island and try and reclaim some honeymoon magic out of the slightly depressing wreckage of our carefully researched plans.

So Wednesday morning dawned, still all Covidy, I got up once again at early doors to email school and set my cover. It was a little sad to be missing the last day of the school year (and to be honest, setting cover work feels extra futile when you know the students are definitely not going to do it). I also managed to video in for a handover meeting so it was good to get that sorted, and then we were back to planning in earnest.

With our itinerary figured out and flights booked, our next jobs were to book places to stay and work out what we wanted to do. Pete took on Java and I tackled Summatra and by lunchtime we were looking in pretty good shape. Still, it was a bit of a downer to watch the clock tick past the times we were supposed to leave the house, our flight check in time, and the take off that should have heralded the start of our adventure.

All told, Wednesday was another day spent glued to the internet, researching, booking, figuring out public transport networks and connecting up the flights. I also dived head first into Maldives research figuring if we were going to do the thing, we may as well do it properly. I was feeling a bit reckless and as Indonesia is very inexpensive to travel in, I was very willing to divert funds towards a fancy overwater villa and an all inclusive ticket to paradise. But also, I was very willing to find a bargain, and with the whole of the World Wide Web at my disposal, I figured I must be able to hunt down a last minute deal, especially for off season.

With as many bonus (ie free) inclusions as possible...

That pretty much set most things in order: we’d made bookings, cancelled our previous arrangements, stuck the new bits of plans to the old bits and tweaked our packing list as Id been busy WhatsApping trekking guides in the Sumatran jungle and figured we’d probably want to take our head torches after all.

Heading to bed in seperate rooms, poor Pete on the sofa on Wednesday night, we knew we had the makings of a trip again. We still needed to sort things like downloading our NHS vaccine passes, logging our details in apps for transiting Malaysia, travelling in Indonesia, entering and leaving the Maldives and literally anything else we could think of. We also needed a ready supply of cash in various currencies for visas and payments in places where card payments aren’t reliable (the place we were staying in Summatra in particular informed us that there’s one nearby cash machine but that it doesn’t work and when it does you can only get very small amounts of cash). I needed to book our choice of resort for the Maldives and also begin collating and uploading the paperwork for our insurance claim. It kind of surprised me how long these things all took.

The final plan was to make Thursday the hype day: to try and get excited and a little more invested in our new plans, acknowledge that it was inevitable to be disappointed about South Korea - that was where Pete has most wanted to visit - and not pretend to each other that we feeling the way we imagined right now. And of course to also remember that we are incredibly fortunate to be able to work out our plans, travel and explore the world at all.

At the end of the day, we knew we would definitely enjoy our honeymoon once it started and we could leave the stress and frustrations of the past couple of days behind. Because we had several glorious weeks of quality time together stretching out ahead of us, doing our favourite thing, living our best lives and experiencing it all as a team.

posts.title: Honeymoon Dreaming
posts.content:
In a few short days, we will be packing up our things, waving goodbye to Old Blighty and setting off on our next big travel adventure and I AM SO EXCITED!

For a few reasons: first because travel is our absolute favourite thing to do together. Which stands to reason really, as travel is about exploring, seeing and experiencing new things in new parts of the world and new cultures, it's about learning about people and places we had no idea even existed and it's about embracing all those things together.

But I'm also excited because with COVID, we haven't been able to do this for a while. And last time we did set out with our backpacks in tow, our adventures were brought to an abrupt end a couple of a months early as the pandemic took hold. It feels like we can now reclaim some of that lost time.

And finally, I'm excited because this is our honeymoon. Which means I'll be on the road with my husband (like, woah) and that we've upped the budget a tiny bit here and there because it's a special occasion. But mostly that means we get 7 glorious weeks careering about the world together, enjoying lots of quality time and sharing in memories that will last forever.

So here we go! Enter, the honeymoon blog.

Following the enormous success of our previous Round the World adventure blog (a big hello to all six of you who read it!) we've decided once again to document our time away. Mostly for us to look back on and enjoy, but we do get a little warm, fuzzy glow when we hear you're reading.

Also, it's something to do when waiting for trains/buses/planes etc and forces me to actually edit and organise my photos before they get overwhelming.

So what are the plans for this trip? Well, that's a long story, as this trip has changed a lot from conception to final plan. Long story short, you're reading the wrong blog if you're after something concise and snappy. This is a long story long kind of a blog so if you're hoping for a 'Top 10 honeymoon tips' Listicle you're going to be disappointed*. If you're hoping for tedious detail and tangential utterings then read on my friends! Welcome to the ride!

Back to the plans: our honeymoon was always going to be a really important part of our wedding celebrations because, as I may have mentioned, we love top travel. In fact, my two priorities for wedding planning were 1) have a fab photographer to capture it all and 2) have an absolutely BANGING honeymoon.

We started thinking about possible honeymoon plans really early on, although as we were living in a lockdown world, it all seemed to exist in a murky and uncertain future. Despite this, there were still a few dream destinations which sprang to mind: Hawaii and Japan. Japan because, obviously, Japan - we've wanted to go basically forever and our honeymoon seemed like a great time to make that a reality - and Hawaii because we watched lots of Lost last time we were travelling and the scenery just looks incredible. We wanted to go and hike and explore and adventure and see the amazing landscapes for ourselves.

Finally, we toyed with the idea of adding a third destination to our trip: somewhere we could go that would be inexpensive and allow us to dip our toes into the more traditional honeymoon waters but without paying insane Maldives-type prices. But somewhere that would also give us lots of interesting things to do instead of just staying in a resort.

This aim was partially met, but rather than opting for somewhere sort of resorty, we decided to add Vietnam onto our trip. Inexpensive to travel in, Vietnam is a country we've been super keen to explore and indeed we had planned lots of things to do there while we were backpacking on our year out. But when we actually got on a bus to cross the border from Cambodia to Vietnam, we found that the borders had closed to Europeans as the pandemic was closing in and so we were turfed off the bus unceremoniously and had to make alternative plans.

Less than a week later, we were back in the UK, slightly stunned along with the rest of the world as daily life dissipated like so much mist.

And thus, Vietnam was added to our honeymoon list.

We researched our destinations, looking up exciting things to do, we added key experiences to a wedding gift list which was shared with our guests, and we started to get excited as 2022 approached: wedding year.

Honeymoon year.

Well, I got excited. Pete was infinitely more pragmatic and sensible and we made a list of about 7 different backup options to work around different pandemic situations and outcomes.

And so this blog is going to be the story of our adventures in South Korea, Vietnam, Dubai and Mauritius.

I know, right? Spot the difference.

Because if we've learned anything in the last two years, it's that you can make all the plans you like but you've really got no control over which ones actually come to fruition. And that Japan won't let you inside their borders just because you really want to go on your honeymoon, no matter how many times to refresh the Japan travel requirements website.

In a nutshell, this is what happened. (Actually, a pretty big nutshell with lots of nuts and lengthy explanations). Even at time of writing, Japan is still not generally open to tourists. Once we hit the two-months-to-go mark for our honeymoon, we had to make the decision to change our plans and go with an alternative destination. We also couldn't move our honeymoon dates: I'm a teacher with a fixed holiday period, and either we travel in the summer or we don't travel.

Naturally, we picked travel.

So we kissed goodbye to our Japan goals, and made the decision to go to South Korea instead. Also high on our list of places to visit and a culture and landscape we thought we would enjoy exploring. Plus, food. I rest my case.

At the end of April, we started looking into booking our flights, investigating different routes between Hawaii, South Korea and Vietnam, looking at the price for various options and figuring out where we wanted to be based.

We've always done our own research and booked all our own stuff before, but we also figured it might be worth looking into booking with a travel agent. While I am quite happy doing travel research - and even quite enjoy it! - we did wonder if booking some sort of custom package would give us good COVID cancellation protection and maybe even score us some cheeky upgrades or give us access to deals.

Well, the answer the that is: no it doesn't. We quickly found that we could easily beat the quotes offered by travel companies on our flights and we were pretty astounded to be told the best price possible on somewhere to stay in Vietnam was £80 a night. A 2-second search on booking.com found us places that were just as nice - if not better! - for £20 a night. So we pretty quickly abandoned that idea concluding that we are very much not the target market and we are not prepared to pay way over the odds just to have someone else book for us.

Decision made, we started assembling our itinerary and costing out the trip. And soon we ran into another problem: Hawaii was unimaginably expensive.

We knew Hawaii was going to be the pricey bit. But when you're looking at over £100 a night for a youth hostel with a shared bathroom - not exactly full honeymoon vibes to shower next to hungover 19-year-olds - it's not the most joyous of prospects. Despite our best efforts, we couldn't find budget options in Hawaii to suit us, never mind when we took into account car rental (apparently they aren't so much into the public transport) and travel between islands. It's not that we were expecting a spendy resort to be cheaper, it's that our usual go-tos of private rooms in hostels, or out-of-the-way airbnbs were still eyewatering on price and were not going to give us an experience that reflected the money we would have to invest.

In the end, we decided that we couldn't afford to sink over two thirds of our honeymoon budget into a quarter of our trip and so we were obliged to back slightly sheepishly away from Hawaii too.

So of our original dream trip, we were basically just left with: Vietnam.

We threw everything out of the window and set about re-thinking our route, destinations and planning. We kept the Vietnamese portion of our trip, decided we were happy with our South Korea substitute, and spent some time googling locations which were similar to Hawaii but, y'know, cheaper. Our requirements were ideally somewhere volcanic with cool hiking, somewhere with a reef for snorkelling and diving and somewhere that would be big enough to have cool things to do. Somewhere where it's just a fancy resort is not really our vibe.

In fact, simply googling "where is similar to Hawaii" produced some useful results and with a quick overview of each, we reckoned on Mauritius for our Hawaii substitute. There seemed to be quite a few things to do, car hire was very inexpensive, and overall, it worked out at about a quarter of the price, even with a pretty nice hotel.

So that was that, destinations decided!

Well, almost. We found that getting from Vietnam to Mauritius involved a change of plane in Dubai. We basically had no choice but to spend a couple of nights there and see what all the fuss is about, as Dubai sort of fascinates me in a weird way. It appears to be such a curious blend - or clash? - of cultures and environments, almost like a science fiction sort of place with bizarre engineered land, crazy skyscrapers and rolling desert.

With about six weeks to go, we booked things in bits and pieces: places to stay, a couple of things to do and the planes, trains and automobiles that would get us around. We scored ourselves some serious bargains, poured over maps to work distances between stations and the places we wanted to visit, scoured the internet for exciting local food to try and also booked ourselves a little treat or two here and there.

And somehow it's now less than a week to go. COVID tests are booked in, insurance details logged, passports poised, international driving licences ready to flash, old-skool style, and I've stitched us luggage tags with our initials which I think are really awesome and which Pete is possibly just about tolerating. This weekend will be a cheerful flurry of packing, hunting for plug adapters and choosing things to read and watch on the plane and then it will be time to go.

Good bye work. Hello seven glorious weeks of summer travel.

I'm so here for this!

*If we do actually become hot shot, savvy influencer types, I am of course happy to produce this kind of post for the right amount of cash and a free stay in a luxury yet eco resort. By all means, get in touch and show us the colour of your money.
